Counteracting the RFI is too hit or miss and requires a PhD in electrical engineering to figure out.UPDATE (13 Nov 2014)- Been running 24/7 since May (almost 7 months). No problems whatsoever. Great inverter! Really great!UPDATE (22 FEB 2015)- Okay...nothing wrong with the inverter...still running strong. However, I have been looking at rewiring my battery bank to 24v. So, this inverter won't work. Reason why: my solar charging station will run more efficient with a 24v system. The max wattage I have ever pushed through the Power Bright is under 1800 watts. So, going with a 24v inverter (pure sine wave this time). Looking at a 2,000 watt unit from Go Power (GP-SW2000-24). It will fit on my panel. The 3,000 watt unit is about $1,000 whereas the 2,000 watt one is around $750. Not cheap.

PROS- Fast delivery- 115 VAC ouput (use a true RMS meter to read modified sine waves)- Looks nice- Amazon return policyCONS- Fans are terrible. I have had three Whistler inverters (1200, 2000, and this one). All of them have a terrible "clicking" sound right at the threshold of the thermostatically controlled (PWM?) fans would kick on. My 2000 watt unit's fans went completely out. I was out of my 30 day return window. So, I sent it to Whistler and pitched a fit. The tech support guy even said the fans are not that good and suggested buying some fans and putting them in myself! WTF? It's under warranty! This 3000 watt inverter is better then the 2000, but the fans started acting up earlier. So, I returned it for a full refund and went with a Power Bright PW3500-12. If my 2000 watt inverter ever comes back from Whistler (and is repaired with correct fans) I will use it as a back up to the Power Bright.- You can get a better return policy (90 day) at local home improvement storesCONCLUSION- Expect it to work initially, and work well. Make sure you use at least 0-gauge battery cables with very short length. These are inexpensive inverters at a great price, but the fans on these things will fail. They will chatter, click, hum, and do weird things right at turning on. PWM fans are the same as on many desktop computers and they last for years. Not sure what are in these...but they fail.

PROS- It works- Programming took a few tries, but linked up- Comes with a 9v "Heavy Duty" battery...nice, but threw it away and put in a Duracell- Inexpensive- When garage door is open, hitting "Enter" once will shut the doorCONS- 12 days to arrive- Not a Craftsman (advertising snafu?)- Note inside box wants a 5-star feedback...kinda arrogant- Hint of cheap plastic- Plastic keypad cover flimsyCONCLUSION- It works fine and is a good replacement for my 8-year old keypad running a 1/2 hp Sears Craftsman belt drive garage door opener.-
I use the 30 amp version of this and love it. I wish I had gotten this 40 amp unit! Worth every penny.

I have been running mine for 4 months straight.PROS- You need the meter to monitor voltage and current- 30+ amps. I run six 100 watt panels (24v) and can get 34 amps (816 watts) coming in.- Solid construction. When I get full sun, it gets a little warm (not hot). I placed a small blower fan behind it. Problem solved.CONS- Get confused sometimes on input array voltage. Sometimes I have to shut it off and back on to get it register 24v.- Screw in cable terminals are heavy duty...but I still managed to strip one.- Delivery took two weeksCONCLUSION- This is an excellent unit if you want to run DIY solar off-grid system. I started small (one panel) and now I am maxed out. Maybe I should have got the 40 amp unit? Buy it. Esp if Amazon says they have them in stock.

The small starter point is a good idea...but not for everyone. These are titanium yet barely lasted three drillings into metal. I am kinda pissed about that. My Irwin titanium bits lasted much longer. I will I went with Irwin.
I have small to average hands and have to get the XL based on experience. The gloves work well when I paint and stain.
It works fine and has done the job. However, when I connected it to my power inverter...the inverter faulted out. My have to use a mechanical timer instead of this one. Dang it.
Don't buy anything else. This one throws out a lot of sparks. The store bought ones (like Coleman) are pretty much worthless. I keep this in my prepper kit along with those wet starter cubes.

I have two of these fans. The output is good...like a gentle breeze. The best thing I like is how quiet they are. Another cool thing is that you can daisy chain them (they come with USB that will allow you to stack them). The only weird thing is that when I did that, the output was split 50/50. Hmmm.

I am not a fan of LED lights. I think they look fake and "spooky". The shadows cast are not natural. What I do like is the output of these lights and can live with the spooky nature of these LED lights. They only use 36 watts...which is pretty good.
I got this to dress up some solar cable coming down from the ceiling into a solar charge controller. It looks good. Easy to insert cable.

PROS- Much less expensive then going to an auto parts store (if they have them)- Flared ends...makes easing on 0 gauge cable- Smaller head then ones from auto parts storeCONS- Wish I could torch/solder the end onCONCLUSION- I like these in bulk...1/3 the cost of store bought items. Mounting them without solder can be done. I stripped the ends about 1" and hammered the end onto the cable. I have a medium vise...used that to crimp/smash the connection. Then I used a punch and hammered the crimped/flat part in about 4 spots. Connection is tight and will work. It just isn't as good as solder.
What can I say? I am using these in my 5 cu ft deep freezer and they are a perfect fit.

7 May 2014 - Got this really fast (Prime). My old Phillips 2GB MP3 player served a tough life (multiple military deployments, gym time, sauna, dropped, thrown around, etc-etc). May it rest in peace.PROS:- Smaller then expected- microSD slot (recommend a 32GB microSD card and put all your music on it...that way you can transfer by just taking it out)- Recorder- Sound is much better then expected (using it as a static player for my old stereo receiver/speakers- Power plug input same as my old Phillips...so, no need to buy another AC plug- Owners manual says 16GB max on microSD slot...installed 32GB w/o any problem. 36GB total is A LOT OF SONGS!- Fast power on/off- $30NOT SO GOOD:- The clip is not removable...you would have to break/saw it off to remove it- The display is much smaller then the Phillips...really have to peer at it to see anything- Comes with micro CD to download crap I don't need...you don't need it at all- No video album display like my Phillips...don't really miss that tho.- No AC adapter for USB cable (additionally, the cable is also WAY too short...like 4")OVERALL: Pretty impressive little player. I hope I don't wash it when doing laundry or it falls into some crevice and I can't get it. I will update this review in a few months. Buy this player...great purchase.

I like this meter. I needed to monitor the output from my solar panels (that range in voltage from 12-42 volts). This meter fits the bill perfectly and it's response time fast. Fast delivery (not shipped directly from China) took only 3 days. I will get a couple more for additional projects.UPDATE: Burned through two of these due to overheating (only thing I can think of that would cause a failure). At $12 per meter...gonna have to look into something that will last longer than a few months. They also don't like being turned on and turned off...shorten the lifespan. If you have to used them in a hobby box or whatever, I would get one that is not waterproof or sealed.

I bought this as a combo with the solar charge controller.PROS- Very useful for monitoring solar panel voltage- Reads battery bank voltage and current pushing down to them- Has many other features that I don't use, but may in the future- Lighted, green. Bright green light comes on when it is in charge mode- Lets you know what your solar charge controller is doing and when the panels come to life- Mounting frame has a slit for the cable so that it doesn't pinch it- CE rating (Similar to UL listings)CONS- Slow(ish) response time, but fast enough for most people- Display glare is really really lousy and is hard to see sometimes- No mounting screwsCONCLUSION- A must buy match for Tracer solar charge controllers...glad I got it.- I added two bright inline LED meters on my system with faster response time and ease of reading. Really not needed for most since the MT5 displays voltages, but supplements this meter. MT5 + additional LED meters = AWESOME!
I ended up returning this item for 10 AWG. MUCH better current flow with 10 AWG compared to 12 AWG. The build quality for the 10 AWG is much better.
I bought two of these on two different occasions. One set was 10 AWG (I ordered 12 AWG) and then the other was 12 AWG when it came in. Weird, but okay.
These worked pretty good for a while and then they got staticy, and then died. Not really impressed with them and they seem to cause more problems then their worth.
I bought this 6 months ago, put some batteries in it and it is still going strong. It is very sensitive and will turn on when a leaf blows in front of it.

I bought this wax based on the high reviews and write ups. I wasn't disappointed at all! I bought the wax to apply it to the polished table of my table saw. The previous wax I used didn't have much of a life at all and if a bead of sweat landed on the saw table it would soon start to rust if I wasn't careful. Also the wood was sticking to the table and it was making my cuts inaccurate. I cleaned and polished the table immediately prior to applying this wax, so I could get rid of some sap and a few small spots that were starting to surface rust. I only waxed 1/4 of the table at a time before I buffed it off so I didn't let it dry like so many reviews warn you about. The first coat went on very easily and you could tell that the metal seemed to soak the wax up. I would do an initial buffing with denim rags to get the majority of the excess wax off before I did a final buff with Extra-Thick Large Cotton Buffing Ball - Hex Shank - Turn Power Drill into High-Speed Polisher. Getting most of the excess wax off made the buffing ball last longer between cleanings. I kept comparing the surface after waxing to surfaces that hadn't been waxed yet and I was amazed at the difference in how slick this wax is! The subsequent coats went on even more easily. I noticed that the extra coats seemed to spread the wax even thinner and more evenly than the very first coat. Again I used the same buffing method. Ultimately I put 4 coats of wax on my table saw. I found a drop of sweat on the table and it beaded up as it should have, and continued to bead when I cleaned it up and the rag didn't soak it all up on the first wipe. I also used this wax on the table guide and the channels in the table. It made a huge difference in the appearance and lubrication!Afterwards I used the saw to cut some of the wood for a project I'm working on. I wasn't careful at first and a block of wood slid across the table and onto the floor on the opposite side. I've never had that happen before with any wood! Cross cuts are a breeze on the saw and the wood isn't dragging or sticking to the table. I'm going to try applying this to my japanese and western handsaws next to see if it helps with binding and saw removal.Pros:Easy to work withExcellent slick finish after buffingLittle goes a long wayVery little odorVersatileEasy open/close lidCons:Pricey, but worth itDoesn't wash out of rags or clothes easily

I have this Keurig and it runs well. But I'm still angry with them. My husband heard that there was a recall on our machine because it could spray hot water. Online it said to get information off the bottom of the thing and send it in so they could tell if it's potentially dangerous.My machine is missing the stamp with the information. I emailed Keurig a photo of the bottom explaining that I didn't have the info, plus told them other relevant information (which was asked for in the online notice) about where/when it was purchased and what color it is.3 weeks, no answer. Emailed again. Received answer asking for the information on the stamp, to which I replied, "Here's the photo again. THERE IS NO STAMP, IDIOTS!" But I said it nicer than that. I never got a reply, even after another email. Buyer beware.

This is an excellent book. More than excellent! However, it contains several interesting and detailed diagrams of stairwells and companies affected by floor. They do not work well on Kindle. Unenlarged, the text is too tiny to read. Enlarged, the the text is unreadable - blurry. I resorted to not enlarging them and trying to read them with a magnifying glass. Even then, a couple could not be read. See my screenshot.The publisher needs to make an update to this Kindle version so they can be read. If that ever happens, I will gladly change my review to 5 stars. Shame on publishers who are happy to take money for digital booksbut are unwilling to make them astotally readable as the paper versions!

I cleaned several guns over the weekend to test Breakthrough Military Grade Firearm Cleaning Solvent - 2oz Spray Bottle, M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner, 8-Ounce Spray Bottle, Tetra Gun Copper Solvent, 8-Ounce, and FireClean Fouling-Resistant Oil 2 Ounce FC-2 against Hoppe's No. 9 Gun Bore Cleaning Solvent, 5-Ounce Bottle. Here are the results for FireClean.I couldn't detect any smell from FireClean and my wife didn't complain while I cleaned several guns next to her. I used FireClean with a 6 inch cotton swab on my 1911s and I did notice that some carbon was coming off areas that I had no idea was getting a carbon build up. I also cleaned the areas inside the slide and the bolt carrier faces of the handguns. Again, I was getting some carbon fowling off the metal surfaces.Fireclean is thicker than most oils and it was easy to work with. I did find out the hard way that you have to close the cap before shaking it. Yes, I did make that bone headed move. It cleans up easily when you wipe it up and it does take a little while before it soaks into cloth or cotton swabs.I mainly purchased the FireClean for my 1911s and my AR-10. I re-cleaned the AR-10 and oiled the bolt carrier group with FireClean. I did get some additional carbon to come off the bolt carrier group that I didn't know was left behind after using Hoppes #9 and a CLR oil. As an oil it seems to lubricate well and it was easy to work with. I will update the review after the next time I take a 1911 or my AR-10 shooting. So far I'm very happy with it, but I'm waiting until I next shoot before I finish the review or give it 5 stars.Pros:ThickClearNearly odorless.Seems to be a good lubricant.A little goes a long way.Lifts carbon, but the first time use isn't like in the videos.Cons:I really can't think of any.Updated 3 Feb 2015: Upgrading my review to 5 stars. The carbon buildup really does wipe off with a rag or paper towel when you clean a gun that was previously oiled with FireClean. I found that I still have to make sure the cap is on and closed before shaking the bottle.

This is the second time that I have purchased a quart of Crystalac Wood Grain Filler. I have been experimenting on a book shelf made of red oak. The bookshelf itself is floor to ceiling at the end of a hallway and I started with rough planks of red oak. This is a water based product and is slightly thinner than syrup. I found it helpful to use a putty knife almost like a spoon and then let it drain onto the wood. After that I used a rubber squeegee to spread the filler diagonally across the grain. I tried letting it pool into some of the wood flaws to see if it would act as a wood putty. I tried staining the wood before and after using the wood filler. Lastly I also tried to see what it was like if I left lumps of wood filler on the wood.Here are my findings:1. Stain your wood before applying this product.2. Make sure you smooth the wood fill out as much as possible with each coat.3. SEVERAL thin coats are better than trying to glop it on thickly.4. It shrinks and will not act as wood putty for large flaws or knots.5. It is sandable, but it is harder than wood and will take longer to smooth out the bumps.6. I found that it worked best with the oak to sand and stain before applying the wood grain filler then doing the fine sanding and stain again.7. This dries very thinly so you will use a lot of it for larger projects. I used a quart on the bookshelf, and I should have put on another coat or two.8. It dries slowly so you have plenty of time to work it into the grain.Pros:Dries slowly so you have plenty of time to work it into the grainEasy to work withWater basedClear dryingFlows into the wood grainDries thin so you can add a little at a timeConsDries thin so you will use a lot of itHarder than the wood so if you leave ridges, they will take longer to sand downYou need 24-48 hours between coats if you live in a humid areaUpdate 9 April 2015: The second batch I bought has the consistency of thin jelly. It dries fairly quickly and is easier to work with than my first batch which was much waterier. I used sharp chisels to remove any dried clumps before sanding. I ultimately used 400 grit sandpaper and the red oak felt like glass afterwards. I'm not sure if the first batch or the second batch I bought is the way this is supposed to be, but they both work well and are easy to use.

I cleaned several guns over the weekend to test Breakthrough Military Grade Firearm Cleaning Solvent - 2oz Spray Bottle, M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner, 4-Ounce Spray Bottle, Tetra Gun Copper Solvent, 8-Ounce, and FireClean Fouling-Resistant Oil 2 Ounce FC-2 against Hoppe's No. 9 Gun Bore Cleaning Solvent, 5-Ounce Bottle. Here are the results for Breakthrough.I couldn't detect any smell from Breakthrough and my wife didn't complain as I cleaned the guns while we watched TV.I previously cleaned all of my 1911s with Hoppes #9 a couple weeks ago. I used Tetra Gun Copper Solvent and then Breakthrough to reclean the barrel and the guns. The very first rag that I soaked with Breakthrough, after the bore was soaked with Tetra gun, came out filthy. I had no idea I was leaving so much carbon and copper fouling behind after I only cleaned with Hoppes #9. After that it only took me 3 patches before I was using clean dry patches to remove the residual cleaner. The dry patches were coming out wrinkled but just as clean as they went in.I also used Breakthrough on previously cleaned guns without the Tetra Gun and they still came out filthy. I've used Hoppes #9 for over 30 years, but I think it's time for me to switch to M-Pro 7 or Breakthrough. I'm reviewing M-Pro 7 as well as Tetra Gun seperately.Breakthrough decreased my cleaning time to a third when I was cleaning newly purchased antique guns. I think Breakthrough and M-Pro 7 are equally good, it's going to come down to personal preference. I ran a M-Pro 7 soaked patch through the bore after cleaning with Breakthrough. I didn't get any copper or carbon residue on the patch.Pros:No smell.Cut my cleaning time to a third of using Hoppes #9 alone.Spray bottle is more conveniant than using a medicine dropper or dipping rags into the bottle.Breakthrough evaporated quickly and didn't leave residue on the guns.Cons:Colorless liquid didn't let me know which rags were previously wetted with Breakthrough.Breakthrough evaporates quickly which is a con if you like to take your time and use one patch to wipe down the entire gun.Small containers

I cleaned several guns over the weekend to test Breakthrough Military Grade Firearm Cleaning Solvent - 2oz Spray Bottle, M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner, 8-Ounce Spray Bottle, Tetra Gun Copper Solvent, 8-Ounce, and FireClean Fouling-Resistant Oil 2 Ounce FC-2 against Hoppe's No. 9 Gun Bore Cleaning Solvent, 5-Ounce Bottle. Here are the results for FireClean.I couldn't detect any smell from FireClean and my wife didn't complain while I cleaned several guns next to her. I used FireClean with a 6 inch cotton swab on my 1911s and I did notice that some carbon was coming off areas that I had no idea was getting a carbon build up. I also cleaned the areas inside the slide and the bolt carrier faces of the handguns. Again, I was getting some carbon fowling off the metal surfaces.Fireclean is thicker than most oils and it was easy to work with. I did find out the hard way that you have to close the cap before shaking it. Yes, I did make that bone headed move. It cleans up easily when you wipe it up and it does take a little while before it soaks into cloth or cotton swabs.I mainly purchased the FireClean for my 1911s and my AR-10. I re-cleaned the AR-10 and oiled the bolt carrier group with FireClean. I did get some additional carbon to come off the bolt carrier group that I didn't know was left behind after using Hoppes #9 and a CLR oil. As an oil it seems to lubricate well and it was easy to work with. I will update the review after the next time I take a 1911 or my AR-10 shooting. So far I'm very happy with it, but I'm waiting until I next shoot before I finish the review or give it 5 stars.Pros:ThickClearNearly odorless.Seems to be a good lubricant.A little goes a long way.Lifts carbon, but the first time use isn't like in the videos.Cons:I really can't think of any.Updated 3 Feb 2015: Upgrading my review to 5 stars. The carbon buildup really does wipe off with a rag or paper towel when you clean a gun that was previously oiled with FireClean. I found that I still have to make sure the cap is on and closed before shaking the bottle.

I cleaned several guns over the weekend to test Breakthrough Military Grade Firearm Cleaning Solvent - 2oz Spray Bottle, M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner, 8-Ounce Spray Bottle, Tetra Gun Copper Solvent, 8-Ounce, and FireClean Fouling-Resistant Oil 2 Ounce FC-2 against Hoppe's No. 9 Gun Bore Cleaning Solvent, 5-Ounce Bottle. Here are the results for Tetra Gun Copper Solvent.This stuff smells horrid! The good news is that I had to have it close to my nose to smell it and my wife wasn't complaining as she sat next to me while we watched TV.I previously cleaned all of my 1911s with Hoppes #9 a couple weeks ago. I used Tetra Gun Copper Solvent and then Breakthrough or M-Pro 7 to reclean the barrel and the guns. The very first rag that I soaked with Breakthrough or M-Pro 7, after the bore was soaked with Tetra gun, came out filthy. I had no idea I was leaving so much carbon and copper fouling behind after I only cleaned with Hoppes #9. After that it only took me 3 patches before I was using clean dry patches to remove the residual cleaner. The dry patches were coming out wrinkled but just as clean as they went in.I used Tetra Gun Copper Solvent on an M1 Garand that I purchased at auction but hadn't shot yet and a M1903 that I hadn't cleaned or shot since buying it. The patches came out black with copper and carbon fowling on the very first swabs after soaking the bores for 5-10 minutes then using a phosphor bronze brush. The M1 Garand had a rough life before I purchased it and a lot of the patches came out green with copper before I was finally able to get it clean.Tetra Gun Copper Solvent has a yellowish tint to it and you can dispense drops of it straight from the bottle. It's also very thick like molasses. It doesn't take much to get the barrel soaked and to start working.Pros:Thick and yellowish tinge so you can see it and work with it easily to keep it off the stock and your clothes.Works quickly.Bottle can dispense drops or a steady flow.Smell doesn't spread throughout the room like other gun cleaners.Very strong.Cons:Very strong, protect your gun's finish and your clothes. Wear gloves.Smells Horrid. It has that burning amonia smell to it.

I cleaned several guns over the weekend to test Breakthrough Military Grade Firearm Cleaning Solvent - 2oz Spray Bottle, M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner, 8-Ounce Spray Bottle, Tetra Gun Copper Solvent, 8-Ounce, and FireClean Fouling-Resistant Oil 2 Ounce FC-2 against Hoppe's No. 9 Gun Bore Cleaning Solvent, 5-Ounce Bottle. Here are the results for Breakthrough.I couldn't detect any smell from Breakthrough and my wife didn't complain as I cleaned the guns while we watched TV.I previously cleaned all of my 1911s with Hoppes #9 a couple weeks ago. I used Tetra Gun Copper Solvent and then Breakthrough to reclean the barrel and the guns. The very first rag that I soaked with Breakthrough, after the bore was soaked with Tetra gun, came out filthy. I had no idea I was leaving so much carbon and copper fouling behind after I only cleaned with Hoppes #9. After that it only took me 3 patches before I was using clean dry patches to remove the residual cleaner. The dry patches were coming out wrinkled but just as clean as they went in.I also used Breakthrough on previously cleaned guns without the Tetra Gun and they still came out filthy. I've used Hoppes #9 for over 30 years, but I think it's time for me to switch to M-Pro 7 or Breakthrough. I'm reviewing M-Pro 7 as well as Tetra Gun seperately.Breakthrough decreased my cleaning time to a third when I was cleaning newly purchased antique guns. I think Breakthrough and M-Pro 7 are equally good, it's going to come down to personal preference. I ran a M-Pro 7 soaked patch through the bore after cleaning with Breakthrough. I didn't get any copper or carbon residue on the patch.Pros:No smell.Cut my cleaning time to a third of using Hoppes #9 alone.Spray bottle is more conveniant than using a medicine dropper or dipping rags into the bottle.Breakthrough evaporated quickly and didn't leave residue on the guns.Cons:Colorless liquid didn't let me know which rags were previously wetted with Breakthrough.Breakthrough evaporates quickly which is a con if you like to take your time and use one patch to wipe down the entire gun.Small containers.

I cleaned several guns over the weekend to test M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner, 8-Ounce Spray Bottle, Breakthrough Military Grade Firearm Cleaning Solvent - 2oz Spray Bottle, Tetra Gun Copper Solvent, 8-Ounce, and FireClean Fouling-Resistant Oil 2 Ounce FC-2 to Hoppe's No. 9 Gun Bore Cleaning Solvent, 5-Ounce Bottle. Here are the results for M-Pro 7.I thought the smell was pleasant and citrusy, my wife still didn't like it, but she didn't complain while I was cleaning the guns while we watched TV.I previously cleaned all of my 1911s with Hoppes #9 a couple weeks ago. I used Tetra Gun Copper Solvent and then M Pro 7 to reclean the barrel and the guns. The very first rag that I soaked with M Pro 7, after the bore was soaked with Tetra gun, came out filthy. I had no idea I was leaving so much carbon and copper fouling behind after I only cleaned with Hoppes #9. After that it only took me 3 patches before I was using clean dry patches to remove the residual cleaner. The dry patches were coming out wrinkled but just as clean as they went in.I also used M-Pro 7 on previously cleaned guns without the Tetra Gun and they still came out filthy. I've used Hoppes #9 for over 30 years, but I think it's time for me to switch to M-Pro 7 or Breakthrough. I'm reviewing Breakthrough as well as Tetra Gun seperately.M-Pro 7 decreased my cleaning time to a third when I was cleaning newly purchased antique guns. I think Breakthrough and M-Pro 7 are equally good, it's going to come down to personal preference.Pros:Citrus smell is more pleasant than most cleaning solvent.Cut my cleaning time to a third of using Hoppes #9 alone.Spray bottle is more conveniant than using a medicine dropper or dipping rags into the bottle.Slight amber color lets you know that the rag is wet.Cons:Wife still didn't like the smell.

Don't get me wrong, this is a great little tripod. I bought it for the outdoor rifle ranges in my area. I mounted a Leupold Ventana SX-1 on it and I could clearly see the targets at 100 yards but the tripod and the scope were very susceptible to shake. I had to keep my hands off the tables and scope to minimize the shake. However, the tripod still let the scope shake in a good stiff breeze.The tripod folds up nicely and the weight is awesome! I think the suction cup will help with the shaking if you are using the tripod on a surface that will allow the suction cup to work.The controls and locks on the tripod work well and intuitively. Once set and locked, there was no drift with the scope and everyone on the range could come up to take a look at the exact same thing without having to constantly reset the tripod and scope.The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because of the shaking in the wind with a top heavy spotting scope.Pros:CompactLightweightIntuitive controlsHigh quality manufacture and materialsGood locksGreat quality for the pricePan and tilt handle is the perfect sizeCons:Allows big top heavy loads to shake in the wind.You can't touch it while examining something with a top heavy tool. Shaky hands are even worse.

My silver dot case arrived today. The box it was shipped in looked fine, but when I checked the case out, the end was broken and caving in at one corner. Now I have to request a refund because amazon can't replace this case. I have to ship it back, via UPS. The return isn't costing me anything other than time and gas to take the package back.The walls of the case are hard plastic and are much like non skid. It isn't a smooth skin and will be a real bear to clean if it gets dirty and you decide to try and clean it. The case itself has the small built in locks on the latches and a loop on each end for padlocks. This case is supposed to meet airline requirements and it probably does, but I don't think it would hold up to the baggage handlers.There are 3 layers of foam inside the case. 2 layers of the egg crate style foam and a third flat layer with lots of slots cut into it. I don't know why all the slots are cut there isn't anything to slide through the foam or an anchoring system. The wheels on the broken end seemed fine. The latches were a little unusual and would take some getting used to, they won't flip open as much as most others I've seen. The loops for the padlocks are pretty thin and felt sturdy on initial inspection. However, if they caught my eye that quickly, they probably won't hold up. The handles feel and look sturdy. There is one on the side and one on the end. The case itself was big enough for two scoped rifles and long enough for a goose gun or a Mosin-Nagant.I really had high hopes for this case but it just wasn't meant to be and now I have to find something different. I'm not even going to look at other TZ cases because this one doesn't seem to cut it.

I am comparing these parallel rulers to ones I've used in the past in middle school and high school shop classes and in the US Navy for navigation and moboards.They are clear and without any graduation markings on them. The edges are smooth and will give you a straight line on your charts or for any other time you use them for parallel lines. The hinges on them are snug and there wasn't any play in them unless you force it. The non stick pads are perfect and will allow you to easily walk the parallel rulers across your charts, drawings, or table saws. These are 18 inches so they might be a bit big for small charts or confined spaces. However, I use them for wood working to ensure that the saw blade and the rip fence are truly parallel. For that I needed a large surface area for more accuracy. They are clear and without flaws or scratches to impede your vision through them so that you can read your charts or watch out for obstructions that might impede your ability to walk them across a table or chart. The handles on them are standardized, free of burs, and comfortable to hold. The verticle grooves on the handles allow you to maintain a solid grip on them without straining your hand to hold them tighter.I've been searching for parallel rulers for years without finding them. I should have thought to look on Amazon in the first place.These parallel rulers meet the exacting standards for professionals and anyone who has to use them for navigation, but they are also priced right for hobbyists. So far, I really haven't seen any down side to these parallel rulers, they meet my needs perfectly.

I constantly leave my power cords plugged into the outlet and I just return the iPad to charge at night when I'm finished for the day. I've checked the plug in on several occaisions to see if it was over heating and I never found it to be more than just warm. The charger works every time I plug my iPad in. The cord doesn't get tangled or retain it's curves so much that it's a hassle to straighten. It's also lasted longer than other cheap cords I've tried in the past. I've never had any issues with any of the connections loosening and falling out of the outlet or the iPad. These, are definitely quality made and worth the money.

Like the saying goes, you get what you pay for. I was looking for an economy rifle case that would fit my Mosin-Nagant. It fits with a couple inches to spare. The case seems well made and I didn't see any issues with the stitching, wrap around handles, or the zipper. It's well made for the price I paid. I certainly won't put anything else in the case with the rifle since there is no way to prevent everything from bumping or scratching the rifle or other items. It won't fit a scoped rifle either, but that wasn't what I needed. I was looking for a light duty case to protect the gun from scratches and dings when I transport it to the range, and I store it in my locker. This case fits the bill and I won't hesitate to order more from Bulldog if I need them.

All my other pistol cases were too small for my Dan Wesson 44 mag with an 8 inch barrel. This one fits great. It has just enough play in it that I might be able to fit a 10 inch barrel in it if I ever get one. You won't be able to safely put multiple items in this case without wrapping them in something to keep everything from scratching your gun, but it does have a small utility pocket on the side that you can fit smaller mags in. However, you won't be able to put your loaded speed loaders for large caliber revolvers in it.I have no complaints about the stitching, wrap around handles, or zipper. Everything seems to be well made and an excellent value for the price. I've never had any issues with Bulldog items.

I have a 2004 Jeep Liberty that I'm using my dashcam on. The first night I hooked the suction cup up to my window, it fell during the night. No big deal, I put it back up the following morning and it hasn't fallen since then and it's been a few weeks. The screen is in color and it's kinda tempting sometimes to try and drive using only the screen, but then the grown up in me takes over as I remember what my insurance rates might do. The low light and night recording is exactly what I expected and I love the fact that it will cycle over the oldest files first when I run out of room on my 16 gig micro SD card.Maybe I'm hard of hearing or maybe I keep the radio turned up too loud or I drive with my windows down too much, but any of the features that require an audible signal are worthless to me since I can't hear them unless the car and radio are off and it's quiet around me.Overall, I like this dashcam but I wish it had some of the features that the more expensive units have like gps and I wish the speaker was louder. The base functionality is great, and it's very easy to use and set up.Edited 21 May 2014: I'm upgrading my rating to 5 stars from 4 stars. The Papago customer service is AWESOME! They replied to my review soon after it was submitted with suggestions to fix an issue I was having! They ROCK!Edit 29 Sep 2014: The LCD screen on this unit started blinking recently and then suddenly it stopped blinking and the screen was staying on. I tried to adjust the settings but none of the buttons will work now and the only way to turn it off is to unplug it. The suction cup would come off the window whenever there was a significant temperature change overnight or during the day. That wasn't a problem until now when it won't stick to the window at all anymore. My wife has a more expensive model and she hasn't had the issues that I have had. I'm reducing my overall rating to 3 stars since the unit didn't even last a year before I had to try and find the warranty records or find some way to fix it.

In my research on stripper clips for my first Mosin-Nagant, I repeatedly read warnings about sharp edges on the stripper clips. These arrived and the outside of the stripper clips were clean, shiny, and bright. I didn't find any sharp edges to slice my thumb on right away and they seemed to be well made and formed. My only minor complaint is that they have some deposits on the inside of the stripper clips. It seems like this will come clean though when I throw them into my tumbler for a few hours.I haven't opened a case of 7.62x54R yet, but I tried some .308 and 30-06 ammo in the clips just for giggles. Even those were held in well and they didn't feel stuck in the stripper clips. I feel confident that these will work flawlessly.Edited 27 May 2014:I took these to the range on Sunday and I was very disappointed. I don't know if it was operator error or clip quality, but rounds kept popping out of the stripper clips when I tried to load the rifle. I also had a very hard time pushing the rounds into the magazine of the gun with the stripper clips. The stripper clips wobbled back and forth a lot and I had to hold them steady with one hand while using the other to push the rounds in. For the most part I could get the first 2 or 3 rounds to go into the magazine and the rest I would have to manually load one by one. Eventually, I just gave up and loaded the rounds manually. It was quicker and easier. Hopefully it is just operator error on my part and I will have to do some digging to make sure I used them correctly. Oh and after several hours in the tumbler, the deposits on the inside of the clips never came clean. The outsides of the stripper clips were nice and shiny though. LOL

You aren't going to go wrong with this conditioner. I would recommend your first coats of new, old, or neglected wood be the Howard's mineral oil. Then when the oil soaks into the wood at a slower pace, you can switch to the conditioner. It swells the grains and smooths the wood out. Knife marks are reduced and it gives the finish to the wood a soft smooth feel. We use our butcher block as an end table now and we never have to worry about water rings from glasses. The butcher block top also has a smooth feel that I like to just rub my hands on. This conditioner also gives the wood a nice glow and darkens it up a little. As others have noted. Only use rags to apply this conditioner and throw them out afterwards. You also don't need a lot of elbow grease with the conditioner. It's kinda like polishing your shoes. Just work it in but you don't need to spend a lot of time doing it.Pros:Easy to applyGreat finishGreat appearanceEasily absorbed into the woodCons:You may need a lot of this if your wood is "thirsty"Don't use your rags for anything else after this

You won't go wrong with this oil. It's perfect for new wood and old neglected wood. My wife and I used this on an 80 year old butcher block we bought at a garage sale. (We dated the butcher block by looking at the local history and when the deli that was stamped on the side of the block went out of business) The butcher block was well used and in good shape but the wood was dry. We coated the entire piece including the bottom and the legs and we used several bottles. The wook absorbed this oil quickly and it never left an oily or slimy feeling behind. It also helped to give the wood a healthy look to the oxidation. It also smoothed out the top as the grain swelled to fill the cuts in the top and the end grain expanded slightly.We use the butcher block as an end table now and we have never had an issue with water rings from glasses and we have no worry about what we set on top of the block. This oil really helps protect the wood as well as restoring the natural moisture.Pros:It helps preserve the wood and expand the grains for a smoother feelIt's easily absorbed into the wood.It doesn't have a foul smell or impart any taste to foodsCons:The wood will really absorb this oilYou may need a lot of it for new and untreated wood or neglected wood.

I bought these brushes for three main reasons:1. They come in their own box..2. I am tired of trying to figure out which brush goes with each caliber.3. I needed some brushes for new guns that I recently bought.Tipton products have been very good to me. I love their one piece carbon fiber rods and I love the jags and phosphor bronze brushes. These brushes are as good as advertised. The ends are made of a one piece wire that loops at the end, and the opposite end is embedded in the brass base. The threads are clean and crisp. They screw into standard cleaning rods very smoothly. Yes I tried them on a 3 piece aluminum rod and a one piece tipton rod. The brushes screwed into both very easily with the exception of the .17 cal. It's made for a smaller rod and I don't have a gun that small anyway. In any case the threads are in industry standards. I will say that if you are cleaning a 44 and a 45 at the same time, you have to be careful to keep them seperate. The individual brushes are not labeled with their size. Each bay though is fitted to a brush. The picture is kinda misleading and it appears as if there are two rows of brushes. This is not the case. The thick plastic band is just there to hold the long brush in it's individual bay.The brushes slide in and out of the bays with little effort. They won't come out and become loose.Pros:The case keeps them organized.Each bay is sized according to the brush that fits it.The case can be mounted on a wall.The lid fits very well and is easy to open and close.Each bay has a snug fit to hold the brush in place so they don't come loose.Cons:The brushes are not labeled with their sizes so be careful you don't confuse them.The brushes have a snug fit and it does require a little dexterity to pull them out.  People with weak grips or arthritis in their hands may have difficulty. This might be fixed by screwing them into the rod while they are still in the bay, then using the rod to pull them out.

I bought these jags for three main reasons:1. They come in their own box with labeled chambers for each jag.2. I wanted to replace all my plastic and loose jags.3. I needed some jags for new guns that I recently bought.Tipton products have been very good to me. I love their one piece carbon fiber rods and I love the jags and phosphor bronze brushes. These jags are as good as advertised. They have the spear on the tip to hold your wads in place and they have plenty of surface area to push the wads against the bore when you push them through the barrel. The threads are clean and crisp. They screw into standard cleaning rods very smoothly. Yes I tried them on a 3 piece aluminum rod and a one piece tipton rod. The jags screwed into both very easily with the exception of the .17 cal. It's made for a smaller rod and I don't have a gun that small anyway. In any case the threads are in industry standards. I will say that if you are cleaning a 44 and a 45 at the same time, you have to be careful to keep them seperate. The individual jags are not labeled with their size. Each bay though is fitted to a jag.Pros:The case keeps them organized.Each chamber in the case is labeled.Each bay is sized according to the jag that fits it.The case can be mounted on a wall.The lid fits very well and is easy to open and close.Each bay has a snug fit to hold the jags in place so they don't come loose.Cons:The jags are not labeled with their sizes so be careful you don't confuse them.The jags have a very tight fit in their bays. People with weak grips or arthritis in their hands may have difficulty.The labels on the bay are hard to read. They are simply raised numbers and there isn't any contrast to them. Maybe a sharpe would help with that.

I bought a 40 inch cleaning rod for my Mosin Nagant and my 1903/A3. I've never liked cleaning from the muzzle to the breach so now with this rod I don't have to. I can also put a plastic bottle on the end of the barrel to catch the wads and spray from the cleaning brushes. This is the second carbon fiber rod I've purchased and I much prefer them over the sectional aluminum rods. With the aluminum rods the jag and sections kept coming unscrewed whenever I used them. I don't have that problem with the Tipton rods. The rod spins so smoothly on it's bearings that you won't even know it's spinning unless you are touching the rod. The handle is ergonomic and provides a good grip especially when wearing nitrile gloves. The threads on the end are the standard 8/32 so they fit most all standard brushes or jags for this caliber rod. The rod is stiff but flexible and you shouldn't have any difficulties with pushing tight wads or brushes through the breech and barrel. The 40 inch rod is also long enough that I can pull the bolt out of my rifles and clean from the breach instead of the muzzle. I also don't have to worry about a big T handle getting in the way and catching on the butt or other parts of the rifle.Pros:Smooth bearings inside the handle for flawless spinningPerfect threads to attach your jags, brushes, and other attachmentsRod extends through the handle with an eye so you can hang the rod upStiff and flexible, if it bends it goes back to it's original shapeWon't scratch the barrel or recieverStiff enough for stubborn patches or brushesAttachments don't come unscrewed when the rod follows the rifling1 piece and easy maintenance.Can be hung upCons:Long and if you don't hang it, storage may be a chore40 inch model is long and requires some room to maneuver

I bought this for a trip to Paris and I kept most of my money, my passport, and metro passes in it. It's light weight, easy to access, thin, roomy, and has lots of different pouches for easy organization. It was also comfortable enough that I could adjust the neck strap and wear it on my chest all day long. I would even forget that I was wearing it, and this was only an issue when going through airport security. I forgot to take it off.It's well worth the small price for the security and peace of mind you get knowing that your valuables will be safe.

I've used other polishes over the years and I've even found out how flamable some of them are. I can honestly say that I like Flitz better than anything else I have ever used on small parts. This is a tumbler additive, but I have also put it on a soft cotton cloth to polish carbon deposits off the outside of a gun barrel that I couldn't fit in my RCBS 87088 Vibratory Case Cleaner-2. I had no problem cleaning the barrell while I watched TV and my wife and son didn't complain about the smell either.I usually add corn cob bedding material from the pet store or feed and seed and a cap full of Flitz TA 04885 Green Tumbler Media Additive - 7.6 oz. Bottle in my tumbler for all my brass shells and other small metal items that need tumbling or cleaning. Make sure you turn on your tumbler with the media in it before adding the flitz, otherwise it will clump up on you. Be advised though, that this works really well and if your brass is dirty, you will get a lot of oxidation off of it, and the corn cobb media will get really dirty really quickly. It's still useable when it's dirty, and I usually judge by how long it is taking to clean the brass in order to determine when to change the media. I've also found that tearing up pieces of a used dryer sheet and mixing it in with the tumbler media will help with the dust.It's eco friendly and I simply throw the old media and Flitz in the garbage. It's not often that an eco friendly product works as well as it claims, but Flitz does it well. I've heard lots of other people recommend it on gun forums as a good cleaner.Pros:VersatileEffecientWorks as well as it claimsReasonable costEco friendlyCan be used to polish metal with a soft clothThe smell isn't overpoweringLong lastingCons:It gets really dirty so wear gloves when changing the media.You can use it to polish metal with a soft cloth, but it's more effecient as a tumbler additive

Great for packing for a trip out of the country, but I found I needed multiple sheets for just one item. Your hands must be totally dry before your touch the sheets in the pack, so I had to carefully dry my hands each time I added another to the sink. Even with several, I never had any suds and the items didn't feel soapy in the least. Also, they don't disolve as redily as I expected and I had to rub at my hands or the clothes to unstick the residue. Our friend was continuing on for two more weeks on the road after we went home, but I didn't even give her the soap for the remainder of her trip as we'd planned. If you'll be somewhere with a sink, just use bar soap or shampoo instead.

I bought this for a trip out of the country. I get warm easily and I needed lighweight clothes to pack, so I figured this would be perfect. Um, no. It's WAY too sheer. The model must not be wearing a bra for the back view, because you'd be able to see it easily. I was uncomfortable with that, so I wore a cardigan over it the whole day. But, alas! A worse problem surfaced. Although it wasn't tight across the chest, it kept unbuttoning at the bust line. We were out and about all day long so I couldn't change. I had to rebutton literally 20+ times. I may try to fix the problem just so I can wear it around the house (sans bra!) in the summer. I'm going to sew the button holes at the edges to make them smaller. The color and fabric held up in the wash, but I had it in a hosery bag on cold and delicate cycle. But I do NOT suggest you buy this shirt!  EDIT: Went to sew the button holes smaller, and discovered a tear next to a seam on the inner front panel. And I washed this on delicate and in a small net bag! :(

I purchased this for a trip out of the country where I'd be sharing an apartment for the week with friends, so I wanted a super large night shirt that I could modestly wear in the common areas in the evening. I overdid it. I am size 20-22, 5'4", and bought the 3x/4x. Sure, it covered me up, but it's way too big! I was concerned that if the smaller size was too short I wouldn't have time to order another before we left. If you are my size I'd suggest you don't get 3x/4x. However, the shirt is attracive, comfortable, and launders well.

I wear 20-22 and bought the 3x. Someone must think you can wear a 3x and have a totally flat tummy! The fabric is very thin. I get hot easily, so I was looking for that (another reviewer clued me in). However, the belt was cheap and didn't seem like it would stay in place and my tummy bulged out like an aneurysm LOL. Instead, I ordered and bought Plus Size Skirt In Soft Knit, Pretty Colors which was much higher quality and much more flattering, although a lot heavier.

I bought these for a trip and liked them so much that I hurried and got a second pair before I left. I wear a size 20-22 and I am 5'4"), and I admit these were a little long, but not uncomfortably so. They look great with a long sweater or fancy shirt. Great for travel as they're light and wrinkle free to pack.

I bought the green version FUNFASH EMERALD GREEN RHINESTONES EMPIRE WAIST TOP SHIRT Plus Size MADE in USA after getting the red one and liking how well it fit. It's nice quality, a light synthetic fabric, and very pretty. However, I was surprised to see in person that it, like the green one, is a peacock feather pattern. That wasn't immediately apparent in the photos. I really like the crystal sparkles on the bodice. I purchased the shirts for a trip out of the country. They were very light to pack, wrinkled little (and the pattern disguised it), and super comfortable. Easy to wash in a hotel sink, too. I wore them with black stretch pants and it looked great!

I bought both this one after getting the red one FUNFASH RED BLACK RHINESTONES EMPIRE WAIST TOP SHIRT WOMEN Plus Size MADE IN USA and liking how well it fit. It's nice quality, a light synthetic fabric, and very pretty in person. The color was a little more muted than shown, though. I really like the crystal sparkles on the bodice. I purchased the shirts for a trip out of the country. They were very light to pack, wrinkled little (and the pattern disguised it), and super comfortable. Easy to wash in a hotel sink, too. I wore them with black stretch pants and it looked great!

I wear a 20-22, and should have ordered the 1x rather than 2x, but it's just a little big on me so I kept it. The sweater is soft, medium weight, somewhat thin, and very comfortable! I get lots of complements on it! I purchased it for a trip and wore it with black tights, which looked and felt great together!

I got the 1x (I usually wear 20-22) and the skirt was flattering and super comfortable. However, you should know that the fabric is very heavy. I personally get hot very easily, so I'll only be wearing this in cool weather. It may be perfect for you other times, though!

This was even better than I hoped! I bought it for a trip and wore it over everything! Works for both casual and dressy outfits. It's good quality,very warm, and the pleated style gives shape to us big girls (size 20-22). Also, it hangs far enough to cover my butt LOL. Easy wash. It also has a 'leash' inside the back top so it will stay on the hanger. However note: no pockets. I'd love pockets, but they'd ruin the look and style of the sweater. I plan to buy another.

I'm a big girl (size 20-22) and this dress is very flattering on me! The fabric is a nice medium weight and the dress is good quality. It's fully lined, as well. It looks great with black hose and either red or black shoes.

This dress arrived and was very pretty, and the quality seemed to be fine. But I returned this dress for two reasons. One, I'm just not busty enough for it. Even if it had fit well, I would have returned it because the decorative do-dad on the side is way to heavy for this dress. The fabric is light and the sewn on clasp very heavy. Clunky. When holding the dress up in your hands, you can feel the pull/weight of it. If you fit and are in love with this dress, I'd remove the thing and sew on something else in its place.

They slip a little because they have no teeth, but not so much that I find it to be a problem. In fact, I flip reading glasses up and down onto my head all day at work and don't have to readjust the band too often. They do look like leather, are secure but not too tight, and you won't have to worry about them breaking like the plastic ones. The colors are neutral, so they'll go with anything.

I've never found a shirt that is truly wrinkle free, but some are better than others. When I recently traveled, I had to pack this shirt in a dufflebag and the travel wrinkles came out after hanging for a couple hours. However, like all dress shirts, I still iron it before wearing them. This shirt fits large men as advertised and is quite comfortable. The shirt does have removeable collar stays. The collar stays can be removed during washing or changed out if they become damaged or bent. The neck size fit well and didn't make me feel like I was being hanged.Pros:Good fabricStylishRemoveable collar staysWrinkle resistantComfortableCons:Removeable collar stays if you aren't used to them.

I have to fold the shirt up to pack it in a dufflebag for trips. However, the shirt will straighten out reasonably well after it has been hung up for a couple hours. I've never found a poplin shirt that is truly wrinkle free. Some just have to be ironed less than others. I was quite pleasantly surprised to find this shirt in my size since I've gained a significant amount of weight since the last time I purchased a dress shirt. The sleeves and neck size were appropriate and comfortable. The color was true to the pictures and description. The collar stays are permanent and you don't have to take them out before washing the shirt. You also can't change the coller stays if they become damaged or bent.Pros:Good sizing (especially for large men)More wrinkle free than mostStylishComfortablePermanent collar staysCons:Not truly wrinkle free but closePermanent collar stays

We bought two of these for a recent trip to Paris. One was used to power a CPAP machine, charge and iPhone 4, and two iPads overnight each night. The unit was next to the bed with everything plugged into it at night. The CPAP was plugged in 24x7 to the converter. The cooling fan noise from the converter was quieter than the CPAP. It was simply white noise that helps some people fall asleep. We left the second unit in the common area of our apartment so that our friends and son could plug any of their devices into it. At any given time we would have smart phones, cell phones, battery chargers, iPods, iPads, CPAPs, or tablet PCs plugged into the converters. There were never any issues with the converters failing to work or overheating. The fan noise was low and non intrusive. The charging times for all appliances that were plugged in were the same as if they were plugged into a wall outlet in the US. The units were small enough and light enough to be packed in carry on luggage. The occaisional drop from the countertop onto a wooden floor didn't affect the operation of the converters either.Pros:SmallQuietDurableReliableCons:Small, this won't be able to power appliances like microwaves or coffee makers.There isn't a way to keep all the adapters with the converter unless you keep the box or use a bag.The on/off button is easy to turn off when you are plugging some USB items in.

Many of us have all been in the situation where we have no choice but to use the local facilities, and much to our dismay there is a lack of toilet paper! I was warned about this possibility ahead of time for a recent trip. Ms. Cypressgreen ordered a few boxes of these to take with us on the trip. Mr. Cypressgreen always kept two packets of these in his pockets. Holy cow, I'm glad I always had them in my pockets! I'll just say that these are good for ANY exterior part of the body that needs to be cleaned. They were also perfect for cleaning our hands in public whenever the need arose. The wipes and packages are small enough to be discreetly disposed of too. I never paid any attention to the scent other than to notice that it was pleasant.Pros:Discreet packaging, they lay flat in your pockets.Pleasant scentMoistDurable, they didn't shred when you used them.Durable packages didn't accidently open when they are in your pockets day after day.Excellent cleaners for skin and other surfaces.Depending on the situation and people, they can be reused multiple times.The actual wipes are flushable.Cons:I don't think the foil packages are entirely eco friendly

I used to wear thick wool socks when I went backpacking as a Boy Scout. I also wore thick wool socks when I used to work outdoors in Northern Wisconsin during their winters. I never in my life thought I would be comfortable wearing wool socks during any season other than winter or cold weather.These socks really are worth all the 5 star reviews they get. I tried them on a trip to Paris France recently and I compared them to my standard cotton socks and also to synthetic sports socks.They are well cushioned and relatively thick. In Paris, we were on our feet all day long and we were either standing on the metro or walking around town the entire time. I never had any issues with blisters, overheating, or that scratchy feeling you sometimes get from wool. My feet still felt good in the evening when I came home and took my shoes and socks off. I didn't have any issues with foot odor at all, and the socks dried quickly after being washed. The smart wool socks exceeded the synthetic sports socks and my regular cotton socks in every category. I was didn't have any hesitation to wear the socks a second day without washing them. I can't say that for any of the other socks I took on the trip. I can honestly say that these make great travel socks, you can take a couple pairs and wash them in the sinks when they get dirty and they dry overnight. 2 - 3 pairs of these socks would have replaced 7-10 pairs of cotton socks for me.Pros:SoftSupportiveDurableCoolComfortableDries quicklyWicks away sweatCons:More expensive than cotton socksLimited color optionsBulkier than comparable cotton socks

I purchased this card for use in my Canon Rebel T2i on an overseas trip. I took several hundred pictures and videos at the highest resolution I could. I didn't use the RAW format though. I never had any problems with the card when I was in the field or in my apartment for the night. I never ran out of room on the card either, and I was also letting my 13 year old step son use the camera and take any pictures he wanted to on the trip. A couple times I pulled the SD card out of my camera and plugged it into an SD card reader for my iPad Air. The reliability was phenomenal and the speed was fabulous. I could plug the SD card reader into the iPad, walk away for a short task, and all the pictures would be copied onto the iPad by the time I returned.I was also taking HD videos during the day and at night without any problems or delays.Pros:FASTReliableDurableCons:Pricey

This is the ultimate stocking stuffer or small gift for coworkers! My nieces who are 5 and 7 loved it. My son loved it at 9, now that he is 13 he loves it when he is with his friends. Then there were my coworkers! They loved being able to non-verbally express how they felt about thier long boring conference calls where there is always someone who drones on and on! It turned out to be a big hit at the office where I gave out several different pooping animals. Even the mildest of office mates would spend a couple minutes to make their own pooping barnyard scene and snap a quick picture.These toys won't stand up to rough play like banging on them or launching them from a catapult. They do last a few years in my office before time takes it's toll and it's time for the office mascot to retire to greener pastures. the legs are sturdy enough for poop after poop and refill after refill. The head stays on well and locks in place for the pooping fun, yet it is easy to open for refills. The jelly beans that came with the animals weren't the greatest, but you can use your own jelly beans or other round candies. In fact, these little pooping critters can handle most anything round that will fit through the back end. At our office you never knew what might come out. Sometimes it was even paper clips that were used for the bosses reports.Go ahead and treat yourself, your friends, and family. These critters aren't just for Christmas. They bring impish delight all year round.

We originally bought the Renaissance wax on the recommendation of others who have used it in the past to protect their art. Once we saw the history of the wax and the fact that it is museum quality, we decided to try it. Hubby has used minwax paste wax on furniture before. However, when the wife used this on her new chair, he was amazed at the ease of application and the shine it leaves. A little of this wax goes a long way. It dries quickly, and easily buffs to an amazing shine. After letting the chair sit for a couple days in between coatings, it didn't feel like there was ever a waxy buildup, and it feels like there is a strong protective coating. It's also very slick, I can see how other reviewers commented on using this wax on jointers and table saws. The next thing for the hubby to wax will be the table saw. We also won't hesitate to use this as a protectant on metal ornamentation, furniture, leather handles, or any other projects that require protection and a high gloss finish.The first time the wife used it, she didn't wear any gloves while applying the wax, and she complained afterwards how it made her hands feel. We would definitely recommend gloves.Pros:Amazing glossEasily buffsDries quicklyEasy to applyVery slick finishA little goes a long wayFeels like it's a strong protectantCons:Makes your hands feel slick if you apply it without glovespricey

I'm starting to tear through these books as quickly as I can. LOL I love the story premises and being able to identify with what the characters are doing and who they are. I apologize for being a little slow, but by the middle of this book I started to think that there was more to the change than I originally thought. The ending confirms it. I also find that I'm eager to read the rest of the books and I'm really hoping that Stirling expands on my favorite characters and doesn't just abandon them. I'm also coming to appreciate that good and bad characters die; and I appreciate being kept on my toes when it happens. I still wish that Stirling would title his books in a different way. I would say more on this but I don't want to spoil it for anyone.Good read and I can't wait to get the next one.

Stirling's style has much improved since Dies The Fire. However, I wish he would choose his titles in a different manner. He isn't abandoning fight or battle scenes in mid fight to leave you assuming who won. You can still pick up the book without reading the previous one and become interested in the story. The book length is short and his style of recapping will probably become tedious as I read more of the books. All in all though the book is good. I'm still planning on reading the rest of the series and then moving on to the series of the Island In The Sea Of Time books. Jumping back and forth in time within a book doesn't bother me at all when it's done logically. It worked for me in this book.Good and easy read.

NO SPOILERSTwo short stories in one graphic novel.In "Throttle," Hill and King pull together a short but exciting tale of another, and very different, son and father. As the description provides, their biker gang is pitted against a murderous trucker who mysteriously wishes them ill. Father and son's personalities and relationship are well drawn and believable. The comic is based on their short story Throttle (Kindle Single).A short story needs to be lean and tightly written, with no elements useless to the plot and character development. Hill and King are both sharp writers who know how to make a character feel real and relatable. Matheson's "Duel" main character is also well defined, but with less background or final explanation. Matheson's story Duel inspired Hill and King's.The book includes a comics version "Throttle" and one of  "Duel" as well. I have never read "Duel" as a short story but, based on the perfect adaptation of the "Throttle" half by Ryall, I'm guessing it's true to Matheson's original.I bought the short story version of "Throttle" first, but after reading the comic I didn't feel the comic was necessary. It felt superfluous, and I'm a big comics fan. Not that it's poorly done; it's well illustrated and true to the short story. Ryall and Daniel adapt and illustrate it well, with, IMHO, two caveats. The style used in "Duel" was not really to my liking. Not poorly done - just not my cup of tea. I loved the illustrations for Throttle, except the use of Ben-Day dots. I found them a little distracting. If they'd been a little smaller I would have liked them better. However, these opinions are just about my personal taste and you may disagree. In addition, the two stories are so similar that it felt like a bit of a repeat reading them as the only things in the book.It also included a prologue by Joe Hill explaining how and why they wrote the story. I enjoyed reading that.The kindle edition of the "Throttle" short story also includes a couple of illustrations from the comic.

NO SPOILERS  Hill and King pull together a short but exciting tale of another, and very different, son and father. As the description provides, their biker gang is pitted against a murderous trucker who mysteriously wishes them ill. Father and son's personalities and relationship are well drawn and believable. I felt pulled in from the very beginning and couldn't set it down until I finished!A short story needs to be lean and tightly written, with no elements useless to the plot and character development. Hill and King are both sharp writers who know how to make a character feel real and relatable. Their descriptions of the terrain and events make them easy to picture. Indeed, I bought the comics version of this story Road Rage (the book includes a comics version of Matheson's "Duel" as well - the  story that inspired Throttle), but after reading it I didn't feel the comic was necessary. It felt superfluous, and I'm a big comics fan. Not that it's poorly done; it's well illustrated and true to the short story. It also included a prologue by Joe Hill explaining how and why they wrote the story.This kindle edition does include a couple of illustrations from the comic, which I appreciated.

I was really disappointed in this story. I can see how people who grew up in this time period and/or lived in the same town. The Amazon book description is 100% about the missing Pecord family; the book is 20% about the Pecord family. Mr.  Naughton clearly knows how to create an atmosphere and show reader like me, who didn’t grow up in the 5os, get an idea of what life was like.But the Pecords? He gives a lot of information about his and his friends’ involvement of the discovery that the family was missing, but no real follow up. The best he does is question a police officer friend years later. He could have done so much more…interview older residents, search newspaper archives, look at land deeds (if they owned the house, who owned it next), search death records, etc. Nope. I myself looked up the address to see it on Google maps and looked at what past sale records I could find in a casual search online.He named the book, “Whatever Happened to the Pecords?”  Well, geez man, put in a little more effort to find out!

I always have this in the house. It’s a great quick cover for scratches and small nicks on furniture. I have a lot of old, “well loved” furniture. One item is an old, dark wood bed with a wreath shaped applique on the headboard. Part of it was broken off before I even got the bed. Once a year, I use a Q-tip and soak the area with Old English so it’s not immediately noticeable that part of the wreath is missing. I do find I have to reapply this to some nicks and scratches once a year or so. It seems to soak in over time.Using the "dark" cover on wood that's light is a bad idea; it shows right up. So use with care.

I use the pourable Liquid Gold, not the type in an aerosol can.Most of the furniture I own is quite old - family pieces or antiques that are just as old. Therefore, I worry about them drying out too much as time passes.The Liquid Gold does the trick. It makes the wood smell really good and gives it a lovely shine. It improves the appearance of, shall we say, lower quality wood items. I purchased our 120 gallon fish tank used. It's on a pine base and was fairly cheap looking when I got it, but the oil darkens up the wood a bit and evens out the appearance. It has also perked up a slightly battered washstand and a converted radio cabinet that we use as night stands.On several occasions I have flipped my 70 yr old dining room table over and drizzled liberal amounts on the underside (done this with other items, too). Then I leave it sit overnight and it all soaks in. I'll also use a liberal amount on surfaces and let it soak in overnight, just wiping off whatever little bits are still there the next day. I've also used it to good effect on pine paneled walls.We got a long, thin scratch on our brand new bamboo flooring, so I tried the Liquid Gold, not expecting a fix. But the scratch is now invisible unless you know where to look and the light hits it just so!

This is my first foray into scoped rifles and if I can shoot groups smaller than a quarter from 100 yards away, the rifle and scope have to be good! I mounted my scope on a Smith & Wesson MP-10 and I'm using a Harris bipod. My second trip to the range with my rifle and scope felt amazing. I was actually able to zero the scope so that I could cover my 3 shot groups with a quarter. The dials on the scope are firm with very distinct clicks. The optics were able to accomodate my poor vision. There was no fog or glare on the glass when I used it, and I had no problem using the scope with enough eye relief for a .308. Considering that this is the first time that I mounted and used a scope on a rifle, I have to give this scope a 5 star rating. However, my first trip to the range to sight the rifle in was very frustrating. It seemed that nothing I did was working to zero the scope. Then I had a flash of brilliance, I read the directions more closely with the scope in front of me. It's amazing the difference it made when I realized I was making the wrong adjustments. I proved that this scope isn't idiot proof, but it is darn close!pros:Very clean and good threads for lense caps or other attachmentsExcellent quality glassClear markings for windage and elevationDistinct clicks when adjusting windage and elevationVery crisp reticleVery accurateConsI wish the directions were easy enough for novices like me to understand them the first timeThis scope does not come with lense covers, you will have to purchase them seperately.

I ordered two of the same pattern but in different color schemes, one for the living room and one for the adjoining dining room. I wanted to tie the rooms together although they are not decorated in the same colors. I admit I was concerned about ordering such large rugs by mail without seeing them in person first. Turns out I made a great choice!I got a large rectangular one in Ebony and an octagonal one in Heathered Rose. I also purchased two high quality rug pads, a move I highly recommend. No matter the rug, a pad will protect the floor and make it more comfy to walk on.  And if you can afford it, buy the best one possible. You're going to have it for years.The rugs themselves have a short pile. They aren't fluffy soft, but also not scratchy or in any way uncomfortable to bare feet. They're nice to the touch. (I recently bought a smaller rug by another company for my bedroom; dang thing is totally flat and scratchy to boot.) They're also plenty thick and will stay in place well. One rug I bought years ago for my office is beautiful but so thin that it rumples up constantly. So annoying! Also, these Milliken rugs were rolled up pattern side out. That scratchy one I just got for the bedroom was rolled pattern side in and two weeks later the one edge has, annoyingly, still not flattened out. But on these new ones, that curl on the one edge is facing down and it appears it will be totally flattened in just a couple of days. I know that's just a minor annoyance, but I think it's worth mentioning.The colors are lovely and pretty true to the photos here. The border looks great going around the octagonal one. That's the Heathered Rose one, and the new curtains I bought for that room arrived yesterday also. Achim Home Furnishings Ombre Window Panel, 50-Inch by 84-Inch, Earth They look awesome together! (Although note my set are NOT the same color as shown here - they are shades of purple.) Today I ordered more of the same style curtains in a different color combo to match the Ebony rug in the living room.I would not hesitate to order Milliken rugs again.

I ordered a set of these for my dining room - two panels and one scarf. I really love them! However, I purchased them from elsewhere so I was able to get them in another color scheme. I don't know why not all the colors the company makes are sold by the different sellers on Amazon. Mine are purple, and the curtains are made in at least 8 color combinations. Burgundy, Aubergine (purple), Autumn, Black, Chocolate/Blue, Earth, Sage, and Sandstone.My only concern when  I ordered them was that they'd be too striped, but once hung they fall into a less rigid look than the carefully placed ones in the picture. The colors are also a bit less bold than pictured, which softens the stripes.The fabric is light and crinkly. When drawn, they'll let in light and obscure the view from outside. I don't know if they'd cover you if you wanted to walk around naked at night (ha ha), but they will definitely afford some privacy.I just received them yesterday and put them up immediately. They go perfectly with the new rug Milliken Pastiche Barrington Court Heathered Rose Rug Oval 5'4" x 7'8" .And I love them so much that I ordered more for the two living room windows!

Burgundy, Aubergine (purple), Autumn, Black, Chocolate/Blue, Earth, Sage, and Sandstone.My only concern when  I ordered them was that they'd be too striped, but once hung they fall into a less rigid look than the carefully placed ones in the picture.
