The quality seemed good compared to other drugstore/supermarket shadow brands, but not as nice as some of the more expensive brands.The main issue I had was that the color didn't look as rich on my skin as it looked in the kit. The pink looked much less pink on my skin and looked almost off-white. The crease color is also  a very neutral earth tone that doesn't have the pink undertone you see in the kit, and appeared as a straight light brown when I applied it. I have a lot of natural pink tone to my skin, so I don't think this was because of my skin color. I would have preferred the shadows to have the colors they appeared to have in the box, on my skin.The darkest color makes a good liner, but the brush that comes with the kit is too thick and is difficult to use. I'd recommend using a thinner brush.I have super sensitive eyes and they get irritated easily from eye makeup. This did not bother me at all, so allergy-wise for me, it was great!

This is a great thermometer! I believe the word I've used to describe this in my home is magnificent. My wife laughed at that, but I meant it! I certainly wouldn't call myself a cook, but this thermometer gives me a chance to cook food right. It has several features I haven't seen in other thermometers:- It lets you preset the desired temperature you want your food to be cooked to. You simply punch in the temperature and turn on the alarm. When the food reaches that preset temperature, the alarm sounds. The alarm is loud enough to be heard from another room. This is fantastic!!!- It has a digital timer that is easy to set. Once it's set, the time counts down and the alarm sounds when it reaches the cooking time you've set.-  It has a long 3 foot probe. This allows you to  place the probe into the food that you're cooking inside the oven, and actually close the oven door with the thermometer in the food, and the screen/control unit outside on the counter.- The thermometer control unit has hinges that allow you to adjust it into different convenient positions so you can check the temperature as your food cooks.- The thermometer has two magnets underneath it so you can place it on your oven, refrigerator, or other metallic surface. This is really handy.Overall this is a very good product that helps you cook foods to the right temperature and helps you prepare food that's properly cooked and safe to eat. It's light, easy to handle, easy to use, and easy to read. It's incredibly versatile, a good value for the price, and a great thermometer for any kitchen.

I received this spray bottle and immediately tried it on the interior of mu SUV that hadn’t been cleaned for a while. To my surprise, it really cleaned my dashboard and car doors great! I used paper towels, and the amount of dirt that I found on the paper towels was astonishing. It even helped remove ground in dirt on the glove compartment door, which seems to be a foot resting spot for my wife during long drives.The best thing about this product was that there was no smell from it. Usually when you’re cleaning a car interior, the fumes can be bothersome. My wife is very sensitive to chemical smells, yet she didn’t notice that I had cleaned the interior of my vehicle.This product does not clean glass. I over sprayed my dashboard and the product spattered on the windshield. I noticed it at night while driving. It was a film that I couldn't see through well. It did easily wipe off with some glass cleaner.Overall I think this cleaner would be a very good addition to any garage, and I think it would work well around the house as well.

From my wife Sarah: Absolutely delicious. This is one of the tastier snacks I've eaten in a while. It's an incredibly satisfying snack. Filling and flavorful. The flavor is scrumptious with a nice, strong buttery popcorn taste and just the right amount of salt. Flavor-wise, it's what popcorn should taste like in an ideal world.Concerning the hardness - I had read other reviews that talk about how hard these HalfPops are, and I have really severe TMJ, so I expected to have a problem. While they are crunchy and firm, they're not what I expected. They're easy enough to bite through, even with the jaw issues I have. They're not rock-hard like unpopped kernels. They have a kind of firm, crunchy air-puffed grain consistency, but a bit harder.I did find one or two much harder pieces in my batch, so if you have TMJ or are concerned about your teeth, I would suggest eating them carefully. Just eat slowly and stay aware of any kernels that are particularly hard.I love that it's made with wholesome ingredients like sea salt, and it's gluten free and nut free. It has no artificial flavors, preservatives, corn syrup or hydrogenated oils. Take a look at the ingredients and you won't see any chemicals at all (they do have dairy).Halfpops would be a good snack choice for many diets. There are 140 calories in one ounce, and one ounce would be relatively filling compared with many other snack-type foods.There is:- 3 grams of protein- 15 grams of effective carbohydrates (18g carbs - 3g fiber)- 6 grams of fat- under 1 gram of sugar- No trans fatLow carb dieters should keep in mind that popcorn isn't great when it comes to the glycemic index, but the carb count is reasonable and the sugar gram count is excellent.I've only tried the butter flavored Halfpops, so I can't comment on the other flavors but I'd bet they're excellent based on the quality of the butter version.The price on this page must be a typo because this product can be found around Amazon for $22.99 for a 16 pack. You can also buy one bag for $1.59 if you wish to give it a try.So I'd certainly recommend this product as a healthy snack.

From my wife Sarah: As an E-reader it's perfect, but I'm also using it as a book light. As an E-reader, it's compact, light, fits securely and easily, it's easy to manipulate, and gives off the right level of light.As a book light and as an E-reader light I really like it, and here's why:- As an E-reader light, this is nice and light.For book reading, the lights I've had in the past were all much heavier and weighed the book down, but this is really light. That also makes it easier to balance it on the book.- At about 6 inches, it's easy to bend the neck to direct the light. As an E-reader the size of the neck is great.As a book light, the necks on the ones I've had in the past were longer, and while you can direct the light over a larger area when the light is further away, the longer necks made them bulkier, awkward and more challenging to balance, especially as you turn the page. This one is super easy to handle.- I think the level of light is great. There's only one level with a single on/off button. Past book lights I've had were so bright that they woke my husband. On this one the light is bright enough so that you can see your e-reader or book pages, but not so bright that you're shining a big flashlight type beam in the room.- The clip is easy to use. It doesn't take much strength. It's wide enough to mount and be stable, and the plastic doesn't tear at my book's pages or the e-reader.As a book reader, the only thing that was possibly a negative is this: Let's say that I clipped the light onto the right side of the book. Because the E-reader light is small, when the book's pages are wide open, the book light didn't light up the opposite page fully. Of course it wasn't designed for books, but I overcame that by letting the book slightly close just enough so the light would be cast on the left page, while keeping it wide open enough to read.So I'd suggest this light for e-reading as well as book reading, however if you're reading a very large book, the beam may not be wide enough.

My first attempt to upgrade my Apple Watch Sport Edition lime green band was with a Luvvitt stainless steel Milanese loop look-alike band--similar in appearance to this Yaha band.  Unfortunately, I did not Luvvitt, and I rated it just 1 star.  This Yaha, on the other hand, is a grand slam.  I am so proud of it that I took 6 pictures and included them with this review.There is so much to love about this Yaha band.  Where do I start?+ Upscale, Protective Packaging: Unlike the Luvvitt, this Yaha came in a very premium-looking black box with velour-padded interior to protect the band (see picture).  This is what I would expect from a premium watch band.  It is so nice that I plan to use it for storing the band when I am using the lime green sport band.+ THICK & Substantial Stainless Steel Mesh: It doesn't feel cheap in the least. Note that Yaha offers a smaller mesh/loop version of this band, if you don't prefer the larger stainless steel loops that I chose. When I say "loops", I don't mean the band itself, but rather the tiny stainless steel loops that make up the mesh in the band.  The difference is purely one of style preference.  I thought this one would look for beefy/masculine and, indeed, it does.+ Secure Clasp: I have zero fear whatsoever that this clasp will ever come loose and result in my Apple Watch falling of my wrist.  The clasp works like so many watch bands on the market.  Even if the clasp comes open, the band stays on your wrist.  You would have to take quite a hit to both release the clasp and somehow dislodge the second clasp mechanism inside.+ Hidden Inner Band Tail: I complained in my Luvvitt band review that the excess length of the band that was inside of the band against my wrist did not line up properly with the outer portion.  The result was a sloppy look where you could see the excess inner tail of the band.  This Yaha does NOT have this same issue.  The excess band length, after adjusting for my wrist size, is nicely hidden from view, as it lines up perfectly with the band that shows on the outside of the wrist.+ Clasp Adjustment Grooves on Back of Band: You will likely need to adjust the band length just once.  Compared to the Luvvitt band I did not like, this one was MUCH EASIER and aided immensely by the grooves on the back of the band that are intended to hold the straight and in position where you want it.  The Luvvitt did not have these grooves.  If you look closely in the product listing images, you can see these grooves on the back of the band.  To adjust the band length, you will only need a small screwdriver, jack knife, or other pointy tool to release the clasp for sliding it up/down the band to the proper position. Securing the clasp is done simply with your hands--no tools required.+ AMAZING, UPSCALE APPEARANCE: Last, but not least, I was stunned when I first put the watch on my wrist.  I have loved my Apple Watch since I first put it on, but I was still shocked to see what it looked like with this band.  My wife was equally amazed.  So, now I plan to use my lime green sport band for sporting activities and my new Yaha stainless steel band the rest of the time.  For those who own Apple Watches, you know that you can change the bands in seconds with no tools.For this price, I am floored that I got such an amazing new band for my Apple Watch. I guarantee you that I will be getting compliments on it virtually immediately. Get one. You won't be disappointed!

We recently purchased a Yakima Skybox 21 Carbonite cargo carrier, which I believe is the largest cargo carrier known to mankind--21 cubic feet of space on top of our minivan.  I wanted a hoist that would hold the carrier high enough and secure enough in the garage that I could still use the floor space beneath it.  Sure enough, this hoist does the job!Installation of the hoist was fairly easy, though I have some advice to offer.  Do NOT follow the instructions for how far apart to space the pulleys if you plan to lift something odd like me.  Their advice pertains to a kayak or canoe, which are much longer.  After I installed the pulleys, they were too far apart, and I ended up needing to move one of them in order for the hoist to work for me.  With this adjustment, everything is working great.  Start to finish, even with my do over on locating one of the pulleys was no more than about 1 hour of labor for installation.This hoist is built very well, and I have no concerns about whether it will hold.  I walk under it all the time in the garage, and I store things below it, too.  Just don't push your luck and load your cargo carrier with anything before lifting the hoist.  Best to store your cargo carrier empty, to be on the safe side.

I've broken more flag brackets and poles than perhaps anybody I know, but then I've never gone around and asked people how many they've broken.  Anyway, you get the point!Years ago, I went to a smaller flag when my poles were snapping and bending.  That did the trick for the poles, but then the point of failure became the brackets.  I always purchased the adjustable-angle brackets made of cast aluminum.  You would think I would have learned my lesson after breaking 3-4 of them in high winds, but I just kept on buying replacements, for crying out loud!Finally, after purchasing way too many replacement brackets, I decided there MUST be something sturdier.  I finally found this cast iron bracket.  It is HEAVY and SOLID with no moving parts other than the thumbscrew that holds your flag in place.  There is absolutely no way this bracket will ever fail in high winds.  I know that for sure.  The only question remaining is whether my poles will start snapping and bending again!

My wife wrote the first review below, which I thought was a little dry and lacking in critical content, positive or negative.  Hence, I will first provide her review.  Then, I have added my own version.  No, I didn't read the book, but I have heard all I need to know!  Hope you enjoy both reviews and find one or both of them helpful or entertaining.**Wife's Review**Abby, Luke and Hannah were friends when they were growing up.  Eventually, Luke and Abby dated.  After a while though, Luke and Hannah got married.  Luke became a doctor and they moved back to Seaview Key, an island off of the coast of Florida.  Abby moved away and married.  She never forgot her roots though.  After a few years, Abby got divorced and moved back to Seaview Key to start a housing development.When she got back she met Seth but wasn't sure if they'd just be friends.  She rekindled her friendship with Luke, but not without jealousy from Hannah.These three are the main characters and the book is about their lives, the good and the bad, back in Seaview Key.This is a good book and very well written.  I gave it 4 stars because it was a slow moving at times.**My Review**For starters, this "romance" wouldn't be nearly as romantic if we replaced Seaview Key with Dubuque, Flint, Pittsburgh, El Paso, or Tijuana.  So, the author used all the tools in the shed to pull off the tale of promiscuity, intrigue, and infidelity.  The beach chair and crashing waves on the cover are a good lead in to the tale, and one can hardly blame the author, as stick figures of Dick, Jane, and Spot on the cover could not have created the same appeal to dive right in.Second, the notion that Luke was just "friends" with Abby and Hannah is totally a chick thing.  Unless they work together with women, guys aren't looking for girls to pal around with.  Sorry to disappoint, ladies, but Luke probably had other thoughts in keeping both of the ladies on the line, beyond friendship.  Sounds like he had his paws in the cookie jar with both of them, to support my point, and he eventually got hitched with one of them.So, Abby eventually got divorced.  Sounds to me like she was longing for Luke all along.  Maybe she should have focused a little more on saving her  marriage, rather than running back to the fictitious love mecca by the sea to look for long lost Luke.  Yeah, she rekindles her flame for him and Hannah gets jealous.  OF COURSE SHE GETS JEALOUS!  Hannah was married to Luke, for crying out loud.  A cat fight was bound to ensue for the doctor with a gorgeous bod and money galore, living in a love mecca by the sea, of course.I would have loved this story a lot more if it had a very unpredictable ending, such as Abby stopping up the toilet, calling a plumber, and falling in love with all 300 pounds of his blubber when he exposes his plumber's crack while turning off the cold water supply to the toilet.  Next thing you know, she's sneaking off to KFC to share a double order of biscuits and gravy before they slink off to a no tell motel to inspect one another's plumbing, if you know what I mean.  Yeah, that would have been an ending that a guy would like, but then guys don't read romance novels.

Until now, men had to trade in their manliness in order to use a loofa sponge or exfoliating scrubber.  Now Bud, Big Al, Rusty, or any other guy can grab onto this ergonomically designed tool for men and experience the wonders that previously only women could enjoy.  Wet the loofa side (not the tan side, which is for exfoliating), apply a little body wash liquid, and lather up your burly bod without wasting the body wash.  Then, turn over the tool and use the tan side to exfoliate.  For those of you who haven't exfoliated before, it is a fancy word for using a mild abrasive to remove dead skin cells.  Think of it like using a little turtle wax on the car.  In order to get a nicer shine, you have to start with a little rough stuff.  The tool is comfortable to hold with either side up, as the gray rubber grip fits nicely in your hand.  There is a loop, as well, for hanging the tool in your shower to dry each day when you are done.  Chances are pretty good that you'll love this tool as much as your favorite wrench, ratchet, or power tool.  But don't go around bragging about it.  The boys will start to worry about you.

**UPDATE ON SATURDAY 8/29/15**Today I wrote a 5-star review for a Yaha 42mm Stainless Steel Apple Watch Band 42mm Stainless Steel Watchband Yaha® Metal Strap Classic Buckle Adapter Watch Bands for Apple Watch Sport (Thick 42mm) that looks virtually identical to this Luvvitt. If you are thinking about this Luvvitt band, forget about it. Read my review on the Yaha and buy that one instead!******************************************My favorite iPhone case of all time is a clear Luvvitt case for my iPhone 5s. So, when I decided to try a snazzy new band for my Apple Watch, I didn't hesitate to try this highly rated Luvvitt. Unfortunately, my perception of the Luvvitt brand has diminished after this very unfortunate experience.My complaint starts with the listing on Amazon itself.  When I made my purchase, there were numerous difference products all listed together on Amazon, and the reviews were commingled, as a result.  I don't think that Amazon should allow this.  It's one thing to have different colors or sizes of the same product reviewed together, but having to sort through reviews of dissimilar products in order to determine how people feel about the product you are considering is a hassle and makes it near impossible to figure out the true star rating of a particular product, unless you want to add up the reviews and do your own math.  Anyway, enough on this.My next issue was with the packaging of the band.  When it arrived, it was packaged with loose screws and a sharp/pointy screwdriver in the same plastic pouch as the stainless steel band.  To me, this was a poor reflection of quality.  A quality watch band would not be packaged together with tools and hardware, as they could scratch or otherwise damage the band.My biggest issue, and the primary reason for the 1-star review is that the band is designed poorly and, as a result, functions poorly.  The clasp mechanism has too much play (extra space in the width measurement).  As a result, it is difficult to get the clasp mechanism properly fastened with the band exactly in the middle of the clasp.  If you do not get the clasp fastened exactly in the middle, then the excess band tail on the inside of the band (on your wrist side) will not be perfectly aligned with the band on the outside band.  This poor design ends up making an otherwise premium looking band appear sloppy and cheap.  As they say, a picture is worth a 1000 words.  Hence, I have provided a picture of this problem with the watch on my wrist.The quality of after market replacement bands is bound to increase over time.  Until then, I am sticking with the original Apple Watch sport band that came with my watch.  Perhaps someday I will splurge and buy a real Apple Milanese Loop band, but at $149, it's a bit too rich for my blood at the moment.

I have high arches and have long been loyal to Asics, both for running and for casual tennis shoes. I never had any reason to try another brand, until Amazon Vine presented the opportunity for me to try these awesome Mizuno Wave Enigma 5 shoes for free. "BLOWN AWAY" are two words that best summarize my experience so far with these shoes.**POSITIVES**+ Style/Appearance: My Asics aren't much for beauty contests, but these Mizunos are lookers, for sure. I love the metallic blue trim, as well as the yellow midsole. Of course, you'll love the color coordinated laces that you will, unfortunately, never find again when time to replace.+ Comfort Beyond Compare: I cannot tell a lie. These are more comfortable than any other running shoe I have ever worn. They are amazing--ample arch support, incredibly soft cushioning, snug but not tight fit, super soft tongue, somewhat stretchy/elastic laces, supple/luxurious sock liner (could wear barefoot!), and perfect width for normal feet (no too wide or too narrow areas).+ Excellent Breathability: I've worn these for extended periods in warm weather, and the cooling from the breathable mesh material is outstanding. I've never had the urge to get them off because they are too hot, and I am the kind of guy who is always taking off his shoes.**UNSURE/NEGATIVES**It's truly difficult to nitpick on these shoes. In the early going, they seem virtually flawless, but here's my attempt at finding fault.- Yellow Midsole Difficult to Clean: These shoes are so beautiful that you'll find yourself trying to keep them pristine. I have the nasty habit of using one shoe to kick off the other by placing the toe of one shoe on the heel of the other. DOH! I dirtied up the bright yellow midsole, and I was so bummed, especially since I could not get it clean with a wet rag. Perhaps I will try a mild detergent, but the typical wet rag isn't doing it.- Extra Laces Please: I know it isn't industry practice, but when you are paying for top-of-the-line running shoes (I got to try these for free, to be clear), it doesn't seem like too much to ask for an extra pair of the perfectly coordinated laces to be in the box. These laces are to die for, both in color match and in performance with their stretchy/elastic feel.- Somewhat Long Laces: I haven't used the extra ankle-tightening laces hole eyelets at the very top yet, which would help, but these laces do seem quite long. With their stretchiness, I found that I needed to have really big loops when I tied them at the top in order to avoid my laces hitting the ground. Not a huge deal, but I am trying to nitpick virtually perfect shoes!Durability will be tested with possible future updates to this review, as I have less than a month on these. So far, they are holding up wonderfully.Overall, it's tough not to LOVE these shoes, and love them I do. Trying is believing. I never expected I'd be won over, given my past loyalty to Asics.

Competition is a wonderful thing, and imitation is the greatest form of flattery, as they say.  And so it is that you can get an ASUS laptop that is beautifully thin, constructed of aluminum, with an awesome screen, multi-gesture touchpad, premium keyboard, and excellent audio (albeit not as loud as I'd like).  Indeed, until you start using the computer and realize that it has Microsoft Windows under the hood, you'd swear it's an Apple.  Of course, the operating system makes all the difference for those who appreciate ease of use, but I'll stay away from tearing down Microsoft.  This is a review of an ASUS laptop, and I'll focus on the laptop, not the software.From an aesthetics standpoint, this computer is truly a work of art.  Sleek is an understatement.  It feels substantial/solid, but not bulky.  If opens and closes like the doors of a luxury car.  The screen is magnificent and so thin it's silly.  The typing surface is equally beautiful with large areas to rest your wrists while typing.  The integrated left/right click into the touchpad adds to the sleekness, as does the sheen of the all-aluminum body.  Wow, it's a sight to behold.From a performance standpoint, it also delivers beyond my expectations:+ Startup of the machine is lightning fast.  My last Windows laptop was purchased about 5 years ago, and let's not talk about how long it takes that heap to start up.  This laptop goes 0-60 like a sports car.  No more waiting and getting angry behind the wheel.+ The keyboard is simply awesome with its dimmable, lit keys and super luxurious feel.  The 10-key number pad on the right is a nice touch that fits naturally on the super-wide surface provided by the large screen.+ The screen is beautiful, too, with its glare-free design and bright, vivid colors.  Plug it in to get the full brightness, or crank up the brightness and burn down your battery faster.  Don't settle for a dimmer screen to save your battery.  You will miss out on the beauty of this screen.+ The stereo speakers, interestingly on the underside of the laptop, have excellent sound, as one would expect.  However, either because the speakers are under the laptop or for some other technical reason, I cannot get the speakers as loud as I'd like them when playing my favorite music.  Don't get me wrong.  The speakers are not quiet, but they seem like they could go louder.  Frankly, I think they should have put the speakers on top of the keyboard or on the screen, which would have made a difference, I believe.+ Speed and responsiveness when navigating the computer and the internet is marvelously fast.  I am sure this is a testament to the hardware at work, though I cannot say, because I am clueless when it comes to computer specifications.  What I can tell you is that you will be impressed.+ Indicator lights on the front edge of the computer, visible when the lid is closed, tell you whether your keyboard is lit, whether your battery is green/yellow/red, whether your hard drive is operating, whether you are in airplane mode, and whether CAP LOCKS is selected.  Nice touch.+ Two USB ports on each side of the laptop provide ample ports on whichever side you wish.  What a novel idea!+ SD card slot on the right side is easy to access.+ Headphone jack on the right also easy to access.+ HDMI port and spring-loaded, flip-down LAN port on left both easy to access.As biased as I am to Apple computers, it's hard not to love this laptop.  That said, it comes with Windows 8, which is a mess.  Supposedly, Windows 10 is available for download, but I spent a good 10 minutes or more trying to figure out how to download it.  When I finally got there, I think, I got cold feet and decided that maybe I'd wait to read about all the problems before I jump in with both feet.  Anyway, this laptop is emblazoned with a sticker that reads "Plays well with Windows 10".  That is hardly a reassuring statement--so the laptop won't fight with Windows 10.  I guess in the world of Microsoft Windows, that is progress.When all is said and done, this is one beautiful machine that performs as well as it looks.  If Windows is what you want, then you'll be the envy of your household, your office, or wherever you flip open this baby.  Enjoy.

I had been trying to get my wife to try these out for weeks. Every time I tried, she passed on the opportunity. Clearly, she didn't believe they'd work as well for her as the tried and true spray bottle and rag. I know it will give many readers great pleasure to read that after trying them myself, I had to admit, once again, that she was right. When will I learn? Never. I'm like most men--overconfident, stubborn, and determinedly stupid.Most of us have used baby wipes or sanitizing wipes at some point in our lives. Admit it, guys. You change diapers now. We all do. So the concept of a wet wipe for cleaning windows and mirrors makes sense. In fact, when I saw this product, I thought I'd love it. What could be easier? Just dispense, wipe, and toss. Unfortunately, this was an unfulfilled dream.My experience with these wipes was brief and frustrating. First, the solvent in them isn't that strong. The bathroom mirror gets unmentionable material on it that usually comes off pretty easily with window cleaner, but not with these wipes. I found myself scrubbing and scrubbing to remove marks, but the worst part wasn't the elbow grease required. The worst part was the annoying particles the cloth left all over my mirror. After cleaning the mirror, I had to go back and wipe again all over the place to remove fine particles. This is completely unacceptable for a window cleaning product.There's only one logical thing to do with these wipes--give them to my mother-in-law.

I installed this rack on a 2001 Lexus IS300. It was a major pain to install, and it never fit securely in the couple of weeks I had it on the car. Even worse, the wind noise it created was unbearable. I could have tried installing a wind deflector/fairing, but that just seemed like too much work and expense for a rack that seemed jimmy rigged from the beginning. Notably, it is shipped without an instruction sheet, which  you must view on Amazon. Also, the metal hooks that wrap around the edge off the car roof are bare metal, which is not only  unprotective but also a hindrance to holding the rack securely. In the end, I removed the rack an returned it.

This kind of luxury is usually discovered in a fancy hotel or spa, but I discovered it on Amazon. Amazing stuff. Though the product description reads like a liqueur or wine, it is, indeed, deserving of such elaborate description. My nose is not as keen as some others, but this masculine essence is unmistakable. The aroma brings me back to the days of walking past the tobacco shop at the mall--not smoke, but sweet and alluring pipe tobacco. If Axe is a chick magnet for teens and millennials, then this is for the grown-ups among us, whether eligible or just wanting to remind your significant other that you still live in the same house.I've been using this brew for my hair and body for weeks now, and I love it. Just a couple of notes worth mentioning: your bathroom will take on its smell (must get on the shower curtain and walls) and it doesn't lather up quite as much as shampoo or a bar of soap. Still, this bottle is lasting me surprisingly long, perhaps because it is a thin consistency that goes a long way, even without a loofa, which would make it last even longer. But a real man doesn't use a loofa.Indulge yourself.

So, you usually buy Trident or Dentyne, and you are wondering what's so special about this Orbit gum? Yeah, I used to be like you. It's just gum, right? And mint even. What could be so special about mint?Well, let me tell you, this gum far exceeded my expectations on several fronts:+ 2 Unique & Wonderful Flavors: In addition to 3 packs of Peppermint and 3 packs of Spearmint, you will be blown away by 3 packs of Wintermint and 3 packs of Sweet Mint. Both of these flavors are now favorites of mine.+ Soft, Long-Lasting Flavor: Softer out of the wrapper than other gums, it stays softer as you chew it, and the flavor doesn't disappear in just minutes, like other gums.+ Big Pieces: With other mint gums, I'm often tempted to eat two pieces at once, because they are such small pieces. Not here. These are generously sized pieces, and I never once thought of eating two at once.+ Cool Reclosable Packaging: Each pack comes in a neatly designed, wallet-like paperboard package--perfect for your pocket or purse (or "murse" if you are a man). These folks know that you don't put a great product in cheap packaging. Kudos to them.I still love my Altoids, but they have met their match now! Try it, and you will see. All gums are not created equal.

OK, lame headline, but great hammer!  Who ever thought one hammer could be different from the next? I am sure there are some carpenters out there laughing at that statement. I'm just an average Joe who needs to use a hammer once in a while. Still, there is so much to like about this hammer:+ Magnetic Head: You can actually attach a nail by its head to the magnet, set the nail into the wood by forcing the nail point into the wood while the nail head is attached magnetically to the hammer, pull back on the hammer, and drive the nail with a typical hammer swing. Advantage? No holding the nail and smashing you fingers or thumb.+ Rubberized, Ergonomic Grip: Comfortable and secure in your hand. You'll love it.+ Low Vibration: Driving nails feels effortless, with no sensation of vibration whatsoever.+ Attractive: In addition to the cool red handle, the polished steel hammer head is very cool looking. I know it's a hammer, but why not choose one that looks cool?I'm not sure how one could ask for anymore in a hammer. I would recommend this one to anybody.

I have twin 4-year-olds, and I knew that Tinkerbell would be a hit. Of course, she was. But the bigger question is whether these would perform. Indeed, they did. No complaints whatsoever. Sized nicely for a comfortable fit (one girl is about 38 pounds, the other about 42 pounds), these diapers never leaked, and the girls were kept dry, judging by no skin irritation.

If you are thinking these are sinful, you are right. If you are thinking they'd be good on just about anything, you are right. If you are thinking you'd like to just open a jar and eat just a spoonful, think again. Next thing you know, you'll be eating it like a pint of Ben & Jerry's.Natural ingredients blah blah blah. Who cares? It's yummy beyond belief, and if you are eating this stuff, you're not terribly health conscious in the first place!So, when gluttony calls your name, a whole jar is only a thousand and some odd calories, and with a cold glass of milk or a hot cup of black coffee to balance the sweetness, you'll be in heaven. Well, I guess gluttony and heaven don't usually go together, but you can always repent. Repentance is a small price for this level of joy.A favorite? Well, for chocolate lovers like me, the one that's like smashed Oreos in gooey goop is impossible to top. Does the graham cracker really taste like graham crackers? You bet! The third one was a bit of a mystery to me, but still worthy of spooning large quantities down the ol' hatch and chasing with milk or coffee.Recommendations? Eat it cold, but not frozen. It'll be stiffer (less runny) and more like eating Ben & Jerry's. Also, be sure to have milk, coffee, or at least water close by to cleanse your palate between mouthsful.Complaints? Are you kidding me? The jars weren't deep enough! If somebody wanted to get really persnickety, one might describe the mouth feel as a bit gritty--not totally smooth. Still, it is a stretch to say that this is a complaint. Rather, it's an observation.So, do you need these?  No. Do you want these? Yes. Do you deserve these? Of course.

I fell for the positive reviews on this product.  Then, I received it and realized that it was basically a big hunk of plastic.  Ugh.  I hate plastic, especially when my water is sitting in it.  I am not a scientist, but I do know that BPA is just the start.  As reported recently by a chemist on NPR, BPA has gotten a lot of publicity, but there are many more chemicals in plastic that have not gotten as much publicity and may be equally harmful to human health.  In particular, heating up plastic is a concern, because the energy transfer from heat can release these chemicals from plastic more easily than they will leach on their own from contact with cold water.So, unhappy that I hadn't considered this purchase more carefully, I decided to search high and low for a BPA-free claim, at a minimum.  I found NONE on package or in the User Manual!  As a marketing guy who once managed a water filtration business, I know that BPA-free is pretty much "table stakes" to play in plastic.  If you don't have that claim, you are either (1) hiding something, (2) keeping your options open to using BPA, or (3) extremely clueless as to what consumers want.  I don't know about you, but I don't want to do business with a company guilty of 1, 2, or 3.I am returning the kettle unused to Amazon.

I knew the reputation of Bosch, but I had never actually experienced it first hand, until now.  If BMW is the Ultimate Driving Machine, then Bosch is the Ultimate Impact Driver.  It's no coincidence that both of these engineering wonders--BMW and Bosch--both come from Germany.Lithium Ion technology has advanced cordless tools in a huge way.  I am reminded of this every time I struggle painfully with my weed whacker or cordless drill, with their short battery lives and long recharge times.  In case you didn't make the connection, Lithium Ion batteries are the same ones that power those ultra-thin laptop computers, iPads, and iPhones.  If you are expecting a heavy impact driver, think again.  This driver is WAY lighter than my cordless drill, with its massive non-lithium battery.I'll be updating this review later, after I have had more use of the driver.  For now, I report on just a few features that I have already experienced:+ Simple Setup: First, you'll need to determine if you want to charge the driver while connected to the battery or whether you prefer to disconnect the battery from the driver and charge it.  If you choose the latter, as I did, then you can choose to place the charging plate either on a flat surface or hang it on a wall with the included bracket (though you'll have to supply the screws to mount it to your wall).  The bracket is perfectly designed to have the charging plate snap into it from one direction and the battery slide into it securely from the other direction.  There is no concern about the battery or the charging plate falling to the floor.  Bosch nailed the details with the perfectly designed bracket.+ Belt Clip: There is an included belt clip, if you wish to use it.  I did not.  If you do use it, it comes both with the clip and with the screw to connect the clip to drill.+ Smooth-as-Silk Chuck: The chuck is the piece at the top of the driver into which a bit driver or socket driver attachment is inserted.  This one has a rubberized grip and slides as smoothly as one could imagine when operated.  I tried it with the included dual-end Phillips head driver bit, and it worked like a charm, just as I expected.+ 3-Speed Transmission: Simple push button transmission with LED light indicator has 3 speeds--plenty fast, very fast, and BMW fast.  The difference is noticeable, and I cannot wait to get it out for a test drive so I can open it up in the BMW fast speed.  In the meantime, I can just rev it up in the garage to get my blood pumping.+ Precision Braking: Take your foot, I mean finger, off the gas, I mean trigger, and the brake automatically stops the driver on a dime.  Zero to 60 to zero in 1 second flat.  Impressive.+ LED Lighting: Working in a not-so-bright location?  Well, you would work like a woman and spend 20 minutes getting the lighting just right, or you can just push the light button on the impact driver and let Bosch light the way, right where you are pointing the impact driver.  Perfect.+ Rocket Fast Charging: When I unpacked the driver, the battery indicator light on the battery itself was indicating just 1 bar.  So, after hooking up the charger, I placed the battery on the charging plate.  I swear it was fully charged in less than an hour.  Amazing.  I have never seen anything charge that quickly--not even a cell phone.+ Free Ballistic Nylon Bag: The included ballistic nylon carry bag says quality, and you won't be embarrassed to use it.  Though it would be nice if it had a few more pockets (it has just a couple on the outside, non inside), it is hard to complain about such a minor detail.So there you have it.  If you are going through midlife crisis like me and need to feel like a kid behind the wheel of a sports car, splurge and spend a couple hundred bucks on one of these bad boys.

...The more you eat, the more you toot!The more you toot, the better you feel.So let's eat beans for every meal!OK, I interrupt this jingle for a product review.The time between selecting this item on Amazon and actually eating the beans was probably probably a week or more.  My wife was excited to try them, too, and she ate half the can before I got to them.  She reported that she really liked them, and she especially liked that many of the beans were still whole, though everything was cooked properly, whereas so many refried beans seem to come as pure mush out of the can.  After eating half the can, she left the rest in a glass bowl for me in the fridge.Today, I heated them and made a bean burrito with nothing else on it--just beans on a whole wheat tortilla.  It was delicious--mild, but flavorful, and not too salty.Fast forward a couple of hours, and here I am reviewing the beans, only to recall they were FAT FREE!  I certainly never would have guessed it.  Of course, fat makes everything taste better, it seems, but these beans were so good I never would have guessed they were fat free.Toot!  Now if they could just make them fa*t free!

True pizza lovers, we wasted no time getting this oven set up and operating. Who doesn't want pizza that bakes in 5 minutes?Having made a half dozen pizzas in just the first couple of weeks, I already know the two faults of this pizza oven:1. SAFETY HAZARD: The first fault presents a safety hazard, in my opinion. When the oven heats up, the pan holding the pizza, which is intended to be inserted and removed with the included pan holder tool shown mounted on the side of the oven, warps and becomes extremely difficult to remove from a hot oven. My wife and I have both struggled to remove the pan from the hot oven. In a tug of war with a hot oven with a hot pizza on a slippery pan, accidents and burns are bound to happen. This is unacceptable and makes me wonder, as a marketing manager myself, whether this product went through basic testing before launch.2. Poor Facsimile of Quick Fired Pizza: Quick fired pizza is all the rage right now. Typically made in a stone hearth oven fired by burning wood, quick fired pizza is made with very hot top and bottom heat. The top heat cooks the toppings, and the bottom heat bakes the crust to either a chewy or crispy crust, depending on how thick or thin the crust dough is rolled and how long it is left to bake. Though this oven does, in fact, make a pizza in 5 minutes or less, it does so almost exclusively with strong top heat. The end result is bound to be a soft, bread-like crust, even if you closely follow the instructions to preheat the pan in the oven.As a pizza connoisseur, I find this oven big on style and short on substance. I am convinced I can more safely produce a higher quality pizza in my full-size oven. So, why make space for this monstrous oven in your kitchen? I see no reason, unfortunately, and I am disappointed, even though I got the oven for free to test out as an Amazon Vine Reviewer.

If your little boy or girl loves pretending to work on things, this workbench would seem, at first glance, to be a great selection. Our 6-year-old son loves to watch This Old House, and this bench seemed like it would be an instant hit with him. He and my wife assembled the bench as a fun project together, and initial feedback was positive. Then, through the course of typical play by him and his 4-year-old twin sisters, the graphics on both the horizontal and vertical surfaces started to come off. Oh, the decals began to peel, you say? No, the designer of this bench somehow thought that it would be better not to use decals, but rather printed paperboard (think cereal box) material that stays in place behind plastic slotted tabs. Big mistake! Either my kids thought it would be fun to tear off these graphics or they began to warp and become detached on their own. Regardless, replacing them is a pain, and it is only a matter of time before they become too damaged to be replaced in our household. Once an imagination toy becomes a nondescript hunk of plastic, the magic fades, in my opinion. It looks shoddy and nothing like the real life version with missing or damaged graphics, and this means the kids will lose interest. This has already happened in our household, where it seems that none of the 3 kids kids are much interested anymore, and we are only 1 month into the experience. Had this toy been made to last with heavy duty graphics, I would be rating it 5 stars. However, since the manufacturer cut corners on a key design feature--graphics--I suddenly feel this bench is worthy of no more than 3 stars. What a shame.

**GENERAL IMPRESSIONS**Anybody who has searched for protein powders knows there are countless hundreds, if not more, versions out there, each claiming to be different in its own way. This one claims to be "LITE" because it has only 60 calories per serving--about half the calories per serving of other protein powders.  I find this to be a weak claim, as this protein powder also delivers half the amount of protein per serving as the others.  So, in essence, you are putting half as much stuff into your glass and getting twice as many servings, each with half as much nutritional content in them.  It's not magic!**NUTRITION**Getting beyond the weak "LITE" claim of this powder, I move on to other nutritional details on the product:- No Added Sugar: It uses sucralose, known as the brand name Splenda.  This, too, is not unique.  Lots of protein powders use it.- Natural Protein: Plant or dairy based protein are both natural, and natural is not a regulated word like Organic.  I am not impressed here.- Prebiotic Fiber: Supposedly helps digestive health and feeling of being full.  OK, perhaps this is something a little unique, not recalling this from other searches, but I don't buy protein power for these things.  I guess it will depend on whether you place a premium on these.  You are only going to feel so full with such a small serving size.- Vitamins & Minerals: Like other protein powders, there is good overall nutritional content on vitamins and minerals.- Certified Gluten Free & Kosher: If these are important to you, you are covered.- Certified Non-GMO Soy Protein (non-hydrolyzed): Claims to have particular benefits to women.- MADE IN USA: A must for me when it comes to food these days.  Kudos.- Ingredients: Only 2 of them stand out as pretty unique from other powders I have seen, and they are quite low on the list, which means they are a low % of the product weight.  They are Garcinia Cambogia and Green Coffee Berry.  Anything with coffee in it is my friend!  WebMD says the following about Garcinia Cambogia: "Garcinia cambogia, a tropical fruit also known as the Malabar tamarind, is a popular weight-loss supplement. People say it blocks your body's ability to make fat and it puts the brakes on your appetite."  Sounds like great marketing material!  At least it's natural!**TASTE**So, it is hard to miss the cookies on the front of the label, and cookies are a high bar for taste!  Does it clear the bar?  Meh.  It's not bad, but it's not Oreos either.  When I tried to mix it with only water or soy milk, it was tough to drink.  When I added bananas, greek yogurt, oatmeal, soy milk, and ice to make a tasty smoothie, it was quite good.  Taste is a personal thing, I know, but my wife wasn't a huge fan of this powder, either, so we are a sample size of 2, and we both give it a resounding MEH!  As a general comment on taste, my wife and I have decided that we will buy only vanilla or unflavored powders from now on.  They are more versatile, and you can add your own flavoring, such as very low-cal baker's cocoa, if you like chocolate.**VALUE**Personally, I think it's always important to compare protein powders on a cost/serving basis, and I consider a serving to be equal delivery of protein, not whatever they call a serving on the label.  After all, it's a protein powder, and you are probably in it for the protein, right?  So, I have found that virtually all protein powders fall in the $.50-$1.00 per serving range for roughly 20 grams of protein.  On that basis, this powder is on the upper end of the range.  Today's price of $7.99 means that you'd spend over $1.00 for 20 grams of protein--nothing to write home about.  You can do much better by shopping around.**SUMMARY**For most people, I am guessing you can do better than this protein powder on all fronts--taste, protein content, and value.  Unless this one really lights your fire for some reason, it's just another protein powder on the "tried that once" list.

I'm new to weight training, as my wife got me into kettlebells just a few months ago to complement my cycling and aerobic exercises.  Now, we are looking at converting one room of our home to a home gym, and we want to expand our equipment and weight training.  I thought this book might be a good reference.Within minutes of opening this book, I knew it would be PERFECT!  It covers everything from why you would want to weight train, to basic principles and terminology, to personal strength testing before you get started, to safety and injury prevention, to setting up a home gym, to working out in a club, to how to work specific muscle groups (with images), to setting up workout programs, including 20-minute workouts for people who don't have a lot of time.Like all DUMMIES books, this book is very nicely organized.  You don't need to read the book cover to cover.  You just skip to what you need to read, and things are straight to the point--easy, short segments that get you the nuts and bolts you need to know.  I see myself using this book again and again as a reference once I get started.Even though it's a DUMMIES book, don't mistake that to mean that this just covers the basics.  The depth of knowledge in this book is impressive.  There is so much I will learn, but I can take it as a pace that suits me, given the very nice organization of the book.  It is clear what I need to read now and what I can save for later.Honestly, this book has far exceeded my expectations already.  I cannot wait to dive into it further.  I would highly recommend it to anybody getting started or considering the idea of getting started with weight training.  I believe Amazon allows you to peek into the book to see the table of contents and perhaps a few pages.  Check it out.  You will be impressed.

I've tried lots of styli (just look at all my reviews, and you will see reviews I've written for several of them), and none of them has really been great, for one reason or another.  Maybe I'll never be happy writing on my iPad.  How can it possibly be like paper, right?  That's the feel I am seeking.  It's just too awkward.  I'd rather write on paper and then scan it into an app like Evernote, which has native document scanning built in, or Evernote's new standalone app called Scannable, which is an unbundled version if you are not an Evernote user (or even if you are an Evernote user).So, getting to discussion on this little Adonis Mini.  A couple of things caught my attention when it was offered to me to try out.  First, the tiny size seemed like it would be handy and manageable taking it with me, since my iPad is on the go with me all the time.  Second, the built-in clip seemed like promised to somehow attach to my iPad or iPad case in an elegant and effective way.POSITIVES: The tiny size of this stylus makes it really unique from anything else I have tried.  Even though it's small, it doesn't feel small when you are using it.  It is mostly small in length, not girth, and it is really lightweight.  I especially love the screw-on cap, which screws onto the back of the stylus when the stylus is in use.  Kudos to the designer who recognized that caps fall off in pockets and sometimes even fall off the back of pens/styli when not in use.  With the screw-on feature, this cap is not going anywhere.  Another cool aspect of the screw-on cap is that it nicely protects the flat plastic disk that is affixed to the tip of the stylus.  Try transporting a stylus with one of these disks and no cap on your stylus and see how long the disk lasts!  Good thinking, Adonit!NEGATIVES: OK, so the clip is useless.  In fact, calling it a clip is a complete misnomer.  To me, a clip has some sort of tension to allow it to hold onto something.  This built-in "clip" is nothing more than a tapered slot that is part of the stylus design.  If you are carrying the stylus in your shirt pocket (who does that--nerds?!?), it might be moderately functional, but if you plan to clip the stylus onto any other part of your shirt, FORGET ABOUT IT!  This clip will never work for you.  Also, the thought of this clip somehow holding directly onto my iPad or iPad case was an imagined use on my part.  This is no way this will be happening.MYSTIFYING: The little plastic disk that is affixed to the tip of the stylus perplexes me.  The idea of writing with such an attachment to your stylus tip is akin to walking with a sack of flour tied to one leg.  Sure, you can do it, but why?  Of course, there is some technological reason why this works and why you would want to do it, but that is beyond me, and it seems so unnatural.  Further, I have read that these disks wear out and need to be replaced.  I have also read that if your screen is not completely clean and you write with a stylus that employs this type of disk, you can actually scratch your screen.  In the end, it's just weird, in my opinion, and it leaves me thinking THERE HAS TO BE A BETTER WAY!PERFORMANCE: Yes, it works, for writing, for tapping/selecting, for swiping, or for anything else where you would normally employ your finger.  However, I am still of the opinion that unless it replicates a true writing experience like a pen to paper, I'd rather just use my finger.  I am giving this stylus 3 stars because it's not bad, but it's not good.  It's just OK.

We have 3 kids ages 4, 4, and 6 who are homeschooled, and I thought this map would be a great learning tool for them.When it arrived, the kids were excited to work with me on the project of unfurling the laminated map and hanging it on the wall near their play area. The metal grommets on each corner were much appreciated on my part, as I have been frustrated in the past by trying to hang things on the wall in a secure manner. For this map, I used 4 cheap plastic Command Hooks (search Amazon for part number B000OEGCL8) from 3M--1 for each corner grommet hole, with the top 2 hooks oriented right side up and the bottom 2 hooks oriented upside down, in order to keep the hung map from curling due to the memory of the rolled up paper. Be sure to use the part number above if you want to use Command Hooks, as not all Command Hooks fit through the holes. We were pleased with the completed project, which is now beautifully displayed in all of its colors in our play area.Next, we decided to place the included stickers on the map, such as where we and family members live. This was fun and engaging for the kids, as it facilitated much discussion. We did find, however, that most of the stickers weren't that relevant to us, and the kids mostly wanted to put all the stickers all over the map, which isn't exactly the point, and I was concerned that the stickers would not remove easily once applied. Therefore, I ended this part of the activity and have since misplaced the stickers somewhere. Not a big deal, though, since we already used the ones relevant to us.Overall, I am quite pleased with this product. I am taking it down 1 star to 4 stars because it could have easily come with the 4 plastic Command Hooks. Not everybody has these lying around, and using a nail or screw is certainly not preferred when kids are involved. Also, since hanging the map, the kids haven't spent even a moment looking at it in a couple of weeks. I thought it would have more ongoing interest for them, but so far not. We will use it as a teaching tool, in time, but for now it is mostly just a colorful addition to the wall.

To some, it's just deodorant. To others, it's as important as the choice of shirt, pants, and accessories. Think of it more like cologne. It sets the tone, from the moment you put it on.Was I impressed? How could I not be? It's a sophisticated essence with a depth of character almost as deep as the men who will choose it. Like a fine Bordeaux, it won't be consumed indiscriminately. It's for those occasions when a man needs to make a statement.Like aromatherapy, applying this amazing essence to your body will change your state of mind immediately, and it will keep on giving all day and all night. I can attest to its generous stamina, surpassed only by the stamina of the men wearing it.If all of this sounds over the top to you, then you are of the common class and should opt for Original Speed Stick. For the rest of us, life just got even better. We live charmed lives, and we deserve this kind of reward.

I'm a big OXO fan. Whenever I need something basic, I usually marvel over the OXO version and sometimes even splurge and buy it. That's why I jumped at the chance to replace one of my nasty, rigid metal sink-bottom protectors with an OXO version. The concept had me sold--soft, cushiony, washable, heat resistant, rust proof. What could possibly go wrong, I thought. Oh, let me count the ways!- HOLE CUT OPTIONS: Universal fit was NOT achieved for me. Yes, my drain hole is off center, but I needed options for front/back, not just left/right. No, I could not rotate the mat, as my sink is wider left/right than front/back.- UNSUPPORTED STUBS: Fully intact and uncut, the promise of sink protection seems credible. However, if you fall for the enticement of cutting out your sink hole access, you'll be left with a massive hole (much bigger than you really need) and little stub extensions up to the edge of the massive hole that are no longer supported by the rest of the webbing in the mat. These stubs would easily be moved around by sharp objects and other rubble in your sink.- IRREVERSIBLE DECISION: Once you cut the mat, you are toast. There is no going back. You will wish you'd never considered something so dumb, but you'll be stuck with the decision for the rest of your life. If you are fortunate enough to have gotten the mat to try for free, you can just throw it away and try to forget about it, but the memory of it wil haunt you again and again. Don't do it. If you insist on buying this mat, take my advice and NEVER cut out a hole.I am back to using my nasty sink-bottom protectors. Someday, I am certain, OXO will release a 2.0 version of this mat and all will be forgiven. Until then, I am not speaking to my OXO kitchen utensils anymore.

I'm not the handiest of homeowners, but I can handle most basic installations with a decent set of instructions and the right tools. This project took me about 1 hour, including fetching all the tools and cleaning up afterwards. For the end result, I am very pleased with that investment of time.MY SHOWER INSTALL SPECIFICATIONS+ Fiberglass Shower/Tub Insert+ 59" Wall-to-Wall Insert Space (56" Insert Interior Dimension)+ Wall Mounted (not into fiberglass) with Included Drywall Anchors+ Bar Height 65" Above Top Ledge of Tub (as per instructions)+ Wall Mounts 5" Inset from Top Ledge of Tub (as per instructions, varies by wall-to-wall dimensions)TOOLS NEEDED+ Drill & Bits+ Hammer (to tap in drywall anchors)+ Pencil+ Level+ Tape Measure+ Screwdriver (I recommend Phillips head)+ Allen Wrenches (included)POSITIVES+ Quick 1-Hour Project Including Tool Fetch & Cleanup+ Beautiful Finished Result--Big Upgrade from Cheap Tension Bar+ High-Quality, No-Rust Parts+ Good Instructions+ Great Value for PriceNEGATIVES- 2-Piece Bar Clearly Visible with Join in Middle (unavoidable for variable-install design)- 5" Inset from Tub Ledge Seems to Partially Counter Purpose of Curved Rod- Required Inset Distance Makes Stud Install Unlikely (drywall anchors included)I would definitely recommend this rod to anybody with a cheap, straight tension rod. You'll be amazed by the great looks and added functionality of more space when showering.

Seeing this professional-looking hoop reminded me of the cheap hoops I used to have hanging on doors 30 years ago. Like everything else, I expected things have come a long ways since back then, and I was right.There is much to like about this setup:+ Quick assembly in 10-15 minutes max. Just 4 bolts and nuts, 1 net, and 1 ball to inflate.+ Ample padding on all contact points to protect doors.+ Spring-loaded rim to prevent damage with expected rough play (with limits, see below).+ High quality details, including relatively thick plexiglass, sturdy metal rim, high quality net, durable protective padding, and surprisingly nice ball.On the downside, I found few faults:- Backboard flexes when rim is pulled down with spring mechanism. This tells me that eventually the backboard will crack and break. You can tell kids to play nice and not hang on the rim, but it's gonna happen!- No ball inflation needle is included, even though it would cost the manufacturer next to nothing to include one. This led me on a hunt around the garage that took me longer than assembling the unit itself.- Door fit is not perfect. I tried putting it on 2 doors and closing them to secure the rim better. Both doors had a fair amount of resistance before they clicked shut. Seems like they could have designed this to fit a bit tighter/slimmer over the top of the door. It is intentionally oversized up there to accommodate various door thicknesses, and this results is excess, rather that compactness.Overall, this is a fine product that should perform well.

I tested this item on an iPhone 5S and an iPad Air first generation and collected the following performance data:- Time to Fully Charge PowerPack from Dead: >8 Hours (fails ready overnight test)- iPhone Minutes Charging Required for 1% Battery Gain at 1 Amp Setting: 2 Minutes- iPhone Minutes Charging Required for 1% Battery Gain at 2.4 Amp Setting: 1 Minute- iPad Minutes Charging Required for 1% Battery Gain at 2.4 Amp Setting: 3 Minutes- Approximate PowerPack Life from Fully Charged to Dead at 2.4 Amp Setting: 265 Minutes- Approximate # iPhone Charges from Dead to 100% on PowerPack Life: 2.65 Charges- Approximate # iPad Charges from Dead to 100% on PowerPack Life: 0.88 ChargesBased on the above data, I see little practical sense in using this PowerPack, for most people.  It takes twice as long to charge the PowerPack as it does to run it to empty when charging devices at 2.4 amps. Who has more than 8 hours to wait for a PowerPack to fully charge?!? This was totally unacceptable to me, as I could not even count on it being recharged with an overnight charge, since I only sleep 5-6 hours.Also, I read another review on this product and saw that a purchaser tried to charge an iPhone and an iPad at the same time to see how it passed the stress test. For that purchaser, the PowerPack would not even work, though the manufacturer replied that the PowerPack must have been defective. I doubt that claim, as my PowerPack failed this same test. It simply would not function at all with devices plugged into both outputs.Incidentally, an Apple Store employee actually told me that charging an iPhone at 2.4 amps is completely OK.  Therefore, give the choice of charging at either 1 amp or 2.4 amps, there is really no reason to choose 1 amp.The only thing positive I have to say about this PowerPack is that it's really attractive, but style does not win over substance with a charger.

Over several generations of iPhones, I've tried more cases than I'd like to admit.  There's usually something about them that bugs me.  This is the first case that I truly love (yes, I Luvvitt!).So, what's to love about this case:+ Shows off your beautiful iPhone, doesn't hide it like other cases.+ Grippy enough to help you hold it more securely than a bare phone.+ Plenty of clearance around camera lens and flash to prevent interference.+ Clear access to silent switch, headphone port, and charging port.+ Ample cutouts to prevent interference with speakers.+ Snug/slim fit while still protecting phone with some shock absorption.+ Unique, soft feel without being stretchy or a magnetic for pocket lint or other dirt.+ BONUS trick I discovered by accident.  Turn on your LED flashlight, and lay the phone down on a hard surface in the dark.  The entire phone illuminates.  Pretty cool!One of my daughters dropped my iPhone on a tile floor from a height of probably 3.5 feet with this case on the phone, and there is absolutely no sign of where the case hit the floor--no scratched/dinged case at all.  Also, the sound that it made was reassuring.  It was a soft feel, not like something hard hitting the floor.I'm a believer.  The next time I buy another iPhone, I'll be online looking for my new Luvvitt!

You can pay 2x or more for tape of this quality at a bike shop.  It has genuine 3M adhesive on the back, and it comes with everything you need, including the plugs and pre-cut strips of black tape for your bars.  What is not to like?  Nothing.
I have a very expensive road bike that I bought used.  It had an Ultegra chain ring on the front with one bent tooth.  I bought this replacement ring, and it worked perfectly.  Good as new!

Somehow, I expected this pot to be larger, but it is just the right size for the amount of fluid that you will run through each nostril. It comes with a simple formula for mixing up water with salt.  Don't try to do that in the pot itself.  Mix up the water and salt separately, then pour it into the pot.Given its compact size, I could see myself taking this on a trip, if necessary. I didn't expect that would be the case.

The headline says it all.  I am 42 years old, and I have owned countless pairs of dress shoes, casual shoes, tennis shoes, boots, and sandals.  These shoes have it all:+ Style: Love the jagged, light-colored soles, blue interior, and awesome dark brown color with burly wingtip look.  These aren't your grandpa's wingtips.  Nicely, there is no visible Skechers logo on the outside of this shoe.  I have never owned Skechers, as I hate how they have their logo embossed in the leather, most often.+ Comfort: Most comfortable dress or casual shoes I have ever worn.  Seriously.  I have high arches, and often shoes don't feel good on me, because they are too flat.  I haven't had any such concerns with this shoes.  They feel awesome.+ Fit: I wear size 11, but some shoes 10.5 and others 11.5.  This one fits perfectly in size 11.+ Versatility: I have worn these with wool dress slacks and with jeans, and they look great with both.  You cannot say that about a lot of nicer looking shoes.

I have an iPhone 5S (at least for a few more weeks until I get my hot hands on one of those iPhone 6 models!).  I love this mount on my Trek road bike.  It holds my phone securely, and I can operate it reliably through the clear material on the front.  There is no way this mount would ever pop off by accident, as I have feared with other mounts.It installed simply in just minutes, with no tools other than a scissors to cut off excess zip tie material.

My first two rides on this seat added up to 100 miles--a 30 and a 70-miler.  I am impressed.  I ride a Trek road bike and have tried many more expensive saddles.  I was intrigued by the positive reviews on this very inexpensive seat.  After trying it, I agree it is a high performer.  I plan to keep using it.The white seat does get dirty pretty easily, but it cleans up nicely with a clean rag and a bit of citrus bike degreaser.

There are 2 things that I love about this bottle:1. Valve Design: Who would have thought that it was possible to improve on the basic lift and squirt valve design used by every bike bottle on planet Earth? Well, believe it! This valve is awesome.  Don't forget that you can lock it closed with a simple twist of the valve on the top of the bottle.2. Keeps Drinks Cold: This is the first insulated bottle that I have ever used.  My expectations were not very high, but they were vastly exceeded on my first 5-hour ride on a warm day.  I filled two of these bottles with ice and drinks before the ride, and they were still cold HOURS LATER! Ordinary bottles would have had warm drinks inside within an hour, based on my experience.  Very impressive.I would highly recommend these bottles to anybody.  They'd be worth it at twice the price.

This part worked perfectly to fix a bathroom faucet that was leaking from the hot water handle whenever we used the faucet.  I am not a "handyman" by any stretch, but it doesn't stop me from trying.  I had no problems whatsoever.The best advice I could give is to take a picture of the orientation of this part before you take out the damaged one.  That will make it much easier to remember how to put the new one into place.I was able to fix the faucet and have everything working perfectly in far less than 30 minutes.  No complaints.

A techie colleague at work mentioned that he bought this device in order to finally part with a half dozen remotes and control his system with his iPhone.  It all sounds too good to be true, and, well, you know how the saying goes.First, the system took a good hour or so to get unpacked and set up.  I expected it would take less.  Still, I would have been fine with it if it worked.Second, because my TV, sound bar, Roku, TiVo, and Blu-Ray player are all flat against the wall, I struggled with what to do with this doodad.  It needed to be located somewhere atop or behind the TV where it could somehow control everything.  I finally ended up mounting it a bit above the TV on the wall, where it was visible.  It's not the ugliest thing, but it did look a little odd.  Still, if it had worked dependably, I could have lived with it.Third, even though it worked when I first got it set up, it didn't work consistently.  Sometimes, it would work "partly", which means that it would turn on the TV, but not the sound bar, or it would turn off the sound bar, but not the TV.  This was always frustrating, and I cannot figure out why it wasn't working.Fourth, when my wife was home during the day when the room was bright, she said it performed horribly--so badly that she went back to our 5 remotes.  I did verify that it seemed to work better in a dim or dark room.Fifth, it was slow as molasses at times.  If I selected a function, such as opening the YouTube app on Roku, it would take FAR LONGER to open than if I had chosen that app with the Roku remote.  This was a mystery to me.Sixth, the look of the buttons on my iPhone was disappointing, and there was not an audible sound click when I pushed something, which always led me to wonder if I had actually pressed the button.  Anybody who has owned a TiVo knows that blip blip blip sound that is so reassuring when using the remote.  Using my phone was so lifeless and lacking.Seventh, and last, the unit failed just a couple of weeks into usage.  Even after reboots, resets, unplugging and replugging, it would not do anything other than turn things on and off.  No other buttons worked at all.  This is when I threw in the towel.  It is going back to Amazon for a full refund.  What a disappointment.Never again, Logitech.  Years ago, my dad tried again and again with one of your universal remotes, to no avail.  Now, I have endured the pain myself.  I'll just stick with my daily aggravation of 5 remotes before I try again.

My 5-year-old son is a Disney Cars and Planes nut who has seen all the movies multiple times.  We are also owners of the LeapFrog LeapReader device that you need to enjoy this book (device not included, just the book).  So, when I was given the opportunity to try this book out for free from Amazon Vine, it was a no brainer.My son was quick to test out the book when it arrived at the house.  I was not home, but my wife said that he was very engaged and happy with the book.  I asked him myself if there was anything he did not like, and he said, "Nope".  I asked him how many stars I should rate the book.  He knows that 5 stars is the highest, but he told me, "58 stars!".  I'd say that was a positive review.Just last weekend, my son asked me to take him to see Planes Fire & Rescue at the local theater.  My wife had taken him to see the movie a few weeks earlier, but now it was my turn.  I enjoyed the movie more than I thought I would (actually, I loved it), and now it gave me an excuse to try out the LeapFrog book myself.I was not sure what to expect with the book, as I had never actually used this system myself.  Would it be the real movie voices, or just some boring narrator?  Would there be sound effects and cool, unexpected features?  The answer to these questions is simple.  I WAS BLOWN AWAY by the experience--ALL the real movie voices, sound effects, story line, and even some music (yes, AC/DC music is in the movie and the book).  How does this thing work?  I have absolutely no idea.  You might as well ask me the meaning of life.  I am dumbfounded, but I am awestruck at the same time.  Point the LeapReader device at any character or scene on any page of the book, and the character will speak, or make sounds, or do something that will remind you of the movie.  I could have spent hours with this book, seriously, but I pulled myself away.  I am a grown man, after all!If somebody had told me as a kid that someday there would be something this cool, I would never have believed it.  I still cannot believe it.  This product is a resounding 5 stars!

I'm not a car nut.  I'm just a regular guy with a 13-year-old Lexus IS 300 who thought it would be pretty cool to have shiny black tires.  So, when I was offered a chance of trying out this concoction for free from Amazon Vine, I took the bait.**Outside the Box**I quickly inspected the box to see what was inside and how much work this was going to be.  There were 3 things inside, and each was pictured on the box: tire cleaner in a spray bottle, Endura-Shine Tire Coat in a bottle, and an applicator sponge.  I guess there was also a pair of cheap plastic gloves inside.  Use your own rubber gloves, as I did, if you have them.  The gloves that came with the kit reminded me of the 3-cent gloves they use when making sandwiches at Subway.  The directions were simple--just 3 steps: (1) clean the tires with the tire cleaner, (2) apply the first coat with the applicator sponge, and (3) wait 10 minutes and apply a second coat.  Heck.  I thought I could handle this in less than an hour with no problem.**Cleaning the Tires**The spray bottle with cleaner has its own instructions.  Pretty simple--wet the tires with water, then spray on the cleaner, wait a few seconds, then rinse off the cleaner.  I was too lazy to drag out the hose.  I actually wetted the tires with a wet paper towel and rinsed the tires with another wet paper towel.  Worked fine, judging by my results (detailed below).**Applying the Tire Coat**The applicator sponge is pretty nifty.  I like the "treads" on it that are like tire treads.  They work perfectly to hold the coating solution, which is, as the packaging describes, very runny.  Soon, the sponge was saturated with the solution, which made applying it to my tires a snap.  I was impatient and worked on a couple of tires at a time, since you have to wait 10 minutes between coats.  I was pretty careful, but not careful enough, in applying the tire coat.  You'll learn more about this below.**Second Coating**Just like the first coating, the second one went on like a charm.  It couldn't have been much simpler.  I was around the car in just minutes, once the 10-minute wait time between coats had elapsed. By the way, my tires still looked wet when I put on the second coating, but I'm not sure if they were still wet or just looked wet.  It doesn't matter, though.  I was too impatient to wait for a dry tire before applying the second coat.**Cleanup**I noticed that I had dripped some of the black tire coating on the garage floor.  I went back and poured a little water from a bottle on each spot and wiped it up.  Unbeknownst to me, this was one of the smartest things I did.  Again, more on this below.**Results**The next day, I took my car through the car wash.  If this tire coating survived a wash and dry and looked awesome, then I would be a believer.  I went through the wash and dry, got out of my car, and gazed proudly at my very shiny black sidewalls.  Pretty cool, except I was also a bit shocked by something I hadn't expected.  See WARNING below.**WARNING: HEED THE NOTE IN FINE PRINT!**So, the one ding I will give this product has to do with the incredible sticking power of the tire coat to surfaces you do not want colored black.  When I got out of the car wash, I was disappointed to see that the drips and runs that I made on my alloy wheels by accident while coating my tires had not come off in the car wash, as I expected.  Oh well, I figured.  I would have to clean it off myself at home.  Another few days elapsed (now several days after the coating) before I had a chance to hand clean the wheels.  I started with a paper towel and some Windex.  In seconds, I knew that this was going to require something MUCH MORE AGGRESSIVE.  In the end, it took about 30 minutes or work with a steel wool pad going around my car to get the drips and runs off my 4 alloy wheels.  Ugh!  I was sure that I did not read any such warning on the box, but I had saved the box.  I went back and read the box.  Nowhere in the "Directions" was this warning provided.  Not even in the "PRO TIPS" was this warning provided.  However, in fine print at the bottom of the box, there was a "NOTE" that read, in part, "Wipe excess product from wheels immediately with a damp cloth."  I sure wish that this had been more prominent on the box.  I would have avoided a lot of aggravation and wasted time.

One of our twin girls is a lefty. She is almost 4 years old. She loves her new scissors. These perform on par with a similar pair of scissors she has tried from Fiskars. I cannot say they are better or worse in any respect, but they are solid performers.

I've used styli before on my iPad Air, and I haven't been a believer yet, based on the performance of the styli. The eternal optimist, I keep believing that somebody will eventually get it right. So, when I saw this latest, top-of-the-line stylus from Adonit, I had to give it a shot.First, I am not a real artist or design professional, but I do want a stylus that performs like a pen. I believe it should be responsive to pressure, just like a pen. So, if I want to get a darker line, I should be able to just press harder. This was a key selling point for me on this stylus, and it was the key feature that I could not wait to test out.Overall, I have to admit that I am really impressed with this stylus, after using it. It does truly deliver on the pressure sensitivity it claims, and it feels natural. Unlike other styli I have used that oddly did not make the line appear directly below where the tip touches the screen, this one gets it right. The line is directly below the stylus tip, as you would expect. This makes writing feel just like writing on paper.As for other positives, I have several:+ Comfortable Grip: Rubberized grip section feels luxurious.
