I love it.+ High Tech USB Charger: Very cool magnetic USB charger included. Just plug in the USB charger, turn your stylus upside down, and sit your stylus on the magnetic USB charger. It quickly lights up to indicate it is charging. It will not tip over. The magnet is very strong.+ High Style: This is the coolest looking stylus I have ever seen. It will get attention. I am sure of it.+ Simple Setup: Took just seconds in Adobe Sketch to get it working perfectly.So, you wonder, why am I only giving it 4 stars. There are several negatives that I still see here, which make it impossible for me to give it 5 stars:- ONLY WORKS FULLY WITH 2 APPS: Yes, you read that correctly. I could hardly believe it myself. The pressure sensitivity does not work in my favorite tablet app for writing--Penultimate. Sure, you can use it without pressure sensitivity, but that's like driving a Porsche under 25 mph. I was so disappointed by this, though I know this is just temporary until more apps are developed to work with this advanced functionality. Right now, it works with Adobe Sketch and Adobe Line.- No Clip or Other Retention Feature: How in the world will I transport this stylus? It has no clip to hold my notebook or shirt. It has no magnet to hold it to my tablet computer. I hate to out it in my pocket. It is too nice, and I fear it will get scratched or broken in my pocket. This is a basic need that is left completely up to the buyer, and I don't like it. To make matters worse, it is completely round and prone to rolling around or off from a desktop.- Mysterious Shortcut Buttons: The manual describes how the buttons near the grip can be used for shortcuts. That is a mystery to me, as I found nothing about that when using Adobe Sketch.Congratulations to Adonit for making the best stylus I have ever used. Unfortunately, I still think it will get limited usage by me, due primarily to limited app compatibility (first drawback above). It won't be long before Adonit hits a grand slam. This one was an exciting triple to try out.

FULL DISCLOSURE: My wife is the reader in the family. She read this book, and the review is from her.Charlotte Caine decides to move back to her hometown of Hope's Crossing and run her candy store and live a simple life.  She has numerous friends and her father and brothers also live in town so it seems like the perfect idea.One day she runs into her old crush, Spence.  He had moved out of town and was playing professional baseball.  She thinks they have nothing in common and that he wouldn't even recognize her.  Little does she know that their lives would be connected in the most unusual way by the things she least expects.She is surprised by Spence's past but their is a twist to it towards the end of the book.  While it is a good read, I gave it 4 stars because the story was a little slow at times.

We have 3 little rug rats at our house--twin 3-year-old girls and a 5-year-old boy.  They all love cool doodads, and this mat fit the bill quite well.  They all enjoyed using the magical markers that go on with invisible lines that instantly turn the color of the marker.  Very neat technology and worthy of some oohs and ahhs for our kids.  It's a sizable mat that allows all 3 of them to work at the same time.I would rate it 5 stars, but there were a couple of things that we would have liked to see improved:- Water Brush Eraser: This set comes with only 1 eraser, which would be fine for most households, I suppose, but in our household, one of anything equals a fight or two.  It would have been nice to have at least a couple of these erasers in the set.  Aside from having only 1 in the set, the eraser only works so-so in our judgment.  The cloth that comes with the set seems to erase better than the water brush eraser.  Ideally, we found that using the water brush eraser followed by the cloth is the best eraser combination, but that is a lot of work for little ones.- Cardboard Stencils: The stencils are neat, but there is no way they'll last more than a few weeks at our house, given that they are made out of cardboard that can be torn easily.  I wish they would have made these stencils out of plastic, which would be more rigid, waterproof, and tear-proof.  Oh well.  We'll enjoy the stencils while they last.Neither of the above concerns are significant in the overall scheme of things.  Our kids will enjoy playing with this set for some time, I believe, and we would definitely recommend it to others.

I typically buy Ziploc storage and freezer bags at my local club store, but they don't offer this type with the slider and gusseted bag bottom that allows the bag to stand up for filling. I must admit, I am more impressed than I thought I'd be with such subtle differences compared to what I usually use. The slider works like a charm--no double checking to make sure you have the zipper completely closed with your fingers. Just zip it and forget it. Silly as it might sound, my 3-year-olds prefer these, as well, since they don't need Mom or Dad to do the zipping for them. That's right, these sliders are so simple that my twin 3-year-olds can do them all by themselves. As for the gusseted bottom, that was an unexpected surprise. Yes, the idea of filling up a bag while it sits flat on a counter is novel. You are still going to want to hold onto the bag to make sure it doesn't get away from you, but this is a nifty added feature that takes away some of the challenge in filling a bag. I am quite certain that these bags are more expensive than the more basic ones that I usually buy, but if you don't use a lot of them, it might be worth the few extra cents per bag. We burn through bags like napkins in our household. We'll stick with the standard ones from the club store, until they begin offering this slider version. Then, I may pay a bit more and stock up on them.

I paid over $700 for my iPad Air. I've tried a few different cases in it, and my favorite, by far, is the Aerb X case Aerb X Armor Series Shock Proof Case with Audio Amplifier Design for New iPad Air, Grey (X-I5). What do I think of this Kensington case? Well, let's just say it has a unique distinction. It is the only case I have ever refused to put on one of my electronic devices.  The entire inside back of the case is hard, textured plastic. That's right, you spend hundreds of dollars on an iPad, then you put a hard piece of textured plastic on the back of it to protect it.  Not gonna happen in my lifetime. I am baffled by the overall strong ratings of this case.

In the interest of full disclosure, my wife is the bookworm in the family. This is her review of the book under my pen name.Brett Bohlinger, 34, works in marketing at Bohlinger Cosmetics where her mother is CEO.  Her mother develops breast cancer and passes away.  As the majority shareholder, Brett is sure that her life is set and she will become CEO of the company and also inherit millions since the cosmetics company was very successful.At the reading of the will, Brett's two brothers are told what they will be receiving.  Brett gets nothing.  That is right.  Not a penny.  Instead she must complete a life list that she wrote when she was 14 in order to get her inheritance.  She had completed some items and then threw it in the trash.  Her mother found it and dug it out and the will requires that she complete the items that are left within one year.  Brett is stunned.  How could her mother do this to her?  They were so close and were the best of friends.Since Brett is single, she feels like she doesn't have much support in trying to complete many of the items on the list.  She does find some close friends going through the process of completing the items.  She also learns that life is not about money and more about the challenges we face and how experiences can make us better people.  Brett meets people that are in far worse situations than she is and actually realizes how good she has it.This is an excellent book.  There is some suspense wondering what her experience will be in trying to complete each item.  I truly enjoyed this book and did not want it to end.  The book flows smoothly and is wonderfully written.  I would also say that the ending is a surprise.

The outside is made of semi-rigid material so it is quite durable.  There is a plastic sleeve that could hold a title page to indicate what is inside the binder.  There is a snap to close the cover.Inside the Trapper Keeper, there are two pockets on the left hand side of the binder to hold documents.  The pockets are only on the bottom.  I remember the old Trapper Keepers having a pocket on the top, side and bottom to prevent papers from falling out of the folder.  There is a 1.5 inch 3 ring binder on the inside.  The binder has 5 color coded, hard plastic dividers.  An elastic loop is attached on the inside for holding a pen.Overall, I really like this Trapper Keeper.  With a 1.5 inch binder, it can hold a lot of documents and I didn’t have to go out and buy dividers to organize my papers.  It would be nice if it did include the pockets on the top, side and bottom to prevent items from falling out though.

Very plush and great padding underfoot.  I bought this for a small bathroom, just because it looked acceptable and was inexpensive.  I was VERY pleasantly surprised when it arrived.  The color I got, Coffee, is a nice, rich brown.  But, most importantly, this is really a thick, comfortable memory foam rug.  It feels wonderful underfoot.  Yes, footprints show when you step on it - it is memory foam - but it springs back to its original shape quite quickly.  I was so pleased that I bought two more of a larger size for in front of my kitchen sinks to provide padding when I stand there on what is otherwise hard concrete.

I just ordered my third one of these.  The first one quickly broke - the prongs stopped folding down properly.  The company sent me a free replacement.  The replacement is still working great and I ordered a third as a preset.As others have noted in reviews, the prongs sometimes quit working and, if that happens, you lose the function of being able to use it without a separate charger cord and transformer.  I used the original for a while with an external charger cord and transformer.  Then it stopped holding a charge.  However, as I stated above, the replacement is still going strong after close to a year.I'm willing to try it again because I love the convenience of no extra cord - when it's working.  And the company has been good to replace the original defective unit.

I bought a set of four of these years ago.  I still have 3 despite using them frequently and putting them through the dishwasher every time - contrary to the suggestion to hand wash.  The dishwasher has never hurt them.  The one I broke was from dropping it.The dishes are fairly small, as shown in the picture.  I use them for Jello, or small desert servings.  The are pretty enough to use for a nice dinner and sturdy enough for every day.

Upfront - I am such a fan of Bodum Pavina double-wall glasses that I have replaced all my other glasses with these - juice size up to ic tea size.  We had broken a couple and bought these as replacements.The Bodum Pavina are PRETTY.  They also do a good job of keeping cold drinks cold and hot drinks hot.  The minimize the sweating with cold drinks.  On the bad side, they are somewhat fragile, double wall glass.  The definitely break if knocked over on a hard cabinet.  I've never had one survive a drop or hitting the edge of a sink.They are advertised as dishwasher safe, but when I first bought them I had the inside of one steam up in the dishwasher, so I had wash them to make sure it doesn't happen again.Not a practical glass, I guess.  But, worth it to me for the appearance and the double wall properties.

It is essential Robert Cray.  If you like Robert Cray, as I do, you should love it.  If he is not your style, you won't like it.The production is wonderful.  He is in fine voice.  The songs are what I expect from Cray.

My husband uses his iPad as a laptop, typing on it constantly.  I'm constantly looking for a paired keyboard which works well with it.  This finally seems to be what he needs.The design is very Apple-looking.  When attached to the iPad, it is a single, slim, Apple-silver unit.  The fit when closed is secure and the keyboard cover functions with the magnet in the iPad - just like Apple's cover - to put the iPad to sleep when closed.When opened, the keyboard has to be removed from the back hinge for use, but it sets up quickly and the back clip design is more secure than other keyboards he has tried.  The keyboard itself is also very Apple-like.  Not a large keyboard (given the size of the iPad it can't be), but the keys feel and function like a normal keyboard.  So far, the blue0tooth connection is very stable and there is no problem with typing quickly.Overall, it seems to be an excellent addition to the iPad.

This is formatted for Windows, but is still almost plug and play on my iMac. Anything with "Apple" on it seems more expensive, so I bought this, plugged it into my iMac, told it to format when I got the prompt, and it's working great. Plenty of room for Time Macine, plus full backup of my several thousand photos and Elements catalog - plus room to manually add a backup copy of my documents.I originally looked for a drive to use the "faster" Thundebolt connections. They are MUCH more expensive. And when I researched, they are no faster in practice if being used like this as a backup.  Although Thunderbolt can carry more data at a faster rate, the practical speed can't be faster than the external hard drive can write - no matter what the connection.  I'll save my money until a solid state external drive with Thunderbolt becomes affordable. That will be faster.I was a little concerned that I might have to stand this up as a mini-tower as shown in the pictures.  I have three large, energetic cats who might knock it over.  However, the vents are on the top, back and bottom of the unit as you are looking at the pictures.  Although there are small feet on the bottom, I think it is better-ventilated laying on its side with all vents unblocked.  It is a small unit and takes up very little space on my desk.

I love Calphalon.  I've had a set of Calphalon Contemporary for 20 years or so.  Calphalon has replaced several under the life time warranty - they are very good to honor it.  Over the years, the quality of the cookware has improved.  My first set could not go through the dishwasher and the non-stick was more fragile.  The non-stick has also improved over the years in how well it prevents sticking.I keep coming back to Calphalon because it is solidly built, conduct heat evenly, has good stay-cool handles and does have an excellent warranty.

This just arrived today, and I've spent quite a bit of time with it trying to arrange lenses, filters.  Whether this bag will work for you will depend on your system and what you are looking for in a bag.For information, I have a Nikon D7000 and keep a fairly large 18-300mm lens with rubber hood on it.  For extra lenses, I have a Tokina ultra wide angle (medium size), a Nikon 35mm f1.8 (quite small) and an alternate Nikon 50mm low light lens (also quite small).  I only carry one of the small lenses at any time.  I normally keep the camera out of the bag so it is more easily accessible, but, occasionally, I want to be able to put it in the bag to protect from bad weather that blows up.  Then there are a couple of filters I always want with me, spare battery, extra lens caps and sometimes a flash.I can get all the gear I carry in the bag.  It is a pretty tight fit.  With the camera out, as it will usually be, there is actually too much room and I'd prefer something smaller - but then I don't have the option of putting the camera in a bag for weather protection.  Nothing is perfect.The bag comes with 4 padded dividers, which seems adequate.  I have lots of padded dividers from other bags over the years so that is not an issue for me.  The interior of the bag is well padded.  The 2 little pockets on the lid of the main section easily hold a memory card, although getting it out isn't easy.  My spare battery will fit in the larger of the 2, but I don't trust it not to fall out when I open the bag.  The front zipper compartment will hold filters and extra lens caps easily.  The compartment between the front zipper compartment and the main compartment actually IS a compartment.  It has sides (but they are rather low), is held securely by the front buckles and is roomy enough for lens caps, filters, cleaners, etc. The 2 mesh compartments at the ends are nice.  One has a circular bottom for a drink bottle; the other is smaller.  The straps at the bottom of the bag would work for a tripod or, more likely for me, a jacket.As for weather protection, it took a while to find the little rain cover under the velcro at the very front bottom of the bag.  When I did, however, I checked it out and verified it fits fine, even with the bag fully loaded.  However, I still need to work on repacking it to the smallest size.  It affects the size of the front zipper compartment and the compartment between the main body of the bag and the front zipper compartment.With my camera out, the bag is comfortable to wear.  With the camera in it, it is bulky and heavy.  If it is overloaded, it can tend to roll forward if the waist strap is not tight - and if it is tight you can't move the bag from back to front easily.In summary, I'm still not sure how well I like the bag for my uses and I could not make any recommendations to someone else - everyone's preferences are different.  I think it will probably be a good compromise for me between too small to actually hold a camera if necessary and too large to be usable.

I bought this to use for my husband and me.  It is very small and light.  It is a mistake to buy it if you want large volume, or heavy metal.  But, for our purposes it is perfect.I saw some reviewers said the whistle was not loud enough.  I have no problems with it, as long as I remember to get the lids on top and one the spout tightly closed.  The one on the spout, where it whistles, sticks in the up position.The handle is fixed in one direction and moves freely in the other.  So far, that has worked well for me to keep it in position.I've been using this little kettle several times a week now for several weeks.
I had never heard of this artist  until this song was featured on the most recent episode of HBO's Newsroom.  Lovely.

A few years ago, we cleared out all of our old and mismatched glasses and replaced them with Bodem double-walled glasses.  These mugs are among my favorite.  I HATE cold coffee.  These provide some insulation and look beautiful doing it - unlike other insulated mugs.  The very first Bodum 10-ounce mugs I bought were a little fragile.  In the years since, Bodum has made the sturdier.  I had to drop a metal coffee pot on the last one I lost before it broke - and even then what happened was the 2 walls separated right at the seam at the top - no shattering.I am sold on these.

I can't comment on durability yet.  However, I hooked it up to my iMac and it ran beautifully - right away.  The quality of DVD playing is very good, definitely better than what I had with my integrated drive on my iMac.  (I bought this one for a new iMac which does not have an optical drive.)  It is ultra slim as advertised.  My iMac does not show the drive unless there is a disk inserted.  I have to eject the disk through the computer, but that is simple enough.Apple was selling their optical drive to go with their new computers without optical drive at a price tag of about $80.  This one cost about $25.  It think it is worth the money.

Don't order them expecting them to be the "blue, black and gold" as described or to look anything like the picture, except the shape and size.  I got a pair that is a sickly lime green color.  I'll never wear them because of the awful color.  Not as described.

I previously bought one of the Dreams And Company sleep shirts which was just below knee length.  I loved it and bought several others.  THEN I realized that it drastically shrunk  when washed and I ended up with 4 tee-shirts which are not much more than tunic length!Then I saw this long version.  I now have 4 of them.  I haven't had the nerve to dry them, but they have survived several washings with line drying and there is absolutely no shrinkage.  The colors stay bright.  (I have the rose color hearts; blue bumble bees; zebra pattern; and pink cats.)  I am about 5'7" or a bit more, size 1X normally, and they fall to mid-calf.  They are VERY roomy, which I don't mind.  They are comfortable as sleep shirts or lounge wear around the house.

I've always used OtterBox - plain, sturdy and woks fine. I switched to this case for my new iPhone 6 because the description said it was lighter, less bulk and still good protection. I haven't tried dropping the phone to verify the protection, but it looks like good protection. Definitely lighter and less bulky. I'm not particularly crazy about the look of it, but I like the grip provided by the irregular shapes on the sides and back. The iPhone 6 with its curved edges can be slippery without a case.I almost took a star off for the screen protector. I'm a perfectionist and usually get screen protectors on very smoothly. This one ended up a mess and I ordered some replacement Halo protectos to replace it - the first of them went on fine. But, maybe the screen protector mess was just the averages catching up with me, so 5-stars.

I have not had to use this particular plan yet, but this is the fourth plan I've bought to protect electronics and I have had the misfortune to need others.  Dealing with the company was easy as could be.  Payment was prompt.I did get the accidental protection, as well as mechanical failure, version.  That eliminates any argument about why the device quit working.For my own ease, I set up an account and register my devices, complete with receipt, as soon as possible.  Then, when/if I need the protection, it is ready for me.

The only TRULY sweat-free glass I've found, after many attempts.  I don't like that it is plastic.  I don't like that the straw is very loose in the lid so it spills easily.  I wish it came in a larger size.  But, given that it IS sweat-free, I'll give it 4 stars.
OtterBox are always solid and safe.  This is no different.  Fits my husband's iPhone 5s smoothly.

Easy set up.  My iPhone, then iPad found it quickly.  I was a little disappointed that I have to be sure to drop it from one device before the other device can find it.  With my husband and I both having iPads and iPhones, it is a pain to track down the other person's device and disconnect it.  That's why I only gave 4 stars.The quality of the streaming when I'm sitting in our living room, where the good speakers are, is excellent.  I don't know how good the range is, but I got it for that good stereo system so I'm not interested in moving away from the stereo system to try the range.

I love the Dresden Files.  I pre-order as soon as I learn one is coming out.  This one was a disappointment.  As others have said, not really bad - but kind of "nagh" (if that's a word) to me.However, I certainly wouldn't give up on Harry Dresden because of this book.  I think Butcher wrote himself into a corner and this is his first novel after that to try to get back on track.  I've read the next one and I'm well into the one after that.  I review them separately.  Butcher is back in the groove in those books.

I wear size 9 shoes (women's) and I was able to get 2 pair of flat sandals, or small dress flats, per pocket.  Only one sneaker per pocket, or one clog.The construction looks solid.  The hanger on top is connected to a heavy metal rod which runs across the top of the canvas.  (I've had bad experiences with jewelry hangers like this which were NOT solidly constructed.)The only problem for me is that it is too long to hang in my closet without the bottom two pockets laying on the floor.  Still, I expected that - even though the listing doesn't specify length - thanks to a helpful customer who stated in that the length is about 4 feet.  (I agree with that estimate although it is tough for me to accurately measure now that it's laying on the floor.)

I had been using a plastic, over-the-sink colander to clean and drain vegetables - which took up too much of the sink and quickly got totally gross if I didn't clean it constantly.  Now I have my sink back and this works better than the old colander for draining.Obviously, check your sink size before ordering.
I don't use a remote very frequently.  But, this little remote is just what I need.  It was much cheaper than the one I could buy from Nikon and works just as well.

I bought this quite a while ago.  I carried it in my camera bag and used it only for the brush.  I was afraid to use the other end on my lenses.  Then, I was going to sell an old lens my husband had been using and discovered it covered in smudges.  I tried my usual cleaning with gentle breath and soft cleaning cloth.  Smudges still there.  I figured I had nothing to lose so I dug this out.  Took me a time or two to perfect the technique, but this sucker did seem to "suck" the smudges right off!  I would put it flat on a part of the lens, press it and roll it slightly to make sure I had good contact, then lift it.  By the time I finished, the lens was completely clean and the coating looked untouched.  I experimented a little and discovered it gently and effectively lifts off dust spots and the very, very hair that seems to land on a lens occasionally.  I could seem them on the black cleaner stick and blow them off.  I'm convinced.  It is worth it.

No need to review the movie - if you're looking at this you probably know how wonderful it is.  (I showed it to my nieces one night.  They'd never heard of it and rolled their eyes at an old black and white.  By the end, they were thoroughly hooked.)  I had this in earlier formats and think the upgrade to Blu-ray was worth it.  Seemed to preserve all the classic film noir appearance, only better.

I thought this series was going to reach the point that so many do - the writer keeping it going when it seems the story line has died.  I had been a little disappointed in some books in the middle of the series.  But, this one seems to be back on track.  New intrigues, new perspectives, etc.  It kept me reading through the night.

I bought this for a 72mm lens which goes from 18mm to 200mm.  It doesn't show in picutures if folded back all the way.  However, it can't be used as an hood - even at the first, shortest setting when you start unfolding it - at any wider angle than 35mm.  Below 35, you see the hood at the picture corners.  And if you extend it all the way, you really have to zoom out to avoid seeing the hood.I have an old, similar hood which is smaller, but even it cuts off corners below 20mm.For what it is, within those limitations, it is great.  I find it much more convenient than the hard plastic "tulip" hoods which come with my lenses.  When those are turned around to attach to the lens when not in use, they interfere with zoom and manual focus (which I need occasionally).  Despite the limitations, I'm keeping it and will use it.  I'm going to try it on a lens which has 67mm threads, with a step-up ring, and see if that helps some.

I bought this to replace a large lidded plastic glass with straw which was broken by my cat.  I wish the volume of this was larger.  The straw goes through a fairly generous hole on the lid, so it does leak if tipped so the liquid reaches the hole.  (My old glass was larger and leak-proof.)  But this one really does an excellent job of keeping drinks cold and sweats less than any such glass I have found.
It works fine.  Good price.  It isn't the thinnest of such rings that I have, and I wish it was thinner, but it will work.

I don't think they come any better.  Very slim.  Repels fingerprints and smears.  NO ghosting or funny image quality.  I'd been using a sort of off-brand on a lens I bought used - filter came with it.  After using it on a long vacation and seeing the results, I dumped the off-brand for this one.  Really a visible difference.
My husband and I bought these for a recent trip to China because we were advised to lock our bags for flights within China.  Two locks, two flights each, and no troubles.

I waited to write this review until I could give the sox a good try out - a flight from Texas to China and back.  I wore them the entire 30 or so hours to China.  No swollen legs.  On the way back, I took them off in Chicago before the last flight to Dallas.  My legs were fine when the sox came off in Chicago, but swollen by Dallas a couple of hours later.  Obvously, the sox were the difference.The sox fit well, true to size.  They were comfortable to wear for the entire long flight.

This is a revised, downgraded review.  I originally rated them 4 star.I ordered these because I had Hanes like this, that I liked.  I ordered this 6 pack instead of the 10 pack because there were some bad reviews of the 10 pack, citing that they were made in Vietnam and quality did not seem as good as earlier product made in Thailand.  What I had was made in Thailand, so I got these.  Guess what?  Made in Vietnam.  I couldn't tell from the product listing.  On first inspection, quality was OK.  Seams straight, secure, everything symmetrical.  Then, I wore the first pair.  NOT the same as the earlier ones made in Thailand.  Seemed OK at first, but then the elastic around the legs got loose or something.  These are as far from "tug less" as panties can get.  I can't return these since I wore one of them most of the day, but I'll try to avoid wearing them as much as possible.  I'm tired of grabbing at my rear to pull them back in place to avoid discomfort.The colors I got included purple and a couple of pink or heather tones, no black.  I like the colors.  That's about the only positive left to say.

We have to clean our pot at least monthly, or twice monthly, with our hard water.  Without cleaning, there is tremendous calcium buildup and we've discovered that can even cause the pot to stop dispensing water.This is the recommended cleaner, so we use it.  The multipack size helps with cost.  I just wish it did a better job of cleaning.  After 15 month we have some permanent deposits on the bottom of the pot that no repeated cleanings will remove.

Bras used to be easy.  I was a 36C, pre-menopausal, in good shape woman.  But now, past menopause - with the resulting drooping - and carrying extra weight, I had just about given up on  finding a bra I really liked.  I wore sports bras, or terribly uncomfortable bras for as short a period as possible when I went out.  Until this bra.I now wear a 42D.  This one fits perfectly.  The cups are substantial enough to prevent nipples showing.  Much to my amazement, the bra is VERY comfortable with great support and shaping.  The underwire is very well padded and does not cause discomfort  The U back really seems to work.  I had been wearing racerback bras to keep straps on my shoulders, but that meant straps showed in boatneck blouses.  No more slipping straps, no more straps showing.  Because of my extra weight, I had a problem with uncomfortable, and unsightly, bulging at the back and sides of bras - but not with this one.I don't know yet how well the bras will hold up, and they are a little pricey to constantly replace.  But, I am so thrilled with the first 2, that I ordered 2 more.  Even if they don't last as long as I'd like, they are worth it to me.

I ordered this for my parents and they love it.  It was their first HD TV and they will never be without again - have bought another since then.  I personally prefer plasma HD TVs, but I have been favorably impressed by the quality of the picture on this set.

I bought this before an Africa trip and used it extensively while practicing with my new camera and lens before the trip.  Then got to Africa and no UV filter on the lens!  I was so pleased with the filter from using it before the trip that I replaced it immediately on my return.  You can find cheaper UV filters, but I don't think they are as good for weight and lack of distortion - you get what you pay for.

We bought several pairs of these pants for both of us for a trip to Uganda.  Turns out we could have travelled with just a carry-on bag each thanks to these.  They are comfortable and cool.  They wash out easily and dry quickly.  Great pants to pack for a trip.
This was wonderful reading before we actually went to Uganda.  It has good descriptions of the parks and what to expect in each park.

I bought this when I got my very first Apple product, a nice, large iMac.  Having used only Windows for decades, I was concerned about losing my Windows programs and not having the familiar features of Windows.  After a few weeks learning curve on the iMac, I realized that I was not using Parallels for anything but Word for Windows.  Word for Mac doesn't get great reviews, so I thought it was worth it - until I discovered the free word processing programs I could use on my iMac, like Apache Open Office.  After several months of not using Parallels - and realizing that I had to pay for yet ANOTHER upgrade of Parallels to use it with the latest free Apple OS update, I just removed Parallels.  Don't miss it a bit.
I bought these as a present for a family member.  I was pleased with the look of them and the quality - and she seemed to like them.

I had been using Elements 9 since it came out.  This looked like enough of an upgrade to justify the cost.  I was particularly interested in the fact it said it worked with Adobe Revel to store my pictures in the cloud on Revel easily.  It was no that much of an upgrade.  And the Revel function is pretty useless.  It is much quicker and easier to put my photos in Revel by opening Revel on my computer and importing pictures from my files.

I like these so much that I bought a pair in red and black.  The are very lightweight and comfortable.  They look good enough to wear with dressy clothes, or with jeans and a knit top.  They are long enough to satisfy me, and I do not like small earrings which get lost in my hair.

At the time I bought this, it was less expensive than other external batteries.  These days, I see them for much less and have even picked up another good one for about $10.  But, this one is still working well after a couple of years of steady use.  It was all I used to keep my Nook charged for about the first year.  It works well on my iPhone.  It will charge the iPad, but it is slow and the external battery drains quickly.Only problem was at first when I didn't realize I had to turn it off with the button on the side to keep it from running down after I used it.  Be sure to turn it off - no lights - when you are not using it.
I had been using old, rusting aluminum pans for decades.  I should have bought this years ago.  Even cooking, good nonstick - just what I needed.

The large handle, extended strap to go around the bag, and the feature so that it beeps when the reading is complete then holds that reading for several seconds all make this luggage scale very easy to use.  I checked its accuracy against our very accurate bathroom scales and our accurate (large) meat scale.  It seems to be right on.I saw criticism of construction quality in other reviews so checked it carefully, expecting to have to do some repair on the stitching.  The item we received is well constructed.  I also saw criticism that the batteries did not last long.  The scale automatically turns itself off after a few seconds to conserve battery.  However, the on button is on the top of the handle so it could get turned on inside a suitcase - repeatedly - and run down the battery.  I made sure that wouldn't happen by saving the small plastic piece placed between battery and contacts which prevented it from being accidentally turned on in its original packaging.  It will be impossible for it to turn on accidentally in our luggage.  (And I'm taking some extra batteries just in case.)

The masks are NIOSH approved.  Good price.I have seen lots of comments about the size of the masks and I was very concerned before ordering them.  I asked other buyers and received inconsistent responses - from small child size to adult size.  I suspect the differences were due to the different sellers.  Amazon offers these from several sellers.  I have run into the issue before where different sellers would ship slightly different items, even though they were all listed under the same Amazon listing.  Our masks came from GlovesAndStuff and are full adult-sized masks.  My husband is over 6 feet and overweight.  Large face.  The masks still fit him.

My cats love it and it is durable.  I clean the pump regularly and I have always used a Drinkwell filter in it - but that's really not a lot of work.  The fountain just keeps on working.  I use it with the large reservoir and it will last about 2 weeks for 2 cats without a refill.

I have Bodum Bistro glasses of all sizes.  These cups are actually the most practical of the bunch.  They are made out of a little heavier glass than they used to be and are a little more durable than the other glassware.
Long-lasting strings make the price more palatable.  Washburn Bass.  These strings play nicely and sound good.  I also have Elixir strings for my acoustic guitars.

If you want a smallish, cute water gun this is it.  If you want something a lot more fun, truly gets others wet, and holds more water, go with the one of hand pump action SuperSoakers.  At the same price point (~$10), you are MUCH better off getting the regular Scatterblaster, which a preschooler can easily use too).  This small squirter only lets out one little stream of water with decent range, fun to annoy, but doesn't do much outdoors.  The light is pretty bright, brighter than the Zombie Scatterblaster and uses 3 AAA batts in a rubber O-ring sealed orange compartment (under the nozzle).  Everytime you squirt, the palm of your hand will also push the light button as well.  This is convenient if you want the light effect, but after awhile it gets annoying since it digs into your palm repeatedly.

Color in the picture is the actual color of the cable.  It's not a bulky thick cable, but the connections are sturdy enough.  Connections fit well.  Ideal for rolling up and stashing in your pocket/purse.  Works.  While micro-USB cable are ubiquitous and are often laying around, it's a bit harder to borrow a Lightning cable, so bring your own spare!

Well made product sturdy cup and baster with Tritan plastic, which is break and heat resistant.  This is BPA-free and was developed and marketed by Eastman Chemical (formerly Eastman Kodak) to great success.  However, if you google the plastic, there is a little controversy whether this is truly a "harmless" product.  Normally, I wouldn't care too much, but since this might hold hot oven temperature liquid, it is on my mind.The fat separator itself is easy to use with clean water.  But using actual oven roasted chicken/potatoes/rosemary sauce, it was frustrating.  With clean water, there is no leakage from the bottom of the cup with the silicone plug, and pours out great.  With actual chicken broth that was not see-through, the space between the silicone stopper and hole just wasn't big enough.  I had to use a chopstick to constantly stir things around to get the goodness to drip through.  Seemed like it took forever...  I eventually got through the whole container, and was pleased with the separated juice.  I merely wiped out the excess grease from the cup (not good for plumbing) and let it sit in soapy water before putting it in the dishwasher.  It cleans very easily.The baster is nicely made too.  The silicone bulb and tip both screw off easily for cleaning.  The bulb is very pliable and easy to squeeze.  It can easily fill up the entire baster (50 ml of liquid) with one squeeze.  This works beset with low particulate juice, like water/clear juice.  The holes on the end are small, which may not let you suction fast if you have a lot of fine particles in the juice.

We have lots of Melissa and Doug sets, and they are generally of good quality.  This set is probably not the best set IMHO.  The playdough is enough to play with for one sitting, but what you get in the four small containers is it.  You'll need to supplement with some extra Playdough.  The rollers have wooden handles, but the rollers themselves are made of plastic.  On the other M&D playdough set, they were all made of wood.  The plastic scissors work okay only if the dough is rolled thin.  Also, I like to use the Amazon packing paper as a table cover, but this playdough sticks to it.  It peels off okay on regular wood table top.

A little expensive compared to other bass strings, but these are nice strings that in theory should last a long time.  Easy to play and sound good.  Washburn bass.  I also own other acoustic guitars, and the Elixir line is a good choice for acoustic guitars too.

We have 7 different NERF Supersoaker models for a total of 10.  We like to use ours around the pool and the backyard for super wet fun.  We have tried other brands of water guns from other makers, but NERF seems to make the best ones generally speaking.I wrote my take on each model, but put my top two favorites for OVERALL performance (ASIN# used to facilitate looking it up on Amazon website).1.  Tidal Tube Blaster, one tube of water: This is UNBEATABLE for soakage.  My 3-4 y/o could operate this with ease.  My wife was often a casualty of mischief with this blaster.  With the right angle, I can launch an accurate good stream of water a good 40-60 feet (all the way to the end of a long pool), giving this the longest range by far of all the supersoakers.  The only drawback is it's a one shot deal, hence this is best as a pool toy.  You can also use a bucket in the back yard, but you're at a big disadvantage when you want to refill.  Ours has lasted through a full summer with no problem.  You cannot really find this in the store, and have to order online.  I got it for <$10/pack on sale by Amazon last year.ASIN: B00EAHXYG62.  Scatterblast Blaster, 22 oz.:  This is frequently on sale for $9 at Target and is normally priced at $10 full retail. There is plentiful supply and easy to buy.  It has a single nozzle that has 4 little holes around 1 bigger one.  The range is decent and the pump action is smooth.  This one is a favorite of my preschooler, which is not surprising considering how easy it is to hold and operate.  Even though the reservoir is on the smaller side, because it is a basic water gun with one nozzle, it actually lasts quite awhile before getting empty.  This is like a shotgun, scattering a decent amount of water over a wide area.  Overall, because of the low price point, durability, ease of use, and good soakage, this is my favorite of the pack outside of the pool (then it's the tube blaster).ASIN: B00EAHXWQI**  Barrage Soaker, 84 oz.:  This thing has a huge reservoir that allows you run around the yard with impunity.  The adjustable nozzle twists to select one of three settings, but the nozzle does not twist all the way around.  The 1st setting is a not-as-good version of the Scatterblaster (stream is so wide it devolves into three small streams and mist).  The 2nd setting is a regular steam with limited range.  The 3rd setting is a thinner steam goes much farther.  The money's at the 3rd setting, and it is very effective, especially if you can keep a good distance from your target.  The giant reservoir with the 3rd setting combines for a fearsome combo in a water gun.  This gun is best for older kids (at least upper elementary) as it is pretty heavy when full.ASIN: B00EAHXYHU3.  Double Drench Blaster, 27 oz.:  This water gun is a lot of fun with it's double barrel multi hole goodness.  It has good range and great spread of water as expected.  You don't have to be accurate at all.  In fact, you probably don't even have to look when you fire.  You'll hit something...  You might feel like a bad boy walking around with this double barreled saw off shotgun water toy.ASIN: B00EAHXYPC** Floodfire Blaster, 43 oz:  This thing holds quite a bit of water.  It fires a single large stream of water at long range, but you have to hold the trigger down AND use the pump action.  This is because it also connects to a garden hose and the trigger releases the pressure from the hose for ultimate range and unlimited soakage.  The hose connector works well and is a quick on/off twist. It's nice to just connect and fill up fast.  However, why use this with a hose when you have a Flippin' HOSE at your disposal?!  I'd much rather drop this on the ground and pick up the actual hose if I'm really getting mobbed. Another thing, it's heavy when fully loaded.  My 8 y/o complained about it after awhile.  It does hold a lot of water and the thick stream has good range, so buy it for that, not the hose function.ASIN: B00MXT4T94** Flashflood Blaster, 23oz.:  This water gun is truly unique as it combines a Scatterblaster with a Tube on top.  If you want to be conservative, just use the pump action scatterblaster.  But sometimes you just really need to drench the other person, and the tube is perfect for that.  You have to have to be careful, though since the tube will use up the standard size reservoir pretty fast.  The Scatterblaster and Tube both have decent range.  But the tube is a little awkward to use and doesn't push in as straight as the Tubeblaster, so you do not get anywhere the speed nor range of the regular Tubeblaster.  However, you do have a portable resevoir so you can venture away from the pool with this one.  The model leaks a lot of water when full, so be careful if you're filling it up in the house.ASIN: B00MXT4SZ4** Zombie Strike Scatterblast Blaster, 35 oz: A cousin of the Scatterblast blaster, but the light is superfluous.  The battery compartment has a rubber O-ring to keep it dry (3 AAA batts).  I wouldn't bother, the light is so weak, especially in daytime.  However, the pump action works well and it functions well as a Scatterblaster.  Save your $ and just get the regular version.ASIN: B00MXT4TDK

We have 7 different NERF Supersoaker models for a total of 10.  We like to use ours around the pool and the backyard for super wet fun.  We have tried other brands of water guns from other makers, but NERF seems to make the best ones generally speaking.I wrote my take on each model, but put my top two favorites for OVERALL performance (ASIN# used to facilitate looking it up on Amazon website).1.  Tidal Tube Blaster, one tube of water: This is UNBEATABLE for soakage.  My 3-4 y/o could operate this with ease.  My wife was often a casualty of mischief with this blaster.  With the right angle, I can launch an accurate good stream of water a good 40-60 feet (all the way to the end of a long pool), giving this the longest range by far of all the supersoakers.  The only drawback is it's a one shot deal, hence this is best as a pool toy.  You can also use a bucket in the back yard, but you're at a big disadvantage when you want to refill.  Ours has lasted through a full summer with no problem.  You cannot really find this in the store, and have to order online.  I got it for <$10/pack on sale by Amazon last year.ASIN: B00EAHXYG62.  Scatterblast Blaster, 22 oz.:  This is frequently on sale for $9 at Target and is normally priced at $10 full retail. There is plentiful supply and easy to buy.  It has a single nozzle that has 4 little holes around 1 bigger one.  The range is decent and the pump action is smooth.  This one is a favorite of my preschooler, which is not surprising considering how easy it is to hold and operate.  Even though the reservoir is on the smaller side, because it is a basic water gun with one nozzle, it actually lasts quite awhile before getting empty.  This is like a shotgun, scattering a decent amount of water over a wide area.  Overall, because of the low price point, durability, ease of use, and good soakage, this is my favorite of the pack outside of the pool (then it's the tube blaster).ASIN: B00EAHXWQI**  Barrage Soaker, 84 oz.:  This thing has a huge reservoir that allows you run around the yard with impunity.  The adjustable nozzle twists to select one of three settings, but the nozzle does not twist all the way around.  The 1st setting is a not-as-good version of the Scatterblaster (stream is so wide it devolves into three small streams and mist).  The 2nd setting is a regular steam with limited range.  The 3rd setting is a thinner steam goes much farther.  The money's at the 3rd setting, and it is very effective, especially if you can keep a good distance from your target.  The giant reservoir with the 3rd setting combines for a fearsome combo in a water gun.  This gun is best for older kids (at least upper elementary) as it is pretty heavy when full.ASIN: B00EAHXYHU**  Double Drench Blaster, 27 oz.:  This water gun is a lot of fun with it's double barrel multi hole goodness.  It has good range and great spread of water as expected.  You don't have to be accurate at all.  In fact, you probably don't even have to look when you fire.  You'll hit something...  You might feel like a bad boy walking around with this double barreled saw off shotgun water toy.ASIN: B00EAHXYPC** Floodfire Blaster, 43 oz:  This thing holds quite a bit of water.  It fires a single large stream of water at long range, but you have to hold the trigger down AND use the pump action.  This is because it also connects to a garden hose and the trigger releases the pressure from the hose for ultimate range and unlimited soakage.  The hose connector works well and is a quick on/off twist. It's nice to just connect and fill up fast.  However, why use this with a hose when you have a Flippin' HOSE at your disposal?!  I'd much rather drop this on the ground and pick up the actual hose if I'm really getting mobbed. Another thing, it's heavy when fully loaded.  My 8 y/o complained about it after awhile.  It does hold a lot of water and the thick stream has good range, so buy it for that, not the hose function.ASIN: B00MXT4T94** Flashflood Blaster, 23oz.:  This water gun is truly unique as it combines a Scatterblaster with a Tube on top.  If you want to be conservative, just use the pump action scatterblaster.  But sometimes you just really need to drench the other person, and the tube is perfect for that.  You have to have to be careful, though since the tube will use up the standard size reservoir pretty fast.  The Scatterblaster and Tube both have decent range.  But the tube is a little awkward to use and doesn't push in as straight as the Tubeblaster, so you do not get anywhere the speed nor range of the regular Tubeblaster.  However, you do have a portable resevoir so you can venture away from the pool with this one.  The model leaks a lot of water when full, so be careful if you're filling it up in the house.ASIN: B00MXT4SZ4** Zombie Strike Scatterblast Blaster, 35 oz: A cousin of the Scatterblast blaster, but the light is superfluous.  The battery compartment has a rubber O-ring to keep it dry (3 AAA batts).  I wouldn't bother, the light is so weak, especially in daytime.  However, the pump action works well and it functions well as a Scatterblaster.  Save your $ and just get the regular version.ASIN: B00MXT4TDK

This set comes via freight service.  They'll call you to arrange a delivery window that suits your schedule.  Two boxes were delivered in good shape.  There were black shoe prints all over my boxes, but nothing was damaged inside.  The edges of the box were all reinforced with stiff cardboard edgers which really help with protection, yet are recyclable.  Great move by the company to keep the contents in good shape without a ton of Styrofoam(though there is some still in there for padding).  When I opened up the boxes, which were not terribly heavy, I expected to have the chemical smells from the Malaysian manufacturing plant waft out of the box, but this set actually smelled pretty neutral.  Nevertheless, I let it sit out for a few hours before I brought the pieces inside to assemble.I took some pictures of the assembly manual so readers could get an idea of the setup involved and if they would want to do that for this bed.  This is not just a headboard that needs a metal base, but has a full slat system that you have to assemble yourself.  The pieces are light though, and I think this can be done by most people by themselves, though two people obviously goes faster.  The quality of the materials are actually really great.  Hardwood supports, and the slats are quality thick plywood that are sanded smooth (came bundled nicely).  I was impressed. The leather is prefect and seams are straight down on the headboard.Once assembled, it is a handsome bed.

This is a NICE racket.  The handle is smooth and very comfortable.  I like to hold it pen style, but it has an even better feel with handshake. If you have small hands, then you might want to file down the wooden edge ever so slightly.  It's a real pleasure to play with it.  Very good control of the ball and good spin capability.

Best feature of this pencil sharpener is the auto-stop.  That ensures that you're not oversharpening the pencil and wasting wood/lead.  I tested it on quite a few pencils from the school designs ones, regular yellows, and colored pencils.  Always a good tip at the end.  The shavings trap is very easy to pop out and dump, and leaves barely any mess.  In fact, the thing is so small, you can just put the whole thing over the trashcan before you tap out the trap to make sure that you don't get wayward shavings on your desk.I recommend holding a little pressure directly downward as you sharpen.  Otherwise, the pencil has a tendency to move around a little and your point will be off-center.  Also, the base will move around as well if you don't apply a little direct downward pressure via the pencil.The motor is powered by 4 AA batteries.  You have to set your expectations accordingly.  This is not a loud, wall plug in, heavy base, super motor model like school ones.  It's compact and runs on batteries, so the motor can only be so powerful.  For some, it may seem way underpowered.  But it gets the job done reasonably well.  You might spend literately 1-2 more seconds sharpening, but unless you have a whole boat-load of pencils to sharpen as a hapless underpaid intern, it's inconsequential.

Super comfortable and lightweight, and that was before I even washed it (cold water only).  It dries out pretty fast in the sun.  I'd say the stitching is 99% perfect.  Collar and pant bottoms have 6 rows.  Chest/sleeves, crotch area 3 rows of reinforcement.  The Blue is spot on and uniform.

I compared this router to the Verizon Actiontec FIOS router (only 2.4 Ghz) and a Linksys 6350AC router (2.4/5Ghz, AC).I was instantly pleased when I opened the box.  The build quality is very nice and solid.  There are vent holes all around the body that keep the unit noticeably cooler than the 6350AC.  It, however, is quite a bit larger and blockier looking.  It looks like a much bigger version of the much older ubiquitous WRT54.Setup was not a breeze.  While my cellphone (HTC One) instantly found the router setup page (which loaded automatically), setup got hung up twice.  I don't know if this was a problem with the router or my cellphone, which is a admittedly a little quirky with WIFI connections lately.  I resorted to hardwiring the router into my desktop, and that worked like a charm.  The configuration page of the WRTAC1200 is basically the same as the 6350AC, which is excellent.  It's very easy to navigate and get to the options you need to modify from basic to advanced settings.  I plugged a Sandisk 3.0 USB drive in the back, and it was easy to find.Using app WIFI Analyzer on my  cellphone, the WRT1200AC has the strongest signal of all when I'm in the same room as the router, even better than the 6350AC, and definitely better than the Actiontec.  However, climbing the stairs to the opposite corner of the house, the advantage starts to dissipate as the signals start to become more uniform in strength at the 2.4 Ghz band.  This is not surprising as the 5Ghz connection is for speed closer to the router while the 2.4 Ghz is more for a good connection at a distance.  The 5Ghz connection is also to help avoid interference from other devices in the home.  You can find a list of devices and easy to read explanation on Wikipedia when you search for "what devices use 2.4 GHz bandwidth".  Baby monitors, Microwaves, and even Bluetooth are all culprits.  Current cellphones have AC wireless standard, and that is definitely a worthwhile upgrade if you have an older router that doesn't have have AC wireless and you do heavy data activity like streaming and uploading/dowloading lots of pictures and files.I also took a picture of the back of the box, so you can see the differences between the routers.  As you can see, the main differences in the routers (besides the current  $70 price differential) are specs that pros care about more (of which I'm not one).  For normal residential use, the extras of WRTAC1200 should not make much of a difference and the 6350AC will give you savings and great performance already.  But for those that desire just a little more power & have tons of streaming devices to link, this router will will be very pleasing.

Perfect pool toy.  Just dip in the water and pull to load  Since you're at the pool already, you never have to worry about running out of water.  This is one of preschooler's favorite water toys, and he can fill it up by himself and squirt with ease.  My wife has to be careful since he can be a little mischievous at times, and this toy can get you soaked REALLY fast.  An adult can get ~40-60 feet of stream, no problem.I also bought a bunch to use at my older kid's birthday party in the yard with buckets.  The other water guns could not compare when it came time to get wet.No leaks, held up all summer very well despite being treat roughly as outdoor play items.
