I'd much rather drop this on the ground and pick up the actual hose if I'm really getting mobbed. Another thing, it's heavy when fully loaded.  My 8 y/o complained about it after awhile.  It does hold a lot of water and the thick stream has good range, so buy it for that, not the hose function.ASIN: B00MXT4T94** Flashflood Blaster, 23oz.:  This water gun is truly unique as it combines a Scatterblaster with a Tube on top.  If you want to be conservative, just use the pump action scatterblaster.  But sometimes you just really need to drench the other person, and the tube is perfect for that.  You have to have to be careful, though since the tube will use up the standard size reservoir pretty fast.  The Scatterblaster and Tube both have decent range.  But the tube is a little awkward to use and doesn't push in as straight as the Tubeblaster, so you do not get anywhere the speed nor range of the regular Tubeblaster.  However, you do have a portable resevoir so you can venture away from the pool with this one.  The model leaks a lot of water when full, so be careful if you're filling it up in the house.ASIN: B00MXT4SZ4** Zombie Strike Scatterblast Blaster, 35 oz: A cousin of the Scatterblast blaster, but the light is superfluous.  The battery compartment has a rubber O-ring to keep it dry (3 AAA batts).  I wouldn't bother, the light is so weak, especially in daytime.  However, the pump action works well and it functions well as a Scatterblaster.  Save your $ and just get the regular version.ASIN: B00MXT4TDK

Feeder came perfectly packaged.  It was very easy to setup and hang.  One packet for red colored nectar was included (makes 8 oz) which fills 2/3 of the reservoir.  It does come with a little metal S hook which you may have to look for.  Still looking for hummingbirds, but some of my other seed feeders took a month before the birds found them.  I may move it to another location after one more week.Edit:  the hummingbirds have found the feeder!Actually, I was most interested in comparing my experience with setup with others who had problems:1.  Leaks:  No leaks for me.  The only time it leaked was when I flipped the feeder around to hang it after screwing the reservoir to the base, and even then, only minimal (so obviously, flip the feeder outside).  I checked the concrete under the feeder for days and I don't see anything there.  However, if the feeder is tipped quite a bit (like a squirrel or heavy wind), some nectar will flow out of the "flowers" as planned.2.  Extra insects:  I hung it high up off a deck rafter.  Haven't seen any bees nor swarms of ants.  There are plenty of them in the yard, but I guess they haven't found it yet, or it's it's too high for them.

Wow, it's a big bottle.  It states 8 oz in the description, but this bottle must be 4x the usual size I get from the grocery store.  Good thing the expiry date I got is more than a year later.  Tastes as expected, good for baking and making almond jello.  Bottle is clear plastic, not glass.

I have multiples of this card and have actively used them for years now.  Very reliable.  Never compatibility problems with whatever device I put them in.  Decently fast.  Used primarily for my cameras RX100 MII, various 4/3 mount cameras.

I wrote an easy to read Amazon review of the newer version RX100 MII camera.  But I really started with this, the original version, until it got lost, about 2 years ago.  I liked it so much, I replaced it with the RX100 MII as it just came out.  However, the two cameras are fairly similar.  Both utilize the same size awesome sensor and both have full auto - manual controlability.  At a lower price point, the MI original may make the better deal.  Both cameras were heavily used and abused and they showed it, but still functioned perfectly.  That's a testament to the build quality.  So if you're wondering if you should spring ~$150 more for the newer (2 years old now) camera, or ~$350 more for the newest MIII, just know that it's not a big upgrade and maybe you'll want to save some money and still get a great camera by going with the original.

...and it is an awesome camera.I actually had the original RX100, which either got stolen or recycled.  Either way, I had to get a new one and the MII just came out.  Me, my wife, and my preschooler are the main users of this camera.  Preschooler you say?  Yes, he likes to take pictures and for some reason I let him use this $750 (back then) camera despite it flying in the face of reason.  This camera goes all over house, outside, purse, pitched around the car, dropped on the floor.  It's tough.  It's shows it's battlemarks on on the view screen and body, but the lens is pristine and the camera works flawlessly.  So 5 stars for toughness.Picture quality is superb mainly because SONY makes pretty good cameras and has experience writing the processing firmware coupled with an outsized sensor for the camera size.  The sensor really is much bigger than other P&S and it allows much better indoor shots.  With the compact and easy portability, it's often the first camera we pick up when take impromptu shots indoors or go on trips.  If I know that I'm going somewhere for serious pictures, then I go for the 4/3 cameras that otherwise mostly sit around.  Colors are good, sharpness is great.  There is a little bit of the big-nose effect that is hard to avoid with small cameras like this.Compared to the original version of this camera, it's really not that much better overall.  If you can get a screaming good price on the MI, then I suggest going for that instead.  Right now, the price difference as sold by Amazon is about $150.  The newest MIII is around $200 more than this middle one.

No kidding.  Even though egg is one of it's "main active" ingredients, it's actually smells quite good.  Lots of minty and essential oil type smells.  They do not recommend spraying near food plants, but if you look at the ingredient lists, it's looks pretty "natural" to me.  No weird chemicals in there.The black handle has a pull out suction loader, and then you press the trigger to release until the handle is empty.  It takes a little of power to fill the handle, so people with very arthritic hands should avoid this pump sprayer.I get packs of deer that roam in my yard daytime and nighttime, though most flower nipping occurs at night.  So far so good.  An alternative to using a spray is to plant orange/yellow type flowers.  For some reason, deer do not eat those very much.

Sweet keyboard.  It's very solid when folded (2 folds like putting a letter size paper in an envelope).  Even the back is made of brushed aluminum.  However, there is a lot of give in the keyboard, such that I would not recommend using in your lap or on a bed (or other soft surfaces like those).  It's best to use it on a desk where the give lessened.  Otherwise, the keys are easy to push and work great.  As you can see from the picture, there is a back stand and a flip out front ledge for the device.Oh, and about that picture of the guy putting it in his inside suit pocket... it's really not that small.  Unless you wear a big size suit with a deep interior pocket, it's not going to be THAT easy to hide.  Nevertheless, it's perfect for a normal size purse or small briefcase.

Nice regular size power squirter.  The container is very soft and easy to squeeze, but seems durable enough to get tossed around the field/gym bag/playground without worry. The mouth is big enough to easily throw in a bunch of ice cubes to keep things extra cool.Once washed out, fresh water tasted good, like water.  If I let the bottle sit outside all day, then it did pick a little plasticky taste. which was not unexpected (not much worse than a plastic water bottle from Costco).  It's labeled as BPA free, and so you can feel good about one less chemical that might leach into your drink on a hot day.The top is kinda fancy, but it works very well.  It has a silicone stopper cut in a "x" hole.  It works very well to keep liquids in even when the spout is open and I'm shaking it upside down (water).  I haven't tried it on carbonated beverages since I really don't drink fizzy stuff when it's not in a can.  We'll see how long the silicone stopper keeps it's integrity, but other products that use a similar silicone stopper system seem to last long term for me.The spout pops up easily with a simple push of a button.  Now that's a REALLY handy feature as dirty/muddy hands do not have pull/touch a spout like on those disposable plastic bottles.

Vibrant colors, looks pretty much like the picture in the product description.  They arrived flat, and are very flat and smooth.  No curling yet.  I haven't put them in the dishwasher yet (but we usually just wipe clean).  They are smaller than the ones we use from Target, but still plenty big enough.

This piece of jewelry is more for teenagers.  It's small, cute, and casual.  Fairly understated.  Chains came slightly tangled but it was no problem to untangle them.  Definitely get a two layer effect that stayed put the whole day that my wife wore it over a casual shirt.  Not something that you would wear in a professional setting she said, but something more for tweens or teenagers.

Stylish case.  Not too big and fits the phone well.  Really extends battery life, but of course, that all depends on how much you use your phone.  I also carry an extra external battery pack for longer trips "just in case".  This case should be good for everyday use.  It's much easier than trying to mooch a charging cable off one of your work colleagues.

First question people are thinking is probably "is this sturdy?".  YES.  My preschooler and toddler like to step and walk on it to get to the other side.  This hasn't warped the top board and everything works just fine.  There are two braces underneath the board.Play:  The action is pretty good for such a small surface area, and delights little kids.  The pucks and pushers slide pretty easily without catching anywhere on the board and ricochet well.  The only thing is, there is no lift in the 4 corners, so the puck will get stuck there if it ends up there (-1 star).Practicality:  The low profile means I can store this under a bed.  We play on carpet, and the fan has no problem sucking up air and providing lift for the puck.  I do wish the fan cord had a on/off switch.. you have to manually plug/unplug to use it.We have had this since Christmas, and it has held up well.  I am happy with the build quality of this set, really is better than I thought it would be.

Have two stuck on my windows.  One gets no visitors.  One get some birds and squirrels.  The suction cups are strong enough to stay on in rain/ direct shine/and widely swinging temperatures.  Seeds seem to stay dry.  Wife even took a picture of one where a squirrel hopped right into it, and it held the weight just fine (I moved it after that).  Very easy to see the level of seeds left.

My elementary school kid LOVES to read, and I got this for him read at the kitchen table since last fall.  It has held up well and still looks brand new.  The spring page holders are still strong and work well.I mainly got this bookstand because he was reading with the books on the table close to him, and that is not good for his eyes and posture.  Now, he has much better posture when reading and he can put the book a little farther away from his face.  He also has a clip on LED light that we attached to the stand.  The book holder is sturdy and hefty enough that he can turn the pages with the spring holders without shifting the stand accidentally.
We use these as bath toys.  Have held up well.  Both the red and blue boat hulls float well.  The animals are cute.
Very good quality.  Fit well.  Have lasted well enough to get passed on to cousins.

Super fun for little kids.  It really gets the juices flowing for moving around creatively.  The volume has two settings, and is loud enough for circle play with a bunch of kids.  The jingles are fun and not annoying.  The toy repeats itself every once in awhile, which is a good thing to let kids play some of the fun animals again.  The top and bottom both light up.  Overall, a well-designed toy that gets kids active without annoying the parents.

For $60 on Woot/Amazon, I thought "why not?".  I've known about Lytro since a couple of years ago when the buzz was starting to build up prior to their first product launch.  I thought the premise of a modern implementation of light field photography was really interesting and very exciting.  The first cameras (this one) were very expensive.  I'm not sure it ever really caught on since I've never seen one used and these cameras are now on Woot (basically clearance).The good things:* Camera is lightning fast to start up (practically instantaneously).* Fairly easy to use controls (note: zoom is on the silicone above the screen, not the screen itself).* Updates for the software and camera firmware installed easily and quickly.* Interesting shape and gets people curious when you are taking pictures.* Software has features for adjustment, playback, and even 3D (red/cyan, or double picture).The bad things:* Even on optimal sunny outdoor shots, a lot of pictures still didn't turn out well.  There is a bit of bleeding between shadows and light, some of the eyes of of my subjects would turn into blobs.  Pictures still look soft.* Indoor shots and outdoor dusky shots yielded grainy photos.* Perspective with trees is messy.  This can be understood as tree branches do not line up uniformly in a plane.* The vast majority of the pictures you take don't even come close to what is seen on the Lytro website.  Don't be fooled since those photographers have probably set everything "perfect" for a good Lytro type shot.  I still don't know how they got such good resolution on those pictures as the resolution on my pictures seem like they were taken with a 1 MP camera from last decade...* Lytro turtorials and products are centered on the Illum.  This product is practically forgotten already.* The lens cap is neat, but the magnet is too weak and it keeps on falling off when you put it in your pocket.In the end, I, like many others on Amazon who have reviewed this camera, feel underwhelmed.  I haven't decided if I should return this camera or keep it as a "toy"... a curiosity item.  Maybe the Illum is much better since it seems to have about 4x the "resolution" according to their website.

Have been using #2 bags for years now.  We use these for cups of tea, to pots of tea/cider, to pots of soup.  Works really well.  Does not disintegrate/tear even when used for a long time in hot liquids.

This is great for pans with LONG handles.  I tried it on my Lodge cast iron pan, and the handle on the pan is too short to get a comfortable secure grip using this pot holder.  Color is true to the picture.  The fabric is soft and comfortable and the opening is large enough to fit pretty much any handle length.  The silicone bands are only on the outside and is just for your grip.

This is a slimmed- down version of the Otterbox I'm accustomed to.  The usual Otterbox is kinda bulky and while protecting the phone, makes it very conspicuous and even ungainly.  This case is a bit better in that it's solid, but not as bulky.  There is a crosshatch cushion on the inside of the case to help with absorbing shocks.  The case itself is textured plastic, not silicone, so it can still get slippery when handled with greasy hands.  This is only a case, not a holster device.

Currently I STOCKPILE Bounty (green wrapper) paper towels.  But I also have some Brawny and generic store brands around my house as well.  My household goes through a crazy amount of paper towels (hey, I have three kids) and we use them to clean little and big spills, wrap all kinds of things, cover items in the microwave, and as napkins.  I have no problem reusing a paper towel pieces laying around on the floor or the table if I need one quick, so I need them to be very sturdy.Bottom line:  These Basic edition will do the job but I won't be buying them.Basic 12=15 rolls.Green Select-a-size 12=20 rollsThe finer points:These feel cheap, rough, wrinkly, and the rolls have lots of air in between the sheets.  The packaging is almost misleading since if you squeezed the air out of the rolls, you could probably compress the whole thing 25% or more.  They are decently strong, even when wet, but you do not get a feeling of very high quality when using them.  Even generic store paper towels feel better than these.  All the down sides would be okay if the price was low.  But the price on Amazon currently (~$35 for 2 packs) is more than what I paid at Target for two LARGER packs of Bounty green Select-a-size rolls this spring.** If you want something quite a bit better, and more economical, go with the Bounty Green Select-a-size rolls.  The sheets are perforated at the halfway point, so you can use 1/2 or 3/2 sheets if you want.  We often just grab a 1/2 sheet at a time, and the rolls last way longer compared to pulling a full sheet every time.  Also, they look and feel way better than Basic Bounty.

I'm giving this set 5 stars on one quality alone:  it's a true ambidextrous set.  Using your R or L hand are equally easy to cut paper and cardboard.  A lot of scissors that are labeled as ambidextrous are really good with R hand use, but leaving the L hand lacking (either in comfort or cutting ability).  So I applaud this set for making it imperceptible which hand I'm using to cut.But there are other things that not so good about this set, and really are 2-3 star.  The build quality of the set is really variable.  Some scissors were totally awesome and opened and closed very smoothly with little effort.  Some scissors were mediocre and either were too tight or too loose to open and close.  Some had very smooth cutting edges.  Some had very rough cutting edges that made them harder to open and close.  For little hands who don't have a lot of power nor dexterity yet, the bad scissors are a real disservice.  I'd like to say that the bad scissors were rare, but quite a few of the scissors in the set were sub-par.  That's pretty disappointing...

It's a very nice case.  It smells faintly, not strongly, of leather, which is good for my nose.  It's a rich blue hue.  Only quibble is that the top and bottom of the phone are not completely covered, just know that before purchasing (but also makes it easier to take off and switch).  Otherwise it's quite a handsome case, especially for those like to color accessorize.Also comes with:  Screen protector (shouldn't really need it), cleaning cloth (you'll probably loose it anyways), small semi-soft plastic edge to remove bubbles when installing the screen protector.

It's very easy to spot where more seeds need to be thrown or which spots have already been done adequately. I used a metal rake to rough up the top layer of dirt and then just sprinkled the seeds. After that, I left the seeds alone and counted on the occasional sprinkle or dew to water them, Very easy to do and did not require a lot of maintenance to start growth.

It's very easy to spot where more seeds need to be thrown or which spots have already been done adequately since the seeds are coated uniformly blue. I used a metal rake to rough up the top layer of dirt and then just sprinkled the seeds. After that, I left the seeds alone and counted on the occasional hose sprinkle or dew to water them, Very easy to do and did not require a lot of maintenance to start growth.

The last Operation game I bought was so cheaply built, it was insulting.  Maybe since this is now a licensed product, Hasbro decided to make it a little nicer quality.  Now the game board seems a bit sturdier and better able to withstand the rough treatment young kids dish out.There is a nice mix of very easy to hard pieces to retrieve.  They are quite small, so I suggest a Ziplock bag for storage.

Very easy and fun to apply with the kids since the seeds are coated blue.  It's very easy to spot where more seeds need to be thrown or which spots have already been done adequately.  I used a metal rake to rough up the top layer of dirt and then just sprinkled the seeds.  After that, I left the seeds alone and counted on the occasional sprinkle or dew to water them,  Very easy to do and did not require a lot of maintenance to start growth.

After I built this monstrous set, no other ship in my fleet could even compare.  I was riding pretty high, laughing at all the puny ships that my friends were bringing to my party (of their destruction!)Somehow my shield generator got blown up by a few mosquito sized fighters.  So rude!  Then ANOTHER little fighter with a screaming guy crashed into my bridge and all my work went crashing down.  Man, I thought my shields were a little stronger than that... I'll have to update the instructions on page 99,905 to make the shield generator casing stronger.  Maybe add a few more Technic pieces...

Installs fairly easy straight into drywall.  I did try to use at least one stud when mounting the rails.  It has held multiple shovels/rakes and various tools with aplomb over the whole winter.  The rails haven't gotten loose at all yet.

The actual housing of the feeder itself is very attractive and clear/clean plastic.  The suction cups, however, not so much so.  When I first took it out of the box, they looked old (white discoloration, like old plastic) and felt stiff.  But, after cleaning the window and the cups with a little Windex, they seem to be okay.  The bottom cup definitely sticks better than the top cup.  So far in sun, rain, and direct sunlight, the feeder has stayed plastered to my window.  They don't look as good from the back side, and if the manufacturer would switch the sourcing of the suction cups, it would make the whole unit look better out of the box.I put sunflower seed in my feeder, though you can also do thistle with the included adapters.  It also comes with a small wooden perch if you elect thistle seeds.  The package says that once you pick the type of seed, it's permanent.  However, I was easily able to attach and detach the sunflower adapters that have small built in perches.  I didn't try the thistle as I definitely don't plan on using that seed.  The seed reservoir is easy to slide in and out.  I mounted it on my window out of reach of the squirrels but near a bush so birds can hide/play in there.

Don't be daunted by the sheer size and weight of the box.  Once you unpack and separate out the pieces, it turns into a more normal sized kitchen appliance.  But, so much better quality than what you might typically purchase.  The stainless steel components and heft really make you feel like you just bought something of quality and longevity, unlike so many kitchen appliances sold these days.The quality of construction and generously powerful motor makes pretty much all kitchen tasks easy.  It's particularly evident when you are using the dough hook and need little more power than the average mixer.  The test I haven't got a chance to run was ice in the blender since my ice maker is currently broken, but from how it's handled everything else, I don't think that's going to be a problem.My only quibbles are twofold:1.  Using the food processor/blender attachments is kinda weird since they attach at the top of the machine.  In fact, shorter people will not like this or may just deal with it and get a step stool.  Tall people may actually like this, since it'll be more at their level.2.  It's too heavy to put away.  Our KA mixer has it's spot in a cabinet to keep the counter space uncluttered.  You're probably not going to want to do that with the hefty Kenwood, so scope out a permanent spot for it before you buy.  On the other hand, the Kenwood is really a space saving 3 in 1 machine.Fortunately, I have a short empty minicounter in my kitchen as well, and may just stick the Kendwood there as it's resting home, which takes care of both minor inconveniences.  I don't mind leaving it out since it's such a good looking appliance.

It's a USB mouse with a generous braided cord (with velcro cord band too!).  It's truly plug and play, no software/drivers are needed nor included. Hooray!  The polling and DPI switches are hardwired in the mouse itself.  I actually like that since I hate loading extra drivers for keyboards and mice.  This makes this mouse exceedingly simple to set up and use. I need the mouse mostly for cursor movement and plot everything out on the keyboard (I don't want the mouse to morph into a keyboard too).  That said, there are not a whole lot of buttons on this mouse relative to other slightly more expensive gaming mice.  I guess this will depend on your setup style.  The scroll wheel is quick and sits right below your middle phalanx of your finger.  I wished they moved it ever slightly more forward so that I could move the wheel with the tip of my finger more easily.  Major surfaces are coated with a thin silicone layer that helps grip and feels good.  I have small to average size hands, and the mouse is comfortable for me.  People with large hands should probably look elsewhere.  Overall, this mouse has a very nice quality feel.In terms of performance, I found it to be VERY accurate, fast gliding, and decently light.  Some gamers like the control of DPI on the fly switching.  I was never into that, and so I'm fine with the switches on the *bottom* of the mouse.  Switch choices are Polling 125, 500,1000 Hz and DPI 500, 1000, 1750.I also recently reviewed an fantastic mouse pad from Turtle Beach as well, which would go well with this mouse if you want a nice gaming duo.(Previous mice = Various Logitech optical and laser, MSFT gaming mouse)

Flouride is very good for your teeth and that this product seems to have a little more than their standard formulation.  I can't really do an objective or even subjective test on my own teeth that my enamel is getting stronger day by day, but I can tell you about some other qualities,  I love Tom's peppermint Whole Care toothpaste for it's pleasing "flavor" (not sugary) and low suds factor.  The peppermint oil is perfect, not too strong and not artificial tasting.  If I can get a good sale on it, I stock up.  This enamel one basically retains all the great qualities of the regular one with a little extra flouride.

REALLY nice mouse pad.  You can feel the difference of smoothness and gliding ability of your mouse instantly (both much better).  Grippy surface on the back.  Even though it comes rolled up in a small box, it unrolls easily and lays flat.The large pad is ideal for large high resolution monitors when you have to travel a bit across the screen, yet don't want to bother changing your DPI resolution on the mouse.  I wish it had a gel pad for the wrist, but that will have to be bought as an additional accessory.

This spreader is ideal for very small lawns, like small square patches.  For grass seed, I'd just use my hand, but you don't want fertilizer to clump together on the ground or the grass will die fast, hence the spreader for fertilizer.For a few dollars more, you can get *Scotts 71133 Handy Green II Hand-Held Broadcast Spreader*, which has the same rotator mechanism on the bottom, but has the added arm rest.  If you are doing a larger lawn without a push spreader, then the #71133 is a better tool.  The basins are shaped slightly differently, but they both hold basically the same amount of stuff.

My 3rd grader enjoyed this book a lot.  He has a special affinity for robots as he has been building Lego bionicles and hero factory sets forthe last couple of years, designing very intricate sets way beyond what can be bought on the shelf.Compared to other series, he says that this bookis much simpler to read than the Redwall series or Harry Potter, which he read last year.  It is more advanced than Ricky Ricotta or Captain Underpants.I asked him who would enjoy this book and he said, "Boys who like robots, gadgets, and thing-a-ma-jigs.  "How about girls?" I asked.  He said "Maybe".  (The main character is a boy and the robot, and girls get the minor parts.)

So easy to setup.  So easy to use.  The filter is set at it's height just below the spout, no adjustment like a regular french press mechanism.  However, that's perfectly fine as the whole point of the filter is to filter out the solids, and this works well for that purpose.  Whether the solids stay on top or bottom is not terribly consequential.  However, it does look better to have stuff at the bottom, because sometimes things stick to the sides when only half full, and it doesn't present as well per se.  Also, as can be seen from the picture, it'd be impractical to have a metal rod that long.The glass is relatively thin for a pitcher, but what's what I expect from borosilicate glassware.  From my days in a bench lab to my favorite tea cup, borosilicate glass is always thin.  If anything, it makes a full pitcher of water easier to pick up while still being strong.  It also held up well in the bottom rack of my dishwasher.I took off one star since my glass pitcher came with some kind of small stain in the upper rim.  It didn't come off with friction, even though you can feel it, and even with an overnight water soak and hot dishwasher.  Still there.

The bracing for this wipers look very similar to the Bosch wipers that I had installed on our Highlander just a few months ago (except for a more knobby attachment site)  I thought could this be a Bosch copy, and maybe that could be good since the Bosch are fantastic wipers.Beside the look, the easy installation, and quiet performance, unfortunately, they are not as good as the Bosch as I had hoped.  In the up-stroke, after about half-way up, a large streak of water can be seen right in the middle of the windshield.  Thankfully, the down-stroke completely cleans off the windshield.  But that's not good enough for wipers, they really need to work well up and down.  You know?

At under $14, this is a handy garden tool to have.  It disperses fairly evenly and the handle is very easy to rotate, even fast if you want.  The selector switch (1-6) moves pretty easily as well.When you hold it, you must use your left hand as the rotating handle is on the right side only.  You also put your arm through the rear hole so that your left forearm can act as a brace to counter the "heft" of the full hopper.  It's a great design that makes holding this for long periods of time very easy.  (Though truly, if you are going to use it for long periods of time to cover a large area, then you're much better off with a push spreader).  Even my preschooler had a lot of fun spreading grass seed with it.I do not suggest walking very fast while using it as some of whatever you're spreading will then get on your pant legs and shoes.

Unlike many other diaper creams, this one is very pleasant to apply.  It's actually more like a think lotion, and almost all of it gets off your finger after application.  It also doesn't smell.  I think it's best application is for prevention or mild diaper rash.Many other diaper creams leave a layer on your finger after you're finished and you need soap and water to get it off.  Of course, if you just put your finger around your baby's bottom, I'd still wash your hands with soap and water, but only for sanitary reasons, not because there is a bunch of sticky leftover diaper cream on your finger!If your kid has severe diaper rash I find that only high content Zinc diaper creams work.  My favorite brands are Balmex and the blue advanced A&D.  Even Target's Up and Up high Zn cream works well too.

We've been using Neutrogena sun block for years on ourselves and the kids with good results.  Usually, we buy the Costco multipack on sale.  Target's Up & Up Kid's sun block works well too, and is inexpensive.This particular Cool Dry Sport pretty much met my expectation for a Neutrogena product.  That is, it goes on smootly, does not irritate the eyes, and works well.  The small hole helps to measure out small drops to put on the face. I would consider it to have a medium strength smell, akin to male cologne.  So, this is more for adults, unless you want the kids to smell "manly".

This is a very nice unit with solid build quality.  The cuff is very simple to insert in the machine and is very comfortable to wear.  Initially, I was wondering why the cuff has such a stiff built in roll, then I realized that it makes putting on and strapping the cuff much easier to do with one hand.  The buttons are solid and easy to push.  The instructions are spot-on.  The wall adapter has enough length to leave it comfortably on a desk if the outlet is not too too far away; the batteries (4 AA) option is great for travel.  It stores 100 measurements per person (2 people = 200) that is also portable via Bluetooth to your smartphone (easily found on Google Play store, but not on Amazon store).  You do have to set up an account with Omron to access the app.  Otherwise, you can have a "guest" option that takes a reading, but won't save it.The cuff is quite long, and can accommodate fairly large upper arms, but if your BMI is like 40-50 with very thick upper arms, you might find it to be easier to use on your forearm.  The readings were very similar from upper arm to forearm on myself with one exception when I was also turning pages while a reading was being taken.

Not exactly the quality I was expecting for $20...It's not really wood.  The figures, animals and clothes are pressed board.  Not even thin plywood, which I would have agreed could be called wooden figures.  Also, there are only TWO animals, a cow and pig.  This is a pretty small farm.  Not even a chicken or dog.The Melissa and Doug sets, which this company seems to try and emulate, are much higher quality, including using real wood pieces.On the positive, the magnets are not too strong nor weak.  The drawings are cute.  The pieces are cut well with no rough edges.I could go with $10 as more reasonable price.

Definitely a heavy duty stapler.  It punches through lots of thick paper with ease.  But you can only use it with thick stacks of paper since the staple tips do curl back up through the front if it's too thin.  The picture accurately shows the stapler in resting position.  As in, the plunger is open and visible, so this is not going win any beauty awards on your desk.  On the other hand, other heavy duty staplers are much larger and have that long handle that sticks out for leverage, so the Rapesco may save you a little desk area.Setup tip:  When I first opened up the stapler all the way to 180 degrees, it got stuck and I had to bang it gently on my thigh to get it to close back up.  After a few times of this, it now will open up all the way to 180 degrees and close back up without problem.Staple types = sheets of paper24/6mm = 2-30923/8mm = 30-50923/10mm = 40-70923/12mm = 60-90

Good product.  Very gentle, yet has good cleaning power.  I even tried it on my own 2 day old oily hair , feels very clean afterwards.  Of course, I tried it on my kids as well, and it works well for their hair and body too.  It doesn't foam up a whole lot (tip: foaming has NOTHING to do with cleaning power, consumers just like to see it) and the smell is very light and nice.  Once you rinse off, there is not much smell left at all.Dispensing is very easy out of the bottle, and has the nice little silicone stopper opening so you don't get accidental seepage/spills.

This is a fairly sturdy gate, a bit short, but fully capable of holding back a toddler from escaping.  It came well packed, no scuff marks, and with all the pieces, including drywall screws (x4).  The instructions were clear, but if you only go by the pictures, it'll be a bit confusing from the way they draw the gate pieces.  Just make sure to look at the "letter" parts and then you should have no problem putting the gate together in the configuration that you want.The auto close works as advertised by a small plastic piece in the shape of the triangle at the hinge.  If the door is open all the way to flat part of the triangle, the gate will stay open.  If you open it up only to the slanted part of the triangle, the gate will close by itself.  This works whether you open the gate towards or away from yourself.My qualms with the gate are two fold:1.  It's not as quiet as advertised.  I thought that it would be a soft closing sound, but instead it's a fairly loud clank as the plastic lock engages.  It is quieter than the Summer Infant full metal gate when it closes hard, but not by much.2.  The colors are kinda ugly.  Who has dark wood and grey metal on a staircase or wall?  It'll be hard to color coordinate if you desire to do so.

Upfront, the Rapesco is a totally awesome stapler and deserves a 5/5 star rating.  I recommend using Rapesco staples for best results, but you can get by with that ol' box of Swingline staples if needed.I tried stapling cardstock, thin cardboard, Amazon box cardboard, and regular old copy paper folded to multiple sheet thickness (from 2 up to 16 sheet thickness).The Rapesco has the best finish of all the staplers, and generally speaking also requires the least exertion to staple besides the Swingline Lighttouch.  The best finish is because as I felt the back of the staple, you can feel the bumps of the Swingline staples (which got my finger sore after all this trialing) versus the flat Rapesco stapler's finish.  Even when you pull the pages apart, the Swingline curved staples jut out just a bit more.Rapesco has a nice gentle spring for loading staples.  It also comes with small piece that sits on top of the staple refill so that it stays in position as the handles closes.  This is in stark contrast to the Swingline staples which have a very strong spring that snaps shut really fast and hard; sometimes the staples do not sit right during closure.  Also, if you get your finger tip accidentally caught when the handle comes to close on the Swingline, it hurts like a b****.The Swingline Lighttouch was by far and away the EASIEST stapler to use (in terms of pressure needed to staple) but it is a bit bigger than the Raspesco and of course doesn't leave the staples nice and flat on the back.

Braven is really going gung-ho in making high quality, well thought out speakers lately.  In fact, it's rare to find such incredibly good packaging and thoughtful design in equivalent tier speakers or even ones that cost a bit more.What lies inside a regular cardboard box will probably leave you pretty impressed, and that's before you even turn it on.Packaging:  First off, it comes nicely protected in thick Styrofoam casing, with two solid plastic clip straps that make sure they stay together.  It's probably more for stylistic points, but it looks nice and you can certainly find other uses for the two straps.Accessories:  Wow, I couldn't believe my eyes, INTERNATIONAL PLUG adapters.  So, if you want to host your pool party or pick an extra contractor job in Europe, you're set...  I figure Bravia just wanted to ship one unit internationally, and the cheapest way to do that for them was to include the major adapters needed.  The adapters are tips only, and easily snap into the back of the wall-wart.  A 3.5 inch AUX cable and Micro-USB cables are included as well.Build quality:  Top-notch.  The silicone casing is thick and basically perfect all around.  The only break in the silicone is the side panel where you access the plugs.  That panel is perfectly smooth and flat when closed.  The speakers have a nice brushed aluminum finish, non-glossy.  Small LEDs for the battery level are perfectly aligned and just bright enough. Overall, it's feels like a quality piece in your hands.Bluetooth paring:  Easy and picks up every time.  With direct line of sight, I was able to get 180-200 feet away down my driveway before the music started to break-up.  For pool parties, and especially contractor jobs, it's nice to have that range of movement.Sound quality:  For a 2 hands size speaker, they are pretty good.  The bass is certainly lacking on my HTC One phone with Beats Audio, but an EQ app is able to increase the bass response.  At high volumes, the bass can majorly distort, no surprise there.  The mids are stand out and are very clear and clean, even blasting the speaker at high volume.  So vocals are easily heard and distinguished even at very high volumes."Extra benefits":  Water resistance.  Shock absorbing silicone exterior that is also slip resistant.  This thing will even charge your phone/tablet.  So, it becomes a portable battery as well, may be good for those who get a lot power outages.  Maybe your phone is running out of juice at the party/work site and you just happen to have this speaker around!

Really nice quality.  Thin, yet effective as pot holders.  I also have the red silicone gloves, but they are much bulkier to use.  The caveat is for deep or top ovens, the silicone gloves cover your wrists and part of your forearms as well.  These are just pot holders, so they're just for hand protection and holding light items.  A joy to use!

This is a very slick looking headset.  Aesthetically, I'd give it five stars.  It's also super light and flexible which makes you forget that you're even wearing it.  I got the hang of the controls after wearing it just once.  Basically, volume and talk on L, music controls on the R.  The buttons are easy to find and push with tactile feel while wearing the headset.It paired up with my HTC One phone with no problem, and repeated pairings were no hassle.  I just turn the headset on and it connects without problem.Listening to music was a pleasure, though I had to boot up a EQ program on my phone to glean a little extra bass out.  Various types of music were clear and vocals were decent.  I'd say these compare favorably to other $20-40 dedicated headphones.  Very decent, even sound.  And when you're done, the buds magnetically pop into holding position at the end of the headset.  It's nice not to have a dangling cord.Talking on the phone was very easy, if a little clunky dialing out using Android.  Voices were crystal clear.

The best feature of this toy is the portability.  It's easy to stack the cups within each other and pop the top on.  A small twist and the top is fairly secure, making this a truly portable toy that fits easily in a purse or diaper bag.As far as stacking goes, you're acutally better off with the traditional FP rings on a pole for little ones.  The Playskool version cups are easy to grap and stacks easily, but do not have a lot of lip on them.  Little 9 months old babies at the beginning stages of learning how to stack are not going to be able to stack CAREFULLY and PRECISELY enough and will topple this set a lot and probably not get much past 2-3 cups stacked until they are a bit older.One solution:  The middle of each cup has a cutout shape, and if you put a chopstick in the middle that will provide a little support to stack all the cups without completley toppling over.

Same prep time, and the noodles came out perfectly.  No broken pieces and no excessive stickiness.  Tastes what you expect multigrain pasta to taste like with all the extra nutritional benefits.  The texture is just slightly chewier than regular semolina pasta.When you look at the nutritional information, note that you should look at the 2 oz servings info, as that is the usual serving size on other boxes of pasta (they list a whopping 17 g of protein... but then it's for 3.5 oz serving).  Also, it's pretty good on vitamin nutrition for pasta, but not so so much better than an "enriched" pasta product.  The fiber % is basically double, though.
KJV Verses...wonderful DVD!  It's very well put together and my two year old knows all 26 verses!  They have other wonderful dvds as well.You can read my entire review here:  [...]
advertises 92 but i only get 88. great sounds for sleeping. my baby loves the humming which isnt on the free...plus on the premium, u can have it in the background on ur kindle fire.

the premium version allows you to play sounds in the background on your kindle fire while letting you do other things on your kindle. if u like the free version...i think its worth the upgrade...and i rarely pay for apps.
you have to go online to awebsite to get the kjv version. not a great setup............ ...... ... .... ...
the game is fun but easily beaten and it doesnt always save your progress.,  its free and the ads arent too bad...but i dont like to replay missions that i have already accomplished.

i love this game but the cards are backwards and the players dont play with skill. been playing it for a few days and it has frozen up on my fire under the game over tab. i can click on the options but nothing happens. will have to uninstall.
gives you three phases but it doesn't keep yourscore for three phases. you really only get to play one phase at a time.
much better than using a usb. very fast and easy. glad I found this app. works great on my kindle fire. highly reccommend this application.  God bless you all!
and fun. good to pass the time and makes u think. I like it pretty well. works great on kindle fire. no problems.

I cant see all my national stores and some of the ones I can, have no info. there is no way to search for an item and you cant see the size of the product, so if your ad matching at walmsrt, you still need to look at a physical ad to be sure. sometimes it doesn't load properly and I have to relaunch it.

For those people who haven't tried them before, these Hershey's candies are obviously, a competitor of M&Ms.  In my experience at least, a lot of pseudo-M&Ms have kind of an off-taste, but not these.  They are different, but excellent in their own right. Piece for piece, these candies are a little larger than a typical plain M&M candy,  and 1 pound goes along way. My only complaint is that when I received the tin, a surprisingly large number of the candy is hard shells had shattered and broken off the chocolate.  I can only assume this comes from abuse during the shipping process: candies banging and rattling against each other inside of the metal container kind of like lapidary rocks.  It doesn't affect the flavor, but it does affect the presentation.

The color and style match our newly renovated contemporary blue-gray kitchen. They're soft, highly absorbent, and work especially well for drying plates and glassware and buffing solid countertops to a shine.  We haven't noticed anything quite as groundbreakingly miraculous about the fabric as the ad copy suggests, but they're soft, bargain-priced and work well.

It's good to have a few of these lying around.  Their short length is convenient for use with my 5-port desktop Anker USB hub, which is an organizational hassle when it gets filled with a bunch of 1-2m regular length cables.  Also more convenient than the long calves for travel packing - minimal need to coil / detangle in my travel pouch.
I bought this as a practical present for my son, age 12, to include in his school backpack. Works great:  it's durable and reliable it is easy for him to pack.

My son, age 12, is pretty independent-minded about his clothes and suspicious of anything we get him.  To my surprise, though, this hoodie one him over almost immediately. He wears around the house, to school, and as a replacement for a light jacket when the weather permits. So comfortable, my wife (5' 1") almost claimed it for her own.

This is a significantly updated version of the 2003 original, containing clarified rules, more content from later books in the GoT series, and some slightly improved components.  A very fun game which emphasizes negotiation and backstabbing between players. If you aren't an experienced gamer or you're planning to introduce this to casual gamers or nongamers who are interested in the GoT franchise, be aware that this isn't a true "gateway" game like Catan or Ticket to Ride, etc. The rules are not overly complex, but they do take some focus to learn.

Extraordinarily lightweight and easy to maneuver on 4 wheels (upright) or 2 (tilted).  I wish there was an external compartment like some hardside suitcases for easier access to small items, but the inside storage is excellent.  One side has clip straps and the other a zippered section, so it's pretty easy to segregate clothes by type or by clean/dirty.  There also is a small internal zippered pouch which is good for storing small electronics or toiletries. The outer shell is durable, but the finish - which looks great new out of the box - collects fingerprints and abrasions and looks worn-in pretty quickly.
Tough, easy to shuffle, and durable.  The matte colors look sharp.  These are the sleeves of choice for all three of the MtG players in my family.

Very convenient and easy to use.  The initial setup process is super easy, and the headphones themselves talk you through the process.  It took my wife around 20 seconds to set up the first time.  The Bluetooth connection to her iPhone was excellent - rock solid and speedy to connect even after power cycling and dormant periods.  Long battery life, easy to control.The sound quality is excellent and has reasonably well-balanced treble/bass.  Noise isolation was very good in situations involving droning noises (airplanes, trains) and "good" the rest of the time.  (the passive noise blocking isn't as good as the in-ear, earplug-style headphones I usually use, so you can still hear extraneous noise from people, cars, trucks and whatnot fairly clearly).The new Soundlinks are fairly large.  They fit my large head just fine, but they're kind of overlarge on my wife's comparatively small noggin'.  They make her feel a little self-conscious wearing them, and I don't think either of us would want to work out or do anything really active with such large headgear.  Also, while they're very comfortable, they can feel a little hot after extended wear in warm weather.

If you already are a fan of Fluxx or one of its other variants, Adventure Time Fluxx is going to be totally familiar to you and easy to pick up.  There are a few modest changes to the rule mechanics (e.g., Creepers), and of course the cards are heavily themed to match the Adventure Time cartoon, and many of the Goals are at least loosely related to the plots of the show. But on the whole, it's much the same game as basic Fluxx.  If you like the original you'll like this one too. Conversely, if you already own one of the other games (Fluxx or Star Fluxx), then I really think there isn't much reason to buy this one unless you are a big-time Adventure Time fan.If you're new to Fluxx, then the basic idea is that it's a sort of a "metagame," where you start with a small hand of cards and a minimal set of rules, mechanics and goals, and as the game progresses - drawing and playing cards - your actions change the very rules you are following and goals you are pursuing. The strategy, such as it is, is to manipulate those rules and goals so that you are able to fulfill them, thereby winning (and ending) the game. It's a "good" casual game but not a classic. IMHO, its chief disadvantage is that the game has a tendency to feel kind of random because all the unpredictable changes make it impossible to plan much of a long term strategy.  The game length also is very unpredictable: it can end in five minutes, or it can still be going after an hour. It's a good casual game to pull out from time to time, and easy to teach kids and novice players.

Great power, easy to handle, terrific range and good aiming precision. The only downside is that it shoots almost TOO powerfully for close range, which can lead to arguments between younger kids. The hose attachment is great for backyard battles.

My wife uses this case & gets a lot of positive comments from friends and strangers about how nice it looks.  It's hard to tell from the photos, but it has a very striking appearance:  quite a bit different than the run of the mill plastic or bedazzled cases you can buy in the mall. Snug fit and decent protection, too.

The SharpFire Blaster is a fun toy at a good price point, and the detachable stock gives you some neat options to hold you darts and change the size/shape of the gun.  The two main downsides are that the practical shooting range isn't as long as many other Nerf guns, and the detachable stock feels a little flimsy in rough play. But for the low cost, you can't really go wrong.  (Battle tested by my 9- and 11-year old sons and me, as part of a small arsenal of other Nerf blasters of various designs and price points that we've accumulated over the years.)

This is a terrible, terrible cable. I bought it from a local branch of a big box retailer, mainly to connect my iPhone to my work computer so that it can stay charged during the workday. Simply put, it doesn't work reliably. My work computer and iPhone both report frequent disconnection / reconnections even though both plugs are firmly attached and left untouched to one side of my desk. Charging happens in slow motion, around half the speed of the frayed Apple-branded cable it was meant to replace. From time to time, my computer reports errors "with the attached USB device." Just avoid this piece of junk and get something more reliable.

This a good multipurpose notebook computer.  We got it for miscellaneous use around the house, and as a backup computer for use running Word, Excel, Chrome, etc., by our two young students (we have two kids entering grades 4-6 but only one desktop computer).  It's relatively large and thick, but light and well-built. Definitely portable, but a bit clunkier than a true "light and portable" notebook.  The screen is bright and colorful, but while the native resolution of 1366x768 is plenty sharp enough for browsing and office apps, it's got a noticeably lower pixel density than the typical HD screen on a modern tablet.Here are some benchmarks, for people who are into that sort of thing.  Geekbench 3 scores:  32-bit / single core: 2602, multi-core: 5137  64-bit / single core: 2792, multi-core: 5528You can compare them other models on the Geekbench website.  In short, this is perfectly workmanlike performance, but it's not going set anyone's hair on fire.  When the system gets really taxed by anything (games mostly, but you'll see something similar when running intensive photo/video editing apps or benchmarks) the fan kicks in at a fairly high volume. With the system's modest speed and built-in Intel 5500 graphics, you certainly can play some games but it isn't the best use of this model. Frame rates and visual detail on 3D graphical games are going to be limited, and the fan is going to blasting all the time.

Another great high fantasy novel from Terry Brooks; and if it's not quite up to the standard of his best works then it's indisputable that there still is some very good storytelling from the old master.  Certainly it's essentialfor Shannara completists (like more than one person in my family).  Although it's billed as a standalone novel, I think you're going to appreciate it more if you've read The High Druid's Blade and some of the other, earlier Shannara books.  The ending is satisfying, but a little melancholy.

A good, clean, masculine fragrance that both my wife and I really like. A grown-up's cologne that carries a light touch of citrus and floral that lasts a long time without an intrusive cloud of scent. Good for day or evening use.

This chair is big and comfortable.  My wife and kids immediately started jockeying for it, and three weeks later it's still the most popular chair in the room.  Soft without being too soft, and large without taking over the entire room.  So far the recliner mechanism seems reliable and easy to use, but we'll have to wait a few months or years to get a real feel for its true durability.  Looking at the internal components, my guess is that this chair will be very durable, though it doesn't seem to have the same super-heavy construction of some of the higher-end chairs you can buy at a higher price point.  Although I was a little concerned with the idea of "faux" leather upholstery, in person it looks very good, and the feel is terrific (sort of a cross between distressed leather and suede).Finally, I have to throw out some kudos to Amazon's local delivery service, which was great.  They worked around our schedule, arranged a tight delivery window, and came when promised.  The chair arrived in great shape.  It breaks into two pieces (the upholstered top and the rocking frame) and can be relocated fairly easily.

My family found this software is very easy to operate and easy to learn to use even with minimal reference to the manuals or online support.  It's very fast when converting and editing videos and sound, and my son loves it for making his Minecraft YouTube videos. It is surprisingly good at making video intros. No glitches or bugs that we've seen yet.

This spinner is almost unbelievably light - effortless for my 11 yo child to handle even when full - and yet the frame is stiff and protective without the kind of alarming bending and popping you sometimes see on cheap no-name hardside bags.  Crucially, too, it has really sturdy wheels, handle, hinge and latch.  Internal storage options are pretty good for a hardside (though I find hardside bags in general don't have as much internal organization as a good soft side bag) and the telescoping handle and wheels doesn't take up too much of the internal space that otherwise could be holding possessions. It has been an easy fit in every airplane upper cabin compartment that I've tried it on so far, including older Southwest 737planes.  I think this is a top quality bag, through retail pricing is pretty stiff - I strongly recommend you keep your eyes open for deals to knock a few dollars off list price.

You already know the basic story from the publisher's description:  Sometime in the near future, something ("the Agent") unexpectedly breaks apart the Moon, and leaves behind a rapidly-disappating cloud of debris, some of which enters degenerating orbits with the Earth.  Within a couple of weeks, scientists and governments realize that in approximately 2 years the Earth will be sterilized by a rain of lunar rocks that will last thousands of years.  The first 2/3 of the novel follows a large cast of characters as they prepare to build, stock and escape into an orbiting habitat that would allow them to avoid the sterilizing hellfire of that bombardment.  And the last 1/3 introduces a new cast of future characters and addresses what happens afterwards.I've a long-time fan of Neal Stephenson, but skewing to his earlier works (Snow Crash, Cryptonomicon, Anathem) more so than his recent novels.  As usual, in this book Stephenson is a world-builder par excellence.  I really enjoyed the story, along with all of the engineering, scientific and political problems the lead characters grappled with as time marched on.  Stephenson viscerally conveys just how difficult and dangerous the project would be - how many technical problems would have to be solved, how many resources poured into it.  I'd highly recommend this book to anyone who enjoyed Anathem, which this book reminded me of in many respects.All the same, this was not a perfect book.  I know that most people are going to say that Seveneves is a "long book" (and it is), but if anything, I think most of the shortcomings of this story are that in places events felt rushed and characters underdeveloped.  Some of my more specific comments and critique, INCLUDING SPOILERS, follow below:(1) Although I loved some of the characters ("Doc" Dubois (aka Neal DeGrasse Tyson), Sean Probst (aka Elon Musk / Jeff Bezos), Dinah, Ivy and a few others), but on the whole, I didn't feel an especially deep emotional connection to the individual characters.  Billions of people died Earthside, and yet most of the time it felt like a pretty remote detail.  You could write a whole book the characters soming to terms with these kinds of issues, but here that sort of thing was just a background event, a table-setter for the chosen engineering narrative.  And the actions / reactions of many of the main characters were frankly inconceivable much of the time.  In fact, the parts of the book that were the least believable to me were the parts most heavy with human interactions, in part because most of their personalities and motivations seemed either underdeveloped, inscrutable, or 2-dimensional.  That's a great pity.(2) My biggest nit to pick with the plot is that the big "twist" that happens at the 2/3 point of the book is given away by the publishers in their ad copy.  Hint: it's not just the people in orbit who survive the calamity.  But if this *was* meant to be some kind of narrative surprise, why did the publisher let the cat out of the bag?  Why did Stephenson himself give it away so many times, and so many ways, in the text?  On the other hand, if the survival of people Earthside *wasn't* meant to be a narrative surprise, then why was the subject (a very important one, I'd argue) virtually ignored by the cast of main and secondary characters, by the US President, and the novel's otherwise fairly detailed description of the Earthside political situation?  Certainly the Earthside political leaders - all of whom knew that at best only a couple of thousand people would make into the orbital ark - would have tried to take steps to shelter people underground by building sprawling shelters in deep caves, former mines and filled-over quarries.  This kind of thing is bound to spawn a long speculative Reddit thread someday, but at a minimum, wouldn't the subterranean preppers have had a lot of adcantages over the ones in orbit?  They could have stockpiled almost unlimited tools, generated unlimited power, accessed mineral resources and water, experienced Earth-normal gravity and enjoyed total protection from cosmic radiation and explosive decompression, just for starters.  The subject could have merited an entire book of its own:  maybe Stephenson will write a sequel focusing on this side of the story.(3) Anyway, as we know Stephenson instead chose to focus his narrative on the people who choose to evacuate Earth.  Much of it was thrilling, and all of it was interesting.  All the same, I kept thinking that some of the just-so occurrences happened mainly because they were convenient for purposes of driving the story.  For instance, no engineers at any space or defense agency thought about running a propellant-needs projection for Izzy and the Cloud?  Really?  How is this possible, except as pure artifice to set up the Sean Probst subplot?  Also, after going through so many unexpected perils and technical difficulties that resulted in something like a 99.5% mortality rate for the people in orbit, how are we to understand that once Izzy reached Cleft everything (including particularly the same food production system that failed so spectacularly through the entire Cloud and doomed its residents to cannibalism) suddenly started working perfectly for decades, giving the remaining 8 women time to lead long lives and begin repopulating the species?  I have no idea.  Again, a whole book could have been written explaining these kinds of things, too.I give this 3.5 stars, rounded down.  A fun read, but not one of Stephenson's better works.

I was introduced to Luxardo cherries late last year by my father, and then I started noticing how these are THE cherries used by almost every upscale bar / restaurant I visited.  These are absolutely great, and I will never willingly go back to the crazy artificially-colored neon-red supermarket brands.  Simply no comparison:  Luxardos are smaller, more natural and intensely-flavored.  The perfect Maraschino cherries for classic cocktails like the Manhattan, Rob Roy, Martinez, Old Fashioned, etc.

This is a very nice saute pan.  Foods slide off really easily, and after several weeks of use it seems to be more durable than most nonstick pans I've tried.  The size is large enough to cook for a family of four, anything from veggie stir fry to eggs to meats with good movement and easy cleanup.  The only real disadvantages are that it's hand wash-only and use should be limited to moderate - rather than extreme - fry temperatures (both limitations are typical of most nonstick pans).

I've got a medium-large house with a few wifi dead spots in some areas, so I was looking for a base station with more power.  In short, the AC1750 works pretty well for normal use, but I was disappointed to learn this doesn't really seem to be the high-performing wifi router the ad copy claims.Before installing this router I took a series of baseline wifi strength measurements all over my house using an ios wifi analyzer app of the signal strength for my existing 2013 model Apple AirPort Extreme (which, as of the day I wrote this review, is available for +/-5 dollars of this AC1750).  Then I powered down the Extreme, and installed the AC1750 in the exact same location, following all the manufacturer's directions, and connected to the 2.4 Ghz band. Wireless speed was about the same, but signal strength was noticeably WORSE in many parts of the house for the new AC1750 than it was for the Extreme. I checked multiple times, repositioned the antennae, rechecked firmware settings to ensure radio power was at 100%, and tested again.  Once again the new AC1750 matched the Extreme's performance in around half my house, but in the rest of my house the AC1750 noticeably lagged.  And the 5Ghz range was simply dismal...two rooms away, and I was at one bar and dodgy speed. So the Extreme wins narrowly but indisputedly at wireless range, and because it wins hands-down at reliability (years of use with no need to reboot or debug) I'm sorry to say that the AC1750 is going back into the box.  To be a really compelling choice, for my dollar, the AC1750 really needs to undercut the Extreme by around 25-30% on price.

I have two kids (9 & 11 yo) who incessantly borrow my wife's iPad Mini and subject it to drops, fingerprints and the occasional close encounter with foods and drink. This case fits the iPad Mini 2 perfectly: all buttons, switches and camera lenses are unobstructed. Based on a few weeks of use and travel, I think it'll stand up to most routine neglect and protect the tablet inside from the occasional accident that even careful kids sometime make. I found it easy to snap together, and the case is strong and its components sturdy (though I figure only half the money you pay for this is going to the cost of the case itself:  probably half is going into the manufacturer's reserve for its insurance / warrantees against breakage).I'm docking it a star for several reasons: First, the price is very high, even compared to Apple-branded products and more so to second-party kits. Second, no integral stand, though I understand you can buy an accessory. Third, the kit contains a shoulder strap that is just a total throwaway - unless my kit was defective (which I doubt, though it's possible), it was impossible to attach the strap securely without its attachment loops coming loose and/or bodging something together with clips or superglue. After 15 minutes of failed experimentation, I just set it aside and probably will throw it away.

This Thule case is a decent product, but honestly I cannot recommend it at this price point when compared to similar products I also own.  For example, I own and have enjoyed a CamKix case that I bought from Amazon.  Over 1000+ other people gave that unit 5-stars, and as of today, at least, the CamKix unit is much cheaper than the Thule.  I'm going to compare some of the pros and cons of each to show why I'd go with the CamKix again over the Thule:(1) The Thule case is significantly larger than the "small" sized CamKix - in fact, it occupies approximately double the volume in my suitcase that this CamKix does. This should mean that the Thule could hold around double the components of the CamKix model, but in practice the two hold approximately the same amount of stuff.  Probably partly because the Thule has thicker, more robust foam on the inside (which is good), but it does take up space and it's a higher-density foam that can't be customized as easily as the foam in the CamKix unit (which is not so good unless you happen to have precisely the kit the manufacturer built it for).(2) The nice-looking blue handle on the Thule isn't very useful, and it actually obstructs the zipper to a certain degree.(3) The zipper on the Thule is heavier-duty, but it doesn't open/close as smoothly.  On mine, at least, it catches a lot.So anyway, the Thule isn't a bad product at all, but in my humble opinion is just doesn't compare well to other products that occupy a significantly lower price point.

The optics are good, and the frames extremely comfortable. When using them as intended (for instance, sitting at a table or desk in an office, and frequently looking up and down between close books/papers, middle-ground computers/screens, and more distant objects like people) these glasses are a treat because the multifocal lenses really do work. Just be aware of that if you were just trying to focus on a single thing – such as if you've curled up to just read a book, they have the opposite effect – multifocal optics mean that only PART of the page you're reading will be in focus, in effect forcing you to read out of the bottom of the lenses. So these things really don't replace traditional readers so much as supplement them for some uses some of the time.

The spray trigger locks in place to prevent accidental discharge in a bag or pack, twists an eight turn to the left to open up.  It sprays evenly and dries to the touch on my skin in less than 60 seconds - within 5 minutes it's as if nothing went on.  IMO, 25% DEET is the sweet spot for insect repellents - much more effective than the 5-10% products and safer (and easier to get effective coverage) than the 90+% super concentrated formulas.FYI, the formula is 25% DEET, 23% ethanol, 15% isobutane and 37% "other" - no idea what, it's not mentioned on the MSDS. But it seems more or less unscented, as only a very faint smell of DEET lingers after use.

Honestly, I'm very conflicted about this review. Large parts of this book are simply excellent.  Mr. Soucie writes very well and engagingly, and he has a real knack for telling interesting stories chocked full of fun anecdotes that vividly evoke the sense of what it's like to fly fish abroad. He gives a lot of excellent big-picture advice on how people ought to philosophically approach this kind of travel to enjoy themselves no matter the weather or their luck on the water. He talks about the importance of patience, realism and preparedness, as well as the importance of acting like well-behaved guest traveling in someone else's country, without sounding like he's sermonizing. Sage advice throughout for working with guides, tour operators, lodge managers and fishing companions.  This book also includes countless detailed lists for packing and planning which, even if they probably are far too complete and complex for any single traveler ever to need/use, they certainly get you thinking ahead. All in all, I think that this is a book very much worth reading for the traveling flyfishing enthusiast.On the other hand, it is only fair to point out that this book felt very uneven to me. Parts of it felt like it was written many years ago, dusted off and only superficially brought up-to-date. Many of his specific anecdotes relate to fishing trips in the Kola peninsula decades ago, before the USSR split up.  A couple of the international travel agents and outfitters specifically mentioned in text have gone out of business (or at least seem to have, based on my preliminary Internet research), others seem to have changed their business models or products. Obviously, that sort of thing happens, and the author cannot be expected to keep the book absolutely up-to-date as to these 3rd parties. However, since the publication date on the book was only four months ago, to find so many changes seem surprising. You see some of the same in the sections devoted to medical advice, where I think the reader would really be much better off visiting his or her personal physician, local travel immunization clinic, or the CDC website for current advice rather than relying too much on the book alone because I can attest from direct personal experience that portions of the book's advice on vaccinations and malaria prophylaxis definitely are out of date. Ditto for the section is devoted to "film security":  i.e., like inadvertently damaging your canisters of film or VHS cassettes (!) while going through airport x-ray machines. I haven't even taken a film photograph in the last 13 years!  Modern digital photography (waterproof cameras / housings, rugged cameras, video, aerial drones with cameras) is only alluded to superficially.Most importantly, the book gives a lot of excellent advice about the sovereign importance of thoroughly planning ahead for your trip, researching your destination, and having a good grasp of natural and cultural points of interest in case the fishing does not live up to expectations.  But The author is talking about the kind of research people would've done of the 1980s.  There is NO mention of the actual importance of email, Google, online mapping, tripadvisor, Wikipedia or yelp in modern travel planning, and indeed the word "internet" only appears twice in the entire book, and neither time in the main body of text. This is astonishing, considering that the Internet is where I do 85%-95% of all my research before making any major travel plans.So in sum, about two-thirds of this book are delightful, engaging and timeless. But to one degree or another, much of the balance of the book feels like it was written in the pre-Internet age, and as such its value to the modern traveler is limited.

I bought this for my 11-year old son before a 2.5 week trip to India.  We wanted to pack light, and yet we needed clothes suitable for daytime temperatures in north India in December (roughly 50-70 deg F) and later in the same trip Kerala in south India (85-90 deg F).  This shirt packed easily and looked great.  In cool weather he rolled down the sleeves, and in warm weather he rolled them up.  My son washed it himself in the sink a few times in the evening, and by morning it had drip-dried and looked good as new.  My son loved it and wore this shirt at least 7 days out of 15:  it got to the point where we joked it had turned into his official uniform.

I think that this is a truly excellent semi-automatic (not fair to call this "fully automatic" as in the ad copy, for reasons discussed below) espresso maker for someone who wants to make great coffee drinks without the overhead of a fully manual espresso machine.  I'm giving it 4.5 stars, rounded up.It makes delicious espresso and ristretto, and it has very useful and easily-set options for, e.g., setting the coarseness of your grind, setting the amount of grounds per shot, setting the volume of water per shot, etc.  The auto-capuccino accessory (basically, a plastic hose which uses steam suction to prepare either hot milk+crema or crema+foam, depending on whether you twist it to cafe au lait or cappucino mode, respectively) is a very nice feature that works well.  So apart from the usual cups of espresso and ristretto, you can use this machine to make very good cups of cafe au lait/latte, capuccino, americanos, steamers or hot chocolates, for instance, with great results and minimal fuss.  Within a week, my 11 year old son already knew how to operate all of its major settings and felt comfortable using it.All that said, there are a few things that could be a little better, or which people at least need to know about before plunking down what is by all accounts a lot of money to buy this unit:Maintenance:  Be aware that this isn't designed for the same kind of one-button operation as a Keurig, for instance.  It isn't (quite) as easy as slipping a cup under the spout, pressing a button, and then throwing an empty K-Cup in the trash.  Most importantly, of course you should remember that you'll need to clean (or at least rinse) the milk steamer every time you use it (by that I mean you don't literally have to rinse it after EVERY cup of coffee - if you're making 2, 3,4 whatever cups one after the other for guests you just need to rinse it at the end of the procedure before you leave it sitting around unusued for a day).  And if you use the auto-capuccino accessory (i.e. the little suction hose contraption for frothing milk) you need to rinse it out as well.  You also occasionally need to empty the ground collector and empty the drip pan (which also serves as a discharge/outflow for steam and the unit's internal rinse water, so that it'll fill up eventually even if you never "drip" your coffee into it).  Finally, you need to be on the lookout for electronic reminders to descale the internal plumbing, which thankfully doesn't seem to happen that often.  My aforementioned 11-year old son is not as good at *cleaning* this unit as he is at *operating* it.[UPDATE: After two months, the machine prompted me to replace the unit's water filter.  On Amazon, that part cost around $20.  So factor that sort of ongoing maintenance expense into the total cost of ownership, if you do decide to continue using the (optional) filter.]Size:  Some other reviewers call this unit "compact."  Personally, I think that's stretching things a bit.  Width is fine, but both height and depth are significant.  For sure, this unit is a LOT smaller than a professional model auto espresso maker, but by the same token it's significantly larger than the kind of normal coffee maker, Keurig, or most entry-level non-automated espresso makers that people buy for their own kitchens.  Honestly, I think that some people might have trouble finding space for this to sit permanently on a countertop, especially under overhanging wall cabinets which wouldn't leave a lot of working room to load beans or remove the rear water reservoir.  And it's way too large, heavy and fiddly for you to plan on keeping it in a closed cabinet and only bring it out when you want to use it.  The upshot:  measure your space before you buy this!Coffee Bean Hopper:  The bean hopper on top is easy to open and load.  However, it's integral to the unit, so it's not as easy as I'd like to remove beans already in there.  This means that in practice the hopper usually will have some not-yet-used beans sitting in it, and if you don't keep using them relatively quickly they'll sit up there and start to oxidize and lose some of their freshness.  It also means you can't easily or quickly switch back and forth between different kinds of beans - regular or decaf beans, for instance, without using your bare hands to pick them out.  I wouldn't even want to try.Bean Limitations:  The instruction manual cautions you against using beans with syrupy coatings (like flavored beans) because they can get stuck in the internal mechanism and affect the machine's operation.  This was good to know, and it doesn't really bother me because who wants to pay this kind of money to make espresso with ghastly pre-flavored coffee beans anyway.  But of more concern, it also says that this same thing can happen with very dark roasts like the "Italian Roast" which naturally have highly oily surfaces - and many reasonable people actually DO like to use that for espresso.  The manual suggests using medium-roast beans most of the time.
