I really loved the feel of these headphones in my ears, the linguini-style straps (which virtually did away with tangles and knots) and the sound. However, they broke after only seven months of normal use, during which time I totally babied them - gentle use, careful winding, and always storing them in their hard shell case; and that's inexcusably soon. Very very disappointed.

This is an extremely fun game with terrific graphics.  Generally, the visuals are extraordinary - it's a lush and detailed depiction of a quasi-north Indian/Nepalese state, with immersive detail in plants, geography and buildings.  Individual missions have an essentially linear structure, though you can mess around with enough exploration and side-quests to keep you busy for a while and make it feel organic.  Controls are very complex but reasonably intuitive and can be mastered with practice.  Violence and profanity make the game unsuitable for kids and younger teens, IMO.FWIW, I didn't own, and never played, earlier games in the Far Cry series.  I've read a lot of online commentary and can understand some of the Sturm und Drang over the developers' changes to this game and the debate over whether that makes the current version 4 better or worse than 1-3, but as a newcomer to the series I can only that this game, taken on its own merits, is a heck of a lot of fun to play.
Good feel, better control and precision when picking notes than less tapered picks.  Good for practice and lessons.

Five stars for value, three stars for performance.  It's remarkable what a couple of hundred dollars can buy these days:  here, it gets you a nice-looking, well-built, and reasonably functional intro-level Windows machine for students or home users who need to run basic internet, MS Office apps and normal social media/communications programs with a minimum of fuss.  Build quality is good, with minimal creaking and flexing, and the keyboard and touchpad are pretty good.  Overall weight and balance are comfortable.  In short, I think this is a very serious high-value computer for use by young students (especially if you want to give them a machine that doesn't encourage excessive gaming), and as a secondary machine for home or light home-office users.All this said, this isn't a miracle product, and you need to have realistic expectations.  Processor speed is limited by modern standards (especially multi-core) and graphics power is very limited.  Don't plan on using this for gaming!  In my experience, even relatively nontaxing games like Minecraft push this hardware to its limits.  E.g., Minecraft Pocket Edition runs MUCH more smoothly on a $179 tablet than full Minecraft runs on this computer.  Also, the screen isn't top-notch:  it looks "fine" in actual use, especially for the intended Office, email and internet apps this machine was designed to run.  However, its color, contrast and brightness will suffer when viewed head-to-head with better notebook computers or modern tablets: the screen looks best head-on, and if you move your head left/right or up/down the screen shows color shifting and brightness dropoff much more quickly than better screens.  But as I said, this is being kind of picky: the screen is just fine for intended uses.

I got this to replace an aging sonicare of a lower model that was approximately six years old.  I have to say that this Diamond unit is a very impressive package.  Great carry case, easy charging (batteries last around 2-3 weeks+ for one person before needing a recharge), good charging/storage stand and nice drinking glass.  I also like that you can charge it with USB power while traveling.The main function - tooth cleaning - is great as I'd come to expect from using the brand for many years, but honestly I don't know that the Diamond does a materially better job at cleaning than one of the lower-level sonicaire models.  Buy this if you want the package, or expect to use the extra cleaning modes regularly.

Not as snazzy as the Nest, but very reliable and easy to operate, and I've found that the iOS app (which initially I thought was mainly gimmickry) is quite convenient.  It's nice to be able to judge the temperature from another room - while reading in bed or waking up in the morning, etc.My only quibble is that the installation instructions are pretty thin.  The consumer instructions basically just tell you how to install the app, and the contractors' instructions basically just are a partly-annotated diagram of control pins on the rear of the unit.  What I really needed was something somewhere in between - a set of more detailed instructions explaining how the pins match up to common house wiring, etc., which I had to supply myself from a half hour or so of Internet research and a little experimentation on my own unit.

It's hard to get too worked up emotionally over a charging cable, but I definitely like this one.  First and foremost, the price is right and it has been 100% reliable as a charge cable for several of our modern iOS gadgets, both iPhones and iPads.  The color is a nice match for the current-generation iPhone's "champagne" finish, though the effect is subtle and hardly necessary over the usual white cable except for people who insist on being color-matched.  Finally, the outer shell of the cable is sort of braided rather than smooth plastic, which gives this cable more toughness, stiffness and texture than the regular Apple Lightning cable.  I think that'll make it a little more durable to resist kinking and fraying, but only time will tell.

I think that most PC gamers looking to buy a 17" notebook would be very happy with this computer.  I've been using it for three weeks (as of this review), and I like it a lot: I'm giving it 4.5 stars, rounded up for value.  The construction, fit and finish is very good.  Maybe not the equal of category-leaders like Apple Macbook Pros with their aluminum construction and impossibly tight tolerances, etc., but Acer did a fine job with this Aspire using traditional materials at a much lower price point.  The case is built well:  there is no creaking, groaning or crackling when flexing the computer or opening/closing the monitor.  There is very little for me to complain about.  I really enjoy the keyboard (illuminated red - nice touch, slick looking).  The touchpad, though, sometimes is less sensitive than I'd prefer.  Especially when doing a two-finger scroll, it sometimes scrolls intermittently.  Not a big deal because I use an external mouse for gaming, but it's a little annoying.The screen is big and beautiful.  I'd say that the sweet spot for maximum viewing quality (uniform brightness and color) is around +/-30 degrees left, right, above and below centerline, so around a 60 degree cone of highest visual quality.  After that, you can start to see some typical fall-off in terms of brightness and uniformity, but the screen is readable and not-unenjoyable almost edge-to-edge, I'd say roughly 135 degree field of view.  Still very good.The fan is very quiet, even when running full screen games.  Lots of ports, all easily accessible.  And the speakers, though hidden on the underside of the case, definitely sound powerful (at least when the computer is on a hard surface like a desk or table) and are surprisingly full-range: they're very good not only for gaming effects but also for movies and music.For those of you who might want to compare this unit's raw performance figures against other computers, I ran Geekbench 3 benchmarks immediately after configuring the computer out of the box and installing all Windows and hardware driver updates.  Here are the summary results:64 bit:Single Core: 3,470 / Multi-Core: 13,010  Integer: 3,612 single / 15,041 multi  Floating Point: 3,452 single / 15,709 multi  Memory: 3,225 single / 3,552 multi32 bit:Single Core: 3,284 / Multi-Core: 12,320  Integer: 3,295 single / 14,040 multi  Floating Point: 3,292 single / 14,983 multi  Memory: 3,248 single / 3,556 multiThis all seems good for a gaming notebook at this price point, but I'll leave it to others to tease out the nuances.  Add a comment if you want a complete report.  Apart from these synthetic benchmarks, I can report that in practice, the machine is "very fast."  Our family currently doesn't play a lot of the most cutting edge games requiring maximum horsepower (we typically play titles like Civilization V, Minecraft and older FPS action games like TeamFortress 2), but all of them run in at high frames per second with maximum detail/quality modes at the screen's native resolution.  There's little doubt in my mind that this computer won't be able to keep up with a high end purpose-built desktop gaming computer, but it won't disappoint users with realistic expectations.Fair warning: out of the box, I did run into the usual slate of typical Windows incompatibilities, made harder than necessary to solve by Acer's policy of blocking user-installation of normal Intel drivers.  Short story: out of the box, Minecraft wouldn't work.  After extensive debugging, it turned out to be a conflict between the Acer-certified version of the Intel 4600 video driver which was installed on the computer out of the box (and which, as of the date of this writing, was only around 4 months old) and the much newer version of JRE/Java Runtime Environment available from Oracle.  It was easy to verify that newer generic Intel drivers were available, but by default Acer blocks installation of video drivers they haven't certified.  So I had to perform a manual removal and deletion of the installed Acer 4600 drivers, reboot using generic Windows drivers, followed by a manual installation of current 4600 drivers from Intel (not Acer), and reboot again.  This resolved the problem, but as the computer is marketed as a "gaming computer," it seems reasonable to expect that it wouldn't interpose arbitrary limits on video drivers needed by commonly-played games - or at least allow you to circumvent the block with a simple driver upgrade rather than force you to take these extra steps.

As a general matter, I'm not a fan of nonstick pans - I prefer to use cast iron or stainless where possible for a variety of reasons (durability, mainly).  But this pan might make a convert of me.  The nonstick surface seems to be very effective - foods just glide across it - and after several weeks of use, it seems to be highly durable.  It doesn't hurt that the pan is PFoA free and dishwasher safe, though neither is crucial to me personally.Other points worth underscoring are that the sides of the pan are high enough to make it more suited to stir frying (albeit not super high-heat wok-style frying - note the maximum recommended temperature of 400 degrees, which I assume is to prevent breakdown of the nonstick surface).  The handle is one of the most comfortable I've used and has relatively slow heat conductivity considering it's bare metal construction.  All in all, very recommended.

I bought this from a local brick & mortar store because I was in a hurry to get something before a long road trip to hold my iPhone 6+.  Big mistake.First, the assembly instructions are presented as cryptic pictograms rather than narrative text.  Those pictograms leave out one important step:  to install it properly, you need a small screwdriver to tighten the "legs" which are meant to stabilize the mount.  Not a big deal, but a screwdriver isn't included in the package so make sure you have one.Second, the "legs" really are an essential part of the unit's structure, necessary to stabilize it.  This limits your installation options - you have to be able to attach it to a vent immediately above a blank surface they can rest upon.  I am certain from using it myself that some cars have dashboards that simply won't allow that.Third, even after everything is tightened down I found the whole structure to be very wibbly-wobbly, especially with the kind of larger/heavier phone that this unit actually is intended to hold.  The mount does not explicitly require a horizontal vent - and it is absolutely clear that you CAN mount it on vertical or even angled vents.  However, horizontal vents probably will be a lot more stable.  My car has vents that are angled by around 30 degrees, and the phone has a tendency to flop side to side.Summary - not recommended.  I'm going to toss mine and get a suction cup model.

Every blade I've personally tried that was made by Schrade at this price point seems a little bit stiff to open and close, which makes them rather hard for young persons' hands to manipulate (and hence a little dangerous for older kids and younger teens to use, in my opinion - you don't really want kids straining with sharp tools).  Apart from that, the build quality seems high and the blades are reasonably sharp.  Also, I think that the "amber" color of the body is a bit more gold/yellow in reality than the photo appears on my computer screen, which seems more yellow/brown.  Recommended with these qualifications.

Every blade I've personally tried that was made by Schrade at this price point seems a little bit stiff to open and close, which makes them rather hard for young persons' hands to manipulate (and hence a little dangerous for older kids and younger teens to use, in my opinion - you don't really want kids straining with sharp tools).  Apart from that, the build quality seems high and the blades are reasonably sharp.  Recommended with qualifications.

True to other reviews, this keyboard has a great feel that is terrific for gaming as well as for routine typing.  The footprint is small enough not to take over our desk but large enough to make it easy to assume a comfortable posture for long gaming/typing sessions.  The adjustably-backlit keys are very sharp, and all of the main characters are extremely easy to read in any light.  Unfortunately, the secondary key functions are a little harder to make out under the backlighting (they're a little dim and undefined compared to the main digits), but it's not quite enough of a problem for me to dock they keyboard a star.  I think that this keyboard is a great deal for the price, and I'd recommend it strongly.

This is a really marvelous book for several reasons.  First, I love the organization.  Each map has a full double-facing-page display of the entire map so that you can appreciate it in its entirety.  The full map is followed by a double-page spread with blow-ups (the so-called "visual tour") focusing on many of the individual items of significance embedded in the map - techniques, cultural motifs, unique items of importance with concise explanations why.  Doubtless something analogous could have been done on a computer, but as it stands this is a really good use of the paper/hardback medium that would be difficult to replicate in an ordinary ebook.  Definitely buy the physical volume if you have a choice.  Second, this book spans a wide range of cultures, times and subject matters, from mosaics in the ancient world through intermediate maps of kinds I never knew existed (for instance, the Portolan Chart by Pizzigano, which is a detailed early navigational map reflecting ports' locations based on compass angles of travel) on through modern realistic depictions of the ocean floor and on through very contemporary graphical innovations like the stylized maps of the London Underground to maps which have been intentionally distorted in ways that add information to the map.  Terrific examples of great design abound.I've read many interesting "coffee table" books - the kind of large format volume that you're supposed to pick up and flip through idly for a few minutes when you're killing time.  But this is one of the very few that I've actually enjoyed so much that it's difficult to put down once I pick it up.  Highly recommended.

This is an excellent, inexpensive addition to anybody's car or home emergency kit. It's built reasonably solidly out of good materials - I wouldn't say it's built like a tank, and I would not take it out for any epic survival missions, but it should be more than enough for the intended market: which I assume is normal consumer use in the event of a blackout, storm, earthquake or so on. Some general comments:1. The internal battery is more than powerful enough to run this unit for a long time, and the multiple recharging operations are excellent. The crank recharges it surprisingly quickly, and of course the solar cells aren't no-brainer if you leave it sitting around in bright lights when you're not using it. Just note that has the manual clearly Sabbs, the solar panel will not fully charge the device on its own.. The internal battery has a  lower capacity than the lithium ion batteries in most modern communications gadgets, though, so you have to have reasonable expectations what this will be able to fully recharge. Remember that the purpose is to recharge your phone enough to give you some emergency communication time, not to fully charge a dead tablet.2. I found the FM reception to be quite good, but the AM reception was a little less then I can get on the other table radios. Both are more than strong enough to pick up emergency information. Also, the NOAA radio seems to work very well for me.3. The flashlight is more than bright enough for most ordinary use, and it's nice to have it built in so you don't have to go looking around in the event of a blackout, for instance. However, once again it's fair to say that it is nowhere near as bright as a modern dedicated high-intensity flashlight that you can buy online for 10 or $15.

We got this for my 10-year old son to use for 5th grade studies.  He likes it a lot, and reports to me that it's got a lot of great organizational options, holds a lot of material, is easy-to-use and not covered with objectionable decorations. I can personally attest to the fact that it seems to be very well-made of good components, better than the old trapper keeper I had as a kid, and – although it is fairly big – it isn't as enormous as some of the competing three ring binders I've seen in stores. A solid choice that should last several years.

Snug fit, good materials and well-stitched. It keeps the 24" wide Camp Chef smoker totally dry (except for the legs, but including the relatively delicate burner assembly and gas knob) and doesn't billow around in a strong wind. Note that it doesn't cover the separate propane tank: of course that wouldn't really be feasible given the design of the smoker but it's worth mentioning briefly as it affects the cosmetics a bit.

We use this clock on a small chrome and glass shelf in one of our bathrooms (recently renovated and decorated with white tile and chrome fixtures).  We wanted a small clock that was reliable, didn't require an electrical cord, and fit the overall design theme of the room.  This clock is made of white plastic and chromed plastic, so it isn't "fancy" per se, but it certainly stands up to casual scrutiny.  It keeps good time, and has good value for the price.

I have been using this for a couple of months now to charge several different kinds of gadgets including my own iPad 3, my son's Kindle Fire HDX, and a couple of family members' iPhones and regular (e-ink) Kindles.  Simple, reliable and easy to use, just what you'd expect of a wall charger.  While doing so, it heats up a bit in the normal way of most transformers but it doesn't get hot enough for any kind of safety concern.

I'm very happy with this seat, which we bought to go with a TOTO CST416M-01 Aquia II 2-Piece Toilet with Regular Height Bowl and Dual Max Tank, Cotton White.  After reading some reviews, I was concerned this seat might be flimsy, but I was happy and little surprised to find that this seat is very strong and sturdy.  Little or no flex in regular use, at least for a person who weighs around 180 pounds.  Comfortable, and the soft-close prevents the earth-shattering kabam from accidentally slamming down a regular wooden seat in the middle of the night.I concur with reviewers who say that this seat's design might make it more challenging than usual to clean, but I don't think it's going to be a big enough deal to dock a star.

We did a complete rehab on a small, but high-traffic, bathroom on the second floor of our almost 90-year old house, and we wanted a high-performing water-efficient toilet that looked good and took up minimal space.  I was not always happy with other toilets bought and used, but this model frankly exceeded expectations.  It flushes powerfully even under a "heavy load," and the bowl design has a good "target zone" which minimizes unsightly staining after use.  The elongated bowl gives room for comfortable seating, but the low-profile tank allows the whole unit to tuck close to the wall without occupying a large footprint.We paired this toilet with the TOTO SS204-01 Contemporary SoftClose Oval Toilet Seat, Cotton White, which matches perfectly and is extremely quiet and comfortable.

I was more than a little disappointed in this bag.  First, the shape and internal design is adequate for carrying around a basic kit DSLR or mirrorless ICL with a couple of lenses and gear, but it isn't very innovative.  It's not great for large lenses or hoods, nor is it ideal to hold a camera + lens (and certainly not with an external flash) in a ready-state between shoots.  You can remove or open up the internal dividers and just lay the camera in there the way you would inside of any sack/bag/purse, but this isn't really purpose-built for that kind of use.  Crucially, though, the inside has limited space, so you have to rely on the external pockets much of the time.  Trouble is, the external stash pockets are not very secure and cannot be closed up (there is no zipper, flap, snap, elastic, etc.), so things easily can slip out.  Medium marks on functionality.Second, I think that many men will be concerned that its size and shape make it more purse-like than they might prefer.  I got some gentle ribbing from men and women of my acquaintance.  Paradoxically, the women I spoke with told me that they didn't like the idea of using it themselves, either, because of its utilitarian style and color.  So low marks on style and appearance.My normal go-to bag was and remains the Domke 701-J83 J-803 Satchel (Black), which is a smallish satchel with removeable internal dividers and external pouches for camera gear, an internal sleeve for a tablet or thin notebook PC/Mac, and a style that carries over equally well to office use (e.g., carrying files) when you remove the internal dividers.

Part how-to book, part gear guide, part photo travelogue.  I enjoyed it - it's a nice volume to keep next to your easy chair when you have a few minutes to spare but you don't want to surf the web or start reading a regular book.  Great photos and graphics, and I found most of the entries genuinely interesting.  You definitely can see its Field & Stream heritage, it reads like an enormous fishing magazine without the ads.It's fair to say, though, that like most books that try to cover all aspects of a very broad hobby, it can be accused of being a mile wide and an inch deep.  For instance, of 317 entries, large minorities are devoted to fly fishing, ocean fishing, bass fishing, and so on - separated not by chapters but shuffled together like cards in a deck.  You might read about fishing in the surf from a rip-rap breaker and then find the next entry is about the use of nymphs in small stream fly fishing.  I enjoy that sort of thing, but your mileage may vary.

The Sony BDV-N8100W is a nice unit with a ton of features.  Rather than write an enormous review of every possible function, I'm going to zoom in on the things that seem to matter most to me.  If I don't mention something, it's either because I don't want to repeat what other reviewers already said, or because I just don't use it.First, I was happy to see that fit and finish is very good for the price.  You don't get all-metal enclosures, wooden speaker boxes with Kevlar cones, or large-gauge cables, but materials and workmanship are a good deal for this kind of package at this price point. The main unit and subwoofer tuck away nicely, and the speakers are unobtrusive in our living room.  Note, though, that we wall-mounted the front speakers, discarding the tall stands that come in the box.  Wall mounted, they produce good sound and visually match up well with our fireplace-hung LCD TV.Second, it was very easy to set up and configure.  Physically, it takes a great deal of time to place everything just so, route cables and power, etc., but at no stage was it difficult.Third, though, the UI menu system is characteristically "Sony" in that - like every Sony camera and other gadget I've ever owned - ordinary usage requires you to navigate a large and fairly discursive menu system. This can actively hamper everyday use.  For instance, astonishingly, there is no function to let you select a particular input mode!  By this, I mean you cannot press a single button and jump to HDMI 1 (etc.).  Instead, you have to press a function button repeatedly, cycling one at a time through all of the many input options until you get the one you want. Alternatively, you can call up the main menu, navigate left or right to the input control settings and then up or down to the one you want. It's pretty much the same either way, because it takes a lot of button mashing and more importantly it makes it hard to use a procedural universal remote control (like a Logitech Harmony).Fourth, sound is remarkably good for the price.  On movies, TV and music (whether 2-channel or simulated surround) the sound is equal to or better than the separate components I bought for a higher price some years back. And the wireless rear surrounds produce extremely good sound for the purpose, and I've never experienced a dropout or disconnection.UPDATE November 22, 2013:=============================In recent weeks, something has gone wonky with the sound in this unit.  My guess is that one of the firmware updates did something to change sound processing algorithms, because all voices now take on a weird, distorted kazoo-like character at low volumes.  It's not completely unlistenable, but it is distracting.  It affects all of the DSP settings (Auto, Movie, Music, etc) except, oddly, 3D Surround Sound mode, so I keep in that mode almost all the time now. A manual software reset did not solve the problem.

This is far and away the most useful stylus I've tried for my iPad.  Great battery life, good feel, and usable as a basic pointer in any application.The absolutely killer feature, though, is palm recognition - a feature that is missing from every other stylus I've seen.  Without palm recognition, your writing hand constantly touches the screen and causes stray marks, zooming and re-positioning of the screen.  To avoid that, you need to hold most stylii in much the same way you might use a paintbrush, which is uncomfortable for me and causes poor accuracy and illegible handwriting.  But to enable this palm recognition, Adonit uses technology that doesn't work system-wide: it only functions in certain applications that were specifically coded to recognize this stylus.  Check before you buy to see if your preferred apps recognize the Adonit.  As of today, there only are a couple of dozen, though many of them are very good.  Pressure sensitivity works similarly - only in apps that recognize it.  Some apps recognize one but not the other, so do your homework if this is important to you.The fine point on the stylus makes it easier to write with precision (compared to the big stubby foam/rubber tips of many other stylii), but the "gap" between tip and LCD panel caused by the thickness of the screen's glass is very visible and can be distracting until you get used to it.

I really enjoy using this camera.  Well-manufactured with good fit and finish, strong image quality, long zoom, good auto focus speed and responsive shutter.  It includes some more advanced features like WiFi hotspotting (though I think most people will be frustrated the first couple of times they use it, because it takes some getting used to how to setup and configure networking functions).  And as usual, Sony's menu control system is a little more complex than it needs to be when compared to similar cameras by Canon, Panasonic, etc., but I've used so many Sony cameras now that I'm getting used to this issue.Fundamentally, the DSC-WX300 is Sony's answer to Canon's superlative S100/S110 line of compact cameras, and I think it should appeal to the same kinds of users: (1) the casual photographer looking for a compact, jack-of-all-trades point and shoot with good image quality, and (2) the more serious enthusiast who wants a pocketable camera with a big zoom when they don't want to lug a larger SLR or interchangeable lens mirrorless camera kit around.The rear LCD screen takes up most of the camera body.  IMO, it's likely to be a major scratch and crack risk if you aren't accustomed to taking good care of your cameras.  If you  often drop yours in a backpack, purse, drawer, etc., with other things, you might want a screen protector.  I bought the cheap but excellent GGS Optical Glass LCD Screen Protector 3 inches for Digital Cameras, which fits perfectly, and couldn't be more pleased with the result.

Relatively large, and it requires a flat surface and relatively flat ground around it so that the IR sensor and spray are aligned properly vis a vis the critters you're trying to scare off (I suspect this is an easy criterion in most people's gardens or lawns but bear this in mind if you live in a hilly area).It takes an inordinate amount of time to charge, and really benefits from open sun.  Bear that in mind if you have large mature trees or want to place this in the north side of your house, garage or a wall.

Allison Taylor and her daughter, Melanie, need a fresh start. Recently divorced, she moves to the town that she spent summers as a child, where her surrogate mother Frannie, and best friends Elizabeth and Sharon, still live. Things seem to be going great, but as anyone could have guessed, it is not meant to last. A former love interest that she hasn’t seen in over a decade shows up, and things start to go sideways. Soon after that, a murder happens in this small town, and everyone’s dark secrets are being dragged, kicking and screaming into the light. Can Allison’s relationships survive all of the turmoil?For a debut novel from this author, it is a very enjoyable book. The characters were interesting to read about, and the relationships between all of them were very believable. I did think that there were some areas of the plot that kind of meandered, and kind of took away from the suspensefullness that the author was trying to build with the rest of the story. But those are things that are to be expected somewhat from a debut author, and it’s definitely not a deal breaker.This is the first book in a series, and I will definitely put the next two books on my ever expanding to read list. The character writing was so good, that it will definitely be worth checking back in on. If the pacing issues are fixed in the next installments, this series will quickly become a must read.

Have you ever been on Netflix, and it recommends shows that it thinks you will like? And it even guesses how you will rate something before watching it? And it will guess that you will give the show a 4.9 out of 5, and you wonder what took you so long? That’s how I felt when I came across this book, and read the description.Rolland Wright is an orphan, trying to get by living out of his car. One day, he is attacked by people that say that they killed his father, and discovers he has an amazing ability. He can slllllllllloooooooooooooowww doooooooooooooooooowwwwwn tiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiime around himself. From there, he is introduced to an entire world that was unknown before, outside of space and time. He groups up with Joan of Arc and Jesse James (the outlaw, not ex-Mr-Sandra-Bullock), who are Knights of Time, to battle evil wherever and whenever it may be. Including General Andrew Jackson in the 19th century. Yep.When I read the words a 'blend of X-Men and Doctor Who with a side of historic fact', that was the same for me as the 4.9 out of 5 Netflix recommendation. You would realize that, if you could see me drinking my morning tea out of my TARDIS mug right now. And while I will admit that it starts a little slllllllllloooooooooooooowww…. Sorry…. It definitely picks up, and becomes a fairly dense story that I quickly found myself engrossed by.This first book was originally released almost 3 years ago, by the time I read it. Hopefully we see another volume in this story soon.

Dr Sara Forrester is the savior of the world, and is set on her path by the Soltari. If you’re taken aback at the abrupt and out-of-nowhere revelation of this news, that’s the same feeling that Sara had. She is thrust into this world that she had no idea existed, full of demons and shadows, ancient keys and amulets, and “past lives” and reincarnation. She gains an ally in a man named Kevin, who is more than he seems. Unlike Sara, he remembers his past lives, as well as Sara; He loves her more than anything, and vowed to protect her, no matter when and where she was, or even who she was. It’s up to Sara to figure out this brand new world, before it’s too late.Alright, let’s get this minor annoyance that I had with this book: This is the first book in the series, it is absolutely not a prequel. Prequels come later, hence the name pre-sequel. Whew, I feel a lot better getting that off my chest.That being said, I really enjoyed this book. As far as sci-fi and fantasy novels of this kind of scale, it is relatively short (under 300 pages is shorter than you would expect), but it doesn’t waste a whole lot of page real estate. The story picks up very quickly, and doesn’t let up at all. Not even when the book ends, since it’s only the first volume in a series! I think the over-arching concept of the story is immensely interesting, and even if it wasn't a very well written story, I would probably continue with the series. But the author is a very talented story teller, and I am very excited to continue on this journey.But seriously, not a prequel. I’m sorry, it just bothers me….

Sometimes I am in the mood for a huge series, whether it be a book or TV series, where it is crucial that you start from the very beginning, and follow the larger storyline throughout the entire thing.  Other times, I enjoy a series that doesn’t really have an overarching narrative to speak of, that I can jump into and off of whenever I feel like. The Social Magus is the latter.The fifth book in the series sends Agent John Mordred to investigate an up and coming new party in British politics.  Seemingly popping up out of nowhere, this new party has gained the attention and support of the youthful apathetic contingent of the voting public, and gained the attention and derision of the governmental establishment.  Mordred is tasked with investigating where this party came from, and who is behind it.  He quickly finds that there is more going on than he originally thought, and things even get personal, when he finds that his sister is inexplicably in the middle of all of it.  Can he save his sister, and get to the bottom of the case?  I mean, he is an MI7 Agent after all, I would hope he could…This is the first book in the series that I have read, and from what I have gathered, they all have different lead characters, and can all be read independently from one another.  I thought that the backdrop of British politics, and the inner workings of all of it, made for a very interesting and suspenseful read.  The author was able to convey the intricate ideas very well, and I found that I was able to understand what was going on, despite not knowing anything about British politics.If you’re looking for a new political thriller to sink your teeth into, I would highly suggest checking out J J Ward’s many novels.

Comedy can be a tough thing to write.  It’s not a universal thing that appeals to everyone the same way.  The world doesn’t move to the beat of just one drum.  What might be right for you, may not be right for some. But they got Diff’rent Strokes…. Oh, that’s a theme song for a TV show.  But the point still stands, that comedy is difficult, and it is kind of risky to write an entire book of funny stories, and the like.Edward Shafik is the author and creator of this book, which is a large collection of stories, thoughts, and observances throughout his life.  Are you interested in reading humerous stories about celebrities such as John Lennon, Donald Trump, or Dolly Parton?  Did you want to read, quite frankly, an alarming number of stories centered on hot dogs?  How about stories about Disneyland, The Happiest Place on Earth?  Did you catch that I used “frank” as a pun when talking about hot dogs?  Well, that’s the kind of content that you can expect in this book!  Except for my terrible hot dog pun….This book is an overall enjoyable experience.  Coming in at a little over 400 pages, it will take you a good long while to get through, considering that it is best enjoyed in smaller chunks.  Most stories are entertaining and funny, but every once in a while, one of the stories falls flat.  Which is to be expected, with such a large variety of content, that not everything works.  But I think that this is definitely worth picking up.

Chasing Joseph is the story of Jamal Joseph D Robinson.  It tells the story of him coming up in the world, and trying to be an upstanding member of society, and his community.  His intentions were for the most part good and genuine, but I am always reminded of that old adage, “The road to hell is paved with good intentions”.  One bad decision after another pulled Jamal further into a world that he would have never imagined he would be in.  A world introduced to him by his own mother, no less, a world that included welfare fraud and murder.  However, at it’s core, this book is a story of redemption, and how Joseph (he calls his “former self” Jamal, to further distance himself) brought himself out of that situation, and changed his life for the better.The first thing you need to know about this book is that it is an autobiography, from someone who isn’t necessarily a writer by trade, so it is a little rough around the edges.  However, that is what I really enjoyed about this book overall.  It didn’t feel like it was overwritten, and every word perfected into conveying the exact idea that the writer wants.  It was raw, and genuine, and I think it helped to convey the emotions of the writer more than the writer agonizing over the perfect phrase.This is a fairly heavy read, but it is certainly worth checking out.  It is fairly short, (118 pages) so it’s not a big reading commitment, but I am confident that you will be glad that you read it.  You might not be “happy” after reading, per se, but it will definitely have an impact.

When it comes to stories and story-telling, you k now what we have in excess? HAPPY ENDINGS. If you’re like me, sometimes “happily ever after” is not what you want, and not what the charaters themselves deserve. I would list my favorite endings along those lines, but I wouldn’t want to spoil The Cat In The Hat for anyone. Whoops… So, if you’re like me, that doesn’t always want a happy ending, then buckle the ffffffffront of your big boy pants, and dive into Deadly Short Stories.I’m not even going to go into each story, since each story is so short, that going too deep into the plots would be pointless. However, I can say that each story is different enough from the last, and each are so short, that you can’t really seem to get your footing on anything the entire time. You will feel uneasy, suspenseful, hopeful, queasy, or downright horrified, and then the author shifts gears with a twist in the story, or a completely different story altogether.I really enjoyed this collection of “flash fiction”, which is a type of story shorter than a short story, and not made up stories of a man only wearing a trenchcoat, as I originally thought. Sometimes I can’t understand how someone like Stephen King can write an absolute tome of a book like The Stand, and keep it interesting throughout, and other times I can’t understand how someone like Carl Plumer can get me so invested in a story in such a short time. I am very impressed, and will keep an eye out for more releases of this ilk.

I am not a religious person, but I am endlessly fascinated by religion itself. I enjoy reading about many different faiths, and educating myself on their beliefs, both good and bad. I was drawn to The Angel Of Antioch because of this.It centers around the mysterious character of Elias, who one day shows up in The Great Synagogue in the ancient town of Antioch, and is able to recite verse after verse of scripture from memory. Before the gathered people can find out more about him, and talk to him themselves, he vanishes. But he returns, on the next Sabbath, and does the same thing, before vanishing once more. Word spreads quickly throughout Antioch: Is he an angel sent to spread the Word of the Lord? Is he a prophet? Whatever the case may be, the religious leaders are threatened by his presence, and try to discredit him to the rest of Antioch. Turmoil between Elias’ followers and the religious leaders ensue, threatening to tear the Capital apartDespite being a fairly short read (110 pages, according to Amazon), I enjoyed this book immensely. The character of Elias is very intriguing, as he is the voice of insight, wisdom, and sometimes doubt, against the monolithic reach of religious beliefs, which as I’m sure we are all aware, are the Word of God, and can not be questioned. I am almost always on the side of the person that asks questions, and doesn’t blindly believe and follow whatever they are told, and this is no exception. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this story, and will definitely look forward to reading more of Daniel Molyneux in the future.

After writing A Birth of an Assassin, Rik Stone decided to return back to the world that he created, with The Turkish Connection: A Birth of an Assassin Novel.The story centers on Mehmet, who is basically a street urchin, in Istanbul, Turkey, circa 1951. It follows his day to day struggle to survive, while learning some of the less savory ways, including thievery, and sometimes violence. As he grows, he realizes that this life that he thought was forced onto him by the poor choices of his father, has actually been manipulated by a third party. Is he able to free himself from their grips, and turn his life around?This is an interesting look into a world that most of us do not have any frame of reference. Not just growing up in poverty (something that is more relatable), but actually being homeless, and having to fend for yourself, with absolutely no support structure to fall back on. It is a very harrowing story, and one that is, at times, difficult to read. I especially enjoyed the fantastic melding of the two parts of the story, of Mehmet as a young boy, and as an adult. It was interesting to see how the situations, lessons, and overall backstory that were presented to Mehmet as a boy, informed how he turned out as a man. The evolution of Mehmet seemed believable, and I very much enjoyed reading it throughout.

I saw that this book was released recently, and it piqued my interest.  Set in the 70’s, during the conflict at Wounded Knee (a moment in history that I was not entirely familiar with before reading this), it centers around Rick Putnam, who is a motorcycle courier, and his girlfriend Eve Buffalo Calf.  Both of which obviously hit the jackpot in the “Super Rad Name” competition.  They stop in the small town of Wounded Knee, to help some activist friends of Eve’s, bringing them supplies and such.  And since it would be a little boring of a story if things worked out perfectly, things actually don’t work out perfectly,  when they find themselves being chased by a cult, who is intent on killing them.As I said, I wasn’t very familiar with the Wounded Knee incident, but  I was intrigued all the same.  I did a little research (see: Wikipedia) before digging too far, so I had a broad idea, and I think that it doesn’t really matter how much knowledge you have before reading this, that you will enjoy it all the same.  Terry Irving does a spectacular job of painting a picture of the time period, and filling the reader in on the tumultuous time period.  The characters of Rick and Eve are fantastic from start to finish.  Another reviewer mentioned that Rick reminded them of a Liam Neeson-type of character, a la the Taken franchise, and I think that is a perfect comparison.Overall, I enjoyed this book greatly.  If you’re looking for a great political thriller with motorcycles, then you’ve come to the right place with your very specific needs!

In the far-flung future, it is widely known that there are zombies, werewolves, and vampires running around.  The only thing that is stopping people from being turned into monsters left and right is?!  RED TAPE!  No, that's not some new superhero with the power of bureaucracy;  The Bureau of Reassignment handles everyone's "transition" from human to something else.  Extensive testing, therapy, permits, and injections are needed before you make this big leap in today's world, but there is a rash of unregistered and illegal zombies running the streets.  Senior Serenity Ambassador Vic (also the winner of Time Magazine's "Coolest Job Title" award) is tasked with figuring out what is going on, and stopping him.Alright, I have to say, that the premise for this book sucked me in right away.  Government regulated zombies, werewolves, and vampires?  That's just an entirely new level of crazy, that I can totally get behind.  The book, while somewhat short, does a fantastic job at hitting the ground running, story-wise, and manages to tell a very inventive and original sci-fi story along the way.  Plus, there's even a love interest thrown into the mix, and it doesn't feel like it was slapped on at the last minute!Overall, I think this book is really well put together.  Like a Frankenstein!  Idea for the next book, perhaps?  Among the cavalcade of zombie stories that we have had in recent history, it is nice to see someone able to weave an entertaining and original story in the tried and true zombie genre.

Deedee is in a relationship that is all too common in this day and age.  Trapped in a marriage with someone she has realized all too late is not right for her, and he takes everything from her, including their daughter, Bea.  Deedee escaped to America, to get away from her old life, and make a new start.  She meets Christopher, a French baker, and quickly falls deeply in love with him.  He promises her that he will help her get her daughter back, and bring her to America.  This harrowing tale is actually based on true events, which makes the entire read even more amazing!Considering that this is Doina Moulin's first novel, I will give it the benefit of the doubt.  It is not BAD by any means, it just doesn't seem like it was proofread enough times, or didn't go through an editing process rigorous enough.  I hate to harp on grammatical and punctuation errors in this review, but they are a big enough problem for me to take notice, so it is worth mentioning.  I hope that the author's next work is more polished, because I did enjoy the story very much.  It was a touching and heartbreaking story at times, and I would definitely read the author's next book based on that.This is a very personal and harrowing tale, that is marred by small writing errors that could have definitely been taken care of with the right editor.  If you are willing to look past those issues, I suggest you check this out.

Were you watching Lord of the Rings, or Game of Thrones, and thought, “Do you know what this needs?  GUNS!  AND ROBOTS!  PEW PEW PEW!!”  Oh, also, you're playing with army men and dragon figurines...  Anyway, if that sounds interesting to you, then you should definitely check this book out.Terrorists armed with mystical powers kill a plane full of people with a dragon, and use their souls to start The Change across the country.  And that just STARTS the story!  We are then introduced to Steve Rowan, who is transformed into a powerful wizard, with a less than stellar success rate.  He is hired by Barnaby, a computer that has gained sentience, and along with Navy SEAL Ace Morningstar (who is a woman... You can't really tell from the name), sets out to figure out what is going on, and how to stop it.Once I read the setup for this book, I was pretty much sold right off of the bat.  I was very impressed with the opening, and what follows after that is a crazy mesh of fantasy and real-world/sci-fi elements, that is a delightful read.  The characters are varied and unique, and the interactions between the three main characters is fantastic.Considering this is the first book in a planned series, a lot of questions are asked, and not a whole lot is answered.  But the questions that have been explored so far are enough to get me to come back, and see where this story goes from there.

Jack Kearns has a pretty awesome job. Basically, he is a PIRATE FIGHTER! He rescues ships that had been kidnapped by Somali pirates. His job obviously makes him some very dangerous enemies, whether he fails or succeeds, and he is always looking over his shoulder.  During one of his missions, he rescues a beautiful girl, and then all Hell breaks loose.  Literally!  Alright, NOT literally...  A lot of powerful and deadly people want this woman dead, and it is up to Jack to figure out why, and keep her safe!Normally I just relax while I am on break at work, and give my eyes a rest from the computer screen.  While reading this, my breaks could not come fast enough for me to run to the break room, and continue reading!  It was a thrilling read, that flowed really quickly throughout the storyline, while at the same time feeling TOO LONG, simply because I wanted to know what happened next! I was drawn to this book partly because I went and saw Captain Phillips when it came out in theaters, and there is obvious connection between the two.  The main difference would be if Captain Phillips, and the special forces people that took out the pirates were the same person.  This story was definitely different in major ways, but they did have the same feel of  overall suspense throughout.  I highly recommend this book.

Carolyn just came off of a breakup, and isn't looking for any kind of relationship right now.  But, just like when you find your car keys right after you've completely given up the search, she finds love in an unexpected place.  With her boss!  Now she must choose between the new and exciting relationship with her boss, or the familiar, albeit rocky relationship with her ex, who wants her back.This book is a light and fun read.  It isn't as heavy and dramatic as some other romance novels I have read, and I very much enjoyed the change of pace.  It was refreshing to read a book that is written in that way, instead of the overly serious and moody style that is so common in romance novels.Of all the things you could say about this novel, one thing that you couldn't call it is slow.  Both the story, and the romance included in the story, hit the ground running, and do not slow down for a second.  The fast-paced nature of the storytelling really lent itself well to the upbeat style mentioned earlier, and these two things come together to create a very enjoyable read.

This book is a nice short story about Sarah, a young child attending a Catholic school.  While on a class field trip to the City of Moon, Sarah wanders off away form the group.  When she returns, she has found that they have left without her!  She waits for awhile for them to come back, but eventually wanders to the nearest building, which happens to be a mosque.  The man that she meets contacts the school, and introduces Sarah to his granddaughter, Raya, who quickly become friends.  Sarah's class comes back to get her, and everything works out, and Sarah  and Raya remain friends.This is a really nice short story, about children, and how judging someone for their skin color or religious or personal beliefs is not something that you are born with, it is something that is learned as you grow older.  Everyone is taught these things, and it is really hard to unlearn them, and understand that everyone is the same:  To regress back to our childlike understanding of how the world works, and what our differences mean.  I think that this is a wonderful story, and every parent should read this to their children.  Or, every child should read this to their parents, so their parents can finally understand the moral behind this story.The author of this book works with orphaned and needy children, from all walks of life, and all different backgrounds.  Some of the proceeds from purchasing this book will go to helping those children.  I was happy to purchase this book for that alone, and the story itself is a nice plus!

I came right off of reading the first book in the series, Tesla Evolution Book 1, and I enjoyed it so much, I dove directly into the second volume.This is the continuing adventures of Sebastian and Melanie.  Melanie, who was weeks from succumbing to cancer in the previous book, has just found out that she has been cured, due to the radiation emitted from Sebastian himself!  However, she is warned that, if she continues to stay in close contact with him, she could be in danger of dying from radiation poisoning.  They have arrived at the Steam Academy, one of their main missions in the previous book, but soon realize that it is not the salvation that they had hoped it would be.  Food shortages and civil unrest threaten everyone's livelihood, as well as the outside threat of the cyborgs.Going from Tesla to Decay was a very nice transition, but not exactly the same.  The author's style has changed slightly from the first to second volumes, as has the overall tone of the book.  This book is significantly darker than the previous volume.  While not automatically a bad thing (I certainly enjoyed the change, overall), it should be noted that, while things were definitely bleak before, it becomes much bleaker this time around.This has shaped up to be a fantastic series, and I am very much looking forward to reading the next in the series.  Which I can do right now, since it's already out!

I don't know what is with post-apocalyptic stories that grabs me so much.  They're not happy and lighthearted stories, and a majority of the time, they don't even have a "happy" ending (I'm looking at you, The Road!) Maybe it is just the simple notion of reading something, and being able to say "Oh man, at least my life is going better than these people's lives!"  But I digress...  I came across this book, and after reading some of the reviews, I decided to check it out.The story centers around Seb and Melanie, two teenagers struggling to survive in this post apocalyptic landscape.  Seb is an orphan, who is being chased by cyborgs, who want him dead.  Pretty normal.  Melanie is dragged in to the adventure against her will, and is tasked with getting Seb to the Steam Academy for his own safety, among other reasons.  Together, they will learn to take care of themselves, and each other, in this dystopian landscape.I have been really enjoying this run that we have been having, of Young Adult novels that have actually been very good books.  Some people have the idea that, because the audience is younger, they need to be talked down to, to comprehend the story.  In my experience, being condescending is never a good strategy.  This book (and series, since I have read the next one already) manages to write this story in a way that would appeal to young adults, while at the same time, not talking down to them.  The characters are compelling, and I am ecstatic that this is the first in a book series, so I can continue to read The Adventures of Seb and Melanie in the future.

Here’s a quick quiz!Have you read the first six Jack Lazar books in this series?YesNoDo you want to read the next story in that fantastic series?Yes!I said no in the first question…If you answered yes to both, then stop reading this and buy it already!  If not, and if this book intrigues you, might I suggest starting from the first book, Lazar’s Intrigue?  But enough about the rest of the series:  This review is for Lazar’s Tempest!Jack Lazar cannot catch a break to save his life.  And he finds himself in situations where he has to save his life, and the lives of others, very frequently.  This time, he is trying to relax on a trip to Hawaii, when wouldn’t you know it, he stumbles upon an international plot against the United States, involving international terrorist groups, and caches of military grade missiles.  Don’t you hate it when that happens?  NCIS and the police do not believe that he is just an innocent bystander in this, and thinks he is intimately involved.  He, along with the “Bond Girl” of this novel, Leilani, have to stop the plot, and clear his name in the process.It is surprising that, after six installments of this series, I still enjoy the antics of Jack Lazar, and his cavalcade of leading ladies.  But it definitely is just as entertaining as the previous installments.  Jack is a fantastic character, as always, and Leilani is a great partner/hero/damsel-in-distress, just as the other ladies in the books have been.  While these books can probably be read individually, and in any order, I highly suggest you start from the beginning, and work your way through the exciting life of Jack Lazar.

I was recommended this book by someone, and I was almost immediately turned off from the description on the purchase page.  Mat is a “geek-turned-hottie”?  A) that is a very clichéd main character type, and B), being a Geek and being attractive are not mutually exclusive.  You can be both….  BUT, I decided to look past that, and try the book in spite of my previous misgivings.The story centers around Jeanne and Mat, a bartender and politician, respectively, who cross each other’s paths at an engagement party.  And for whatever reason, they just seem to keep running into each other!  Is it fate?  Or is it because they are the two main characters in a romance novel?  MAYBE BOTH!?  The story follows their many romantic dalliances, and their budding relationship.  These two crazy kids are such different people!  Can their relationship ever work?  Yeah, probably.It’s funny, I don’t have a whole lot to say about this novel, at the end of the day.  It is a nice read, but nothing really stands out as spectacular, and I also can’t point to any real negatives in the story, either.  Which may be my main problem with this book:  there’s nothing to talk about.  It is a well written, straightforward romance novel, that has compelling and relatable lead characters, and is overall enjoyable.  And that’s it.  It is a little rare for me to finish a book, and not really have any strong feelings one way or the other.  I would recommend this book, if only because I have no major issues with it overall.

I am normally not the type of person that reads nonfiction books.  It’s not that I don’t enjoy nonfiction, but I would much rather read a fantasy or sci-fi novel, if given the chance.  Moreover, I am a very big fan of historical fiction, which is the perfect melding of the two worlds.  When I came across this book, I noticed that it is filed under fiction and historical fiction, (although after reading, I don’t think that’s 100% accurate…) so I decided to check it out.It tells the story of Antonio Ponton, the first Hispanic person executed in the electric chair in the United States.  He was the troubled son of a tobacco farmer, who emigrated from Spain to Puerto Rico in 1870.  His father sent Antonio to Albany Law School in New York in 1911, but no one could have predicted what was to come next.  Antonio is convicted of murder, and executed by electric chair in 1916.  What is even more heartbreaking, however, is that he was wrongly executed.  This story tells the confluence of events that set in motion the events that led to this horrible injustice.The story that is being told in this book is an amazing read, but I have to say, the way that it was written leaves something to be desired.  It felt to me that the author would get bogged down in the details, instead of keeping the plot moving at an even pace.  Sometimes the slight deviations are welcome and add a lot of background to the story overall, and other times it sort of seems like filler, and I found myself skimming some parts, to get back to the main story.  Overall, though, I think it’s a compelling read.

The Bone Wall is a dystopian novel, centered around twin sisters, Rimma and Angel.  They are tied together through powerful magic, and not only that, but when they are together, only one is visible to the outside world at a time.  They are thrust into a dangerous world that has been all but torn in two by two warring factions, that will stop at nothing to gain control of the entire planet.  The sisters not only have to contend with the warring factions, and the rapidly decaying planet, but also with the actions of each other.  Angel normally takes the path of peaceful conflict resolution, and always looking for the good in everyone in any situation, while Rimma is the fight first, as questions later type, that is looking for revenge over peace.  Together, they will keep each other safe, in this world that they are thrust into.The dystopian world the author creates is a very compelling setting.  It is a future that isn't actually that difficult to believe actually happening:  Polluted water supply, megacities in disarray, and two factions diametrically opposed in their core belief systems.  Sound familiar?  The twin sisters are fully realized characters, that are entirely likable and relatable.  The dynamic between the sisters' personalities, while somewhat obvious on the surface (passive vs aggressive), works perfectly with the idea of the two sisters not being visible at the same time.This is a fantastic Young Adult Sci Fi novel, that could be enjoyed by anyone.  I highly recommend it.

I don't know why it is, but I have a knack for finding books that I very much enjoy, but are very hard to explain, plot-wise.  Enter A Hungry God by Pia Chaudhuri.  It is the story of two women, Aruna and Maya, who are brought together during a very bizarre chain of events, that involves magic, and blood, and an enchanted forest.  It sounds like it is a fantastical story, but it is really the story of these two women, and the trials and tribulations that they endure, on their path through life.For a story that has very fantastical elements, this novel seems to be a very personal story told by the author.  In her short biography on the Amazon page, it mentions that as a young child, she showed an innate ability for writing, that was nurtured by her mother, but she rebelled in later years, before giving in and following her "destiny".  Having that background information puts this particular novel in a different night.  It turns this intriguing mystical story into a compelling story of strong women that are not the "damsels in distress", but the heroes of the story.  It is refreshing to read a story that has strong female characters, although I am a little bummed that having a strong female character is something to be celebrated, because of the rarity.I very much enjoyed Pia's first novel, and will definitely be waiting patiently for the next one!

I have recently started a website with a friend of mine, and while we did not start this whole thing out to make a ton of money, we have been looking into different ways to make some money back, if only to recuperate the cost of the website itself.  Plus, we are both complete fools. If only there was some kind of instruction manual to teach us how to earn money on our website, that is so easy, even fools like us could not possibly screw it up!This guide actually has a lot of good ideas.  It starts you out with the basics, and an overview of the different kinds of revenue streams that you can have, and then it delves deeper into each one.  From impression advertising to affiliate sales and marketing, there is definitely something that you can utilize, and would feel comfortable using for your blog.The explanations in the guide are very simple, and it offers tips on how to get the most out of each form of monetizing.  If acronyms like CPA, CPC, CPM, and CPV seem like pure gibberish to you, and you think one might be a type of accountant, then this guide is perfect for you.  It introduces you to these concepts (they are all types of ads, by the way), and how each works, and which would be most beneficial.  Trust me, this is a very good guide to get you started on the path to making your blog make money for you, for a change!

I am a sucker for a good time travel story.  There is something about learning how each particular stories rules for time travel works, and wrapping your head around it.  This story not only has time travel, but ALIENS as well, I was completely on board from the start.Naami is from the latest 21st century.  She leads a group back in time to 1505, to change history.  It is there she meets Mohkave, a SON OF A Chief, who wants to gain some favor back in the eyes of his father, who is disappointed in him.  But they soon find out that they are not the only ones that are traveling back in time, to meddle in the affairs of human history.  Which is rude.  It was Naami's terrible idea first!  Avram and Lilith are aliens who have been steering the course of human history for a very long time.  And they are not about to let Naami ruin their carefully laid plans.While the time travel ideas do not work the way that I think they should (that's an entirely different discussion...), I very much enjoyed reading this author's take.  It was interesting, and complex, without being frustratingly so.  All of the main characters are interesting enough, and have unique perspectives on the situations that they have found themselves in.  I especially enjoyed the interaction between Naami and Mohkave (considering the latter met the former during a "vision quest"), and am very interested in seeing the next installment in this series, to see where this story goes!Who knew the fate of the world was already fought for, in North Dakota, in 1505?

FBI Agent Joe Roberts has finally found that one person that completely changes his mind about love and romance.  Problem is, she is partnered with him, as a mole for the company that she is working for.  When Dr Madeline Price learns of a criminal network run through the medical facility that she works in, she is recruited to collect information for the FBI, to shut them down.  Joe, along with Police Chief Matt Connor (and his wife / Joe's sister), are out to bring back their quiet little town to what it was before the meth labs took over.  And boy, is this situation going to get methy.... Sorry.There are two competing story types in this novel:  Detective/Cop Thriller, and "Forbidden Love" Romance.  For me, I came into this book looking for the former story type, and not as interested in the latter.  Don't get me wrong, I enjoy romance stories, as both the main, and side stories.  But I enjoyed this book as a thriller so much, that the romance part was a little bit of a distraction.  If both halves were equally compelling to read, I wouldn't have a problem at all, and would gladly give this book 5 stars.  The medical mystery that is the main focus of the book is excellent, and it was definitely worth the read, but I would have enjoyed it much more if the story wasn't sidetracked sporadically by the love stories.Bottom line, if you are looking for a romance-thriller novel, this might not be exactly what you're looking for, but if you're looking for a thriller-romance novel, you should check this out!  And yes, there is a difference between those two!

Bea's life is very complicated.  Trying to cope with the death of her mother from a strange terminal illness, her and her father move to a small california town, for a fresh start.  There, she meets Luke, a 17 year old surfer, and they both fall pretty hard for each other.  Then this book is pretty straight forward, and it ends... WRONG!  It's called TWIST!  Did you think that was it?  Turns out, Bea's father is a fugitive, and running from the FBI for unknown reason.  And, a video of her and her boyfriend "together" somehow ends up on the internet, and is passed around like wildfire.  The story follows Bea and Luke (both main characters and narrators of the story), as they try to carry on with their lives, and try to find out what is really going on.I very much enjoyed this story.  There are a lot of twists and turns throughout (as there should be, with a name like that), and it kept me hooked all the way through.  I especially enjoyed the storytelling style used by the author.  The perspective switched from Bea to Luke, so the reader can see different points of view of the same story.  Not that there's a lot of backtracking or overlap, the author does a good job keeping things linear and consistent, while at the same time showing both points of view.  It is really well done, overall.This is being sold as a Young Adult novel.  We have had many Young Adult novels recently that have been good reads for all audiences, and I hope that the "stigma" of a book being in the YA section has been softened a bit, because this book definitely deserves to be given a chance by everyone.

Zara loves her brother, Zach.  She loves him so much, that she will do whatever it takes to help him out of the situation that he has found himself in.  Zach owes Cal a lot of money, and Cal knows exactly what he wants as a form of payment:  His sister.  The deal is simple:  Cal basically owns Zara for three months.  She has to do everything that he says, and comply with any of his darkest desires.  She reluctantly agrees, and soon finds out how far Cal is willing to go to get his moneys worth.  From BDSM to exhibitionism, Cal and Zara cover the gamut of sexual experiences.I have to say, I wasn't that big of a fan of this story.  That might be because I am not a "huge" erotica fan, but I have read several different stories that I have really enjoyed.  But it seemed to me that the overall story was just a flimsy excuse to get from one sec scene to the next.  There was a little bit of setup for all of the characters, but not a whole lot of development after that.  But hey, if that's what you're looking for, then by all means, jump right in:  The sex scenes are very good overall, and worth the price of admission, but I am looking for a little more character development in stories.The ending did leave some room for a next installment, but I don't know if I have enough interest in the characters to keep going.  Then again, the author certainly has talent, judging from the erotic scenes, so maybe a second installment will allow the author a chance to refine their story telling, and bring a much more character developing story.

I was looking for a book on how to properly make yogurt at work at my desk, and I was thoroughly disappointed...I'm kidding, of course. This book is not about making the delicious and healthy snack; It is a book about creating a very efficient and happy work culture, and how to help all of the people in the group grow. I will admit, I wasn't that familiar with this type of team building idea, but as a new small business owner, with a group of five people total, I thought I would check out some ideas on how to make everyone's workplace a little better.One of the things that stuck out to me was that he says that there is more to Agile and Lean practices than doing things exactly by the book.  The best way to implement the ideas in this book is to take them as a jumping off point, and tailor them to your workplace, the best way that you see fit.  That is what the author tends for you to do with this guide.  I think there is a lot of good advice in this guide, and you could learn a lot from this author.The main problem that I have, is that there are many errors in spelling, grammar, and entire sentences being in incorrect places, things that a good editor would have easily seen, and fixed.  I think that is what this book was ultimately missing:  A second pass by someone, to tighten things up, and make things flow smoother.However, the ideas in this book are interesting, and if you can look past the issues in grammar and such, this is definitely worth a look.

Alright, I know that if you see that this is skewed towards 7-9 year olds, and you don't have any children, you might dismiss this right away.  It's a book about animals going on an adventure, and it's not for you.  But I think that, even if you don't have children to read this to, you should still give it a chance.It follows Banna and Bree, two baboons that are transported to The Volcanoes National Park in Rwanda.  Once they arrive, they meet the rest of the wildlife, and soon learn firsthand the dangers that they all face.  Poachers have been capturing or killing the animals for their own profit, and they have their eyes on the gorillas, who are worth a lot to them.  The animals band together, and make plans to protect each other, and their land, from these invaders.I'm a little torn when it comes to this book.  It is really well written, and it was a good story overall.  I enjoyed the interactions between the different kinds of animals, and all of their different personalities.  My main problem is, I don't know if the targeted audience is correct for this.  In some points it is definitely skewed younger, but when the animals plan their defense and attacks, it is kind of like being in a war-room for a country's military, planning their tactical strikes.  Plus, the whole "poachers" plot line is a little dark for kids that age, if you ask me.  Their entire profession centers around killing or catching animals to sell, that's kind of dark for a kids book.  I would say that this book would skew just a little higher than is currently stated on the books page.  Maybe put it to a YA audience instead?It is the juxtaposition of a purported children's book dealing with such adult topics, that I have to give it four stars.  I would suggest you check it out, but I would definitely check it out for yourself, before reading it with your kids, or having them read it.

Note to evil spirits out to kidnap people for their own purposes:  DO NOT kidnap someone that is married to a supernatural expert, because you're going to have a bad time.  But that is EXACTLY what happens in “The Anarchy Scroll”.  The expert, and friend, set off on an adventure that sends them to a different world where magic is prevalent, and what we call "supernatural" in this world, in the other is "regularnatural".  The only way to stop this rising tide of darkness is for them to find The Anarchy Scroll, and save that world, and ours.This book brought up an interesting question for me:  in the future, are the “ancient scrolls” that people are going to be searching for going to be on Kindles?  Honestly, you never see paper in the far flung future, so these “world-saving MacGuffins” are going to have to be data stored on thumb drives, or on e-readers.  That seems like kind of a bummer to me.  Anyway…This book is a very interesting read.  I love a good supernatural story, so I was immediately invested in the story.  I joke about the Macguffin, but honestly, every story like this, where people "go on an adventure to save the world", have something that they are adventuring for, and are ultimately trying to acquire or unacquire.  It is a solid paranormal story overall, with interesting and fully realized characters, but this book does have some issues.  The author tends to explain things that are inconsequential to the story, and over-explains things that are actually relevant.  It took me a little out of the story each time it happened, and I found myself skimming those parts, to find where the story picks up again.  But then again, there are parts of even my favorite books I skim through in the same way.Problems aside, this is an enjoyable book.  There are small sections that you will probably skim, but that shouldn't keep you from checking it out.

We are all familiar with famous wartime animals.  Donald Duck (Navy) and Snoopy (The Red Baron) being the most notable.  But what if I told you that there was an actual, real-life cat that has survived harsh wartime conditions, and even won a medal?The disappointingly ordinarily named cat Simon (considering how awesome this cat is)  is smuggled aboard the HMS Amethyst, a Modified Black Swan-class sloop of the Royal Navy during WWII.  He, and “ship dog” Peggy have their own fight aboard the ship:  Rats.  Yes, while the British Naval Servicemen were fighting Chinese Communists, Simon was fighting a scourge of rats aboard the ship!  When the Amethyst runs aground, and is stranded for 101 days, Simon fights his fight, to save the food stores for the men aboard, so they could fight for us all at home.  There is more to the story, and I won’t spoil everything, but Simon did win a medal for “Animal Gallantry in Wartime”, which is military talk for “Wicked Brave Cat”.Alright, I will admit, when I first looked at this book, I thought it was ridiculous.  But I ended up checking it out, because I happen to like ridiculous.  But I have to say, this book was a fantastic read.  WWII in general is a fascinating era for me, and I was especially interested in reading this story from such a unique perspective.  And what a unique perspective it is, after all, A CAT IS TELLING THE STORY!  DID I NOT MENTION THAT EARLER?!  WHY AM I YELLING?But honestly, this book was a fantastic read from start to finish, and I highly recommend this completely unique WWII story

The story follows Detective Jason Scarsdale and Police Analyst Dani Mueller are investigating a murder in Austin.  The victim in question, however, is a suspected pedophile, killed in unusual circumstances.  Both main characters have had children, so they both obviously have a personal connection to the acts perpetrated by these people.  But Dani, who changed her name and moved away to escape her past, has an even more personal investment in this case.  Her own 10 year old daughter was raped and murdered, and the man responsible was set free.  Obviously seeing that verdict as unacceptable, Dani takes the law into her own hands, and takes care of the killer.  Now, in a different city, she is trying to leave her past behind, but it is quickly catching up with her.There are obviously two main characters in this story, but I was much more focused on Dani's side of things.  She was a very compelling person to get to know, and to travel with on this journey.  Reading what her and Jason have to go through solidifies in my mind that that line of work would not be for me, because I don't think I would be able to look at each case objectively.  It was interesting to see the two investigators wrestle with their own emotions and background, in order to do the job that they are tasked with doing.  The story itself moves along at a brisk pace, without a lot of lulls in the drama.
