The twists and turns throughout added to the already suspenseful narrative, and the result is a gripping and thought provoking police procedural.If you are looking for a compelling crime drama, with many shades of grey, you should definitely check this out.

Once again, we delve into the complex relationship and love life of Kelly and Sam, in the latest installment of the "Experience" series.  As with the previous installments, this book explores once again the ever evolving kinks and interests of the couple, when Sam surprises Kelly with a trip to Europe.  It's not just a sightseeing trip, however:  Sam meets up with an old friend, who takes them on a tour that is more than likely not in any run of the mill travelogues out there.  They are introduces to clubs and gatherings that Kelly didn't even know that she was missing out on, culminating with a session with an actual dominatrix!As soon as I saw that Kelly and Sam see a dominatrix in this book, my first thought was "Yeah, of course they are!  I'm surprised that hasn't been brought up yet!"  Which is not a bad thing, mind you.  I just saw it as the obvious progression of this couples relationship.  If they wanted to keep getting more and more adventurous, this was definitely going to be on that path eventually.  Kelly and Sam's relationship continues to be a compelling read, and I still enjoy their relationship a little more than I like the erotic sections of this series.  And those are very well written, as well!If you have been following this series up to this point, this is a no-brainer.  It continues with the characters that you have come to care about, and shows even more growth in both them, and their relationship.  If you are just starting on this series, however, you should definitely check out the intro to the series.  It is shorter, and free!  You can't go wrong with free!

Just when you thought it was safe to go back into the water…. Now you have to worry about drug smuggling surfers!  Wait, what?  I have to admit, “Drug Smuggling Surfers” is what convinced me to check this book out, and I am glad I did.This is a true story of a group of friends who are airport baggage handlers by day, and surfers by the rest of their time.  They come up with a plan to smuggle drugs into LAX with the help of accomplished marijuana smuggler, August Taracina.  They are making tons of money, until the airport changes procedures and security, and they are forced out of the smuggling trade.  But they soon find another, more lucrative way to make money:  A heist.  They are able to pull the whole thing off, though, but things don’t turn out that easy.I had a couple of issues with this book.  It was an exciting and entertaining read, but every once in a while it seemed to languish in details that was not pertinent to the story.  There were several instances where I was reading, and thought “Wait, why do I need to know this?”, and most of the time, it didn’t really come back around and pay off.  It also tends to change tone in places.  One minute it is written like it is trying to give an honest and concise account of what happened, the next it’s a seemingly exaggerated description about different characters escapades, mostly concerning August.  This book does list 2 different authors, so that might be where the disconnect of the two styles comes into play.Amazon classifies this book as a Memoir, but I couldn’t really find any evidence stating that this story actually took place.  However, regardless if it happened or not, it is still worth the read.

Man, Michael Corrigan really likes historical fiction, huh?  Fortunately for me, so do I!  After previously reading and enjoying “Mulligan”, a book set during the Irish Potato Famine, I decided to check out what else this author has to offer.Down the Highway is a story told by two old friends, Terrance O’Hara and James Dean (no, not THAT James Dean), reminiscing about their past adventures.  And what adventures they had!  During their trip across England in 1962, they met such legends as Bob Dylan and Ringo Star, and were witness to the construction of the Berlin Wall.  They also reminisce about more personal, or “intimate” moments in their travels, especially Pat, the third piece in the love triangle that forges between the two old friends.While I was reading this, I kept thinking “Wait, so this is “Forrest Gump: European Vacation”?”  Which isn’t a bad thing (Forrest Gump is an amazing movie), but it definitely had a similar feel.  It was entertaining to see these two guys interacting with such monumentally influential people, before they became important figures in society.  I also enjoyed the relationship between Terrance and James that is portrayed in both the flashback stories, and current day.  They both felt very genuine and fleshed out as characters, and I thoroughly enjoyed listening in on their conversation about their past.It is an entertaining, and relatively short read.  I highly recommend it.

“Human Beings only utilize 10% of their brain power.  Imagine what we could do if we used 100%.”  Sounds like an over-the-top tagline to a movie that has actually already been made a couple of times recently, right?  Well, A) the whole 10% thing is not actually correct, and B) in some areas, we actually use our brains TOO MUCH.Have you ever had a decision to make, and vastly over thought every possible hypothetical outcome, that it actually caused real life stress?  Trying to factor in how people will think about the decision is another mistake that people make.  What this book tries to get you to do, is to make more decisions based on intuition, rather than outside factors and motivators.  To rely on intuition, and let your sub-conscious have a louder voice in the debate, allowing you to focus your brainpower on the more important things in your life.This book is very well segmented into the different ideas and rules set forth by Rajith Rajappan.  It is easy to understand and follow, as far as self help books go, and manages to not be “super preachy” about his ideas.  He even states that not all of the ideas he puts forth will work for everyone, and you should instead focus on the ideas that work best for you.  No really, it’s a self help book that doesn't spend an obscene amount of time convincing you that their guidelines are going to work, and less time actually going over the guidelines themselves!  It’s a fairly quick read (49 pages by Amazon’s count), that is simple, and to the point.  I highly recommend it.

After the final Hobbit movie came out this December (seriously, THREE hobbit movies?!?!  Come on…), I was ready and raring to go for a fantasy novel full of dragons once again.  I realized that I had never actually finished The Dragoneers Saga, a series that I very much enjoyed, so I decided to end this epic dragon saga, as well!Honestly, I don’t think I can give a concise summary of a sixth and final book in a series if I wanted to.  But this is obviously where the human fecal matter collides with the air circulating machine, and it pits King Richard against pretty much everyone that you have come to know and love in this series.  And it’s not even that simple, either.  Even though this is the final book in the series, it does not stop the author from introducing even more terrifying foes for the protagonists to tangle with amidst everything else.  Who will live?  Who will die?  Find out in the thrilling conclusion of The Dragoneers Saga!  That last part should be read in your best radio announcer voice…Endings are hard.  For every incredible ending to a story (The Dark Tower series, Breaking Bad), there are terrible endings (That show where it was all in that kid with the snowglobe’s mind?).  They are obviously not an easy thing to write, both in execution, and actually bringing yourself to write it.  I mean, come on, you CREATED these characters and this story, now you’re supposed to close the book on them, literally? While I have a feeling that we will see the characters in future works, I have to say that this is a hugely satisfying ending to an already fantastic series.I would not really suggest jumping onto this series with this volume, but I would absolutely recommend you checking this book out, if you are a Tolkien fan, or a fantasy fan in general.  Both the series, and this final volume, are a very enjoyable read from start to finish.

Cloud Atlas is one of the most interesting books I have read in the last five years.  That book consists of six different stories, each of which is in another one of the stories, in one shape or another.  It was an interesting idea, that worked well in conveying different peoples points of view, in similar circumstances, and how we are all connected by these experiences.Epiphany uses this idea, although in a much more concise and focused way.  It concerns 2 different stories. One focuses on Rosetta Melki, a tarot card reader, and Matthew Weissler, a finance executive, who are magically brought together by time traveling sprites from another era.  That “other era” being the 18th century, where author Edward Lillibridge is working on a fantasy novel, that turns out to be anything but fantasy.  It deals with an empire that is obsessed with gold, and the aforementioned sprites that they are oppressing, whose only wish is for there to be a kind of “Currency of Kindness”.  This book is actually a history book, chronicling the beginnings of the global monetary system, and is filled with warnings of the past, and a possible roadmap for the future.  Rosetta and Matthew need to work together, in order to bring about the Silvering, a new age for this world.For Sonya Deanna Terry’s first printed work, this is a very ambitious novel.  It perfectly balances the two stories/time periods, and somehow manages to make both halves better as the whole work.  The real world storytelling and the fantasay novel type stories might not necessarily work 100% on their own, but together, they create an intriguing and mesmerizing story, that I am very excited to see how it ends.

Everyone is looking to make their lives better in some fashion.  Whether it’s with more money, a better job, or better relationships with family and friends, everyone is trying to make things better for themselves.  The real question is, are there lengths that you would NOT go to, to accomplish this task?  Dari Ghaznavi would.  And did.Dari is a man who grew up in Pakistan, who pulls himself out of the gang lifestyle, and joins the Pakistan Air Force.  That eventually was not enough for Dari, so he moves to America, in pursuit of “The American Dream”.  Which obviously involves running drugs as a pilot over the Mexico/America border.  And you would also be surprised to find out that that isn’t necessarily the craziest thing that happened to Dari in his life’s journey.This is a no holds barred account of Dari’s life, that at times delves into the unbelievable.  And I don’t mean “Then Dari totally fought a dragon”.  I mean “Then Dari did some crazy things that he honestly should not have survived, but he is the author, so I guess he did…”.  It is an intriguing read, that deals with money, family, and religion, among other things.  Dari’s story  is a captivating look at the Pakistani life, the Islamic faith, and the ill-conceived notion of the American Dream.  I highly recommend checking it out.

Gifford Ulrich is living on the streets of St Louis, when a string of murders perpetrated against homeless people is taking place.  He decides to pack up and move from downtown, into the possibly safer (and possibly more dangerous), Benoit Neighborhood, full of abandoned buildings full of drug dealers and users, and other less than savory folk.  He is thrust in the middle of a horrible situation, created by even more horrible people, and he must use his previous military training to survive.This is the first book in a planned series of books, with Gifford Ulrich as the main character.  Gifford is an intriguing and troubled character, that makes for a fantastic read.  What this book does really well is portraying the depressing reality of the large amount of homeless American soldiers in this country, most of whom suffer from some sort of PTSD. It brings to light issues facing our service men and women today, and also shows that the idea of “if they would just get a JOB, they wouldn’t be homeless!” isn’t always so cut and dry.  It puts a human face on an issue that most Americans do not want to think about, or confront in any way, because that would admit how poorly we take care of the people that take care of our country.  Sorry, let me step down form my soapbox, and continue my review…This book is a fantastic thriller mystery novel, and a great first installment in what I hope to be a long running series in the future!

Demon Days is a story about a large group of friends, each with a more ludicrous name than the one before them, living in New York City in 2035.  Who just happen to have to deal with a massive crime wave, full of kidnappings and murders, perpetrated by demons.  From outer space.  You read that right.  It is a fight for survival in this brave new world!The main problem that I had with this book is the overall tone.  Sure, the author is trying for this zany and crazy feel, but it comes across as trying too hard at times.  I mean, there’s a character whose voice is auto-tuned all of the time (albeit, he IS a demon…).  The story itself is written rally well, and I enjoyed it for that in itself, but I did not enjoy the personality of the book.  Plus, it had NINETY SIX references that linked to passages in the back of the book, that would make you click each reference link, read a sentence or two of flavor text, and go back to the story.  Sure, they are optional, but it kind of took me out of the story each time I had to do that.However, I would say that you should read the sample of the book before you make the final decision.  It did not connect with me in a style sense, but the story overall was solid.  If you can look past the style issues that I had (or if you enjoy them), then I would definitely suggest you check it out.  If not, then I might suggest another work by this author that I very much enjoyed, Zombie Ever After?

When I saw the term “space opera” to refer to this book, the first thing I thought of was “FLASH!!!!  AAAAHHHHH!!! Savior of the Universe!!”, which as we all know, is the worst Queen song ever written.  However, I am a sci-fi fan, and I do enjoy dipping my toe into new YA series, so I checked it out.The story centers around Guy Erma, a 13 year old boy who has had a lifelong dream of joining the Dome Elite, which are kind of like "Space Marines".  He teams up with an unlikely ally:  Prince Teodor, who has recently been kidnapped.  They must work together if they want to survive.  It is a story of action, danger, blade fighting, cyborgs, shape shifting aliens, and Gorons, which are, in the easiest way I can describe them, RACING CATS!I have to say that YA novels can be hit or miss sometimes.  For every “Harry Potter” or “The Hunger Games”, you get “One That Isn’t Good, That I Don’t Know The Name Of…”.  But I am happy to say that I really enjoyed this book.  It has a lot of setting up to do, considering this is the first book in a series, but that’s obviously to be expected.  The sci-fi elements seemed grounded in the story, and very natural.  There was a definite lack of actual opera, though, which was disappointing…This book is a great YA novel:  It’s fun, exciting, and a blast from start to finish.  I highly recommend it, and will definitely be on the lookout for more adventures of Guy Erma in the future!

I am not necessarily the “targeted demographic” for The Adventures of Jo Jo.  It is a book comprised of eleven short stories centered around Jo Jo, written as bedtime stories for the children of the author, James Lawless.  I decided to check it out regardless, since they are short stories, and if I didn’t enjoy them, I wasn’t out that much time and money.There are a wide variety of adventures that eight year old Jo Jo finds herself in, ranging from meeting Rudolf (as in, The Red Nosed Reindeer), to helping squirrels cross the street.  …Alright, that doesn’t SOUND great when I describe it, but the stories themselves are whimsical, and fun.  They are all that kind of lighthearted yarn that is perfect to read to your child for bedtime.  Except for The Moving Door Handle.  That was kind of creepy, honestly…This book might not be one that anyone reading this review will pick up for themselves.  But, if you are looking for a great collection of short stories for “putting children to bed” purposes for cheap, this is definitely one that you need to consider.

I know what kind of book you have been clamoring for all this time.  You are looking for a book like Twilight, but the male in the relationship is human (Donovan), and the female (Cathren) is a zombie, and instead of all of the melodrama and moody everything about Twilight, you have a much more upbeat, fun, even humorous storyline throughout the book.  Also, you weren't actually looking for a book like Twilight at all, and the card you were thinking of was the six of clubs.  MAGIC!In the midst of a zombie outbreak, Cathren and Donovan are trying to survive a zombie outbreak, as is the rest of the world.  The main difference, however, is that Cathren has been bitten by a zombie.  But she, for some reason, has not went “full zombie” as of yet.  The couple are trying to deal with that situation, as well as the aforementioned zombies, and other survivors, to find peace in this world.When I saw this book compared to Warm Bodies, I was a little skeptical, as that book did not compel me in any way.  But after reading this, I guess that is because that character was “full zombie”, whereas Cathren is something in-between.  It turned the fairly straightforward relationship of the two main characters, into a much more complicated and interesting one.In an entertainment market that has been completely inundated with zombie stories in the last couple of years, this is a breath of fresh air from a pair of rotting lungs of a shambling corpse that is RIGHT BEHIND YOU WATCH OUT!

With everything that has been going on in the world today, especially involving Russia, I have been very interested in learning more about the USSR.  So when I stumbled across this thriller by Tim Tignor, it made my purchase of this book a no brainer.Alex Ferris is ex-CIA, who leaves the agency to become an international private investigator.  Which hasn't been working out that well, and hasn't exactly been paying the bills.  One day, he received a phone call from his twin brother, asking for his help, who very quickly ends up dead by an apparent "suicide".  While investigating in San Francisco, he uncovers a plot being run by a group in the Soviet Union, that is trying to steal US intellectual properties, in order to use them to create new patents, and bring huge amounts of wealth into Russia.While Putin himself is not in this book, we do have a fairly good replacement:  Vasily Karpov.  He is an interesting character, and the most compelling part of the book, in my opinion.  He was an ambitious and cut-throat KGB officer, that only wanted what was best for Mother Russia.  I enjoyed Karpov so much, that him by himself would have been enough for me!  But there is still a fantastic thriller here, and I highly recommend you checking it out.

Kyna Hughes is an ordinary girl, who, upon receiving a letter from a long lost relative, finds out that her entire world as she knows it is a lie.  Thrust into her new life of MAGIC and OTHER CRAZINESS, she has to quickly learn to adapt to this new life to survive.  If that wasn’t enough going on in her life, she starts to fall for two different men:  Aedan, a Navy SEAL hired for her protection, and Darcaryn, a wizard hired to train her and her new founded powers.  Which is ridiculous that she has to even think about who she chooses.  It’s not even a contest, if one of the choices is a MOTHER FLIPPIN WIZARD!If I wanted to be SUPER reductive about the plot, I could say “If Harry Potter was a girl, and lived in Ireland.  I’m not trying to disparage this book, or try to say that I didn’t enjoy it, but come on, it’s EXACTLY the same, down to the sexual tension between Harry, Snape, and Dumbledore… or maybe that was fan-fiction I read.  Anyway…  I have read many books that say that they are (insert any genre) / romance novel, and they are either straightforward romance novels, or a book in the other genre with a romance stapled in-between pages where it doesn’t fit.  This book however, is a nice blend of the two aspects of the story.  Add in to that characters that are engaging and interesting, and you have a really compelling read.MOTHER FLIPPIN WIZARD!

This book is an amalgamation of several different sci-fi tropes rolled into one.  James Hood was a Captain in the Earth Defense Force,  when humanity first ventured into space.  Transported on their trip by rockets made by the Epherium corporation, the colonists set out to find another habitable planet for the human race to colonize.  Then suddenly, ALIENS!  Sorry.  The remainder of the human race is thrust into a war against an alien race, which they eventually, and barely, survived.  During and after the war, secrets about the Epherium Corporation are discovered, revealing what their plans for humanity really are.First, I want to say that, even though I say that there are “several different sci-fi tropes”, there is a really good balance overall.  None of the separate stories seem rushed, or smashed into the middle of the book, just because they could. The odd part is that all of this stuff is included, and it is only the FIRST VOLUME in a new series!  The character of Hood is a compelling character, as well.  Sure, he is the “savior of the human race”, and “everything rests on his shoulders”, but would you really want to read a story like this with an inconsequential main character?  How boring would that be?  “And Captain James Hood just kicked back and read a book, as the Earth was saved by someone who really should have a book written about them, to be honest…” …..Great, now I want to write that book…..A somewhat straightforward start to a sci-fi series, that I am really excited about continuing in the future.

Historical fiction can be a tricky genre to write.  The story that you write could be fantastic, but if the “history” part of the book is uninteresting, you’re kind of sunk before you push away from the dock.  it is also important that YOUR story, and the TRUE story, mesh together well, and believably.  You can’t have a story about cyber bullying in Ancient Rome, it wouldn’t make any sense.  The difficulties that arise with this type of storytelling are why I am drawn to historical fiction, and especially this book.The story centers around Michael Mulligan, an Irish Freedom Fighter around the time of the Irish potato Famine, and the American Civil War.  Michael emigrated from Ireland because of the Famine, and, among other amazing things that happened to him in his lifetime, found himself fighting in our Civil War.  Numerous plot lines and motivations shape this haunted man into the person that you grow to know in this engaging and fascinating read.The worries about historical fiction that I mentioned earlier are completely unfounded in this book:  Mulligan’s story is a personal and harrowing story, and the historical context makes it all the more incredible.  The author is able to weave these two aspects of the story very well, and the end result is an all-around great read, for any fan of the genre.

Siri’s Heart revolves around Siri Wright, a Vegas exotic dancer and “adult entertainer”, that loved what she did, and did who paid for the privilege.  Her happy and exciting life is interrupted, when she is called back to her hometown, to take care of her injured mother.  Leaving her previous life behind, for a much quieter and secluded one, she happens to meet Aurei Moore, a helicopter pilot and neighbor.  When she first lays eyes on him, she feels that electricity that she felt when she was still in Vegas.  And the feeling is definitely mutual.  They have an immediate connection (wink wink!), and lets just say it definitely earns its “erotica” genre status!For an author’s debut novel, I have to say that this is a very well written story.  The characters of Siri and Aurei are compelling and likeable, and I was genuinely interested in their stories as they played out.  Which is fortunate, since this is Book 1 in the Siri Saga;  It would be bad to have a planned series with characters that the reader could not care less about.  But, if you’re reading this review, you probably just want to know how this stacks up as an “erotica” book.  It is definitely racier than your average romance novel, without being shockingly obscene, just for the sake of it.  It seems like a genuinely real relationship between the two characters, and I am definitely interested in reading more in this series.

Don't let the relatively large budget fool you. The Cannon Group was flush with junk bond cash at the time, and greenlighting practically everything, including this pointless mashup of JOURNEY TO THE CENTER OF THE EARTH, RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK, and BLADE RUNNER. Supermodel Kathy Ireland was hired for the lead, despite having a speaking voice like Minnie Mouse and all the acting ability of a deer in the headlights. (As far as acting goes, she fits right in with the rest of the cast.)It's the top-drawer riffing that makes this fifth season episode so enjoyable: Mike and the 'bots are not only improving Kathy's dialogue, but doing such beautifully arcane throwaway jokes as one referencing Laurence Olivier in THE ENTERTAINER -- yeah, this is the kind of thing I really like -- and, in a display of early '90s über-geekiness, there's a LOTR reference, years before the Peter Jackson movies. Oh, and don't feel bad about Kathy's abortive movie career: she's still a self-made multi-millionaire.

The RiffTrax shorts compilations can be hit or miss, but PLAYS WITH THEIR SHORTS is one of their better packages. There's not a dud among the comedy offerings on this disc.If there's a theme here, it seems to be how paranoid American society was in the mid-twentieth century. "What it Means to be an American" is a propaganda film that becomes increasingly unhinged as the stentorian narrator contrasts the virtues of American life with that of the godless Commies, while "Teenagers on Trial" raises the apocalyptic threat of juvenile delinquency. The view of teen life in "Understanding Your Ideals" turns borrowing your dad's car into an existential crisis, while the wartime "Women in Blue" demonstrates that women can do men's jobs, which America would work hard to forget just a few years later."Constance Bennett's Daily Beauty Rituals" squeezes a lot of useful, Depression-era beauty tips into five minutes (such as, have a servant make sure your bath is at the proper temperature). Every one of these nine shorts is a comic gem.

Loosely based on SEVEN AGAINST THEBES, OEDIPUS AT COLONUS, and a handful of comic books, HERCULES UNCHAINED turns a game of mix 'n match mythology into Steve Reeves' second (and final) outing as the title character, who must escape the clutches of the Lydian queen, Omphale, in time to save his wife Iole and his hometown of Thebes from a war between two power-mad brothers.It sounds more exciting than it actually is, but there's the riffing to make up for it. Truth is, I give the edge to the host segments this time: not only do we get Crow and Servo's spirited debate on puppet ontology and classification, but there's Mike Nelson's priceless portrayal of a latter-day Steve Reeves, and the SoL crew in "hedonistic" Roman drag.

Any attempt to make sense of "Star Force" (or its predecessor, "Fugitive Alien") will only confuse you and give you a headache, so let's just say that this installment has Ken and Rocky going undercover to sabotage a gigantic...something or other. Meanwhile, Tammy is left to look after Cap'n Joe, who's slowly recovering from another drunken binge, as far as I can tell.You'll have to wait 'til the last twenty minutes for the big showdown between star wolf Ken and his nemesis, a Darth Vader knockoff in pancake makeup. This Japanese space opera somehow owes its existence to a 1960s trilogy by pulp writer Edmond Hamilton, which I suspect is not significantly better in its original form. (This is one of those movies in which every line of dialogue seems to end in an exclamation point!)

A lavishly illustrated primer on SF movies and TV shows, the book runs the gamut from A TRIP TO THE MOON (1902) to big-budget flop JOHN CARTER (2012). Written under the auspices of Universal Television Networks and the Syfy Channel, the book takes its boosterism just a little too seriously, shamelessly pushing our nostalgia buttons while downplaying how ridiculous, or downright unwatchable, much of this stuff really is. (Dead giveaway: MYSTERY SCIENCE THEATER 3000 is mentioned only once, in passing, and doesn't even rate inclusion in the index.) On the other hand, the book is chock full of stills, posters, and publicity shots that are fun to look at.

"The Unearthly," shot in six days on a nonexistent budget and based on characters created by Ed Wood, falls into the limbo of "nice try." Despite John Carradine hamming it up as a mad scientist obsessed with the secrets of immortality, the movie is a snoozefest about three strangers who can't seem to find their way to the front door. Not even Tor Johnson and the Miss America of 1946 (as Carradine's jealous assistant) can raise the film from its own doldrums into something campy enough to stay awake through."Posture Pals" and "Appreciating Our Parents" are so-so third season shorts: amusing but unmemorable. A skippable episode, for completists only.

The words "French pantomime artist" can strike terror into anyone's heart, but the eight movies (five features and three shorts) in this collection are still worth watching. The influence of Jerry Lewis and Jacques Tati on Pierre Etaix is inescapable, but Etaix's character -- not as juvenile as Lewis's, not as sentimental as Tati's -- would happily settle into bourgeois society if he could, but the material world and the people in it simply won't let him. The character is a misfit existing on the fringes of consensus reality.The movies are wry as hell, and in "Yoyo," Etaix attempts a slapstick mash-up of silent comedy and Fellini-inspired autobiographical fantasy -- not a winning combination. I'm glad that the films have been rescued from legal limbo, and that we can finally enjoy what this interesting minor filmmaker accomplished in his one-decade directorial career.

Can you blame Archie Comics and Syfy for hacking this out to make a quick buck? It's as deliriously stupid as the Sharknado movies, which is precisely the point. Blood, mutilation, and ridiculous action scenes abound in a dopey one-shot comic that's perfect reading for a summer afternoon. Enjoy the cameo by Anthony Ferrante and Robbie Rist, who join Josie and the Pussycats to sing "The Ballad of Sharknado."

Richard Schickel at 82, taking a leisurely, rambling journey through the history of (mostly American) cinema, noting that what he liked as a younger viewer he probably likes now -- with qualifications.This isn't some tiresome list of masterpieces, or for that matter, a niche list of anti-masterpieces. They're largely familiar fare, though Schickel does direct our attention to such underrated genre pictures as AIR FORCE and NONE SHALL ESCAPE. These brief essays are most fun when Schickel delivers his informed, contrarian opinions on sacred cows: that M, for example, has been coasting on its reputation as a great film; that THE MALTESE FALCON and GONE WITH THE WIND are not particularly interesting to watch; that Frank Capra was a better filmmaker and Orson Welles a worse one than we've been lead to believe; and, mortifying for a professional critic, his admission that he just doesn't get The Rules of the Game. But he brings something extra to his consensus views too, such as his summary of TAXI DRIVER as "perhaps the most terrifying great movie ever."It's not a strictly linear, chronological take on Schickel's lifelong love of movies; it takes interesting detours and backtracks, ending for no particular reason in 1987 (BABETTE'S FEAST and WINGS OF DESIRE, anyone?). I like this modest little book, and I have the feeling it's going to grow on me even more, over time.

The combination of Liebman's testy lyricism and Stowell's low-key acoustic guitar playing makes this the sort of duet album one listens to with curiosity and respect, if not a great desire to hear it again. It's a chance to hear Liebman in an atypical set of standards and jazz repertory tunes, mostly on tenor (doubling wooden flute on "Black Eyes"). The three soprano sax tracks are the standouts, Lieb curdling the melodies of "Blue Rose," "Everybody's Song but My Own," and "Until Paisagem" (aka "If You Never Come to Me") to memorable effect. He also plays piano on mercifully brief versions of "How Deep is the Ocean" and "Time Remembered."

Roland and his cyborg partner Liz get a new robot vixen maid; erotic wackiness ensues.Tegerio takes an uncharacteristic step into drawing hardcore sex scenes, but his simple pen lines strike just the right balance of silly and sexy to make this an enjoyable furry romp for adults.

It's one of those albums that wants to be everything at once: light jazz, instrumental pop, Hollywood homage. What's impressive is that it all comes together as a unified statement: treat Mancini's music well, and it'll do the same for you. Some of the obvious choices -- "Charade," "Moon River," "The Pink Panther" -- are missing, in favor of such kitschy (but enjoyable) rarities as "Baby Elephant Walk" and the theme from "Hatari."Diana Krall, as far as I know, hasn't recorded any of Mancini's songs apart from her performances here of "Dreamsville" and the rarely heard, "Soldier in the Rain." The renditions are as sultry as one would expect, and if Ms. Krall ever wants to release an all-Mancini album, I'll happily buy it. "Days of Wine and Roses" is straight piano trio jazz for Grusin, John Patitucci, and Harvey Mason, and is the one track that strays furthest from the original melody. It also swings like heck.

Oh, what would we do without Joe Don Baker? In FINAL JUSTICE (aka "Mitchell's European Vacation"), we get to enjoy watching his sweaty Texas lawman chase a Mafia hitman all over the 122 square miles of Malta, the characters shooting at each other against the scenic, sun-drenched backdrop of this charming Mediterranean island. "We got cow pastures bigger'n this place," grouches Deputy Sheriff Thomas Jefferson Geronimo, in a movie made partially to promote the Maltese tourism industry.Of course Mike, Kevin, and Bill deliver a fresh new barrage of Joe Don Baker riffs -- not even MITCHELL could exhaust that motherlode -- and the movie is great, if sometimes painful, fun.

We owe the existence of this album to Howard Alden's luthier. The custom-made seven string guitar Alden plays here allows him to "complete the harmonies that Bill wrote," whereas his customary six string instrument couldn't have handled the low notes without a bass player's help.The album gets off to a powerfully swinging start on "Tune for a Lyric" (better known as "Show-Type Tune"), and brings in Frank Wess to blow some tasty tenor and heated flute on several tunes, including a Latin treatment of "Time Remembered" and a coolly cerebral version of "Five." Bill Evans on guitar? Oh yeah, it works for me.

This is one strange mama jama of a movie. Coleman Francis's 1961 directorial debut is not only one of the last (and worst) of the "atomic monster" movies of the 1950s, it's also a trial run for his next feature, that incoherent melodrama THE SKYDIVERS (1963). Tor Johnson is a scientist, fleeing through the desert from his KGB pursuers, when a nuclear bomb just happens to go off. Wackiness ensues.The movie was shot without sound, so instead of dialogue there's Coleman Francis's stream-of-consciousness narration: "Jim Archer. Joe's partner. Another man caught in the frantic race for the betterment of mankind. Progress." As in THE SKYDIVERS, there's a trigger-happy cop in an airplane, shooting at someone below (in this case, a guy who's not guilty of anything except lousy acting). There are the "trademark Coleman Francis butt shots," and Francis himself in a cameo as a lazy gas station attendant. Since the movie is basically an exercise in pantomime, it's like a 1960s version of a silent movie, only weirder and more obsessive.You also get two shorts: "Money Talks," in which the American Bankers Association tries to teach teenagers about the importance of financial planning, and "Progress Island, U.S.A.," a promotional film extolling the many attractions of Puerto Rico, including beaches, cheap labor, and rum.

Christian Tamburr's high-energy quartet makes a mighty, uptempo swinger out of the Genesis/Phil Collins chestnut, "That's All," and pretty much sets the tone for the rest of the album. Jason Mraz's "I Won't Give Up" is taken at a ballad tempo, "Every Little Thing She Does is Magic" is set to an infectious groove, and only "Wonderwall" is beginning to sound like a cliche in jazz set lists (it's one of those pop tunes that Mehldau made acceptable for everyone to play).Cleveland trumpeter Dominick Farinacci (a Marsalis-backed star in Japan) appears on a few tracks, blowing some good if slightly anonymous solos.

Howard Waldrop's stories are proof, if you need it, that science fiction isn't a collection of tropes (far future, space travel, technology, etc.); it's a way of seeing things. While there's no such thing as a typical Waldrop story, a familiar Waldrop protagonist keeps surfacing: working class, tough-minded, practical, contrarian. This is the character who has to figure out how to live when the bottom drops out of his universe ("Calling Your Name," "King of Where-I-Go," "Mr. Goober's Show").But then there's the sheer otherness of the bulk of his stories: a thirteen-year-old African boy obsessed with writing a history play; secret agent Kit Marlowe, dispatched to terminate the sorcerer John Faust; an obsessed American director using CGI to create a French New Wave art film starring himself; a wily sheriff vs. H.G. Wells' Martian invaders in 1898 Texas; Mickey, Donald, and Goofy at the end of time; and have you heard the one about the three Romans and a centaur? ("The only way I'll write a fantasy story is as if it were happening to truck drivers," says the author.)Science fiction, Waldrop keeps reminding us, is a great way not to make money: he points to "US" (included here), the shorter, better version of an idea that Philip Roth ran with in the later novel THE PLOT AGAINST AMERICA, as Exhibit A in a long career of one-of-a-kind, Hugo- and Nebula-nominated, perennial best-of-the-year-anthology stories that hardly anyone seems to know about.You should get to know them. You'll be glad you did.

An Ohio jazz educator leads his quintet (quartet on three tracks) in a program that oscillates between melodious ballads and midtempo tunes, and faster pieces in which the dissonance skirts the edge of free jazz without quite crossing over. The waltz "Gray Then Blue" gets the album off to a good start; VanMatre opens "Solstice of Another Age" with a meditative wooden flute before switching to soprano sax for a pensive variant on Coltrane's "Equinox." Pianist Kim Pensyl's funky "I Had You in Mind" lingers in my mind longer than the leader's slightly generic tunes, but it's quite a good album as a whole: accessible but challenging small group jazz, well worth checking out.

A big-toned Philadelphia tenor player who's gone underrecorded for decades, Michael Pedecin has one genuine surprise on this album: a relaxed version of Coltrane's "Song of the Underground Railroad" that sounds equally inspired by reggae and smooth jazz. The two originals by guitarist Johnnie Valentino are standouts: "Newtown" is a gentle elegy for the victims of the infamous school shooting, while "Then I Saw You" is an inspired ballad, six and a half minutes of sheer, soul-soothing beauty.Pedecin's originals are good blowing vehicles, and his quintet is first rate. So is the engineering, which I can't always take for granted in these DIY days.

THE HELLCATS is amazing. The sound is atrocious, and most of the dialogue, due to both bad recording and untrained acting, is incoherent; much of the film is out of focus; the plot, such as it is, is incomprehensible; the movie's idea of biker life is something like SONS OF ANARCHY for the Disney Channel; the songs are third-rate British Invasion rock 'n' roll that seem to share the same key, tempo, and lyrics; and the star is the mumbling, stonefaced Ross Hagen, whose acting runs the emotional gamut from A to A. In other words, it's a perfect MST3K episode.The movie is one extended non sequitur, and even the host segments, composed mostly of clips from earlier episodes, come off as maddeningly arbitrary. THE SIDEHACKERS is a model of logic and clarity compared to THE HELLCATS, but does that make it a better movie for riffing opportunities? You decide.

Another novelty record with real musical substance, which seems to be pianist Ted Kooshian's specialty. The contributions of saxophonist/clarinetist Jeff Lederer are invaluable to this music, which revamps the "Captain Kangaroo" theme, a train-inspired piece of light music by Edward White, into a Trane-inspired, odd-metered juggernaut. The "Spider-Man" theme is reimagined as a blues with a wailing clarinet solo, compared to which the sparkling 4/4 swing of the "Top Cat" theme seems almost prosaic.The longer I stay in Kooshian's pop culture saturated musical world, the more I like it.

Sherrie Maricle's small group jazz recordings cover a lot of territory, and cover it well. "That Old Feeling" is an infectiously upbeat feature for Anat Cohen's clarinet (when this record was made, she was still known primarily as a tenor sax player), deliberately evoking the swing era. Karolina Strassmayer's alto solos are nasty and honking in "Mr. Broadway," dry and sweet in her ballad feature, "Crazy, He Calls Me," and a bit of both in an uptempo "Polka Dots and Moonbeams.""Pure Imagination," arranged as a Brazilian choro, will bring a smile to your face, as will a swinging arrangement of "On the Good Ship Lollipop," powered by Maricle's flexible shuffle rhythm. "In the Wee Small Hours" is a feature for bassist Noriko Ueda, and the piano trio has fun with "If I Only Had a Brain." Music for blowin' the blues away, for sure.

The extras may determine whether or not MSTies who already own the Rhino set (from 2002) will want to buy the same thing twice, so let's clarify what's new to the Shout! Factory re-release:-- The bumpers and stingers omitted from the Rhino release.-- "The Crown Jewels," a featurette on Crown International Pictures.-- An extended trailer for Pete Schuermann's feature, "The Creep Behind the Camera" (2014), the fictionalized story of actor/filmmaker/con man Vic Savage, aka A.J. Nelson, and the making of "The Creeping Terror."-- Frank Coniff and Trace Beaulieu Q&A on "The Creep Behind the Camera" at Screamfest 2014-- Theatrical trailer for "The Creeping Terror"-- Improved audio and video transfers over the Rhino set (?).We don't get the unriffed versions of the features this time around, but does anyone really want to watch them that way? By the way, if you haven't yet seen "The Creeping Terror," it's a terrible micro-budget 1964 movie produced, directed, and edited by its lead actor, Vic Savage, and it reaches depths of incoherence, cheapness, and cinematic incompetence worthy of Ed Wood. It's so unintentionally hilarious that it barely needs the MST3K treatment, but I'm happy to have it; Mike and the 'bots hit this one out of the ballpark with one of the show's funniest barrages of riffs, ever, and that's while barely acknowledging the director's undisguised foot and leg fetishism. This is an episode for the ages.As for the other episodes, "The Skydivers" (1963), the second film in the infamous Coleman Francis trilogy, is a bizarre melodrama about an extramarital affair that leads to murder, without anything actually happening onscreen. Like "The Creeping Terror," it's a Mike-era masterpiece of savage riffing, but "Skydivers" reminds me more of a Daniel Clowes fever dream than of anything else in the history of cinema. It's unwatchable, but unmissable.After that, the Joel-era episode "Catalina Caper" (1967) and season six's "Bloodlust!" (1959) are disappointing by comparison. "Catalina Caper" is a beach party crime comedy with the anodyne Tommy Kirk, a musical number by a high-as-a-kite Little Richard, and the unfunny pratfalls of Robert Donner and Jim Begg."Bloodlust!" (1961) has Shaggy, Fred, Daphne, and Velma in a ridiculous version of "The Most Dangerous Game," which explains everything. It substitutes shock effects (boiled heads, etc.) for suspense, features future Brady Bunch star Robert Reed squeezed into a skintight T-shirt, and has a Vincent Price knockoff as the maniacal hunter. Interesting that Crow's wisecrack "Scooby-Doo, the Movie" was both accurate and prescient, 'cause just a few years later...This disc's short is a considerable improvement. Two city kids enjoy a working vacation on "Uncle Jim's Dairy Farm," which Mike and the 'bots rip to shreds, of course, in one of the funniest shorts in the show's entire run.

Solid, swinging, no-frills jazz recorded live at a New Jersey nightclub. The set list is about evenly divided between repertory jazz tunes and pleasant if not-too-memorable originals, and Bob Ackerman, who carries the weight of the solo space on tenor, flute, and clarinet, is a lively and engaging player.The DVD duplicates the CD's contents, but was filmed with a stationary camera, and the video resolution is atrocious. Trying to watch it will give you a headache, but the sound, ironically, is fine.

"The Benevolent One," the still, calm center of the Dave Holland Quintet's Points of View, serves the same function in this album of aggressive, angular hard bop. Every member of the band on BLUE SHIFT brought an original tune to the session, and the only cover -- Woody Shaw's "Tomorrow's Destiny" -- is a modal burner that fits right in with the '70s acoustic vibe of the session.Rex Richardson's trumpet and flugelhorn playing has speed and power to spare; he's faithful to the boundaries of tonality but likes to stretch them to the breaking point. Fellow Virginian Steve Wilson's inside/outside alto solos are as thrilling as ever, and high-energy guitarist Trey Pollard is an interesting solo voice in his own right.

Steve Heckman's laid back tenor playing is as groovy and tuneful as you could wish. There's very little angst here: Tyner's "Search for Peace" never sounded more relaxed than in this band's rendition, all yoga classes and green tea.The album is a connoisseur's selection of jazz tunes (Monk, Randy Weston, Grant Green, Blue Mitchell, and Sonny Clark are among the composers), featuring the swinging guitar of Howard Alden and the first rate Bay Area trio of Matt Clark on organ, Marcus Shelby, and Akira Tana. Heckman plays baritone on two tracks, but it's a tenor showcase otherwise.

Apparently no one alive now knows what a "swing parade" is, but who cares? Even without the riffing, this movie would be worth watching for one of Curly Howard's last performances before his career-ending stroke, for Louis Jordan singing his R&B hit, "Caldonia," and for rare footage of the great Connee Boswell singing "Stormy Weather." (Much fun is made of her elaborate dresses, which concealed her paralyzed legs from the audience.)Gale Storm (which sounds like a stripper's name) would go on to become a 'fifties TV star, but here she's the more interesting half of a romantic couple faced with various money and legal troubles. The disc gives you the option of watching this corny but amusing 1946 time capsule with or without the riffing, but the jokes do kick it up another level. This low budget musical comedy was directed by future film noir heavy hitter Phil Karlson.

There's a whole lotta Mehldau goin' on in this 2006 recording, but Moller's arrangements of classical and pop tunes are so devilishly clever, and so well played, that he'll win you over anyway. "Clair de Lune" becomes an unrecognizable juggernaut, the poco allegretto of Brahms's Third Symphony is now a 5/4 montuno -- Brahms meets salsa -- and Sting's "When the Angels Fall" is heard as an insistently rhythmic nocturne. The simplest tune on the album is Rachmaninov's "Vocalise" -- a soothing piano ballad in a set bent on celebrating the art of the odd-metered tune.

If ERASERHEAD's Henry Spencer had a cinematic father, it's surely Dr. Henry Krasker, the eccentric psychic sleuth of THE DEAD TALK BACK (1957). The amazing salt-and-pepper hairdo is a dead giveaway, and Dr. Krasker's obsessions, including a radio that communicates with the dead, and a blonde cadaver he keeps in a display case in his lab, are over-the-top weird. It's pretty funny for a super low-budget supernatural whodunit, but it's preceded (and almost blown out of the water) by the short, "The Selling Wizard," which demonstrates why Anheuser-Busch got out of the ice cream display business and concentrated on selling cheap, crappy tasting beer.HOBGOBLINS (1988), the sleaziest horror/comedy of 1988, is GREMLINS as softcore (very soft!) porn. A wise old security guard instructs his young, minimum wage apprentice in the ways of fighting the murderous, mind-controlling hand puppets that escape from a magical film vault to terrorize the city, which seems to consist entirely of the red light district. It's risible, but not terribly funny; it's a failed comedy, after all.Bill Rebane is nobody's fool. Having abandoned his 1961 Chicago-based horror movie after his investors refused to put up additional funds, he sold the uncompleted footage to exploitation king Herschell Gordon Lewis, who retitled the film MONSTER A GO-GO, releasing it in 1965 on a double bill with Lewis's own MOONSHINE MOUNTAIN. Rebane went on to film THE GIANT SPIDER INVASION (1975), and to run for governor of Wisconsin as the Reform Party candidate.What can one say about MONSTER A GO-GO? It's a low budget movie so inane, so inept, and so dull it makes MANOS look like THE SEVENTH SEAL. (Unlike MANOS, an over-the-top anti-masterpiece fueled by its director's sexual obsessions, no one connected with MONSTER A GO-GO seems to've had any interest in it whatsoever.) The creepy scene involving the truck driver and the helpless female motorist is the movie's defining moment of ickiness, much more so than the "monster" that staggers through the picture like a wino in search of his next bottle of Night Train.The defining moment of THE PHANTOM PLANET (1961) is Lt. Ray Makonnen's windy speech about the wise and the best, the good and the beautiful, just before he's taken out by a meteorite to the head. It's a typically dopey sci-fi film of the era, the kind of story that plays out as if science fiction hadn't evolved since the planetary romances of the 1920s. Funny? Yes, especially with a Pinto Colvig alien on the loose.

What happens when a mad scientist and a former vaudeville impressionist go into the grave robbing business together?Imagine Tod Browning's FREAKS crossed with a Three Stooges short and you get the flavor of MANIAC, a 1934 exploitation movie loosely (very, very loosely) based on Poe's "The Black Cat." The story, such as it is, is meaningless. What matters is the film's endless chain of bizarre images: cats pouncing on mice in a morgue; a madman running through streets deserted except for cats and dogs fighting each other; a drug-addled mental patient abducting and raping a dazed, female zombie; a bare-knuckle fight to the death between two plump matrons, and a human heart devoured by a cat named Satan; all this, interspersed with images of witches and demons, as well as with long blocks of dry, clinical text supposedly taken from the medical journals of the day.On top of all that, there's the unintentionally hilarious overacting of the two male leads, and the leaden non-acting of almost everyone else on camera. The film is the ultimate in found objects: a profoundly disturbing piece of folk art repurposed by RiffTrax into a masterpiece of dark comedy.There's a bonus feature: a 2010 panel from Comic-Con, with the guys riffing the short, "Buying Food", and then riffing on their fans as they line up to pitch ideas for the next RiffTrax movie. And I've asked this before, but I'll ask again: who the hell is Veronica Belmont?

The story started out slowly and I remember thinking I'd made a mistake trying out a new author. Of course, several hours later I finished the book and realized she'd done it - she sucked me in and I couldn't put the book down.So now I'm going to buy the rest of the books in the series because yep, it's that good. The author does a good job of showing New Orleans and the wonderful atmosphere that is Southern Louisiana. She could have developed it more but that's not enough to detract from an unusual and different storyline. If you like light hearted, fast paced and well written, you'll enjoy this story.

What a great book. I love Elle Casey's books and this one is no exception. It is light-hearted, funny and I had several times of full out belly laughs. Some parts just made you realize what a great sense of humor Elle Casey has. The only thing I didn't like is that I'll have to wait for more - I hope - stories in this series (which I hope is a series)!  The characters are likable although the ending seemed a bit rushed. I would have liked a bit more,  maybe an epilogue to finish it up a bit. It felt incomplete - sort of rushed. Other than that, it was a good story and a great beginning to a (hopefully) series.

I like using this app on my Kindle products. With a quick glance I can see how much time is left on my Kindle. It even tells me the approximate hours (or minutes) left for each use - reading, watching video, etc. I find it a handy app and will continue to use it no matter what Kindle product I have!

I have a couple of other lambswool dusters and needed one that would reach higher than I can reach. This great product has a telescoping handle that easily reaches where I need it to. I'd also forgotten how soft and handy the new (clean) lambswool works to get dust off furniture. I invested in the shampoo specially made for the lambswool so that I can take good care of this product. I will buy a couple more of these because they work so much better than paper towels!

I have used Nivea cream for years and when I saw this handy 5 pack, I had the epiphany that I could carry this wonderfully thick cream around with me and have it where I need it. I tossed one in my purse, have one by the chair in the tv room, and one in the kitchen for my hands for after washing dishes. This particular one is made in Germany (as opposed to Mexico and Thailand). It is thick (like Crisco) and works beautifully on dry and very dry skin without feeling sticky or greasy.

I've had my lambswool dusters for a long time and had no idea they made a shampoo for them! I ordered this as soon as I saw it and using this specialty shampoo refreshed my dusters so they are like new. If you have those wonderful dusters, you owe it to yourself to take good care of them so they last a long time - use the right shampoo for them!

I try to purchase Hefty bags anytime I need trash bags. I purchased these because they had the "apple" scent (different than lemon). They are strong, stand up to whatever trash I put in them, don't break no matter how heavy the bag gets. I like the handles because they tie up without breaking and keep the hole at the top of the trash bag closed so items don't fall out even if the bag falls over. What else do you need from a trash bag?

I needed strong bottles because I make my own household cleaners. I'd been reusing older bottles of products I used to use but they were not in  good shape. These bottles will stand up to abuse and multiple use! The sprayer has a "straw" long enough to reach bottom so no product is wasted. They are also easy to handle (i.e., not too big for my hand). All in all, this is a very well made product and I believe it will work for anything a person needs it for - and last a long time, to boot!

I received an ARC of this book in exchange for a review - but I loved it so much, I am also going to purchase the e-book so that I always have it. When I finished this book, I had such a feel-good feeling - what an amazing story! The relationship between the hero and heroine is so beautiful, complicated, twisted, fun, and as they learn about one another, even though you know it has to have a happily ever after, how they get there is so precious and well-written, you *sigh* and smile and love the story.This author is one of my favorites and you would think after awhile, the stories would become predictable, but no. This was such a different take on the reality tv series twist - I just loved this book. One thing I've always liked about the author is that she doesn't fill the book with excessive sex scenes as filler. She takes her time and builds up the relationship just like in real life. You get a REAL story, a book chock full of great secondary characters and well-developed heros and heroines.  This book? It's on the keeper shelf!

I've been using Neosporin for years and find it to work perfectly on any small cut, burn or scrape. I like the ointment because it tends to have better staying power. I like when they added the pain relief because sometimes you just need to numb it a bit. All in all, Neosporin is a great antibiotic.

I've enjoyed this author's books for several years and was glad to be able to buy them in e-format, too. This tale is a cute romp with few surprises but is well written, fast-paced and leads to the usual happy ending. The secondary characters are enjoyable, too, and all-in-all, if you're looking for a quick, enjoyable afternoon read while relaxing, this is a perfect book to start. You can't go wrong with a Judi McCoy book. Although sadly, the author did pass away in 2012, she's written several books that have left people in a feel-good place!

My husband has dry, dry skin and this Cortizone-10 works wonderfully to stop the itch. It works in, disappearing into the skin as it relieves the itching immediately. He has tried MANY other products but always comes back to this one.

I've been purchasing my toilet paper in bulk on Amazon for quite awhile now and am never sorry. This particular brand works beautifully for our household because we wanted the Mega rolls but also softness. Charmin Ultra Soft delivers. I also buy several each year as Christmas gifts for my son's goody box. He and his wife love having a bulk supply of toilet paper (and other products) as gifts that last almost all year! We all agree this Charmin is a great buy.

I have loved Nivea cream for many, many years. As my skin has gotten so much dryer, I've had trouble finding a product that was relatively greaseless and would still rub into my dry skin. I noticed this one advertised being made in Germany rather than Thailand or Mexico, so gladly purchased it. I will come back and buy several more for the other rooms in the house! It is a product I want to be able to grab anywhere, any time my skin feels dry. It is especially good on elbows and dry feet!

Since I make my own window and household cleaners, I wanted bottles that were more sturdy than the used ones I was using. These bottles are a thick, hard plastic that I can see lasting a long time. They are well made and the enclosed sprayer attachment is long enough to curve at the bottom to get every drop out of the bottle. It stands up straight without falling over, is well made and now I am going to buy the 16 ounce ones, too! I will gladly buy Chemical Guys bottles from now on!

My husband has been using Effergrip for years and won't switch to anything else. He finds it holds better than other grips and doesn't need reapplying as often. Since our local "big box" store quit carrying it, I've been grateful to find it here on Amazon. I buy in bulk each year and each tube is fresh and does what he needs it to do.

I have used Microsoft Wireless "mice" for a few years now. They are even easier to hook up now than in the past and are always easy to operate. I bought this particular one for one simple reason - it was red and matched my laptop (smile). It is a bit smaller than I'm used to but once I got used to it, the one I use with my PC feels slow and cumbersome! It's handy to toss into my laptop bag and I'd buy another one if I needed one!

I'm always on the lookout for delicious recipes for my slow cooker. I think anything I'd try in this book would be delicious and so easy to fix. The recipes are easy to follow and you know it is going to taste wonderful! I'm glad I added it to my cookbook shelf because I slow cook so much more than I used to but was having trouble finding unusual recipes. This book does it for me!

I always enjoy studying Solomon. This book is an easy to understand and read study on the practices of Solomon and is great for anyone wanting to understand more about this great man of the Bible! Mike Murdock writes books that are incredibly easy to read yet are packed full of knowledge and wisdom. I like to say he writes in "one-liners" because you'll end up quoting those one-liners later. They're easy to remember but are powerful tools!

Lately I'd noticed my dishes were developing a film that was impossible to remove. I also noticed any greasy dishes took several attempts to get the greasy feel off, especially plastic. I could pour dish soap right on the sponge and wipe the dish and still, it would feel greasy after it dried. I read reviews on Mrs. Meyer's Lemon Dish Soap, purchased it, used it, and immediately threw away all my other dish soap products. This dish soap is so wonderful that if I leave a container with used dishwater in it, the next morning if I put fresh water in, the bubbles come right back (not that I use it). It lasts! This soap cuts through grease immediately, no reside left over. I can use one squirt for all my dishes, without adding more. I will never use another dish soap but this brand.

This spray seems to cut through grease better than other products I've used. I love the scent I chose (Lemon). I find a lot of products now days no longer do what they are supposed to. So for, Mrs. Meyer's products seem to deliver!

If you've never used any Deva Curl products, you owe it to yourself to try this product immediately. The Deva products help your curls look healthy, well-defined and non-frizzy. This Light Defining Gel is like a miracle product for me - non-sticky and my hair feels soft and silky, with beautiful curls. The next morning, if I dampen my hands and run them through my hair, it is like it refreshes the product again! My hair is permed and before I used this, my curls were beginning to fade, looking like I needed a new perm. This product was recommended and I tried a very small bottle. After a week, I purchased this 32 ounce bottle because that is how much I love what it did for my curls. They bounced back and were perfect! It sure helps keep me from having to perm so often and the curls last 2-3 days.
Deva Curl brand has excellent products for people with curls - both natural and permed! This product helps keep the frizz away - easy to spray on and smells great, too!
These Glad bags are a perfect size for most small to medium trash cans. I find the product to be strong and have never had a problem with ripping or bottoms falling out!

I like the scent of this scrub, but what I really like is how easily it cleans my sink. It cuts through grease and doesn't scratch surfaces. I even used it in my tall narrow coffee mug, stainless steel. I know it isn't recommended but NOTHING would get the coffee stain out so I sprinkled a little bit of this on a brush and rubbed the sides - the coffee stain came off almost instantly but the product did not scratch the interior!  GREAT product.

My family has become so used to this Organic ketchup that normal ketchup tastes way too sweet. It seems to have a fresher flavor, too. We no longer use regular ketchup. This Heinz organic is a great one for families trying to eat healthier!

I know garbage bags are garbage bags, but these Glad bags are strong and smell great, too! They fit my smaller trash cans perfectly. I am glad I can get them here on Amazon because it's so easy to shop online here!

My local grocery and local big-box store both quick carrying the Ultra version of these disposable plates. I find all other versions don't hold up as well and even with this brand, we need two plates to hold up to the food. Ultra is stronger and sturdier and I was so glad to find the plates here on Amazon so I can always get this product.

I love this cookbook - it has healthier, lighter versions of Emeril's excellent recipes. There are tips, shortcuts, making your own seasonings, and how to stock your pantry. I have several of Emeril's cookbooks - this is a great addition to my shelf!

This is a light blue lip gloss. I don't know how well it makes your teeth look brighter and lighter, but it is an excellent lip gloss! My lips are soft and the product is not sticky. NYX (pronounced Nix) has some really neat products and if you haven't tried them, do so!

The pita pocket bread is fresh and tasty. Love that it comes whole because sometimes we grill a hamburger and just cut the top of the pita off and the burger fits in just fine. Most of the time we cut in in half and it makes two nice-sized sandwiches. I will order this bread again because it is a great buy and tastes great!

I love this eye liner. While it is waterproof, it doesn't really last that long. I've had some liners that, because I didn't remove my makeup, lasted for a couple of days! I love the color of this one and I would purchase it again. There was no eye irritation and it removes easily if you make a mistake (if you move fast, smile).

I love Kindle for PC. I have it on all my PCs and laptops (4). I love that I can read Kindle books on my computer without hassle. I love that I can read anywhere on anything! I have two Kindle Paperwhites but sometimes I just want to read at my computer and Kindle for PC takes care of that for me!

I had heard Ceylon Cinnamon was the type to purchase if you wanted to add cinnamon to your health regime. This has great, robust flavor and comes in a handy jar to shake or spoon out of. I'd purchase it again.

I'd heard the Ceylon Cinnamon is a better product for those who want to add cinnamon as a supplement to their health regime. My husband uses it daily so I needed a larger amount that normal. This brand tastes great and is something I will be buying again.

I actually purchased another brand crimper, a 1", but it was too long - this is a much shorter crimper and that works good for me. My hair is fine and thin and I needed something that could help with root boost. While this product doesn't have a temperature gauge - you're either off or hot - it works well for me. I would recommend it for anyone with fine thin hair.

This is a great crimper but a bit more than I can handle. My hair is fine and thin and I wanted this product to create a better root boost. It works wonderfully but I actually bought another one in a smaller size that is easier for me to handle. I would highly recommend this - it's a great product. I just needed smaller in size and inches to accommodate my fine hair.

If you like the smaller bottle hand soap and lotion, you will love this shower gel! I have fallen in love with this scent. It is fresh and not too strong. I have it in all sorts of forms - soap, lotion, powder, AND candle. You could say I'm hooked on it. It is a very rich soap and leaves my skin soft.

While I adore this lipstick, it was a bit too "stark" red for me. It is a bluish red but more red than I can handle. My skin is light and I believe this would look much better on someone younger! It IS beautiful and so soft and silky. I'll try to find a less RED color but again, it is beautiful.

Love, love, love these pans. They are definitely non-stick, heavier than expected and feel like quality. The label says you can use metal egg turners with it, but I'm sticking to nylon and rubber right now. I don't want to scratch! I do have to cook on a lighter heat setting - low on our gas stove. I'm used to that. It cooks faster than most pans and things slide around like they're supposed to - i.e. NO stuck eggs! I will be looking to get a couple more pans in different sizes - like a larger skillet! If you're looking for a good nonstick pan, this is one I can recommend without any hesitation. Well worth the money.

As an Amazon Vine reviewer, I requested a sample of "Intertape Polymer Group IG235 Iron Grip Duct Tape, 1.88 in x 35 yds, BlackIron Grip 17-mil premium duct tape" but instead received a roll of cellophane self-sticking packing tape for bunching items into a group or cluster.The cellophane packing tapes works great.  Just for fun (?), my wife tied me up in it and it's so strong I could not escape -- and I am one strong dude.  Random thought: It would be great for binding burglars until the cops arrive.  But you might also need a gun to get the crooks to agree.Sadly, I have no way of evaluating Intertape's Iron Grip duct tape.  And this review site won't let me post an item with no stars so I am only giving it 3 stars.  I know it's unfair, but what else can I do?

I love this colorful classic comic for it's wonderfully wacky, inspired, illustrations as much as I do for its timeless wit.  It's so nice to see the entirety of Jack Mendelsohn's strip in chronological order.  I can remember laughing out loud at what I preferred to think was a wise ass kid with anarchy on his mind -- although I probably read a lot of my own somewhat deviant perspective into it. It was hard for me to accept that an adult actually created this because it was so unfiltered and the art was so utterly, perfectly childish.  It takes a genius to pull this off and Mendelsohn is just that.  There's a terrific biographical intro that reveals the amazing accomplishments of the man behind the strip.  It appears he's partially responsible for creating the millions of laughs classic comedy shows generated including Laugh In, the Carol Burnett Show and the "titcom" Three's Company (among many more).  Oh, and Mendelsohn is one of the credited writers on the Beatles' Yellow Submarine animated classic.  This guy sure gets around.  I can't recommend "Jacky's Diary" strong enough!  It's an instant collectible and this edition will likely be sold out very soon.

Ever since I was a kid, the story of Noah and the Great Flood has been a source of fascination.  And I'm not alone.  After all, it's the most-told story on the planet.  By a casual count, there are about 200 independent "flood" stories that are organic to cultures both modern and primitive.  Of course, Christianity, Islam and Judaism share the same core story.  But was there a cataclysmic event at the far edge of history that accounts for all these rather similar stories about one family and the seeds of life surviving a deluge brought on by angry gods?  And what does it mean?  We still call big natural catastrophes like floods or earthquakes "acts of God" even though few of us believe it to be literal  -- or do we?The intensity of the story is so persistent numerous expeditions continue to search for the remains of Noah's ark on Turkey's Mt. Ararat, the region of the Biblical landing place.  During the 90s, I co-produced a segment of NBC's popular "Unsolved Mysteries" on the subject and shot footage around Ararat and interviewed eyewitnesses who saw something huge and manmade that has been preserved in the permanent ice cap of Greater Ararat.  I showed a special cut of this footage (RIDDLE OF ARARAT) at our local Short Film Festival a few years ago and was invited to show it in London.  Both screenings got wide attention and drew full houses.What is it about this story that still resonates with us on such a deep level?Darren Aronofsky has been working on his NOAH film for 15 years in one form or another.  He's known as a visualist and uncompromising filmmaker who loves stories about obsessive loners who are compulsively driven to the brink of madness in their quest to find God.  In NOAH, he has fashioned a $130 million epic film that reboots the Biblical myth with a bold look and modern sensibility.  The film has already raised the ire of some conservative religious groups that think they have the only interpretation of this scriptural disaster story.  They don't.  The power of myth is that it has relevance to each successive age and Aronofsky has delivered a film that's a fine fit for the 21st Century as well as a great return to the popular Biblical epics of 50 years ago.The fine cast features Russell Crowe, Jennifer Connelly, Emma Watson and Ray Winstone.  Crowe is a wonderful Noah who may be fighting a private madness.  He is a dark and intense protagonist full of existential angst.  Who can't relate to that?  He does not exactly hear the voice of God, but get's the message of his mission and the impending disaster in an acid-like dream.  Anthony Hopkins is a scene stealing (and scenery-chewing) Methuselah who endorses his grandson's dream.  If there's an antagonist, it's Ray Winstone as Tubal-cain, an environmental raping leader of a rogue army who attempts to hi-jack the ark.  There's a terrific ten-minute battle sequence that looked like something out of Tolkien.The production design and art direction throughout are superb and I liked the computer graphics that made the migration of the animals and the horror of the flood vivid and hyper real.I hope this film makes connects with a global audience (and makes big bucks) so that other mythic and Biblical tales can be realized on the big screen with all the personal vision of artists like Aronofsky.  In many ways, he's the Kubrick of the 21st Century.Forget the negative things you may have read or heard about NOAH.  Be assured, it is not sacrilegious, even though it may not be what you expect, it is an authentic retelling of this ubiquitous, enigmatic and powerful story.  For those conservative believers who are uncomfortable with the movie's theme of environmentalism and stewardship of the planet, it might be helpful to read the Biblical book of Revelation that specifically damns those who "destroy the earth."But does NOAH have meaning?  Well, that's up to you.  For me, it's a potent reminder that we are one human family and the earth is our ark.  No matter how you look at it, we are truly all in the same boat.  But first and foremost, NOAH is a grand, big screen, spectacularly satisfying entertainment that dazzles the eye and provokes the mind.  What more can you ask for?PS  If the ancient world and Biblical myths are of interest, you might consider reading the fascinating "GOBEL TEPE Genesis of the odd" by Andrew Collins.  It takes a look at the 10,000 (?) year old Turkish "Temple of the Watchers" that is linked in many ways to the Flood story in the real world.  There's so much we don't know about the outer edge of so-called written history.

I gave our little 14 year-old terrier "Bullet" a piece of Waggin' Train Chicken Jerky Tenders and he eagerly took it and carried it around the house in his mouth, but he eventually dropped it without taking a bite.  So, my wife soaked one of the dry, brittle pieces in a mug for a half hour and then cut it in smaller pieces. Happy to say Bullet seemed to relish it -- but only at first.  He never finished the pieces we gave him.But it may be that he has only had soft treats for the last several years and was stumped when he was given a hard one.  He's also an older guy and rather spoiled.NOTE: When I taste tested the Waggin' Train Chicken Jerky Tender, I thought it was a fine snack.  If I were a dog, I'd ask for it by name if I could.

Speed Stick GEAR applies easily and does not clump up, create a rash (!) or leave a stain on my shirts.  I like the way it dries quickly.  And it easily "lasts" (if that's the right word) for two days.  I am not a heavy sweater, and am not aware of any fragrance from regular use.  I like that.  How much can one say about an antiperspirant/deodorant beyond if it does what it's supposed to.  Someday, I suppose, I'll look into how the gel-like stick's chemicals actually react with one's body in a long term situation.  What is Aluminum Zirconium?  And Tetrachlorohydrex Glycine 18%?  How does it work on human skin to mask or stop perspiration and potential body odor?  For now, I am unaware of any possible side or ill-effects.

I love the feel of this "task" super light weight Tee.  I am not a clothes horse kind of guy, and I live in a place that has a lot of sunshine, so I usually wear sandals and shorts and comfortable shirt.  This shirt is perfect for me.  It's casual and looks stylish enough to step out in.One thing I noticed is that there is no washing instruction tag nor is their any suggestion of what kind of material from which it is made.  Apparently it is organic cotton and "viscose" from bamboo.  Does that make it synthetic?  Not sure what that combo is, but it does not stick to me when I perspire and the fabric seems to breathe.  It feels very much like cotton -- only better.  The material is extremely soft, light and comfortable -- almost like no shirt at all.  My wife likes wearing it as a pajama top.Hope it comes in more sizes and colors.  I recommend this great Tee.

I got this product after an email asked if I'd review it.  The glass seemed unusually thin, I couldn't remove the "double filters," I didn't like the underside of the lid -- it looked ceramic but was in fact plastic.  Oh, and the seal around the lid never seemed tight so there was an air passage when steeping.The coffee I prepared tasted fine, but the press unit itself was a tad shoddier than my Bodum unit.

Ever since I was a kid and first became aware of the impossible seeming migrations of our fellow dwellers on this planet we share, I have been fascinated with any explanation for this incredible "instinct" - whatever that means -- that very small and large creatures share.Bernd Heinrich's deep interest in the mystery of the natural world and his marvelous, sometimes mind-bending prose, draws the reader into another dimension that borders on the miraculous, at least to me.I need not detail the specifics of "HOMING INSTINCT" here, but among other things it covers solar, smell, visual imprinting, magnetic fields and other facets of the so-called mysterious homing instinct.Frankly, I could hardly put this book down.  Many more questions are raised by the partial answers in Heinrich's book.  But it's the "why" of it all that most fascinates and how it all relates -- and is shared --  by humans.Admittedly, there's a lot we don't know.  Perhaps embracing the mystery is the first step to understanding.  In many ways, I could not help but feel the natural world is still programmed by another world that barely exists.I was equally enthralled by Heinrich's "MIND OF THE RAVEN."  That one dispelled the last vestige of any notion that "bird brain" is an insult.Highest recommendation.
