This book will sweep you away with a sense of wonder and awe -- an emotion that we sorely lack in our everyday world.

The lingering horror of this murder mystery may be solved by a closer look at the parents.  Especially the mom.  Was she somehow involved in the killing or at the very least the deception?  Seems so to me.  This book makes a case that is hard for me to completely refute. I found it fascinating on many levels.

In spite of the haters, this epic taps into a great story of an incredible historical figure.  I hope this ultimate cut does it justice.  Director Stone has a gift for biography with a point of view.  And his commentaries are well thought out and fascinating.  Just listen to his defense of JFK.  Dense and detailed.  Fingers crossed on this title.

As an Amazon Vine reviewer, I get notices of products to review.  This one offered a "pack of eight 13 ounce jars" to consider.  I requested it, but only one jar arrived in heavy packing material.I am not a chocoholic, but sampled the product and shared it with my family.  No one really took to it after spreading it on toast and on banana slices and tasting it.  I will be surprised if this product catches on, even with chocolate lovers.The taste is kind of chocolaty but not really enough like a Hershey's almond bar.  At least according to my sensitive palate.And please know that I am not saying this just because I was shorted on the samples.  But if I had gotten the promised eight jars, what would I do with them since no one I shared it with was crazy about the rather bland but sugar heavy product?
Among the best tales of Hollywood life.  Raw and honest and -- at times -- very funny.  Part cautionary story and part love story.  Sharon should keep writing.  She has a gift.

Brutal and intense, writer-director Peter Berg's superb combat film, based on the vivid New York Times bestselling tale of heroism, takes a look at the 19 American deaths - and lone survivor - of an ill-fated incident in the Hindu Kush region of Afghanistan.Bloody and poetic, the incredible true story follows four Navy SEALS on a secret mission to kill a Taliban leader when they stumble across a trio of goat herders.  The SEALS choose the difficult decision to release and not kill them.  That act of mercy is rewarded by a relentless firestorm from at least forty Taliban fighters who quickly surround the four.Marcus Luttrell (Mark Wahlberg), Danny Dietz (Emile Hirsch) and Michael Murphy (Taylor Kitsch) are the brave SEALS.  Ben Foster and Eric Bana also star.  And they do justice to the real men they play - and honor.  Berg's smooth direction captures every horrific moment whether it's a bullet's impact or a treacherous fall.  We always have a sense of where we are and the camera movement is not frantic but wide-eyed - it's shot in the same way we remember frightening real-life moments.  The editing is tight and the performances never seem anything but real.  But in the end, it's the big questions that linger.  This ambiguity gives heft to this fine film and raises it to a level of meaningful contemporary art, especially with the ironic and satisfying ending that bookends the act of mercy the men showed to the goat herders.LONE SURVIVOR ranks with and is, in my opinion, superior to "Platoon," "Battle of Algiers," "Paths of Glory" and the sentimental, boring "Saving Private Ryan" in its visceral and moral intensity.  But finally, this brilliant film is about our common humanity and not the the hell of war.  Over the end credits, there are photos of the real soldiers who sacrificed their lives for what they believed to be a worthy cause.  I wept.

I love adventure -- both on the page and in real life.  I think I read most of "The Lost City of Z" at one sitting.  Similar books are hard to find.  Now I am enjoying "Mother of God."  Paul Rosolie's thrilling adventure in the Amazon jungle is a wonderful escape to a pristine place unexplored by white men and where the untamed planet functions with it's own awesome power, harmony and balance.  Here's a sample of Rosolie's vivid prose:"The jungle at night is the greatest freak show on earth.When the sun goes down the landscape welcomes a churning nightshift of murdering, slithering, creeping, fornicating, stalking, swimming, glowing life.  To walk the Amazon by night is to enter a world where you are gravely disadvantaged compared to millions of sensory savants.  Some exchange chemical signals, others complex vocalizations outside our auditory spectrum, and almost all have night vision."There are passages that will haunt your dreams.  Rosolie's dedication to preserving this last, vast natural patch of wildness on our planet is admirable and worthy of large scale support.  But it is his personal, solo, up close story that seduces the reader.  And to top it off, it becomes a love story.  Jungle love prevails in this truly awe-inspiring read.

I was delightfully surprised by the strong clear sound from my Simple Audio Go Compact Rechargeable Bluetooth Speaker.  I write a lot as part of my job (in the film industry) and sometime I like to take the earbuds out and hear music the way out was mean to be heard -- that is through the open air in a natural or human environment.The set up is easy with a smart phone or tablet and the battery lasts an awfully long time.  The thing that surprised me the most was the rich bass that came from such a small footprint.  Sometimes my wife carries the Simple Audio Go speaker in her purse.  Yes, it's that handy.The other thing that surprised me was the smooth interface when I got a call.  The Simple Audio Go acted as a speaker phone. The music stopped and when the call was finished it automatically started again at the same place!  Nice.Of course, it's all wireless and the Bluetooth signal carries much father than I expected.In a few minutes company is coming over and we are dining on our patio.  I'm putting the Simple Audio Go speaker on the garden bench a few feet away and will be playing select music (maybe "Iron & Wine") from my iPhone which is another ten feet away.Nothing better than good friends, food, conversation and great sound from my Simple Audio Go speaker.I am not aware of any cons for this ultra compact device.  It's all pros.

Attorney Bushkin's non-linear anecdotal account of Carson's flaws and Buskin's own career seems to be more about defending his (Bushkin's) actions (and firing by Carson) than a serious look at the enigmatic Carson who maintained a consistently upbeat, engaging, funny on-camera persona along with an apparently troubled, lonely, mean, unhappy, indulgent private life.  Carson once remarked (not in Buskin's book) that he had recurring nightmares of a big camera lens pointing at him and that he'd wake up screaming.  The dichotomy of the public and private Carson is revealing and certainly fascinating but Bushkin's bio of Carson seems like a vindictive last word in what must have been a long simmering anger at the man who made him very wealthy.  Bushkin glibly writes he hopes Carson would be pleased with this book.  Really?

It's been over 40 years since Leatherface terrorized us on the big and then smaller screen.Now Leatherface has returned, and in the true persona of actor and poet Gunnar Hansen we find a funny, self deprecating guy who is intelligent and articulate and with great recall skills.I was captivated by his observations of the low-budget  filmmaking process and the numerous complications behind, in front of and around the camera as well as the wider repercussions after the controversial and violent film was actually released under a wave of unkind -- to put it mildly -- reviews.Gunnar has an acerbic wit and a philosophical bent that makes his behind-the-scenes account of this indie and dangerous production somehow meaningful.  "Texas Chain Saw Massacre" is more than a blip in the rear view mirror of our dubious pop culture.  All the energy and time that went into the making of this film and the ripples that remain from just knowing it exists is a testament to something I cannot quite name.  Hansen debunks some of the myths that have attached themselves to this iconic film that ironically is now part of esteemed museum collections.I recommend this entertaining volume that was written with insight that not only details a sub-culture of low budget horror filmmaking, but also a sense of the absurd.But what still puzzles me is why we eagerly pay to be terrified and repelled at movies that depict the unthinkable nightmares that paralyze us?  There's an art to dabbling in fear, even if it's done on a shoestring and naively.  And there's an art to writing about it.  This is an unexpected book.  I loved it.

Since I was a kid, I have been fascinated by secret societies, the Masons, Illuminati, and the Templars among others.Susan Hodge's large format book is lavishly illustrated with beautiful color illustrations.  In the 200 plus pages, there are ots of reproductions of art, maps and photos of places that make clear the nicely considered copy.  The book begins with the mostly accepted notion that they Knights Templar began in the early 1100s to protect pilgrims to sacred sights in the Holy Land or Palestine.  (I have found here other historians who suggest the Knights morphed from a much older secret tradition.)I was engaged with the details of the rise and fall of the Knights Templar.  I have heard stories -- not  recounted in Hodge's excellent volume -- that the Knights still exist and have been active in Chechnya where they have recovered and removed nuclear warheads while both warring sides stood down anklet them pass.  Pretty amazing if true.If this subject is of interest, this richly detailed and compelling book about the legendary warrior monks will hold your attention and is strongly recommended.
I gave this made for TV movie a very generous 3 stars.  It is exactly what you'd expect from the title, if not quite the DVD box art -- which is superb.

On November 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was assassinated as he rode in a motorcade through Dealey Plaza in downtown Dallas, Texas.  That is a fact beyond dispute. To commemorate the 50th anniversary of JFK's untimely death, a remarkable collection of exclusive footage reconstructs the story as it happened, moment-by-moment.Kevin Spacey narrates the story of that tragic day through the memories of some of the people who played a part in those extraordinary events - from the journalist who was with the Kennedy family all day to the nurse who checked his vital signs at Parkland Memorial Hospital to the cop who was with Oswald when he was murdered by Jack Ruby.  New interviews and striking, rarely seen footage and photos make vivid the emotions and drama of that day.  In all fairness, it must be noted that this Smithsonian sanctioned production comes with the imprimatur of the federally funded institute and as expected, there is no deviation from the official government approved scenario of Oswald as the lone shooter.  Even a superficial examination of the now massive evidence raises doubts to the notion that Oswald acted alone - if indeed he acted at all.  That said, this is a remarkable collection of images, impressions and memories.If this documentary had included any elements that alluded to the multitude of doubts that Oswald acted alone as well as the many eyewitness accounts of another shooter, I would have given this otherwise fine compilation 5 stars.

If you miss old-school, 80's style action dramas with iconic leads, look no further than ESCAPE PLAN.  There's no deep meaning here.  The big (?) draw is watching Sly and Arnold share the same screen, and they do in numerous scenes.  This complicated prison-break thriller from director Mikael Hfström was mostly shot on a great set built in a NASA compound in New Orleans.  There's a futuristic feel to the oppressive, high-tech setting, "The Tomb," in which Ray Breslin (Stallone) finds himself as a hired "volunteer" prisoner to determine the security in this brutal prison under the control of a sadistic warden (Jim Caviezel).Quickly Stallone realizes he's been tricked and wrongly imprisoned -- for life!  Now he must team with fellow inmate Emil Rottmeyer (Schwarzenegger) to devise an escape from this incredibly fortified fortress.  But things are not exactly add they see.  Isn't that really the plot of almost all movies?  Yes, it's all kind of ridiculous, but it looks great and there are some big twists and surprises.  Co-stars Curtis "50 Cent" Jackson, Vinnie Jones, Vincent D'Onofrio and Amy Ryan are all on the same page.  This is a manly movie. It's a testosterone fueled, brawny action thriller, but the audience I saw it with was skewed mature with a majority of women.  And there was applause over the end credits.  Go figure.At the screening I attended, producer Mark Canton was present before the film started but we were told he had a "medical emergency" and would not return for the much anticipated Q&A.  Rumor had it that Canton made a date with two comely women he met in the lobby, invited them to dinner and discovered there was no escape.

For his new job at a tech-company, our son had to give up his iPhone since his work specifically required Android related concerns and applications. I suggested the Kyocera Hydro Elite as an excellent replacement.  So far, he is very happy with the choice.  He says the sound of phone conversations is clearer even in crowded train stations and the big screen (larger than his iPhone) is bright and super sharp.  Memory can be expanded and the device is waterproof up to 30 minutes in 3 meters (great for underwater video and photos!).  The latter is a huge plus for him.  Camera is 8 MB (most smartphone cameras are 5). He says the downloads are very fast and it's easy to wirelessly share files (photos and music). Web navigation is quick and easy and there's no problem running multiple apps!  The 4G Lite is many times faster than 3G (check the specs) and the 1.5GHZ dual-core processor and Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) is state of the art (as of this writing).  Also the device has wireless recharge.  Recommended.

I'm a visual learner.  I like to be SHOWN how to do something.  I hate reading manuals written by foreign engineers (you know what I mean, I'm sure).  Complicated, obfuscating jargon is not my thing.  I love photography.  (Hey, I even remember when something called "film" was used!)  I have been experimenting with digital photography manipulation on my iPhone and iPad.  What's not to love about the ease of iPhoto.  Even though iPhoto is user friendly, the best learning tool that got me up to speed was TEACH YOURSELF VISUALLY: iPHOTO FOR iPAD.  The photos are clear and direct and the minimal text (yes!) makes the images impossible to misunderstand.It's hard to imagine there are persons who don't realize what a perfect camera the iPad or iPhone can be in most situations.Richard Wentk's terrific series of books and especially this one are wonderful for people like me.  The iPhoto download is relatively inexpensive and the app has an ease of use and a friendly learning curve that is greatly enhanced (even for the novice) by this fun book.

My pretty wife has a full head of blond curly hair.  It's one of the first things I noticed about her.  I gave her the Remington D3020 Volume and Shine Hair Dryer to test out and this is what she told me:"I love the powerful air flow and the diffuser attachment.  My thick hair takes a long time to dry and I've used several different hand held dryers.  But I gave up on them and have been letting my hair dry naturally. Sometimes that's a problem if we are going out and running late.  I love the Remington D3020.  The unit is not too heavy and the heat button allows for three settings.  I use the middle one on the slower speed.  The "diffuser" attachment allows for a deep penetration of the air, appears to enhance the curls and seems to add significant volume without frizziness.  For me it's a perfect tool with a beautiful, balanced design.  The coollng setting is especially welcome I can "lock in" my final style.  I recommend the Remington (D3020) without reservation.  Oh, and the removable filter makes it easy to clean -- unlike my other dryers which I am giving to Goodwill."

Our son has just started his sophomore year in a sprawling apartment he's sharing with three others.  For some reason, picking up a wi-fi signal was a problem in some areas of their living space.  With the installation of TP-LINK TL-WA850RE 300Mbps Universal Wi-Fi Range Extender, that is no longer a problem anywhere in their suite of rooms.  They all have a sturdy signal for their various study, ahem, needs.  I'm told game play is also strong.  I like the clean, smallish design, the range extender button (not sure why it is not always "on").  I am thinking of getting one for our home.  Mainly to extend our wireless network into the shaded, park-like far corners of our yard!  Recommended.

I finally got around to watching the extended director's cut (at 3 three hours) of this 2006 film that was finally released theatrically in 2011 and for home theater at the end of last year.  Wow, I was mesmerized by this unexpectedly compelling -- almost operatic -- story of a 17-year-old New York City high-school student (Anna Paquin) who believes she has unintentionally caused a traffic accident that killed a woman.Her desire to set things right is met with opposition at every step. Torn apart by guilt and frustration that justice is an increasingly distant option, she punishes herself with self-loathing and hurts those around her as she realizes the real world of adults is a nebulous place where doing what's right is a foggy ideal seldom clearly defined.Margaret is not a character in the movie but rather a reference in Gerard Manley Hopkins 1888 poem "Spring and Fall." Hopkins asks: "Margaret, are you grieving, Over Goldengrove unleaving?" and then answers at poem's end "...It is the blight man was born for, It is Margaret you mourn for."The theatrical release has a running time of 150 minutes and it's the Blu-ray disc on the combo pack.  The far superior, more richly detailed and moody director's cut is 180 minutes and is on the DVD.  But it's the latter that seems shorter.  The superb supporting cast includes: Matthew Broderick, Matt Damon, Jean Reno, Allison Janney, and Mark Ruffalo among others.  It's safe to say this singular film has already garnered a cult following as an ever-growing number people continue to stumbled on this hellish emotionally journey of realization and redemption.

This amiable, meandering and finally satisfying documentary follows Chris Overton, a self-taught rural Quebec stonemason as he plans to build a 1,000-foot long stone wall in eight weeks.  Ten years into the project, the wall does not seem to be fully completed, but the obsession and the process has yielded a film about expectations and two guys - the other guy is filmmaker Bill Stone (yes, stone) - who are stumped to explain exactly what they are doing and what it means - if anything.  Clearly the lesson learned - at least by the viewer of the film - is that art and life are much more about the process than the thing itself.  Or maybe not.What I really liked, and why the movie is worth seeing, is for the last 30 minutes which are spent in Scotland with a "diker" who has spent 20 years learning his trade of making free standing hedgerows and explains why his is the best life possible.  I found a new way to think about stones that help in my own quest to be ever more mindful of the precious passing moments.Like Tolkien said, "All we have to decide is what to do with the time we have left."

Directed by Julian Pölsler, award-winning German actress Martina Gedeck stars in this riveting, allegorical tale of survival set in the spectacular Austrian countryside.  Exquisite cinematography propels this puzzling and thoughtful story of isolation and its impact on the human spirit as it is forced to rejoin the breathtaking but indifferent natural world.Naturally I thought of Stephen King's "THE DOME" (both the book and the cheap looking, seemingly endless CBS series with the god-awful music) as the movie began.  But this is a different take on a similar premise with superior satisfaction and rewards for the viewer.Gedeck delivers a tour-de-force performance as she endures all kinds of physical and psychological challenges when she discovers, to her horror, that she is trapped behind an invisible, impenetrable wall in a remote mountain area. This compelling, mind-bending adventure that's seasoned with philosophical, psychological and sci-fi elements kept me involved.Based on Marlen Haushofer's highly-praised 1962 novel (the only novel of her works to be translated into English), THE WALL is the story of Gedeck's unnamed character -- The Woman -- who is vacationing in the stunning Austrian mountains when an invisible wall suddenly and inexplicably encompasses the countryside and cuts her off from the civilization she left behind.  Though the blue sky, chirping birds and surrounding nature appear to be normal, The Woman is in fact cut of from all human contact and separated from the rest of the world.  With her loyal dog Lynx as a sole companion, The Woman becomes immersed and enmeshed in a pristine world hardly touched by civilization and ruled only by the laws of nature, which prove to be both benign and dangerous.  As she grapples with her bizarre circumstances, The Woman begins an inward journey of spiritual discovery and eventually transcendence.  At one point we hear her voice over narration (taken from her journal): "I pity animals and I pity people, because they are thrown into this life without being consulted," she says. "Maybe people are more deserving of pity, because they have just enough intelligence to resist the natural course of things."

A wonderfully goofy -- and arguably classic -- exploitation film collection that includes infamous movies about getting "doped up" and paying the consequences of such dubious behavior.  The films, in various degrees of preservation (I use the word loosely), are campy and unintentionally hilarious -- except of course if you take any of it seriously.  The mindset presented in these unintentionally hilarious cautionary stories was in fact somewhat representative of the conservative concerns of the 30s, 40s and 50s.  And no doubt in some cases people still living.  As an art form, this sub genre can be enjoyed on more than one level -- and not just as an excuse for breaking out that medicinal marijuana stash.  I still have a warm place in my heart for TERROR OF TINY TOWN (a western with a cast of small persons and their shetland ponies), and CHAINED FOR LIFE (starring the real life "Siamese twin" Hilton sisters (no relation to Paris).  Recommended for what it is.  More than 12 hours of solid laughs at a great price.  How much is that worth?

Since I was a kid I've been a film buff and as an adult have been lucky enough to work in the film business in several creative capacities from screenwriter to animator.  My fascination has never wavered with those dancing shadows on the screen and the shared experience of a global audience.For over 50 years Badiou, the French philosopher, has been musing about film and it's cultural, artistic, political and sociological significance.  His writing is fascinating to me and I was able to get past what at first may seem like "pretentious high-brow hog wash," as a friend recently said.I love that he, Badiou, is able to look at cinema as a subject that deserves serious philosophical consideration in style, theme and subject.  He loves film but I feel he loves thinking about the medium even more.The casual reader must be warned -- or reminded -- that Badiou is French and he writes from a decidedly French philosophical context and perspective and this English translation can be a bit hard going at first.But yes, I do recommend this collection.  For some, if you read in bed only to more quickly go to sleep, this might be literary Ambien.  For others, it will engage the mind and be rewarding.

The is an excellent addition to a desktop if you need a lot of extra USB ports.  The unit that sits on your desk is well made and takes very little room.  It has a  rather large power supply that you have to plug in, so you won't want to haul it around with a laptop.  It handles USB 3.0 and USB 2.0, so it's read for the next generation of peripherals, like USB 3.0 external hard drives.  It works on my Mac Mini with OS X (Yosemite) and also has worked on my Windows 7 desktop PC.  It has one port that provides power but no connection to the computer so you can charge a device that you're not synching to the computer such as a spare battery.  It works with my Brother and Epson printers, with a external hard drive, and with a webcam, among other things, but it doesn't work with an Apple SuperDrive DVD.  You have to plug that directly into a port on your computer (at least on the Mini).

The major advantage of the Dyno vs. a comparably priced Brother label printer is that Dymo labels print with less than 1/2 inch of leading and trailing  tape, so you don;'t waste a lot of tape between labels.  In contrast, current Brother models leave about 1-1/4" of tape unused at both ends of the label, so you waste a lot of tape (and buy more sooner from Brother).  A second advantage is that unlike Brother units you can set this to stay at a default the size, turn it off, and turn it back on without the size changing.  My Brother labeler defaults to large type when it's turned off.  Again, that can waste a lot of tape.BUT:  The disadvantage of the Dymo is the very poor keyboard layout vs. Brother labelers.  There's an oddly placed caps lock but no shift key to change just one or two letters to upper case, and there are almost no symbols on the keyboard.  Even for common symbols like "&" and for commas and periods you have to go into the Symbols menu.  This means a lot of extra keystrokes and extra time.  A minor issue is that Demo offers just a couple of label types vs. Brother, which has several.  Bottom line:  If you don't make a large number of labels at one sitting, the Dymo is  a good choice because of its efficient use of tape.  If you use the labeler a lot and make several labels at a time, you can set a comparable Brother to narrow margins and save some tape, and save a lot of typing time and annoyance.

This is an easy to use, easy pack blood pressure monitor.  It goes on your wrist, not on your upper arm, so the strap is much smaller than a typical arm monitor.  It comes with a small case that's great for travel.  It has an indicator light to tell you when your wrist is at the right height.  It's easy to use, has clear instructions and gives consistent results.

this connects a monitor with DVI output to a Mac Mini that has  miniDVI port.  The Mini has two of these ports closely spaced next to each other, and the plug on the connector I got is about 1/3rd wider than the one shown in the photo.  That means it wouldn't be possible to use two of these side-by-side in a Mac Mini.

This replaces a plain 1-1/4" nylon web strap on a briefcase.  It's length is sufficiently adjustable to carry the briefcase on a shoulder, and the wide foam shoulder pad makes it a lot more comfortable than the strap that came with the briefcase.  It's well made, and the availability of a few colors for the trim on the shoulder pad is nice.

Works for connecting a monitor with DVI output to the Thunderbolt port on a Mac Mini (2014 version in my case).  BUT... the connector that plus into the Mac Mini is wider than the Thunderbolt or Mini-DVI plug that Apple supplies, which is designed to fit into the tight spacing between the two Thunderbolt ports on the back of the Mac Mini.  If you want to use both Thunderbolt ports, one of the connectors needs to be from apple or at have a plug no wider than Apple's OEM version.  You can't use two of these side by side - the one on the right side won't fit.

There's a much less expensive version -- Model H-800, and you should probably buy that one instead of this one.I bought this a couple of years ago (in 2013?) to use with Dragon Naturally Speaking on a Windows 7.0 PC  It worked well, with good enough clarity so that the dictation was about 98% accurate.  Recently I switched to a Mac running OS X 10.10, and the headset wouldn't pair, but there's a solution (although it's kludgy).  Go to Logitech's website support page, search for Model A-00006 or A-00007 and click on Downloads.  Download and run  the firmware updater for the USB dongle that you have to plug into the computer.  That still didn't work when the dongle was plugged into a USB 3 hub, but Logitech advises that if you have USB 3.0 ports, this USB 2.0 device may not work unless you plug it into a USB 2.0 port or extension cable. I moved the dongle to a USB 3.0 Port on the computer itself and the headset works fine. In fact, I dictated this review using it.

The Colormunki colorimeter does reasonable job of setting profiles for LCD monitors, but the setup and execution are seriously flawed in annoying and stupid ways.  Three stars may be too generous, given these flaws.I have a Mac Mini purchased new in July 2015, and it is running OSX 10.10.  The primary monitor is a HP LP2575w with an excellent IPS display.  The secondary monitor is an aging  Samsung SynchMaster 906BW.  The software recognized both monitors and asked which one was being calibrated.  The annoyances and stupid flaws are:The CD that comes in the package has Version 1.0.1 of X-Rite’s software.  There’s no message one the CD offering to look for updated software.  When I tried to install the Mac version from the disk, it displayed a message saying that the software could not be installed on the internal hard drive (which has over 1TB of free space).  I went to the website and downloaded Version 1.1.1, which installed OK.  The downloaded version is dated December 2013, so X-Rite has been shipping units for almost two years with CDs that have outdated software.  (Either that or the one I bought has been on Amazon’s shelves for that long, which seems unlikely.)Second, after I plugged the ColorMunki into a USB port and started the software, it displayed a message saying that there was no ColorMunki detected.  It was plugged into a powered USB hub, so I switched it to a port on the Mac Mini.  Same result – no ColorMunki detected.  I had to reboot to get the software to find the ColorMunki. If I have to plug in directly, the opening screen or the printed quick start directions should tell me that  And why isn’t it detected after it’s been moved from a hub to the computer?  If I should have rebooted after installing the software, tell me that!Third, I was calibrating dual monitors on the same Mac Mini.  The software has a nice feature – it offers to match the display of the second monitor to the first.  Sounds good, but the match was inly so-so.  When I selected the option that starts the second monitor's calibration, second display was switched so that it appeared at the \primary display. It was necessary to open System Preferences on the Mac to switch back.The software offers two calibration modes – “Easy” and “Advanced”. It took about 14 minutes to run the “Advanced” mode on the first monitor, and about 6 minutes to run the “Easy” mode on the second monitor.  Monitors should be recalibrated every few weeks, but a 14-minute routine is a deterrent to checking calibration often.All in all, this unit is OK if you can live with the annoying flaws in the software and the slow calibration process in the advanced mode.  The flaws should have be long gone by the time X-Rite published version 1.1.1.

I bought this chair for its high degree of adjustability and its overall comfort, and it does not disappoint.  It replaced a desk chair that I spent a lot of time that was causing arm pain when I used a computer mouse for long periods.  The pain went away when I switched to the Leap chair and was able to adjust the height and horizontal position of the arm rests.  It's a very expensive chair even when discounted, but if you spend long hours at a desk and particularly if your using a. computer for long periods, the adjustability and overall comfort makes it worthwhile.

I bought this to use in "light painting" -  taking a nighttime photo outdoors with a long exposure and using a flashlight to light up a tree or other object so that it stands out in the photo.  The light is powerful enough and focused enough to illuminate the branches of a tree that was about 40 feet away, and it lit up an ice formation that was a similar distance.  It also functioned perfectly at ambient temperatures under 10 degrees Farenheit.  In addition to usual steady beam, it has a flashing white strobe and a f lashing red strobe - not often useful for light painting, but it would be visible from hundreds of feet away on a dark night.

This is a very handy little keyboard for an iPad, and it also works with Apple TV and Macs.  (You can get a different version, Logitech's K810, for PCs and tablets).  I bought it to use with an iPad Air after trying the Logitech Ultrathin keyboard/cover.  That one puts the iPad into a slot just in front of the keyboard.  The Ultrathin is the same width as an iPad, so the keyboard is somewhat cramped, and having the iPad in a slot just behind the keyboard made it feel even more cramped.  The Easy-Switch has a full-width keyboard with a full set of keys including arrows and a proper delete key, and it can work with almost any Apple device with Bluetooth connectivity.  The only negative is that it's a separate item to take with you, unlike a keyboard that attaches to an iPad (or one to which the iPad attaches). SO while the keyboard can rest on your lap, unless you're willing to cradle your iPad in on arm and type with your other hand, you need a stand for the iPad, and you have to be near a table to make use of it.  Still, if you're mostly taking notes at a school desk or in meetings around a conference table, it works perfectly.  The keypad is "clicky" and the keys have good travel. It would feel very good to a touch typist, and as a fast hunt & peck typist I'm happy with it.  It's light enough to be taken with you in a backpack and the case is aluminum, so it's solid enough to survive as long as it's not banged around.  (Logitech could pry another few dollars out of my wallet if they offered a nylon carrier for this keyboard.)There are several neat features, the most obvious of which are the ability to store the Bluetooth connection data for three devices and the backlit keys.  Once you pair the keyboard with, say, an iPad, you press a button to store the connection, and next time you're in range of that iPad, the keyboard will automatically connect with it.  You can do that with two additional devices, since there are three storage keys, and you can toggle back and forth between them -- say between an iPad and a Mac.  The advantage of illuminated keys should be obvious, unless you always work in a well-lit area.  They're great for use on a long plane flight, and even in moderate light it's helpful to have the backlighting on -- at least for a hunt & peck typist like me.  You can adjust the level of the backlighting.There is a full range of dual-purpose functions keys across the top.  They can work as either a regular function key for the application you're in or you can use them as special keys to adjust the backlight, or to select one of the three Bluetooth pairings, or change the volume or the backlight setting, or start and stop a video.  Taken altogether, if a separate keyboard fits your way of using APple devices, this is a great portable choice -- highly function, small, light and well-designed.

Smart TVs have come a long way since the first clumsy tries at integrating TV with access to the Internet.  This one is a good example of what's been done right, recognizing that there are still problems with the interface.  The TV has a neat remote control that projects on screen when you're setting it up so you can easily enter the info needed to get access to the Internet features.  You point at a series of on-screen prompts and you use the same interface to navigate the on-screen keyboard when you set up the TV, so you get through the setup process quickly and painlessly -- very different from the not-so Smart TV I tried about 2 years ago.A range of Internet services including Netflix and Amazon Prime are included so you can stream movies and recent TV shows.  You can select from a range of inputs including a Roku or Apple TV box, cable TV, or a computer, and the TV comes with built-in wi-fi that's simple to connect to your home network,  You can also plug it directly into your router using standard Cat. 5 cable, or connect it via a Powerline adapter.  This model has four HDMI inputs and various other ways of loading content, including a USB port.  What's still missing?  The Netflix and Amazon Prime apps don't take advantage of the excellent user interface built into the Samsung remote, so you're back to moving around their on-screen keyboards using direction keys rather than simply pointing at the letter or number you want.  You can make that process less painful by buying a Logitech keyboard for 70 - 100 dollars, but that shouldn't be necessary.  Perhaps someday soon, all of the installed Internet apps will respond to the type of remote interface that Samsung has come up with.Of course all that connectivity stuff wouldn't be much good if the TV didn't have a high quality HD picture, and it does.  The contrast ratio is good -- deep blacks and reasonably white whites, and you can tune the color rendition to your liking by getting into the setup menu.  We haven't used the 3D capability yet, but it's there if and when you want it.  (The Samsung 6350 is missing that feature, and it's a somewhat less expensive  choice of you're sure you won't want to watch anything in 3D.)

Michael Pearce finds a way to take us back 100 years and convey a superb sense of place, and then he takes readers on a enjoyable detective journey.  The detective story is nothing special, but the way he recreates the setting is worth the price of admission.  In this case he takes us to colonial Egypt and Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and right at the beginning he captures the tentativeness of the Levant.  Two workers in a transport depot come upon a box - a crate, really -- that's leaking unpleasant fluid and emitting a foul odor.  Sounds like there's a body inside right?  Call the cops?  Get a crowbar?  No, that's altogether to proactive.  And so the story unfolds from there, a good but not great murder mystery told with wonderful tongue-in-cheek humor and a superb sense of place.

My experience is that it's best to buy OEM lithium-ion batteries rather than take a chance on aftermarket ones, inexpensive/cheap though they may be.  This is a new OEM battery for Bosch 10.8/12 volt tools at a reasonable price.  It comes packaged right from Bosch, and it's compatible with numerous lithium-powered Bosch tools.  .

I've been using Office for years, probably since it first arrived.  I bought 365 because (1) it has an iPad version that allows the creation of documents on a mobile device and (2) that capability is supposedly integrated with OneDrive, the MS cloud storage offering.  So you should be able to create a document on an iPad and store it either on the iPad or on OneDrive, where you get a free terrabyte of storage with your subscription.Alas, while Word and Excel work very well on a keyboard-equipped iPad, there's a big glitch with OneDrive. Large numbers of users (including me) can't connect iPad Word or Excel directly to our OneDrive accounts.  So you can't create a document on the iPad and save it in your OneDrive account in one step.  If all the threads on the MS Office 365 support page are right, this problem has been unsolved for months, and it's a deal-breaker for many people. There's a work-around: Download the iPad OneDrive app from iTunes and open docs stored in the cloud from there.  While that's OK for documents already created and saved in OneDrive, it's no help for docs you create on your iPad.  You can save them there, but if you want to use the cross-platform capability you paid for and store them in OneDrive, as far as I can tell you have to email them to yourself, open the email on a computer and save the document in the cloud.  That's a stupid workaround, and if anyone who can tell me how to fix this, please adda comment to this review!  And it's very strange, because it's easy to connect to your Dropbox account from the iPad and access your documents, and it's easy to connect to OneDrive from an iPhone!Apart from the sad problem with Office apps on an iPad not connecting directly to OneDRive, Office 365 works well and the apps for iPad work surprisingly well.  If you want to use Office on a mobile device, subscribe for a month to try it out and see whether the missing link to OneDrive is too much of a pain to bear.Having said all that, it's only fair to say that the installation process on a computer was surprisingly easy despite the large number of one-star reviews.  When you install Office 365, it doesn't remove previous versions of Office applications (Word 2010, etc.) but it DOES keep all of your settings, including plug-ins for programs such as Dragon Naturally SPeaking.  That was a surprise and a great relief.The opening screen for Word and the other applications differs earlier versions of Office.  Instead of a blank spreadsheet or document, there's a screen offering to open create a new document. If you click on Open and then Browse you get to the usual Windows Explorer list of folders and files.  There may be an extra mouse click involved, but from reading some of the unfavorable reviews, I think people were thrown by the changed interface.  It's really OK -- it's just different and you have to get used to it.So... all in all, I'm still very unhappy by the inability thus far to figure out how to connect Word on my iPad to One Drive without a lot of stupid work-arounds, but the new version does integrate OneDrive so that you can access it from multiple computers.  That puts all of your stuff up in the cloud where it's not going to be destroyed by a hard drive crash.  And oddly, I could get to the files in the cloud seamlessly from an iPhone, but not from an iPad.  If I find a way to do that, I'll edit this review.

This is a three-way level to hep you get a perfectly level horizon or perfectly vertical lines when you're shooting landscapes and architecture.  Having three vials means that you don't have to take it off and turn it 90 degrees when you go from portrait to landscape mode.  It fits OK in a standard camera hot shoe.  It went into a Canon 5D Mark II easily - not too tight, not too loose.  It was a bit tight fitting into a SOny NEX 6 hot shoe.  I checked it with a small carpenter's level and accurate in all three orientations.  It's alot less expensive than the two-ways levels I've purchased before (and lost).  Hopefully I won't lose this one,but if I do, the replacement cost isn't very high.

EDITED 1/6/2015 after 6 weeks' experience.Slingbox is a great idea, but the Sling website and some of the software is awful, so it's hard to know what rating to give.  A zero for support and the awful app that that runs on an iPhone (and costs an extra $15!!).  A 3 for picture quality, and a 5 for the Slingbox software that runs on a laptop.We bought this so we could cut cable service in a second home and still get local channels from where we live.  We planned to do that by "screencasting" to a WiFi enabled TV in the second home, using an iPhone or iPad as the remote receiver for the Slingbox, and using WiFi to connect the iPhone/iPad to an Apple TV box and then to the HDTV.  That didn't work well at all.  There were too many WiFi jumps, and each one degraded the picture. But there's a work-around that's OK.Setting up the Slingbox on the TV at home was quick and easy.  After the box is hooked up, load SLingbox's PC/MacBook app onto a remote computer and you can even see and use a virtual remote control that looks exactly like the one that comes with your home cable box.  But when you try to use the Sling remotely for screencasting from an iPhone/iPad or laptop to TV via a set top box like Apple TV or Roku, TV, it barely works.  The picture quality gets maybe a 4 out of 10, and there are many times when the buffer runs out and the screen goes blank.  So rather than screencast to the TV using WiFi, we connected an HDMI cable between the computer and an Apple TV box.  (You could also use a Roku box).  You need a PC/MacBook in the same room as your remote TV to do that, and you need right adapter to connect the computer to a standard HDMI cable, because laptops don't usually have standard HDMI output.  (Apple TVs and Rokus have standard HDMI inputs.)For us, it was worth the effort and the kludgy work-around.  We had a old MacBook that can connect to our Apple TV box via a 25-foot HDMI cable, so we can avoid the unsatisfactory screencasting via WiFi.  The picture to the TV isn't high definition by a long shot, but cutting the cable in the second home will pay for the Slingbox in 6 weeks.  And the Slingbox app that runs on your PC/Mac laptop is quite good and it's free, a startling contrast to the expensive, awful iPhone software and the useless Sling website.The lack of decent, detailed information on the Sling website is very odd considering that this is a company that sells Internet-connected devices.  Examples: The instructions to screencast to an Apple TV are nowhere to be found on the Sling website, but if you poke around on the unintuitive Slingbox iPhone app (for which you had to pay extra...), you'll eventually blunder onto the right sequence of screen taps.  The website's Knowledge Base doesn't have information on the full range of products, and info on the Slingbox M1 I notably thin.  To access your account you have to go to a different web site altogether, but there's no link on the Sling home page and nothing on the main web site tells you that you need to do that.  But wait, there's more! The apps that allow you to access your Slingbox don't have consistent interfaces, and they're not linked.  Sure, you can set up a list of favorite channels on the Sling iPhone app (although there's nothing on the web site or in the help screen of the app that tells you how).  But the favorites don't replicate in the application that runs on your computer.  And if you search for instructions on setting up favorites on your computer, you only get info on how to do it on a mobile device, not on a computer - at least not with a Slingbox M1.  And all this lack of connectivity is from a company that makes it living selling Internet-enabled devices... strange.Once you figure out how to use this thing, it's possible to view your TV 100 or 1,000 or 10,000 miles from home on your mobile device or computer.  It's a neat trick. And if you can put up with the hassle, you can get a so-so connection to your remote TV so you several people can watch without having to huddle around a laptop screen.Four suggestions to reduce the hassle:(1) If your cable box isn't turned on at home, Slingbox doesn't work, and that's an ugly surprise whether you're 10 or 10,000 miles away.  But: If you have the free app for the M1 on your computer and click on the icon to show your cable remote on screen, you may be able to turn the cable box on remotely.  (The website doesn't mention this, of course.)  Just be sure to install the little IR booster light that comes with the Slingbox and place it right in front of the IR receiver on your cable box at home.(2) If you want to display the output from the Slingbox on a remote TV, forget about using WiFi from a mobile device - it's not worth the effort.  Instead, use a laptop and connect it via HDMI cable (not by WiFi) to your Apple TV or Roku.  If possible, use a wired connection from the computer to the router rather than wifi.(3) You may also be able to connect your laptop device directly to your HDTV as a computer monitor.  The picture quality may or may not be satisfactory, depending on the video card in your laptop, and you need an HDMI cable and the right plug converter to get from your laptop to you TV.  But it could save you the cost of a Roku or Apple TV, and like the HDMI connection in Suggestion (2), it reduces the reliance on WiFi.(4) If you can connect the Slingbox M1 to a wired connection to your router, do that rather than use the built-in wifi capability.  Even if your house isn't wired for a local area network, you can buy a "Powerline" adapter and connect via your home's electric wiring.Final advice: For watching on a remote TV, screencasting via WiFi is a weak link. Multiple leaps via WiFi seem to degrade performance significantly.  If you can eliminate all the WiFi links, the stability and quality will improve a lot.

Whiteside makes high quality router bits, and this one is exactly that.  It's a dual purpose bit, which accounts for its relatively high price.  It has bearings at the top and bottom so you can trim around the edges, flush with the face of our workpiece, or set the top bearing to ride against a pattern for pattern routing.  It has a 1/4" shaft so it's not for heavy duty routing -- for that you may want a bit with a 1/2" shaft, and Whiteside makes that type as well.

This is a solvent that works by dissolving the two surfaces of acrylic that you're putting together.  It works well when the two surfaces are quite smooth.  It doesn't fill gaps well, so if you're putting a cut edge of acrylic onto a flat piece, the edge has to be sanded smooth and flat to make a secure bond.  For example, an edge cut on a table saw is too rough to be adhered without sanding it first.  For smooth surfaces, it works quickly and seems to make a very good bond.  It has a solvent odor, but it's not overwhelming or objectionable.  Use thin rubber gloves when you apply it,  If you use  a brush, let the brush dry after use and the solvent will evaporate.  The open time for this version of Scigrip is just a minute or so before the solvent evaporates.  Scigrip 3 has a longer open time.

This is a well-designed, well-made tool.  It's smaller and less powerful than a standard sized 1-3/4 to 2-1/4 HP router, so if you're buying your first router you should look elsewhere - the DeWalt 618, Bosch 1617, or Porter-Cable 690.  The DeWalt 611 has a 1-1/4 HP motor and it's small enough to be held with one hand, but it only takes bits with a " shaft, whereas a standard router will accept both 1/4" and 1/2" bits.  If you use it with one hand, be sure to keep your other hand clear of the router bit.  It's good for chamfering, rounding over edges, edging countertop laminate, and for trimming the stick-on facing used on the exposed edges of plywood.  It might make shallow dados, but for any moderately heavy work it's better to use a standard two-handed router.  Similarly, it wouldn't be sensible to mount the DeWalt 611 under a router table, because the lack of extra power would limit the depth and width of cuts.The design of the fixed base is similar to the Porter-Cable 690, which is a classic.  The motor rotates inside the base like a big screw inside a big nut (the base).  So it's easy to make fine adjustments up and down.  A rotating collar lets you set zero and then rotate the motor to a specific depth.  A locking collar holds the motor securely so that the bit stays at the desired depth.  The adjustment mechanism probably makes it a better choice than the Bosch Colt trim router, with which it competes, and it has a couple of refinements vs. the Porter-Cable trim router, even though both brands are owned by the same corporation.  The motor has a soft start, which makes it safer and easier to use as a hand-held tool.  There's a shaft lock you hold so that you can tighten or loosen the bit with one wrench instead of two, and it works better than most router shaft locks.  The wrench that was included (in Nov. 2014) was made from heavy gauge steel - heavier than the wrench included with the larger DeWalt 618.The plunge base included with the 611PK kit is well designed, with four turret stops and a threaded stop rod that can be used to make very fine depth adjustments, so it's suitable for doing marquetry and inlay work.  You can orient the router in both the fixed and plunge bases with the cord facing toward you or away from you.The 611PK kit comes in a heavy duty nylon bag rather than in a hard case, which some reviewers complain about.  I think it's fine as long as you don't fling it around.  The only complaint I have is that the instructions are printed in 8 point type, which is just too small.  That seems to be a corporate policy for Porter-Cable routers, and P-C owns DeWalt.  Even the downloadable PDF manual uses tiny type, and if you enlarge it and print it at home, the image fuzzy.  Bosch makes a much more readable instruction manual and DeWalt could learn from that.

I think it works well enough, seems to capture all the micro-dust I expected. My complaint is that I had searched within Amazon for "washable air conditioning filter" and got this result. I admit I cannot recall if it stipulates otherwise in the description, but the actual filter is not washable (if you follow manufacturers recommendation). Will probably replace sooner rather than later as the replacement material for the filter is still a bit on the pricey side.
Very cute and exactly what I wanted. Price cannot be beat (especially for a trendy fashion ring that I probably will not wear in a year). Sizing was accurate.
Perfect little shoes, they are inexpensive but look really, really cute with cuffed jeans and a white tank or tee (what I wear them with). Can't go wrong and the sizing is accurate.

I'm new to using white powder and highlighting; I primarily use under my eyes. This stuff is so great and will last FOREVER AND EVER, so I'll honestly never even try anything else. I use an angled kabuki, which I've also ever used before, and am quite pleased with the results. I bet if I knew what I was doing i could get results that were super awesome instead of pretty awesome :)

After doing the whole tanning bed/sunning phase in my 20s, I found myself at 38 years old having a huge basal cell carcinoma removed from the top of my butt crack...the scar made my b/c look like it was 2 inches taller. At 40 I had a second huge basal cell carcinoma refused from my left butt cheek. I *never* laid in the sun naked, just the tanning bed, FWIW. At 44 I had a blue nevus with melanoma 'spindles' removed...it literally wasn't there and then 3 days later it was there on my shoulder. I honestly wouldn't have found it if I hadn't been using my Fake Bake Flawless Darker. So, theoretically, self-tanning can save lives :)  I started self-tanning several years ago and have used Tan Towels, generic tanning towels, Jergen's lotion, and Jergen's foam. I caved and bought Fake Bake Flawless two years ago, started using it during the end of winter so I could figure out how to apply for a truly flawless finish before summer arrived (with built in bronzer it is possible to streak). I've gotten my application (whole body) down to under 10 minutes. I've learned what works best for me: On Sunday evening, when I take my shower, I shave and I use a Scotch Brite scrubber (that's right, those green kitchen scrubbers...laugh all you want, but they are THE BOMB and so much cheaper than body scrubs!!!) to wash myself with a good moisturizing body wash. I get out, towel dry, use my towels to cover where I'll stand on the floor (overspray is inevitable), mitt up, spray the mitt, start from the feet and work my way up. I can do my entire body except the center of my back. I rub and rub and rub each section until it is obviously dry before moving on to the next section. I wear loose clothes to bed. With the FB Flawless Darker I can go longer between re-application (necessary after a week but I usually do after 3 days, just without applying as many pumps of the spray for maintenance applications) and the color is crazy good. Whereas my natural tan was a sort of beige tan, this is a bit warmer (though not scary Kardashian bronze). I love, love, love this stuff!!!

I usually look as good or better in bras than the models do - this bra not so much. I mean, it's okay, but it just looks more matronly and plain than it does in the photo. Also, it's weird how it almost makes my breasts look frumpier than they are without a bra. I kept it to wear around the house or if my other nude bras were being washed.
Very cute swimsuit. I'm a girl of a certain age (44) and the suit doesn't look silly or immature on me. Matter of fact I also bought it in polka dots, still cute without being "too young".

Compatible with my Cuisinart (Keurig-style).  I use mainly with loose teas, 1 teaspoon for 4 ounces of water because I do love my flavored teas (Teavana) strong, especially if I'm making a chai latte. Clean up fine in dishwasher, I put them in the flatware bins upside down with the lid folded back. Economical, too. Last forever unless I tear them up being careless

As soon as I opened the bottle, I could smell the difference in the Saigon Cinnamon and the 'other' cinnamon.  Now I can literally smell the bitterness in the 'other'. The taste is like comparing filet mignon to soy steak (this being the filet), in that I now can taste that the 'other' isn't real.

I've lost enough weight that I've gone from a 14 to an 8, but I still love these stretchy, comfortable jeans.  Just enough spandex that if the fit isn't absolutely perfect in certain areas, they have give if you need it.  To this day, as a girl growing up in the 80s, I don't think any current brand of jeans compliments the backside like the Levi's do. The others are either weirdly low (half on the butt and half on the thigh...that's just weird) or way up the butt (like Mom Jeans...Ick).  Perfect back pocket placement.

Got for my mother for a Christmas gift.  She has severe COPD and anything weighty would have really taxed her when she got out of the shower.  (She is on oxygen 24/7 except she does take it off to shower.)  This wasn't see through or thin, it isn't 'hot' like one made with synthetic fibers, and she is beyond pleased.  Perfect!
Love it.  Easy to hang.  Screws that accompanied were silver,  but I keep a bottle of dollar store black nail polish for such 'touch ups'.  Hung at the end of our kitchen cabinets.

Have been using Xanthan Gum for a couple of years (after discovering how much cheaper it was, because I had to use so much less, than the Thick-It 2 food thickener.  Unfortunately, my kid developed something that is shortened into EoE, and the three triggers are dairy, nuts, xanthan gum.  I had really hoped that Arrowroot Powder would have the thickening capabilities of Xanthan Gum, but it sadly does not...not by a mile.  I would guess this is more consistent with using plain corn starch.  By the time I used enough to barely come close to the thickness we needed (stiff pudding), you could taste the Arrowroot Powder and were also aware of the chalky texture from needing so much Arrowroot Powder.  Also, as my kid is a heavy drooler, after a few bites, if any of his (slobber) was on the spoon and re-entered the bowl, the Arrowroot thickness would disappear.  I can't recommend this for medically necessary thickening (for poor swallowers), but it might be fine for baking or what have you.

Such an easy at home solution for those averse to tanning beds and/or sunning.  Nice color; I know what I look like with a tan and that cannot be replicated, but this is the best cancer-free option.  I sometimes do a 'threesome':  I start with Tan Towels and rub myself down all over.  I follow-up with the Jergen's Natural Glow in the darker tone (I'm blonde, green eyed, and lily white but remarkably tanned pretty dark back in the day), applied all over.  I finish with the Fake Bake, applied all over.  I use the FB last since it has the temporary bronzer.  I also should note that I use nitrile exam gloves to do all of my self-tanning, because no amount of any miracle product and scrubbing REALLY gets all that stuff off your palms.  As dark as I self-tan, it still isn't visibly noticeable on my hands.  (Sun from driving?)  Anyway, my 1-2-3 approach gives me really, really, REALLY amazing results that last about a week without touch-ups.  But, most of the time, I'm just too lazy to spend all that time self-tanning, so I just use the Jergen's because it is, by far, the best of them all as a stand-alone.

Formerly used EZ Sweetz, which is quite a bit more expensive.  This tastes identical.  The seller NuSweet ships with the flip lid sealed in some kind of heat-sealed clear film, so there was no spillage or leakage in shipping. Glad I took a chance and tried NuSugar.
Exactly what my Mom wanted

I am not a huge girl (I am a size 8 US, so take that how you will): IF these towels do half of a body, it must be half the body of someone who weighs under 100 pounds.  While I can get both legs, toe to hip, out of one towel - I can also tell a difference the next day as the leg I started with is noticeably darker than the leg I finished (the next day).  The other brand, which I mistook these for when ordering - totally my fault - would do at least half my body with one half body towelette without showing any differences in tone the next day...and I was over 4 sizes bigger when I used them last year.

Actually it is, for me, more like 4 or 4.5 stars BUT because the issue I have is due to personal taste and not the functionality, I'll give 5 stars. I viewed this product three times before deciding which size of the exact same product to purchase - on my iPad 4, my Droid 4 phone, and on my Dell AIO/desktop. I mention this so that no one will berate me or my screen resolution for not noticing the finish (which is where my personal taste preference issue lies). The actual fixture is a great deal shinier white finish, moderate to high gloss, than what I perceived it to be (my perception was that it was a satin or even matte that was reflecting flash from the camera that captured the image). For me the finish gave the fixture a clinical feel, like the shiny white you see in hospitals or other medical facility lighting...admittedly our family has spent more than our share of time in hospitals, so it's probably just my problem (thus I gave it 5 stars). I happened to have a can of the matte white textured paint on hand, so I just gave the fixture a couple of quick, light coats and I think it looks great. The fixture, in my opinion, needed the grainy (almost like fine salt mixed in the paint) matte finish to go with the opaque glass. Easy to install (one gal with mediocre patience and one ladder, plus my 12v cordless drill [but a screwdriver would suffice]). Make sure, if using the CFL bulbs that the lumens are higher. I've noticed that some 60 watts are as low as 800-something lumens and some are as high as 1100-something lumens. The lumens-output isn't noticed by most folks, but is critical, I think.

This movie...this movie is one of the best movies I've ever seen.  So endearing, such a good 'moral' to the story, and enjoyable for anyone over 3 or 4 years old.  Some of the funniest quotes; we constantly quote this movie around our house ("Christmas means death; death means carnage: CHRISTMAS MEANS CARNAGE!" -Ferdinand the Duck).
I think any flavor of the Quest Bar is better than this mainly because there was so much icky aftertaste from the artificial sweetener.  Change that and I'll add at least one star.

Works perfectly with my Andis UltraEdge 2.  I actually prefer the jagged teeth blades to the finishing blades for cutting my Havanese, it just goes faster and smoother (which I know they appreciate).  This is a good length for one of my six - the only one with an uber-curly coat (and no way do I have the time or patience to dreadlock him, which I think is the 'thing' for the curlier Havs after a dreaded Hav won an AKC National event) for his summer cut.  His fur is so much thicker and silkier than the rest that he really needs the shorter cut.  One thing I'd like to suggest, if the blades getting hot is an issue (and I think it is for most anyone), I've invested in 2 of almost every blade I have and I keep one in a Ziploc in the freezer to 'chill' while I use on the clippers.  I check every couple of minutes on my forearm and as soon as the blade heat is uncomfortable to me, I swap the blades.  It is more expensive, obviously, but not even worth mentioning when you see a poor fur-baby on the 'net with burns that require a vet because some big-box groomer used a student to groom the dog.  (Plus, I have six... that was $240. plus tips every six weeks.  I have the clippers, the table setup, and two of every blade and still paid off within two grooms of all six.)

After 20+ years of trying, in vain, to dye my hair the color on those L'Oreal Excellence boxes (for me #7.5 Ash Blonde, which is only slightly lighter than my natural color) and have it come out a not-so-lovely color that I call Burnished Apricot, I finally figured out that if I switched out the developer in the box (which is only 10 volume, I believe) for this Ion Sensitive Scalp 40 Volume, in an exact ounce for ounce swap, then my hair can turn out the exact color on the box.  Yay!

I am grandfathered into my 4G plan, so I get unlimited data for $30/month still.  We've been going significantly over our DSL allowance each month because there are 3 of us with a Netflix habit in our house, and I wondered if I could stream Netflix off my unlimited data Droid X phone onto our 1080 LCD tv.  I did an internet search, found one of those 'geek' sites that gave the simple steps and necessaries-list, ordered this cable based on reviews by others in similar want of this type cable, and gave it a go.  Our home internet provider is gonna be mad :)

My older teenaged son is medically fragile with pervasive developmental delays; while he is quite small for his age, his bladder is not.  He's at the weight where he has about 10 more pounds and he will outgrow these (he's 102 pounds at 5'3" height).  I've tried some of the XS adult 'diapers' that claim to hold up to 30 ounces of liquid, not because he wets that much at once (who does?!?) or because I allow him to stew in his own filth all day, but - quite bluntly - because parts of him that inside the 'diapers' has a tendency to come out the top or the leg hole of these 'diapers' that are made for pre-pubescent boys.  The adult XS are just huge on him and cause more leakage issues with the large leg openings and massive stretch allowance in the waist of the adult briefs than we accidentally have with these sometimes.  We did find in our particular situation that putting boys boxer briefs on top of the GoodNites has all but eliminated shifting and 'escape' of his privates.  I apologize if this review is embarrassing for anyone to read, but I know that we are not the only parents/caregivers in this situation and I wanted to leave a review that might help someone else who, like us, doesn't have a "plain old" kid :)

I have a FB friend who swears by her FitBit Force (which I understand is no longer available), so I thought I would compare FitBit models and get the one that was right for me.  Not only did the FitBit One have more features that appealed to me, but the reviews were resoundingly more positive, so I figured I would give it a try.  It came early this morning via UPS, I've already given it a good full charge, read all the pertinent information on the website, and have a solid understanding (I believe) of what I needed to do - and have done - to set it up and get to using it.  Right off the bat I began counting my steps:  The first 30 steps recorded as 84 steps.  Ten more steps (which put me at 40) recorded as (a new total of) 106.  It does say STEPS, not feet.  Hmm.  Will definitely add to this update, but it looks like a cheapy $5 pedometer would have been as accurate for step count (heck, I think Google and Apple have apps available for free that couldn't be worse - I mean, this thing was wayyy off!).  I will update my review a couple of more times IF I find the discrepancy either improves or worsens over the next few days.

Was it THE ANDY GRIFFITH SHOW where one of the characters (Goober?) said that not even shining a light in their eyes would make 'em talk?  Yeah, this flashlight would.  It's THAT bright.  A must own flashlight if you live out in the country and are wondering what critter is way off in the distance, howling, at 1 am.

I belong to several Facebook loom knit groups and had even questioned the die-hard loomers, and this was recommended by almost everyone.  I've also read the blogs of some loom knitters, not on any of my FB groups, that recommended this book, too.

At first it was very awkward, but I persevered.  Now I am faster with this hook than I ever was with any of the other hooks (trust me, I have them all).  Give yourself some time, be willing to experiment with your 'moves', and in no time you'll find a groove where you'll be flying through your loom knitting.

We use for our corporate records.  They look very professional in the accounting office bookcase (even more so than the cheapy binder our attorney used on our principal corporation, which I have replaced with one of these as well).

Having a 'perpetual' child (special needs/medically fragile/developmentally delayed), I've used just about every bed pad known to mankind: They're all pretty good, but none are large enough for more than a twin bed or crib. My 'big kid' needs more than a twin sized bed - he's very much a traveler when he's in bed (imagine how two year olds are all over a bed...now imagine a two year old the size of an adult all over the bed) and he ALWAYS came off the twin sized ones, whether it was up or sideways; he even manages to get along the edge of the bed and then have his accident down the side of the bed).  This size will fit the top of a king size mattress, so it hangs off the sides of a full and definitely is full coverage on a queen.  Another plus, for me, is if you don't want to bleach bed pads to remove urine stains, these can be washed with the detergent of your choice, and you know they are clean without a dingy yellow cast that only bleach can remove.  If there is a detraction from these, it is that the fabric on the back side is knit so so tight, to keep anything from going through, that it kind of makes your own body heat radiate back up.  In other words, they can be warmish - even under a quality sheet.  For us, though, that's not an issue.  I have MANY of these pads, so if there is an accident in the middle of the night, he can be changed and the bed pad can be swapped without too much hassle.  When you do need to launder, throw 'em in the washer as if they were a load of towels - they're durable enough for multiple washings on even a whites setting (hot water, etc.).  Price is, on a price per square inch basis, much better than the white cottony bed pads.

My doggies love these things! I was concerned that they wouldn't be able to figure them out, since they are a little older and have never had anything but their water bowls before, but I showed them each once and they took to it immediately.  I like that each bottle comes with a little plastic, floating turtle to let you know what the water level is without having to pull them out of their holder (oh yeah, they do come with the wire holder for inside a rabbit cage - or in our case a dog crate).  One does leak a bit here and there, but only sometimes.  I just put their food bowl underneath to help catch (I also line their crates with a washable whelping pad instead of disposable wee pads or towels or just leaving them with a plastic pan, so that also catches any errant drips if the food bowl gets moved).
and if you loom knit a hat, unless you own a pricey wood one, this is THE loom to have for hats.  The original is still the best.

I have had every high priced pillow on the planet (yep, I'm a gullible gimmick geek) - memory foam, cooling gel, latex foam (those were the high priced ones back in the day), down, down alternative - and I've bought every el cheapo within driving distance.  Nothing ever satisfied me.  Low expectations in place, I ordered this pillow.  Yes, the individually Thank You note inside is really, really nice; of course the THANK YOU! on the outside of the box makes you feel good about your purchase.  But the true test is lying down, doing the flip-twist-flip of getting into the perfect position (I don't have just one sleeping position, I vary from night to night).  I was amaZzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzed :) at how truly incredibly comfy this pillow sleeps.  I will never, ever, ever buy another pillow of any brand or hype again.  This is THE PILLOW.************UPDATE: It is now September 2015 and for about a month I've wanted to replace this pillow. It doesn't look flat, but I lie down and no matter how much I punch it and flip it and fluff it, the second my head hits the very poofy looking pillow, it goes straight down to the bed like the pillow was full of nothing but air. The "5 stars" feelings of one year ago lasted a couple of months before the euphoria (and some of the pillows perfection) wore off. I would guess that every time I washed the pillow, per manufacturer instruction mind you, it lost a star. Five stars in August 2014 down to 1 star September 2015 averages to 3 stars overall, I'd say (the current rating I've given in this review). Do pillows this price really only have a one year life span?

Granted, I think they're a dollar or two less for this size at the wholesale clubs, but if you're like me and live 30+ miles to the closest one of those, then it's completely worth it in gas alone to order off of Amazon.

I bought this to make some fudge for my mom (No Bake Oreo Fudge) and it was perfect. Some syrups have a fake taste, but this is the real deal.  We are looking at some super cold weather here in GA the next few days, and I think I'll use this syrup to take the ho-hum out of our hot chocolate drinks.

My teen takes the Melatonin, as advised by his neurologist, to help with the insomnia that is a side effect of each of the anti-epileptics he takes. Previously we've used the Spring Valley 10 mg Timed Release melatonin with good result.  I purchased those in store and ran out, was placing an Amazon order and saw what a good price this particular Melatonin was (melatonin 10mg timed release is melatonin 10mg timed release, right?!?) and purchased it.  I don't know what, if any difference, there is between the two brands but not one night has he slept with just this product.  The result we see is none, it's as if he didn't get this given to him at all.  Maybe this product has more of the stuff in it that makes it timed release, so the other brand gets more into his system quicker.  I don't know.  He does sleep through the 'night' by the time he finally falls asleep, but if I give this product at 9 or 10 pm, I kind of expect him to be out by midnight and it's normally 2 or 3 am.

Even though my storage containers are still a mish/mash of glass and plastic, screw lid and suction lid, etc., everything was really brought together by the labels.  It's almost like my kitchen has a cool eclectic look.  Only word of experienced warning:  Do apply the labels and *then* write on them with the liquid chalk pen.  The pen dries quickly and then when you peel the labels the chalk kinda chips off and makes your writing looking spotty.  It takes a minute or two to get the hand of writing on the side of a glass cylinder, but thankfully a wipe down with a damp paper towel and a sufficient air dry and these labels look brand new.  I imagine if you wanted to make your label more permanent you could spray with clear coat to set.

I pick my cuticles and just peel, peel, peel away.  (That scene in Black Swan ain't no joke!  People really do that.  Thank God I don't peel the tops of my fingers.)  There are no real treatments for dermatillomania other than behavior modification ($$$$$$ or your first three offspring is the going rate for that) and the suggestion of using acrylic nails.  For some reason acrylic nails do help me a good bit; I would say I pick 60% to 70% less on average.  There's something about putting on an acrylic nail that makes the picking less (whatever - picking is not pleasurable or comforting, but there's really no right word.  We don't pick because we want to just like those with eating disorders, or alcoholics, or drug addicts don't have their vices because they want them.  It happens and in it you find that "control" that you need in that moment and you're hooked.  It sucks! It really, really is gross!! It just sucks!!!) Anyway these nails help more than anything else.  So, why 4 stars instead of 5, you ask:  The color isn't as pretty pink on my lily white skin as I'd hoped; it's almost an 'electric rose'.  Kind of hooker-ish for my tastes.  (Nothing against hookers, they just have a more outgoing color-scheme preference to mine).  I had hoped I wouldn't have to paint them, but I do as a matter of personal preference.  That isn't necessarily anything I'd deduct a star for; I did deduct a star because I find that once I cut these down to my desired length (just beyond the tips of my fingers) and then file them to my desired shape, they do break/crack and then peel very easily.  Perhaps that's because I just glue mine on, cut, shape and leave 'em.  Maybe you absolutely are supposed to put the acrylic gel on top every time and so my deduction of a star is unfair.  If that's the case I apologize to whomever may be offended by my deducting a star.  BTW:  You have to get the Bondini glue that's sold on Amazon.  It makes the beauty supply store/monster-mart glue look like a joke.

While I've had all my looms for years, I rarely have the time that I wish I had to actually sit down and complete a project.  I've made half a dozen or so hats, a handful of scarves, and started (then frogged) about 3 or 4 afghan/blankets/throws.  Hats are my favorite thing to make because I can actually finish a project in one day.  I also belong to several FB loom groups, and one day another member posted photos of a work in progress and the stitch was amazing.  I don't know why, but I just fell for that stitch.  She mentioned that she'd gotten the stitch from this book.  I perused Amazon (<3 <3 <3 my Amazon!) and found it available both paperback and spiral bound.  I chose spiral bound because, after receiving the book VERY QUICKLY, I plan on *making* time to learn most of these new stitches.  I think most books out there are by one of a handful of authors, and sometimes you end up with two or three of these books and realize that - pretty much - two books could've covered everything (but, of course, there's no money in that).  Ms. Erling's book is sort of a different perspective with more than a few stitches that I don't have in my other books.  Really, really glad I got this book.

My parents buy this gravy from the mega-monster's dotcom site (24 pack @4.75 oz per pack) for about $26 with free shipping and it lasts them FOREVER.  I asked them for a couple of bags to try, as I've just learned to make biscuits.
