Best in the series to date! Super sweet PERFECT hero.

Gift Wrapped started with such a bang out of the gate… Brinn has no holiday plans after she caught her boyfriend cheating on her. She just doesn’t feel like driving back home to be with her family this year after working late on Christmas Eve. Then in walks Davis our Christmas hating hero looking for a last minute gift and maybe a hot night with the woman behind the counter.What starts out as a one night fling slowly turned into more of a F buddy system with both having growing feelings for each other. The story was hot from the start with likeable characters of both the hero and heroine…  too bad that didn’t stick around for the hero. The heroine is a very easy character to connect with and even easier to love. She is feisty, funny, up for some hot sexy times, and extremely relatable. All and all the author really made you love her which is a giant part of the problem. Give me a heroine I love, but please don’t give me a hero I think is undeserving.Davis wasn’t as quick to fall for Brinn as I was. Did he fall balls deep into her snatch? Of course he did and that was the only falling he wanted to do with her which he did make clear.. but it still hurt. His quick reminders of what he wanted from her really started nicking at my like for him. The author even gave us a moment where we thought he did something great, but it was just an accident. There was time and time again where the hero could have made a great play and really won me back, but again he falls short of my liking.The good, the bad, and the ugly …. The good, the sex was outstanding and I found the heroine made me laugh out loud quite a few times. Plus she did have a backbone and chose herself when I really felt like she should. The bad, missable moments when the author could have made this sucker an outstanding Christmas book! The ugly, by the time the hero got his head out of his butt I was gone. Was his turn around sweet with a sweeter happily ever after? Yes, it really was, but as a reader the author lost me a few chapters before the end so I just didn’t care that much. I was happy Brinn got what she wanted I just still had a bitter taste in my mouth. Plus I REALLY wanted to know if he was banging that neighbor when these two were apart for those few months. Oh well…. Sometimes the little things just really matter.

Deadly Fallout is the tenth book in the Red Stone Security series. While I have read them all and really enjoy them on audio (audio is great for romance suspense) you don’t have to read the whole series and I promise you won’t be lost. While the heroine is in the previous books it’s nothing that will leave you feeling out of the loop. The author does a great job on refreshing readers without being redundant so the newbies aren’t lost.I was excited that this was Dr. Zoe Hansen’s book. We have gotten little tastes of her in the past being one of the security firms agent’s sister and she has spunk plus she’s a hot little doc to top it off. Nothing like a strong female lead to kick off a story, but there is always one thing that can even shake the strongest of strong… a deadly good stalker who has already made one really good attempt at getting his hands on you.Zoe made changes in her life to protect herself but tries to keep it low profile. She knows her brother would lose his s*** if he found out about the attack and may even try to kill the man who came at her. Everything seems fine until Zoe’s stalker shows back up in her life and all hell breaks loss."He was going to slide into her soon, but first he desperately wanted to taste her release on his tongue. The need was damn near primal. He wanted to see her completely undone because of him, to see her lose control."This Red Stone Security addition is a lot like the rest. While it’s not my favorite in the series (Breaking Her Rules) it gave me what I wanted: suspense that actually might be the best in the series so far, an alpha hero who falls hard and fast for my heroine, and a heroine who isn’t too stupid to live. Hey! That last one is extremely important in a suspense romance. It has a great mix of everything you could really want in a fast paced suspense and kept me wanting more from the Red Stone Security series…. As always I can’t wait for the next in the series.

This one was a total random buy on Amazon... what can I say? With a cover like that and the word obsession in the title I was sold. Plus, it looks to be a new author (unless this is a pen name) so I jumped right in!Alex Hanas was not happy when he found out his father was marrying. He had been widowed for years and he never thought his father would want to walk down the aisle again. On top of that, he's sure his step-mother-to-be is probably just after their money. He wants nothing to do with her or her chubby little daughter, Elynn. Like most arrogant billionaires Alex is completely wrong about his new mother and maybe her daughter Elynn isn't so chubby after all... but under the age of eighteen she is.Alex starts to notice Elynn more and more at forced family events and his feelings for the smart, nerdy, baggy wearing clothing girl start to change. She starts to catch his eye and he even starts to like coming to family functions to get time with her. The problem? She's not really legal with their 10 year age gap plus Elynn has some problems. She once had a boy who was obsessed with her and beat her when she didn't return the feeling. While she wasn't raped her trust in men was gone causing her to be skittish and Alex knew that.After Elynn's eighteenth birthday and Alex's mad dash to make the event, he knew he was in love, but had to wait for her. He needed to give her time to grow, maybe even have a few relationships and get some of her trust back with the opposite sex. Alex even bought a ring knowing one day he would marry her. All this is really sweet and I ate a lot of this up... my problem was Alex went on with life even still banging starlets and models knowing he was in love with Elynn. What did help some of this blow for me was Elynn wasn't pinning for Alex having to see his sexcapades in the paper. I will also give Alex SOME credit that once Elynn turned eighteen he really toned it down only having maybe one partner a year and for only a few weeks at best.Even with that knowledge it didn't sit well for me. I was still angry that he was in love with her... bought her a ring and was nailing other women. It really bugged me and I'm sad to say it messed with the sweet little love story that was going on here. A lot of the story was boring, but a sweet boring. Not a lot happened but one could enjoy the sex and the liteness to it all but because of Alex's past it really kind of shot the softness to with his past.I just felt like this could have been so much better if that wasn't hanging over the love story. Boys will be boys doesn't work for me.... She went through something hard and needed time to grow and him not be able to keep it locked up showed some of his character to me.If you wouldn't have this hang up like me then this is an ok read. You have a heroine with some depth and a hero who is pretty smitten. I think there were some key things the author could have done to make me love the hero more such as putting us in his point of view more (I became bored when in Elynn's) Maybe if I had a better understanding and he had been more obsessed I could have loved him. I will say the sex scenes were sweet and realistic and I even giggled during the de-virgining. While they were sweet they were by no means hot or matched the cover and the author tried to bring in a smidge of bdsm which just sat there kind of oddly. With that all said I would try another book by the author but only if the hero doesn't know the heroine before so I don't have to risk him not keeping it locked up... but I will say that once he did know he was making his move on Elynn he was never with anyone else nor do I believe he would be.

It might just be my mood, but this isn’t working for me… the hero is an odd ball and the only thing going for this book is the nasty, dirty, out there sex. Normally I’m totally down with this, but now the sister is on the scene and I just don’t really care anymore. I’ve been reading this off and on for 48 hrs and I can’t seem to stick with it.

This Cynthia Eden book kind of snuck up on me and just popped up one day. I track most of her books because I’m a pretty big fan. Watch Me is a start to a new series, Dark Obsession, which I think hit the spot oh so nicely and set up for a great new series.Chance Valentine’s (god I love that name) new job is the one woman he has been trying to stay away from, Gwen Hawthorne. While he has been hired to keep an eye on her, watching her will be an easy task because keeping his eyes off her is the last thing he wants to do. Chance has worked for Gwen’s father for years, but after a night of getting too close with Gwen, Chance decided it was best he leave and start his own bodyguard firm. When Gwen’s life is put on the line her father reaches out to Chance knowing he is the one man Gwen will let close enough to keep her safe.Second chance romance? ... kind of ...kind of not. See, while they have known each other for years their attraction didn’t really start to  blossom until the end as Gwen got older. They were spending a lot of time together and things just seemed to grow. They felt comfortable around each other and both wanted more. But Chance of course, like most alpha war heroes, thought he wasn’t good enough and hooking up with the boss’s daughter wasn’t a great idea for his career. But once she was gone from his life and he didn’t even get to catch a glimpse of her at work it really hit him hard how much he missed her.I think what really made me love this one was that Gwen was the one who tried to move on. She went out and started dating and even got a boyfriend. It’s so typical that normally it’s the man who goes out and bangs all these chicks while out heroine is sitting at home crying into her ice cream with her girlfriends. I loved watching our alpha hero having to get a good look at what he let go and work at making her his own for good. It was sweet, sexy and filled with lots of alpha male goodness.As most Eden books, this one packed a good punch of suspense that kept me guessing the whole time. I was never quite sure who Gwen’s stalker was even when she put us into the villain’s point of view. We also got to meet Chance’s teammates and I believe the heroine of the next book and I already love her. I can’t wait to see where the series goes, but I’ll have my one-click finger ready for the next.

I’ve always had a sweet little crush on author Aurora Rose Reynolds and it started with her debut novel ‘Until November.’ Her books are always lite, sexy, and leave me with a giant smile pasted on my face. When I heard she had a new one coming out that was the dirtiest thing she has published so far I was so excited I downloaded it the same day and well…. it gave ‘Until November’ one hell of a run for its money."I wanted to consume her. I wanted to brand her. The need to own her, possess her, was almost crippling."Nolan knows the minute he lays his eyes on Chloe through a bakery window that she will be his no matter what. There is no stopping this alpha male from getting what he wants and having it in all ways. When I say no stopping him I’m not joking… this is insta-love with “I’m going to plant my baby inside you so that you are branded by me and can’t get away.” Guys, it’s a little over the top in author Jordan Silver fashion, but I loved EVERY single second of this book. While like I said the book hero has a Jordan Silver feel, it’s done with a better writing style and a more developed story.There are two things that really kept the story going… one of course is the smutty sex. Hands down the best the author has written to date. I highlighted so much of my Kindle I could give you quotes for days that made me cream myself… and two was the little bit of suspense. With an alpha like Nolan it can be hard to keep a story up to pace because he’s so balls deep you know he will have the heroine so there is no fall to love over time. We’re there BAM page one. A little bit of suspense can really give this story flow and it did. I just think the final build to the suspense could have landed a little harder, but it really didn’t matter.I love these kinds of stories if they can be done right and not bore me and the author did it well and I never felt like we dragged. We got to meet the key players who I think will be head lining the future books and I can’t wait to get my hands on them. If you’re looking for an extra smutty quickie and an over the top alpha trying to breed your virgin heroine…. look no further. This perfectly dirty book lands a nice little spot on my re-read shelf.

I only picked this one up because I thought the series had potential after I read 'His'.  With a little more effort I felt like the author could really do something with it, so I had pre-ordered this one. I’m sad to say not much has changed, and I was still left feeling that the author didn't flush this couple out just like with the first. When you are dealing with something so dark and messed up you really need to pull it back around and leave the reader in a better, more okay place. I won’t be reading anymore in the series. I think I need more obsession from my heroes when they are this messed up in the head, so I know they would never truly hurt my heroine. I mean she even thought he was going to kill her like 87% into the book.
I love these! I'm a size 12 and the fit me just a smug big (i got the median)

I was hesitant to read this one because, well I tend to find tattoo artist fall in with the motorcycle and rockstar themed books… you know, manwhores who sleep with everything. These types of books tend to make me mad. While our hero, Payne, is a manwhore that title goes straight out the door when Becks Delgado comes storming into his office. Little does Becks know, she just fell right into Payne’s trap.Becks is an up and coming artist and Payne not only wants her for himself, but he also wants all of her future work to be his. One of my favorite things about Payne is his obsession for Becks. It’s endearing to watch him try to hide it… yes I said hide. It’s refreshing to have someone try and hide it instead of run from it. He wants her so he will have her and nothing will stand in the way.“You’re beautiful. My eyes can’t get enough of you. My hands can’t feel enough of you. I can’t bury myself inside of you deeply enough. But none of that will stop me from trying. And trying. And trying.”What Becks doesn’t know is Payne has met her before on the night that changed her life forever. Over the years Payne had kept tabs on her and got closer and closer like a moth to the flame until his need is so great he takes steps to pull her into his world. What Payne doesn’t know is that Becks lived in hell and self-misery after that fateful night four years ago.Becks was an easy heroine to love. In fact, both the hero and heroine are but Becks just takes your heart. She’s been through a lot and truly believes no one could ever want her, well at least for an extended period of time. While she is confident in some parts of her life and even smug about it there are other parts she isn’t. Her struggles with her self-importance are real, heartbreaking, and completely understandable. I tend to shy away from heroines who can beat themselves down, but the author did a wonderful job of making me get her and understand why she does and thinks some of the things she does. I never once got frustrated with her when she would push Payne away because I got it… the author made me love her.Very early on I caught on to where the plot was going and what I thought would be the climax of the story; Becks finding out Payne was there on the night of her accident, but while I could see where the story was going (and I’m sure you will think the same) it didn’t go along like I thought it would, which was great. It was more adult and the author once again showed me how incredible Becks really was.I know I gushed a lot about the book so you’re probably wondering why the 4 stars…. While I loved it and can’t wait for the next in the series, I still felt like there was a little something missing. I could tell Payne was pretty done in early on, but I think I wanted that obsession to burst through more. A lot of it did during the sex scenes, which were nice and smutty, but I wanted it in words. He does give us some great lines. No denying that but I just needed a little extra… I wanted her to know how much he was obsessed because well, like I said the author made me love her and I wanted her to have everything. I’m really looking forward to the next in the series about Payne’s assistant and the author now has my attention.

‘Rule’s Addiction’ is the third book in the House of Rule series and by far my favorite in the series so far. While I read the first ‘Rule’s Obsession’ and really enjoyed it (4 stars) I ended up skipping the second ‘Rule’s Property’ because the reviews didn’t fair too well. Each book can be read as a standalone so feel free to jump right into this one… get ready because this review is about to be a gush-fest.Garrett Rule has wanted Maria Alvarez since the moment he heard her voice on a telephone call. Want isn’t even a strong enough word for the feelings Garrett has for Maria. It’s all-consuming from page one of the book and I ate up Every. Single. Word. I don’t even think I can explain his obsession to make you understand how intense it was. He’s been jacking off to her voice for weeks. He couldn’t even think of other women because she owned his every thought. So he of course does what every billionaire does in this situation… he makes plays to get her in his reach.While Garrett can’t wait to come face to face with Maria, she isn’t so inclined. See Garrett bought the hotel Maria works at and she knows he’s coming in to flip it and/or just push her out of a job that she has worked hard for. This is what most of the book is about; Maria trying to fight to prove she can run this hotel and she should have the job. To be honest there isn’t a lot going on or a real build up to some climax that might rip them apart. It’s just about two people fighting their feelings for each other when they are so clearly done in.Their build to the relationship really took center stage to owning the book. It never felt like come on let’s do this already… it was perfectly timed and I loved when they fought their attraction. It was the best part of the book. Garrett would be a giant a-hole and oddly I loved it. He was just so grumpy because he wanted her so badly and she was pushing him away. He would get so jealous off of nothing and start stomping around… I’m shocked he just didn’t pee a circle around her. I do want to say that it was refreshing that the author didn’t have the hero try and make the heroine jealous. That seems to be such a thing lately and I find it to be childish for a grown man to do such a thing. Another woman was never even a thought to Garrett… in fact the idea of one just made him mad.This book gave me everything I wanted from a Lynda Chance story. An alpha male who literally made me gasp out loud (good gasp), a feisty heroine who gives as good as she gets, smutty scenes that are probably the best I’ve ever read from her, and a love story that ended with me in a pile of goo. This book is pure junk food that you will just consume. It’s been a while since I really got to gush over the author, but it seems Chance is back to giving me the alpha males I crave from her. No one does an alpha like Chance and I’m glad I am getting some of the old Chance’s passion in this one and I hope it stays around because I’ve really missed it. I am already dying to get my hand on her next in the series and I wish her most luck topping this one because this one has landed on my top ten of 2014 and most definitely on my re-read shelf.

Really sweet historical with both the best friend's-little-sister and marriage-of-convenience trope. I knew Rathburne and Emma from The Rakes of Fallow Hall series, so it was nice to revisit this world and characters.I did think issues between Rathburne and Emma were somewhat contrived - as in, Emma hasn't a clue, even when Oliver spells everything out in plain English, and her "big"secret (spoiler alert: not big at all)Daring Miss Danvers was a sweet story, and a fast one, at that. I look forward to more Wallflower Weddings.

“I know you fear that a single action or alteration on your part will put everything you have with Penelope at risk. What you don’t see is that by doing nothing, you risk even more,” she said simply, then lifted her palms, weighing her words with one, then the other. “All you have to do is decide if what you have now is worth risking for the chance at greater happiness.” “I could lose her,” he said before he could stop the words from tumbling out. His mother blinked up at him, surprised by his admission, but pleased. She gave him a watery smile. “Or you could gain so much more.”I enjoy Vivienne Lorret's work, so had good expectations for this novella. My expectations were met, and exceeded. This is a heartwarming friends-to-lovers story, one that left me misty-eyed and smiling.

The Turncoat was BRILLIANT.The prose was clean, clever, and enchanting. The plot was, again, clever, and fascinating. I'm a hardcore history junkie, particularly for the American Revolution. The author seamlessly wove fiction with fact, leaving me stunned, thrilled, and, honestly, sad that so much of this time and people will always be unknown.The Turncoat isn't exactly a romance, though it does have a strong romantic story within. There is even -GASP- a bit of a love triangle, though it's more of a romantic entanglement of necessity. If you let the thought of a triangle scare you away, you're missing the point of the story, and going to miss out on a hell of a book.What The Turncoat is, in addition to being a love story in the time of war and deception, is a testament to the women who fought the Revolution behind the scenes. They are the unsung heroes, and I believe the war would not have been won without them. The Turncoat is an epic page-turner, a spy thriller that will leave you breathless until the very last page.Donna Thorland has won herself a new devotee.

I really enjoy Gina Conkle's Midnight Meetings series, which is why I picked up Norse Jewel. NJ was an interesting story, and I tend to enjoy a good Viking romance. I liked the Hakan and Helena, and their story. I did find the writing to be a little rough (it was her first book, I believe) and the story didn't feel deeply fleshed-out.I didn't love Norse Jewel, but it was an interesting and fast-paced story. I would give another book in the series a try.

"Tonight she’d altered the bounds of her marriage forever, and there was no going back. They’d made a crease that could never be ironed out, and more were likely to come. Folds, turning pretty paper into origami, shapes emerging, seam by seam, his instructions, her hands, two dimensions becoming three. They might end up with a perfect swan or a torn and crumpled wad, but either way, they’d find out together."Whew! Crosstown Crush was something! My first thought is "DAMN". My send is: longtime McKenna fans are going to like this one. I personally love when McKenna's books get kinky, and when she digs in deep, delving into the body, heart, and especially, the mind, no one writes it  better.The kink in Crosstown Crush is cuckolding, a first for me. So yes, there is cheating, but, is it really cheating if all parties concerned are on board and involved? If cheating in books is a concern for you, you may have issues with CC. I'd say, let it go. Enjoy the story, and trust in the author, because I promise, she will explore the dynamics and examine the issues and aftermath. If you've read McKenna, you'll also know that she doesn't do tidy endings. What you will get is a believable Happy For Now.AND! Emotional book issues aside. If you are simply looking for a filthy book with lotsa sexing? Look. No. Further. CC was maybe 75% sexing. Yasssssss.If you love the trademark CM erotic romances like Willing Victim, Shivaree, Unbound, etc; you're probably going to really dig Crosstown Crush. Read it, absorb it, and try not to burn up.

Only a Kiss was an okay book for me, and I'm not sure why. On paper, it seems to be right up my alley, but you know, I can't even remember the main characters' names, so either I'm awful and distracted, or it just wasn't memorable to me.Here's the thing: despite my not remembering the lead characters' names, Only a Kiss was a nice story. The H/h were likable characters, with the heroine having a particularly good, yet tragic backstory. My very favorite part of the book was the Survivors Club. When they come into play, and the heroine really confronts her husband's death in the Napoleonic wars, it was good stuff, and left me curious to read more about the rest of the Survivors.I don't know why Only a Kiss didn't resonate heavily with me. It may be that I've come off a high of reading a book that's a new favorite, or that I'm in a mood. There's nothing about this book that struck me wrong, irritated me, or left me cold. It was fine, and what may be my "fine" might be someone else's "amazing".

The Sisters of Versailles is a fascinating book. I love when an author can bring obscure historical characters and/or events to life, and Sally Christie did that so well. This book is both a compelling historical and scandalous page turner. If you're familiar with The Other Bolelyn Sister, then you have a good idea of what you'll get with The Sisters of Versailles.Told in alternating chapters between Louise, Pauline, Diane, Hortense, and Marie-Anne, along with letters between the sisters, Sisters recounts the years between 1730 and 1745 Versailles. From the time the sisters were simply young, sheltered daughters whose lives consisted of only their nursery, to daring to dream, reach, grasp, claw and betray their ways to the King's bed and heart. Some of the sisters were nearly harmless and naive, others led easily astray, and others were vicious, awful, power-hungry vipers."Goodness, but sisters are a thing to fear. "I was horrified by these sisters (and almost grateful I don't have any!)I have no idea how much of this book is fiction and how much is fact. No one knows that, I think. The author took on a very ambitious piece of French history, and really pulled it off. The Sisters of Versailles is an interesting and compelling story. I doubt I'll ever forget the tragic Mailly-Nesle sisters."But through it all, through the good, the bad, the sin and the scandal, the heartbreak and the joy, the exiles and the deaths, through it all, they were my sisters. And now I am all that is left. I sit in my darkened rooms, an old woman, passing my days rustling through their letters and my memories. If I am careful, and still, I can hear their voices once again."

I don't read a lot of historical romance anymore, but books like A Wedding in Springtime make me question that. I'll admit, I fell in love with this cover, and that played a huge part in my decision to take it for review. I'm so happy I did read A Wedding in Springtime, because I truly enjoyed this story.A Wedding in Springtime is essentially the story of "ruined" Genie Talbot and the man who made her laugh in front of the Queen, William Grant. The chemistry between them is apparent from the beginning, and I loved that they were continually drawn to each other, despite their best efforts. Genie needs a husband to save her from the scandal, and quickly. Grant is an avowed bachelor, and the most coveted single man in England. Of course, this means that the two are truly meant to be together, but the road them seeing this does not run smoothly, though it is humorous.Though A Wedding in Springtime is about Genie and Grant, there are quite a few secondary characters that make up the story. There's Genie's family, including her distant uncle, bossy aunt, and meek cousin. We also have the Marchfords, made up of the Duchess, who may be the only woman powerful enough to find Genie a suitable husband, the Duke who is Grant's best friend and engaged to Genie's husband. And I can't forget Miss Penelope Rose, who may soon enter spinsterhood, but is an accomplished matchmaker. I think she just may have a story coming her way, as does Marchford.I like a humorous historical romance, and A Wedding in Springtime delivered. The dialogue between the characters, particularly Genie, Grant, and Marchford. The easy and teasing comraderie between the friends made for a lot of fun moments, as did the teasing and flirting between Genie and Grant.I was a little worried that too many characters and secondary plotlines were being brought into the story. There was a plotline about spies and the war between England and France, as well as a bit about Genie's gambling brother. I did find myself losing a bit of interest during the middle of the story. However, when these secondary stories began pulling together and incorporating into the main plot, everything began to fill in nicely and the overall story became much more exciting.I truly enjoyed A Wedding in Springtime. I found the story to be sweet, engaging, romantic, and fun! I will definitely be reading book two in the Marriage Mart series, A Midsummer Bride.Favorite Quote:  Marchford studied him for a moment, as if noticing him for the first time. "I fear, dear chap, you are in love."  "Do you really think so?"  "I cannot find any other reasonable explanation. You have bought a special license, sworn off drinking, lost control of your emotions on a public street, and most disturbing of all -- done all this before noon. I would say the evidence leads me to no other conclusion."

** 2.5 stars **I have a question: Why is the title of this book Scotsman of My Dreams when the man in question is not a Scotsman? Sure, his last name is Scots, as is his ancestry, but this man was a Brit through-and-through. In fact, the only Scot in this book was a distant cousin who had one scene. You're just setting readers up for false expectations.Speaking of unrealistic expectations, there was this:"She reached down between them and grabbed his erection with both hands, stroking it, measuring it with her fingers. It was at least nine fingers long and so wide around that her thumb and forefinger didn’t meet when she extended them around it."A nine-fingers long penis! Good lord that thing should be registered as a deadly weapon. But seriously, I'm totally fine with giving book hero unrealistic proportions, but even I know you must draw a line somewhere.Scotsman of My Dreams was okay. I thought the plot moved terribly slow, but was interesting enough. The leading characters were fairly likable, even endearing at times.I just can't get past the monster peen, really. I won't remember anything about this book EXCEPT the non-Scottish Scotsman with the nine fingers long peen.

“Logan, you are my dream. You always were. You have to know that. The deepest desire of my heart. And as wild a fantasy as I spun .. .” She laced her arms about his neck. “ . . . the reality of us is so much better."This review is a Hot Mess. Spoiler alert: I loved it.Oh. My. Heart. When a Scot Ties the Knot far exceeded my expectations, and trust me, those expectations were high. The plot was unique and and endearing. It is a love story, obviously. But it is also a story of dreams, chasing and finding your dreams. Choices. Daring to dream of love and family of your own making. A dream of a home and love to fill it.Maddie Gracechurch didn't dream of ballgowns and society parties. Shyness and a paralyzingly fear of crowds had her seeking quiet solitude and her art. A fake,dead fiancé and the inheritance of a castle in the Scottish highlands gives her the opportunity to have a life of her own choosing, in peace. I adored Maddie. Her deceit was born of a need to protect herself, and was never meant to go beyond the letters she sent to herself from a make believe Captain, off fighting the Napoleonic war. When her dreamt up, supposedly dead suitor (and his band of soldiers) comes calling to her castle, Maddie's reaction was quite cute. She is torn between shock, disbelief, and attraction to her supposed intended.But most of all, I loved that Maddie cared. She cares for this rag-tag group of men; some scarred either mentally or physically, others forgotten, lost from their homes and families forever. To see Maddie quickly moving from shock and irritation over this invasion of Scottish warriors, to gentleness and willingness to give them back home and sense of purpose, it would be impossible not to love Miss Madeleine Gracechurch, soon to be Mrs. MacKenzie, if her trumped-up suitor has any say in it.Logan MacKenzie is a Scottish warrior come to claim the woman who claimed him first. Yes, Logan is braw, sexy...but, I have to say Logan's physical attributes are the least sexy thing about him. It's in his actions, his devotion, in his heart. He loves to read, for chrissakes. Now, I would love to proclaim every single reason I loved this character, but I'm not. And that is not because I'm a lazy reviewer (even though that is sometimes the case), but because a large part of this book's appeal is uncovering Logan for yourself. What causes this man to lead his band of broken brothers to this castle after so many years at war, why does he brush off the slightest affections, and, why does he not dream? I swear, if you come out of this book not loving Logan MacKenzie, you should probably see a physician about your heart.As with the entire Castles Ever After series, this installment is witty and so very fun. Maddie's spinster Aunt Thea is devilishly charming, with a few secrets of her own. Logan's men always brought bawdy charm to the story, along with tenderness and more than a few tears. I loved When a Scot Ties the Knot. I loved every.single.word.Maddie and Logan might have been each other's dream come true, but Tessa Dare, you are a reader's dream come true. Thank you.

I'm so, so glad I stuck with this series because Taken is a good example of why I'm a fan of Charlotte Stein. It was deliciously odd and sexy and completely endearing. I can safely say I, nor you, have ever read a story quite like this. Despite the potentially dark plot, Taken was quite funny. The dialogue between the free-spirited Rosie and pent-up-tighter-than-a-drum Johan was so cute. And very sexy.I will say that Rosie's incessant inner monologues drove me a bit nuts at times. It did tend to overtake the story and potentially more excellent dialogue between herself and Johan. I was also a little bothered that Rosie's and Johan's "voices" were exactly alike.I've been a little (okay, a lot) snarky about some of the bad lines in the first two books. So to be fair, I want to point out some lines that I really liked in Taken:“What, so you think I’m some thrill seeker?” I ask, half laughing. Until he answers, that is. Then I stop. “No, I think you have no idea what your own worth is.”“I think that might be the most amazing thing anyone has ever said to me.” “Honestly, that is pretty much the bare minimum of what you deserve.” “Or maybe that is the most amazing thing anyone has ever said to me.” “People should be saying this to you all the time. I just said it despite really not wanting to. It’s simply a fact like water is wet and Nicholas Sparks writes derivative stilted nonsense.” “I can assure you no one has told me any of that before.” “Not even the stuff about the way you talk?” “Most people call it annoying.” “It is annoying,” he says..“But you do have a nice ass,” I say, and when he sighs in response I think okay, now you went too far. Only to be surprised with the greatest answer to anything ever, in a voice as weary as worn stone. “It’s the Pilates.” Honestly, I think I might be in love with him. “That why you have those arms too?” “I can do handstand push-ups.” “Probably should not have said that.” “I know. As soon as it popped out, I thought: man that was a mistake.”So yeah, I I thought the writing in Taken was so much better.I'm glad I gave this one a try. It is my favorite of the series, by miles. If you're a fan of Stein's, or if fun, weird and endearing romance, give Taken a try.

** 2.5 stars **Forbidden definitely delivered another interesting story from Charlotte Stein. I'm always interested in books that examine the impact of religion on sexuality, so in that respect, I liked Forbidden.There were a few issues that held me up, though. First, I'm not sure that Dot could be so thoroughly changed in the time allotted in a novella. There was just too much baggage and I'm not sure someone with her background could go from thinking she would go to hell for even thinking a mildly dirty thought to extreme dirty talk in a matter of weeks. I mean, the girl didn't even know what the name for a radio was.Another issue is Dot's dialect."[...]and he don’t care nothing about it. I reckon he likes it."I am from the South and yes, I know there are many people in the South who do not use good grammar. They also drive me crazy and I just prefer not to read it.And then....there were lines like these:"I swear to God he’s wearing jeans like he just did some fancy thing that jeans-wearing people do.""His cheekbones are so big and manly I could bludgeon the counter guy with them, and I’m liable to do it.""--and his tongue is so awesome at licking. <--- I'm pretty sure all tongues are good at licking. THAT IS WHAT THEY DO."They sound rubbed raw and sort of rude, like his thoughts aren’t full of chicken soup or soothing hugs."I guess the author is trying to make Dot sound as naive as possible. I feel like I need Google Translate for the ridiculous.
I gifted this poster to a Cap-obsessed (very picky) friend for her birthday. She loved it! Excellent quality.

Charlotte Stein is one of my favorite erotic romance writers. Telling Tales and Control are two particular favorites. She writes awkward characters awkwardly exploring love and sex and I love it. I typically find her books interesting, unique and very sexy.I'm not quite sure how I feel about Intrusion. I did think the sexy bits were smoking, and yes, it was quirky and compelling. It's the added suspense that didn't really work for me. It's like Intrusion was suddenly a psychological thriller in the last chapter, and that threw me.And then there were lines like this:The guy in front of me looks like a [expletive] painting of himself.All I can think of is my hand, as though my hand has suddenly grown a [female genitalia].His curls are clinging to his forehead; his T- shirt has dark circles the size of the Pacific Ocean all over it.Not trying to be overly picky, but yeah. I just didn't expect lines like that from Stein.I will be the first to say that I am overly picky these days. But I won't apologize for my feelings. I am going to give this series another shot, and if they don't work out? I'll still have my old favorites.

I have read many of Jane Green's books over the years, and am always amazed by the how thoroughly she taps into her books' themes. Saving Grace is no exception. It is, in fact, exceptional.A dysfunctional childhood with a mentally ill mother, a successful but largely dysfunctional marriage with a volatile man, fears of her own mental health and impending menopause, are the issues that swirl through Grace Chapman's life. Those issues become the perfect storm when Beth, the family's new assistant comes on board. Confusion, betrayal and a health crisis follows, orchestrated by Beth, who must be a sociopath.Mental health is an issue that has affected so many families, my own included. I have shared Grace's fears about following in those footprints. Now, thanks to Saving Grace, I don't feel alone in my thoughts. I feel more educated and empowered about my own health and what sort of help I would like to seek if needed in the future. (to be clear-this is not, nor claims to be, a self-help or educational book)Saving Grace is a powerful story about a woman, a marriage, friendships. About finding oneself, and ending up exactly where you were meant to be. It is not a romance, but there is a wonderfully endearing romance within the story. I loved this touch and I absolutely loved how Grace's story concluded.There is a reason Jane Green has been a go-to author for more than a decade: every single book more than satisfies.

I'll admit that the Poldark series only came to my attention due to the upcoming television series. A fellow Outlander lover mentioned Ross Poldark as something fellow fans may enjoy. (I should mention that I believe if you're looking for something similar to Outlander, you're barking up the wrong tree.) I am always in the market for new book/television obsessions, so count me in.Ross Poldark was very good, but I can't tell you exactly why. Unhelpful, I know. It wasn't dramatic and it wasn't especially passionate; there were even parts that were quite tedious (mining business, the town business, etc.). And yet, the book had me almost totally compelled. I didn't feel the full-on immersion I feel in my favorite books, but I never wanted to put it down and was quick to pick back up.Ross Poldark was often morose, always upstanding and a really good man. His servants Jud and Prudie were ridiculous but faithful. I loved seeing Ross's interactions with people under his care. And then there was Demelza. Major admiration to an author who can make me fully love and support a relationship I would side-eye many other author's hands.Even after finishing, I cannot stop thinking about it. I feel very satisfied, yet unsettled in a way. That's probably because I was an idiot and read series spoilers.So maybe I do know why I so enjoyed Ross Poldark? Whatever the reasons, I'm anxious to begin Demelza (Poldark #2).
Maybe it's coincidence, but I haven't had any troubles with lice in my daughter's hair since I got this.A heads-up though, I found it for half the price at Walmart.
This is a great case. Very pretty, and durable. The kickstand is a cool touch, as well.

I was slow to come around, but Between the Devil and Ian Eversea was very,very good. Ian and Tansy were both a bit hard to crack, which initially slowed my all-out love fest. She seemed unfeeling to the havoc she wreaked around her, and he seemed simply unfeeling. Fortunately Ian and Tansy were both  revealed as their story unfolded, and both came to realize the many painful and beautiful truths about the other.I'm being so vague, I know.Some of my favorite moments in Between the Devil were the funny ones, especially between Colin and Ian. And I loved how Ian and Alex's awkward/tense storyline unfolded and concluded here. As always, Julie Anne Long is a wonder with her storytelling."But .. . Tansy . . . you are the world to me. You are my home, and, quite ironically, my peace, though I haven’t truly known a moment’s peace since I’ve met you. Which I quite like. And if you would do me the honor of being my wife, I will always love you better than anyone in the world, until our children come, and then I will love all of you more than life."Never let it be said the men of Pennyroyal Green don't know how to win a heart with words.

** 4.5 stars,  because that ending totally won me over **I am so in love with the Pennyroyal Green Series. I feel as if it has taken over my reading life, and am happy for it. The Eversea and Redmond families are enigmatic and passionate and always surprising, and given that, I wasn't sure how How the Marquess Was Won would work without either family playing a leading part.Maybe I overthink these things...How the Marquess Was Won was terrific. It was thoughtful and funny, and very sweet. Despite some very large bumps in the road to Happy Ever After (I'm looking at you, Jules), it very much had a fairy tale feel to it.It is a story of Phoebe, who has never truly belonged to any one or any place, and Julian, who carries a lifetime of burdens on his shoulders, who is feared and imitated, but has never been truly known. From the moment the two meet, there's a...feeling of rightness. That moment when you just know you've found your person. (best feeling in the world)This knowing does not mean smooth sailing for Phoebe and Jules. Nope. He's determined to marry the right girl in order to get what he wants, and Phoebe, sadly, isn't it. She's just a schoolmistress, good enough to teach the girls but not good enough to be one of them. Theirs is a relationship that is just not done in society, but you know how that goes....Looking at what I've said here, I realize I'm not painting the romance between Phoebe and Jules in the best of light. Honestly, it wasn't always winsome. He had his eyes on the prize (a Redmond cousin who comes with everything he's always wanted), and sometimes his thoughtelessness broke Phoebe's heart. Believe me when I say he earned his redemption. Jules gives good grovel.And OH. How the Marquess Was Won also gives delicious little morsels in the ongoing Lyon-Olivia saga. I have to admit one revelation felt like a smart little slap in the face, and my excitement for their book continues to build by the day. And Jonathan Redmond. That boy is the best.How the Marquess Was Won is not my favorite in the Pennyroyal Green Series. A Notorious Countess Confesses still holds my heart. But once again, any book in this series is always the best of historical romance.

We purchased this to replace the reeds around the bottom of our poolside tiki bar.This stuff is the absolute worst! It's brittle, cheap, inconsistently sized bamboo, and coming apart minutes after installation (see pictures).
I've had this clock for a little over a month now & absolutely adore it. It's beautiful, keeps great time, the Westminster chime function is lovely, and I've had many compliments!
These sticks should not be labelled "low odor" as they're the smelliest bully sticks I've ever purchased (and I purchase a lot of bully sticks for my dog).
Purchased this lotion for relief of arthritis and neuropathy pain in my feet and feel zero relief after using it for weeks. Wish I could get my money back.

Got a Facebook deal for these - the entire set with case for $10 with free shipping. For $10 I say go for it but they're no better than any of the run of mill brushes you'd find at Target or Walmart. The case is nice to have if you're traveling.

We purchased this mattress for our RV and after having slept on it for over 10 nights now I must say that we're extremely dissatisfied. The mattress is nowhere near 9 inches and measures in at barely 7.5 inches. Parts of my body actually get numb because it has such little cushioning it feels as though I'm sleeping solely on the wooden platform beneath the mattress. Also, this thing makes you so hot it's ridiculous. And even with a mattress cover and sheets on the bed your entire body "sticks" or adheres to this mattress (even if you're not perspiring) which makes turning over without physically sitting up virtually impossible.If I could return this thing I would in a heartbeat!

The thinnest, cheapest cord I've ever seen - I've purchased higher quality chargers from Five Below. Also, while charging my iPhone 5 I keep getting a message that this device may not be supported - and when that message pops up the phone stops charging. To get it to start charging again I have to unplug and replug charger. Absolute crap.

My 65 lb. bulldog has been playing with this ball daily for over 2 weeks, and while there are tons of teeth marks it's holding up very well and officially tops her list of favorite toys! It's soft enough for her to pick up and carry yet sturdy enough not to burst like the dozens of balls we've tried before. Worth every penny.

I purchased the 32 oz. Eddy bottle and love the functionality & design. The only thing that could improve it would be if they added some sort of texturing on the outside of the bottle as when full with any icy beverage the condensation on the outside of the 32 oz. bottle makes it very slippery & hard to hold onto.

I received this glass as a Christmas gift from my husband. Lolita makes some very pretty (and witty) collectable wine glasses that I've purchased to give as gifts over the years but this is the first glass of my very own. I've owned this glass for almost 4 months now and have used it probably a total of 10 times. I'm always careful to hand wash and treat it with care, as I would any fine china or crystal. I'm sad to report that the purple paint at the bottom of the glass is coming off. Very unhappy and won't be buying any more Lolita glasses for myself or to give as gifts.

"Hamidbar Medaber" makes for a great listen. While influenced by Jazz, Zebrina plays Klezmer with a Rock emphasis. The result is easy to listen to yet sonically satisfying. As would be expected, Ben Goldberg is the front man. His solos are articulate and fiery on this clarinet-centric album. Jonathan Feldman plays various keyboards, but his work on the Fender Rhodes is remarkable. This listener has a weak spot for a great Rhodes piano. When listening to the sound samples for this album, it was the Rhodes that sealed the deal on the purchase. Feldman plays strong solos on songs like 'Chant of Ages' and 'The Spirit Within.'  Thanks to the Rhodes, there are times when "Hamidbar Medaber" echoes Miles Davis'  "[...] Brew." Joel Schwartz also plays a mean guitar. In particular, he rips things up on 'The Spirit Within.' Playing a Middle Eastern jam, 'The Desert Speaks' is moody and introspective. 'Higher Power' combines avant-garde and psychedelia. 'Breath of Life' is infused with Surf Rock. Highlights include 'The Spirit Within' and the funky 'Freedom Groove.' Featuring all instrumental songs, the melodies are delicious, the arrangements are clever and the improvisation is fantastic. Beyond this, the band has a great chemistry. While the appeal to listeners of Jewish music is obvious, "Hamidbar Medaber" is also likely to appeal to the adventurous that enjoy instrumental Rock and Jazz.  In the end, what can you say, John Zorn knows how to pick 'em. "Hamidbar Medaber" is a most welcome addition to the Tzadik catalog. Listen to "Hamidbar Medaber" and rock out.

"The Testament of Solomon" is the fourth beautiful album by John Zorn's Gnostic Trio.  The Frisell-Wollesen-Emanuel group plays music that is always meditational and peaceful but never new agey. As with the last couple of releases, Bill Frisell is the standout. Indeed, on "The Testament of Solomon," Frisell's notes gracefully dance about the ether. Carol Emanuel plays a supportive role on the harp and Kenny Wollesen creates a mystical ambiance with the vibes and bells. Given the meditative quality, this is wonderful music to play first thing in the morning. The only drawback to "The Testament of Solomon" is that it's a rehash of the group's recent work. It's stronger than the first album, "Gnostic Preludes," but there's little differentiation between this effort and the previous two albums, "In Lambeth" and "the Mysteries." Given a blindfolded test, most listeners would be unable to tell the difference between "The Testament of Solomon" and the previous couple of albums. So it's a beautiful recording but only completists will need the entire quartet. In the end, "The Testament of Solomon" may be redundant but it's still as lovely as a lotus blossom.

"Shop of Wild Dreams" is a beautifully eclectic jazz recording. The first wild dream in the shop is 'Number Six.' It's a fantastic introduction to the album for a few reasons. First, the song orients the listener to the beautiful tone and range of Lurie's sax. Second, it makes it clear that while this is real jazz, it's also not the jazz that your father listened to. Along these lines, the song features a banjo riff and psychedelic background effects that project a vibe of modernity. Indeed, this music finds a curious balance between being fresh and familiar. Next up, 'I Don't Care If I Don't Care' features vocals. When great instrumentalists sing, they tend to spoil what otherwise would have been quality instrumental music. In contrast, this song works. Not only do Lurie's atypical vocals work but her song writing is good. The next wild dream is 'The Unusual Things' which features standout piano work by Erik Deutsch who is known for his work with Charlie Hunter. The vocal infused 'Grey Ocean' is a bit dull, but the mood is saved by the following track, 'Grinch.' Featuring congas, the wonderful song is enhanced by hallucinogenic electronics and a killer post-production. In this song, Lurie's flute solo is remarkable. The title track features hauntingly beautiful vocals. John Zorn would approve of 'Pinjur,' a Jewish themed jazz tune. It fits right in with the wonderful downtown scene that's populated by artists like Anthony Coleman, Erik Friedlander and Jon Madof. 'Circus Rain' is a quirky song with an Eastern European feel. This song embodies Jessica Lurie's curious way of singing that gives her words a foreign aesthetic. It's a great tune given the catchy melody, psychedelic atmospherics and post-modern feel. 'Flying Man' is straight jazz bliss. The last wild dream in the shop is the lovely 'Anthem.' As with Lurie's other albums, "Shop of Wild Dreams" finds a beautiful balance between music that is enjoyable to listen to yet thoughtful. It is a travesty that after five years, this is the first Amazon review. At the time of review, the new CD could be had through Amazon for only $7.32.  For such a paltry investment, "Shop of Wild Dreams" offers a satisfying experience of just how wonderful modern Jazz can be.

Compared to groups like Rebirth and the Dirty Dozen, the Stooges are newcomers to the wonderful world of New Orleans brass bands. What the group lacks with experience is made up with passion. Known for both their stage performance and second line parades, "It's About Time" shows what the group can do in the studio. To start things off on the good foot, 'Stooges Party' is a self-fulfilling prophecy. It's easy to listen to this music and imagine dancing in a second line party. 'Deal With This' is a great instrumental with jazz style solos. "Where Ya From' celebrates the NOLA wards. 'Can't Be Faded' features a sweet brass melody with whistling and vocalizations that give the feel of a live performance. A salute to former Saints football player Michael Buck, 'Wind It Up' is the album's highlight. It's a blast to experience live because the Stooges have worked out an accompanying dance. Moreover, this is one of the songs that the group plays in the HBO show "Treme." In season three, Antoine Batiste plays trumpet with the Stooges in a second line parade. No gangsta rap here, 'This Is The Time' is a life affirming song about working for progress. With moving lyrical content, it stands as another sparkler. 'New Funk' is a jazz party.  Tunes like 'Bin Laden' and 'Mo 1' are filled with scintillating brass solos. 'Paul Barbarin' honors the hometown drummer that played with King Oliver and Lois Armstrong. In the ultimate New Orleans death, Barbarin died in 1969 while playing a Mardi Gras parade! 'Weed Drought' is a fun tune about the quest for herb. In the studio, it can difficult to capture a musical experience that's usually woven into a rollicking street party. Despite such challenges, "It's About Time" perfectly captures the energy of the band's live performance. Featuring a mix of instrumentals and songs with vocals, "It's About Time" is very danceable. In fact, it's hard to listen to and remain still. At 70 minutes, "It's About Time" is packed with Crescent City brass bliss.

"On Leaves of Grass" is the third release by John Zorn's Nova Express Quartet. When it comes to musical vision, the first two albums were similar in that the focus was avant-garde jazz. In contrast, this Walt Whitman inspired project is classified by Tzadik as a mystical work. To begin, 'Whispers of Heavenly Death' and 'Song at Sunset' are both cheerful and light. Such material is the embodiment of Zorn's mystical works, at least as expressed by this group. In a similar vein, the theme for 'Halcyon Days' is a delicious Jewish melody that inspires awe in the mysteries of the universe. Every now and then, this soundtrack to transcendent glory makes a surprise transition into a brief avant-garde breakdown. The juxtaposition is very well done. With a roller coaster of tempos, 'Portals' is straight-up avant-garde. After a jarring ride, 'Sea Drift' and 'Song of the Open Road' are a return to relaxing jazz. 'The Body Electric' is another avant-garde offering. Infused with Ikue Mori's electronics, 'Mystic Cyphers' is a lightning rod for darkness. The song is reminiscent of Zorn's Dracula inspired "Nosferatu." Before arriving in 'America,' each of the album's songs are only a few minutes. Almost fifteen minutes in length, 'America' is the album's epic offering. This is another sunny jazz song. "On Leaves of Grass" offers a curious foil between peaceful jazz and cacophonous avant-garde.By itself, "On Leaves of Grass" is enjoyable but for anybody listening to the last few years of John Zorn's mystical and avant-garde works, "On Leaves of Grass" is a rehash. The avant-garde here is outmatched by offerings on the previous two albums, "Nova Express" and "Dreamachines." Beyond this, the sunny jazz may seem like a paradigm change for the group, but it seems to have gone unnoticed that the Nova Express Quartet (Joey Baron, Trevor Dunn, John Medeski and Kenny Wollesen) has recorded outside of their current moniker. Indeed, "At the Gates of Paradise" is one of the jewels in John Zorn's mystic series. While possessing merit, none of the songs on this 2014 release are as good as those on "At the Gates of Paradise" with regards to the melodies, compositions and performances. Unfortunately, "On Leaves of Grass" doesn't exceed or even match the group's previous work. In the end, this is a good album by a great group.

"Adramelech" is a glorious celebration of Afrobeat, John Zorn style. The twenty-second Book of Angels was handed to longtime Tzadik artist Jon Madof. For this project, Madof leads Zion80, an eleven piece band. The name of the group is surely a nod to Fela Kuti's beloved Egypt '80. Stylistically, the band plays Afrobeat with a Jewish twist. This is in contrast to the band's debut which expresses a more straight ahead vision of Afrobeat. Alas, this isn't an original idea, but it exceeds previous efforts of those like the Fourth Ward Afro-Klezmer Orchestra. A heavy Afrobeat groove is the foundation of the project's musical formula. On top of this, the brass section plays Afrobeat phrases that are often infused with a Klezmer sensibility. Instrumental Jazz and Rock are also woven into this musical tapestry. The eclectic instrumentation includes multiple brass and woodwind instruments, bass, percussion and drums. 'Araziel' is a good opener in that it introduces the listener to the "Adramelech" experience. The album features fantastic keyboard work courtesy of Brian Marsella who also plays on "Caym," Cyro Baptista's Book of Angels. As on 'Sheviel,' Marsella's retro organ sound brings much to the table. Considering that the bandleader is also the guitarist, Madof practices restraint with regards to the modest amount of time that the electric guitar is heard. That said, he rocks hard on a few songs like 'Metatron.' 'Lelahiah' brings to mind the fantastic work that he's done in projects like Rashanim. Moving along, 'Shamdan' has a strong Jewish sensibility. Many of the offerings have a psychedelic, trance vibe. Along these lines, 'Kenunit' is a ten minute jam featuring Jazz style solos. In many of the Book of Angels releases, the last song is one of the strongest. Featuring beautiful flute work by Jessica Lurie, 'Nehinah' doesn't disappoint. The groove is to die for. For fans of Afrobeat, "Adramelech" offers instant gratification. That said, this is no rehash. While an Afrobeat revival has been going on for around a decade, most members of the movement have been reluctant to step out of Fela's long shadow. In contrast, "Adramelech" is fresh on the ears as it successfully integrates Jewish aesthetics. With its twenty-second eclectic installment, the Book of Angels now features an Afrobeat offering. It begs the question, when will John Zorn run out of ideas? How many more sonic frontiers can he and his compatriots incorporate, break, and create? If the past is any predictor of the future, let's hope that John Zorn is only getting started.

I'd like to start out with an excerpt from M. Richards' Amazon review, "I avoided this cd despite it's great reviews because I always like Frisell's later works from the early '90's. I was wrong. This is as strong as some of his best recordings today." I appreciate this sentiment. Frisell has always been a guitar visionary. That written, his music didn't really bloom or mature into consistent greatness until the late 1990s. Thus it's easy to be skeptical about Frisell's second album. That written, "Rambler" has turned out to be one of the most rewarding efforts that I've come across from Frisell's early period. Up there with "Where in the World?," "Rambler" is surprisingly strong. As with much of his early music, it is orchestrally driven. That written, it is loose enough to feel like a proto-Quartet project. Those accustomed to his later discography get immediate gratification with familiar songs. The title track and 'When We Go' are played on the Ginger Baker Trio's "Going Back Home." 'Strange Meeting' is one of the highlights off "Bill Frisell with Dave Holland and Elvin Jones." Despite the album's strengths, it is not a place to begin with Bill Frisell -unless the listener is an ECM junkie. At the end of the day, "Rambler" sounds dated. This is due to the production and performance. That written, this dated quality sometimes plays as a strength. For example, Frisell occasionally employs a synthesizer used by Robert Fripp during the same time period. This wonderfully retro sound is immediately recognizable by anyone familiar with King Crimson's music from the same epoch -think of albums like "Discipline" and "Beat." While not a place to begin, "Rambler" is a great listen for the Frisellian that has played out Bill Frisell's first tier recordings.

"Jazz Shots from the East Coast" is a collection of jazz videos. On volume 1, the selections are uneven given the balance of legends, obscure gems and unknowns. Mostly coming out of public domain vaults, the video quality is poor. No attempt was made remaster these selections. Fortunately the audio quality is on average, good. The first two songs feature the Bill Evans Trio. The second song is his great, 'Waltz for Debby.' Next up is the Ahmad Jamal Trio on grainy black and white. The third act features a forgettable performance by the Phil Woods Quartet. Thelonious Monk is the first heavy hitter on "Jazz Shots from the East Coast." While it's rough footage, it's still a treat to see Monk play live. The band plays a good version of 'Blue Monk,' complete with Monk's signature foot floppin'. Keeping the theme, Johnny Griffin next plays 'Monk's Dream.' Despite what seems to be a lousy VHS transfer, it's actually a good retelling. Oscar Peterson's performance is one of the video's gems. On the keys, Peterson is spellbinding! This is vintage footage from the glory days. Fortunately, the editors included three Duke Ellington songs. Most likely from '40s, the cinematography on the first two songs is precious. Through audio hiss, the orchestra plays 'Mood Indigo' and 'Sophisticated Lady.' In contrast, 'Take the A Train' is played by a trio. Ellington's amazing phrasing as a pianist comes through on all three selections. The strangest material here is by Keith Jarrett's group. Beginning with 'Tagore,' Jarrett plays the piano's interior strings. Packed with flower power free jazz, 'Passin' Thu' shows what experimental jazz in the '60s was all about. There is very little remaining footage of this fleeting moment in jazz history. Jimmy Smith follows the freak out. Live footage of Smith is rare and often lacking in quality. Unfortunately, this material is no exception. Aside from the organ having that roller skating rink sound, every scene is a close-up making it a bit difficult to watch. Oscar Peterson returns for another swingin' tune at what is surely the Newport Jazz Festival. The last tune is by the great Rahsaan Roland Kirk. While the video quality is poor, Kirk is seen doing his amazing multi-instrumentalist thing. The track only shows a single solo but the incredibly rare footage is remarkable! Volume 1 of "Jazz Shots from the East Coast" is an eclectic look at several decades of jazz history. The inclusion of dates and venues would have been appreciated. As is, this video program mostly shows uneven and rough footage. There are a few gems but most of the stronger footage is available elsewhere. Get "Jazz Shots from the East Coast" if you can't live without the rare footage, but avoid it if you can.

Glen David Andrews is the real deal. The music here is distinctively NOLA but the Big Easy is a sound, not a genre, so Glen David Andrews mixes things up with an eclectic variety of styles that include Funk, Gospel, Jazz, Soul, Rock and Christian Contemporary. For starters, let's talk about the voice; if you've never heard Glen David Andrews, his vocals are amazing. It's like Willie Dixon meets James Brown. The album kicks off with 'NY To Nola.' It's a great autobiographical song that plays New Orleans Rock. Many of the Rock songs on "Redemption" sound remarkably similar to the Crescent City's best Rock band, Galactic. As it turns out, this is no coincidence as the project features Galactic's Ben Ellman, who also produced an album for Glen David Andrews' cousin, Trombone Shorty. Featuring Ivan Neville, 'Chariot' is a sweet gospel number. The funk gets turned on high for 'Bad By Myself.' In this song, the horns cook! For 'Didn't It Rain,' Andrews is assisted by the The Queen of Gospel, Mahalia Jackson. They sing a moving gospel song about the flood that will get anybody clapping or toe tapping. Accompanied by Jamison Ross, 'Surrender' is Contemporary Christian: "What is a woman who gains the world and all these material things / I'd rather have Jesus in my life." 'Kool Breeze (Glen's Season)' is a great Jazz instrumental. It will inspire anybody to get up and shake their bones. Never afraid to combine the sacred with the secular, 'Movin' Up' is another Christian Contemporary offering. Playing Rock, 'Lower Power' features Anders Osborne, who previously worked with Galactic, Toots and the Maytals, and Karl Denson. 'You Don't Know' is the highlight on the album. It's an anthemic Jazz/Rock/Funk tune. 'Something to Believe In' makes for a chill closer. "Redemption" stands as a good Glen David Andrews studio album. It features good song writing. While NOLA permeates every tune, Andrews works in broad musical styles to keep things interesting. Additional assets include special guests and a strong production. In the end, this effort does not surpass Glen David Andrews' previous release, "Live At Three Muses." The live release captures the magic of a phenomenal club performance. It also features fewer sacred selections. Moreover, in that environment, the listener is able to appreciate Andrews' enormous stage presence. When it comes to this 2014 release, the man has captured the real sound of New Orleans by telling his story. Join Glen David Andrews on his musical journey to find redemption.

Anybody in-the-know appreciates that while Bourbon Street hosts New Orleans' most famous nightly party, it's not the seat of the town's best music. For the best live music, many would argue that you need to travel a few minutes north-east to Frenchman Street. There one will find clubs like Snug Harbor, Blue Nile and the great Spotted Cat.  To celebrate this magical street, Mystery Street Records presents "Frenchman Street." It's a fantastic compilation of artists that you've probably never heard of. So while it doesn't feature anybody like the Jazz Vipers, Kermit or Meshiya Lake, the musical quality of this sampler makes the case that you should know these musicans. New Orleans artists often sing about their hometown, both celebrating its unique merits and venting about the city's struggles. In that vein, Shamarr Allen offers the perfect introduction to the compilation with 'Meet Me on Frenchmen Street.' Through 'You've Got to be Crazy to Live in This Town,' Alex McMurray laments the challenges of living in what many consider the most northern Caribbean city. Jesse Moore makes a Bluesy contribution with 'When the Hoodoo Come Down.' 'Dumaine Street Blues' is in the New Orleans Jazz style that the Vipers typically encapsulate. Here, Glen David Andrews shines! The Nightcrawlers represent the New Orleans Brass Band tradition. One of the highlights comes from Margie Perez & the King Cake Babies. Perez's 'Mardi Gras Carnival' is a fantastic celebration of the Crescent City's most celebrated annual event. Another sparkler is Craig Klein's 'Shake Your Rugalator,' which is a New Orleans Jazz inspired reworking of the Blues standard 'Got My Mojo Workin.' 'Stew Called New Orleans' features the compilation's most well-known artist, John Boutté who is best known across the country for doing the theme song to the HBO show "Treme." Matt Perrine's 'Sougouya' is the album's one instrumental. The final John Boutté song was pulled from the 2006 Jazz Fest. In this amazing retelling, Boutté reworks the lyrics of 'Louisiana 1927' to describe what the city went through after Hurricane Katrina. Released in 2011, "Frenchman Street" is a strong compilation of underappreciated New Orleans artists. The songs are fantastic and the production is tops. It offers an eclectic sampling of the roots music we most associate with the Big Easy. If you can't get down to Nawleans and meander in and out of the clubs, "Frenchman Street" offers the next best thing.

I'm having a hard time with this series. On the one hand JA Sutherland is a good writer and the character Alexis is fantastic; on the other hand the universe is getting harder and harder for me to swallow. The whole idea of this series is sailing ships in space. You get that from the first book, but in this second novel you realize that its not just sailing ships in space, its basically the British Empire in the height of its sea fairing navies in Space. All of it.From Lords, to Colonies, to Gentlemens Clubs, to Captains being powers unto themselves. And for me this is starting to come apart in this novel. He does I think, as good a job as can be done relocating the 17th century into the distant future, and it is very interesting to read a future very unlike the others, but thinks just don't quite add up. Technology is advanced enough for us to spread amongst the stars, but somehow communications got left in the 22nd century? Captains are more or less unaccountable, because somehow our current trend of 24 hour news cycles and organizations being slaves to public opinion is no longer the case. That part is an excellent example of the premise starting to show some holes. Were not sailing ships anymore... people can all read. There are no slaves. And yet the Navy is still conscripting people with no recourse and captains are beating and killing the crew. Gender equality took a huge step back... and their are still swords and sails and cannons and my frustration.This is a great story: good writing, fun adventure, a heroine you can root for, but its starting to seem like it should have been set 300 years ago. Not 300+ years in the future. I hope the author can work away from some of these silly conceits and start to move into the future. I think as the story progresses these "universe holes" will only become more prevalent and harder to surmount. But Mr Sutherland if 1000 years from now this is what the universe looks like, I will gladly eat my hat.

Just Fantastic. Instant winner. The shade is perfect for a sunday brunch or just to add a little fun mid week. It last a week without chipping with just two coats and is still going strong. It looks good on just about any skin tone, but really shines for someone with a more coppery/brown complexion, as the color really pops and seems to have more orange then pink. But not a neon... no idea how people got that. The consensus was that this formula was in fact thinner then previous years, but no one had a hard time putting it on, and once it dried it stayed. So they might have taken out a thickening agent but 4/4 users at my place had no problems with it. Still don't expect it to be quite like essie you remember, and make sure you shake it up well.

If you're reading this because you loved the nightstalker series be prepared for something completely different. This was an enjoyable story in its own right, and if you've read Bob Mayers other books from the beginning, what he did with this one I thought was masterful--the way he tied it all in and had interesting call backs and just all around is a superb and tight writer.That being said I didn't like it as much as the Nightstalkers books... not enough to take a star off, but it wasn't one beginning to end story about the team. Instead they all had separate adventures in separate times that picked up and left off simultaneously. If that makes sense. So you'd read the first 4 hours of one adventure in viking times, then the next 4 hours in victorian England, then 4 hours somewhere else, etc etc. None of them completing it until the end of the book. And like lots of others in his very intelligent series you're left with a lot of questions. In addition to the team members, you also follow the Cellar and catch a glimpse of a few other players. It was nice to see everyone, but at the expense of not sticking with anyone as long as I would have wanted. Even though this book reads more like an Anthology the stories were still fun and full of twists, and Mr. Mayer still brought his trademark excellent writing. Getting historical and technical details as correct as possible, which I love. I'm so sick of reading books where the author just completely makes up how the Army works or puts external hammers and safeties on Glocks, etc etc.So this was a good read, and you'll enjoy it, so long as you're prepared for something different from, yet at the same time touching on, his previous offerings. You don't necessarily need to have read them to understand this book, but I would recommend starting with the Nightstalkers as its just a great series.

This is where its at. When you have too much stuff for your pockets, but not enough to warrant a full size backpack this fills the gap nicely. Perfect if you're toting along a camera or a scope. It looks stylish and holds a wide variety of stuff. I've used it hiking, traveling, and on extended road trips. Its comfortable, well made and built tough, as almost all Max products are. It has a CC pocket if thats your thing, which I found works almost as well for books or kindles or anything else you want fast access too. The Khaki/foilage color is legit. It has plenty of admin/organization pockets too. You can easily and smartly manage and fit everything you need into this bad boy. I wish they could make it ambidextrous for either side carry so you could switch, but I know thats more a me issue since I shattered a collarbone and it gets sensitive after a while.

My only real complaint about these is the "feel." My friend had an old pair that I swear had a slightly rubbery feel to them but were definitely Holbrooks. I have other oakley glasses that have the rubbery feel and it just makes them feel more quality. At any rate if you want a slightly sportier/tougher pair of wayfarer type sunglasses (both rayban and oakley are owned by same company luxottica) these are great. They are very light and wear extremely comfortably. They have no screws so the arms will just pop out. (They could break too I suppose, but mine have just popped.) You can also change out the lenses when you get bored. I get lots of complements, and while my face is a little more narrow, I think they look good on a variety of face types. the commenter who said they look feminine... well I just don't know how anyone would think that. These are probably some of the most masculine glasses I own. And I have authentic aviators, new wayfarers, steve mcqueen persols (also a luxottica brand) as well as others.

Loved. for the price, these are exceptional. It was a little smaller then I thought, but my gf who I bought it for thought it was perfect. Quality was good and its so nice she almost doesnt like to write in it or take it places. Ours came in a little bit more of a blue/purple hue. Still we loved it. So check the size, don't get it for the color shown, and be prepared for an amazing product that will make you smile overtime you pack it or open it.

Ive taken my USMC Gen II ILBE Digital MARPAT Assault Pack on many adventures and is has performed amazingly. Its not perfect but it has served me very very well. When my environment is 100% urban I've gotten by with an older briggs messenger bag that has also performed fantastically. As circumstances changed, and I found myself needing to carry more stuff, traveling a lot more and finding myself in multiple climates in short periods of time the messenger just wasn't cutting it space wise and I often had a a ruck and my messenger which was unwieldy at best. I wanted something that would blend into urban and travel environments better than the Marpat pack and hoped also to find some worthwhile improvements. In furtherance of that goal I picked up the Hazard 4 Patrol Pack, the Maxpedition Falcon 2, the 5.11 Rush 24, and the Spec Ops UAP.4.5 starsI realized upon receiving the packs that this was going to be an uphill battle for the maxpedition to win me over. I thought I was getting a pack of a similar class, but realized how small it is compared to the others upon receiving it and comparing the specs. Its 1500 compared to 2000-2500 for the other packs. It was  a lot more narrow then I realized from the pictures. Partly my fault I know. I have a lot of Max stuff, and I feel like its all of the best quality, well made, and well thought out. I love my versa pack, my cooler bags, and various pouches I have from them. This pack didn't seem to quite have the same well thought out design features as my "man bag." The ergos were wrong for me, it did seem weirdly stiff, and the straps, while serving a definite purpose, made access difficult. I also wish their black was black. I don't especially enjoy the contrast stitching highlighting each and every molle strap, and I don't think it serves much of a purpose other then highlighting my tacticool pack.If you're looking for something lightweight and high speed this is a great choice if you won't be carrying a ton of gear. I expect the stiffness would go away after some time, and I trust Maxpedition and their fantastic/high quality products. I can see this pack really shining on a motorcycle or bike, or any place (back) space is at a premium. The design will really be hit or miss for some people, and pay attention to how narrow it is. If you want something a little more traditional, but still with great urban/thoughtful features, I recommend the Hazard 4 day pack. It has contrast lining, a padded pocket for organization, and great padding. Its the ideal urban/travel bag for medium duty.
