If you want the best value in more traditional shaped rucks, I recommend the 5.11. It doesnt have any earth shattering features, but its good quality, has good ergo's, has good organization, its tough, and can be found for a great price on amazon. I ended up going with UAP, its pretty much bomb proof, its made in america and is infinitely customizable. Sadly like everything customizable that costs extra. It already is the most expensive of the bunch, but figure in another hundred or so for back panel if you want one, admin pouch if you want organization, hydration hook if you want it hanging, etc etc. Still I think my grandkids will probably be passing it down to their grand kids.

Ive taken my USMC Gen II ILBE Digital MARPAT Assault Pack on many adventures and is has performed amazingly. Its not perfect but it has served me very very well. When my environment is 100% urban I've gotten by with an older briggs messenger bag that has also performed fantastically. As circumstances changed, and I found myself needing to carry more stuff, traveling a lot more and finding myself in multiple climates in short periods of time the messenger just wasn't cutting it space wise and I often had a a ruck and my messenger which was unwieldy at best. I wanted something that would blend into urban and travel environments better than the Marpat pack and hoped also to find some worthwhile improvements. In furtherance of that goal I picked up the Hazard 4 Patrol Pack, the Maxpedition Falcon 2, the 5.11 Rush 24, and the Spec Ops UAP.I had some extra cash so I ended up going with the UAP. But if I was on a budget this would have been my choice. You can sometimes score them around double digits. This doesnt have a ll the bells and whistles of some of the other packs, but for this price you can see why its the top seller in tactical backpacks. You get a lot for your money. Lots of organization, fleece lined front pockets, admin pocket, zippers and mesh inside. If you want a pack thats going to get you through your adventures with minimal fuss and minimal wallet impact this is the one. If I knew without a doubt that my pack would be done by the end of my trip, either left behind or beat to death I'd get this one, because Id feel like I got my money's worth out of it. All of the features have been well thought out and work well. It had the most organization of any of the packs. I wish the padding was a little more robust on the shoulder strap but thats made up for a by both a padded back and removable back panel. Also its missing a belt.It also was the mose inconspicuous of the tactical/rugged/molle packs I looked at. It just didn't have the same bulges or eye catching weirdness that all the other ones have. The Max is weird shaped and has contrast stitching, the uap has huge velcro swathes that demand to be studied, and the Hacard 4 has an eye couching padded pouch. The Maxpedition was a little smaller and more stream lined then the others so if you're looking for light and fast wait I'd get that one, its very different then other packs. The Spec Ops UAP is by far the most bullet proof and is extremely heavy duty (and most expensive--in addition to price you have to add pieces a la cart to it) and the one I ultimately decided on. The Hazard 4 is a great backpack if your more urban/office centric. It just feels a little more civilized and has little details like a padded pouch and contrast lining, but didn't feel quite as touch as any of the other backpacks (opinion only since I didn't put it through the grinder.) And this 5.11 brings the value. It doesnt offer the same situationally specific advantages as the other packs, except in the price department which makes it my choice for best value. You get good features, very good quality, and an unbeatable price.

This is a very very relaxed fit jean. For the price its pretty good quality. The material is a little on the thin side, and the fit is very much on the loose side, making for a very comfortable, light weight, almost flow jean. Oddly I'm a 32 in some jeans, a 33 in others, but this 34 was the right size for me. (in the interest of full disclosure, I have gained a little weight since an injure and am now about 175 and 6') My fit looks similar to the picture, except with more material and more bunching which you should expect unless you have them hemmed. These are longer than my other 32 length jeans. If I got another pair (and i probably will) Id stick with 34 and try non relaxed boot cut. I really wish for review purposes they'd send us the same thing in a couple different sizes so I could tell you the differences. Its been my experience that at this price point for clothes and other textile goods its very common for items to be made in a (relatively) wide range of measurements for any given size.The fly is button, the stitching is of ok quality with some missing and loose threads here and there. Again it all comes back to the price for me. I've owned some $200 selvedge diesel jeans that lasted years, and the next pair lasted months. I've had levis at higher and lower price points that were all over the place quality wise. I don't expect these to wear in and last a lifetime, and they are thinner then other wrangler jeans I have, but for the price I'm ok with getting just a year or two out of them.

I saw some other reviewers say they had problems with the stitching. So far I've had no problems. I got this for my dad for fathers day and its been great. Ours was a little darker then the picture (and i hoped it would be lighter!), and it was a little tighter fit in some pockets then it should have been. Still its a great looking wallet that is sure to please any baseball fan. It seems high quality and has great fit and finish. Highly recommended.

Each time I watch and listen to this disc, it brings me renewed pleasure. One Mo'  Time is also in my collection, another disc to watch when you want or need a bit of joy in your life. As were some of the other reviewers, I was surprised to find that I had not bought another variation on the three operatic tenors which was such a bit hit. A pleasant surprise, it turned out, since these three are equally at home in both the operatic and the popular realms. In addition, the staging adds to the vitality of the performance, as they tread lightly about  in various formations, always in direct communication with the audience and with each other.One need not ask which of the singing trios now on disc is preferable to the others. Each has its virtues. When it is adept handling of both pop and classical styles, though, few can match these guys.

An entertaining more or less tough guy P.I. with a soft sentimental side. Some of the violence of the classic tough guys of the thirties and forties, but with a kind of 'not to be taken too seriously air' about it. Hero of the tale is a dog left in his care by a girl friend, one of a passing parade, who does not win any dog-show metals but has the mettle to take on the bad guys. Hero is unexpectedly embarrassed by the invitations to have sex of some of the passing parade of women...not in keeping with the classic tough guys. There are nasty thugs and nasty police with a pretty good plot involving a dog show, drugs, dogs in love and an assortment of typical situations. All-in-all, author does not let cutesy dog stuff entirely control the show, which is what saves the book from dying in saccharine sentiment. Should be good reading, a bit, but not too much, sentiment for the tough guy adherents and a few, but not too many, beat 'em up sequences, to drive away the 'cosy' readers.

I write only as a viewer who watches dance only as an 'amateur'. My only live experience with it, aside from various forms  of  tap dancing and chorus lines, was a couple of years with season tickets to watch Balanchine. I was interested and entertained by the three dances performed for this disc. As one reviewer has  pointed out, one with the "senior" group whom he supervises is more a somewhat active skit than anything else, although the meaning is rather more clouded than were those we use to see on television's Bob Hope, Jack Benny, &etc. shows. The heart of the disc are the two others. The setting is pretty much like your average High School or College Gym in which a group of young men and women in their tightly fitted work suits (although some of the men and women have occasion to put on skirts) are going through series of intricate body movements at various speeds, from excruciatingly slow to lightning fast, both  alone and in intimate contact with another. There is none of the flowing grace of the traditional ballet, nor the costumes and scenery. What one does get to see are how almost inhumanly slim both sexes are and, for the bare chested men, how the skeletal structure of their chests and back are  part of the show. Kylian does try to enlighten the viewer as to his intentions in a brief interview accompanying each of the three pieces...one may, or likely, may not, see much relationship between his  words and the action on stage. I say these things so that viewers who still expect the customary context for ballet, the wonderful scenery and costume, the graceful flow of bodies, the interweaving of the dominant female with the subordinate male, save when he is given leave to turn incredible leaps about the stage, will know that they will not find them here. On the other hand, those who take a neutral stance toward variations in style, may well get the same pleasure as I did from observing the patterns of physical interaction and individual....contortion? Oh, yes, those interested, will find some confirmation of what I saw once on a film about an American ballet school associated with a major company....a very ambitious and apparently skilled dancer was shown being rejected from further study because she would never be successful with her  curvaceous body and clearly defined breasts. In the first ballet on the disc one can see for oneself some verification of the statement....although I have no idea whether the intervening years between then and now (and between the date of these performances and today) have altered the situation perceptibly. In brief then, these are not in the style that once dominated formal dance, if you want to stick with the wonderful work done in that manner, this is not for you. On the other hand, if you are open, even as a stranger (as am I) to some of the contemporary variations, these might well provide an enjoyable evening.

Just to add a footnote, along with joining the applause for a wonderful singing actress. She has announced her retirement this year, 2015, from the opera stage, although apparently recovered from the voice problems which so troubled her in her forties. She will continue singing but no longer will be bringing to the public vital performances such as are sampled in this outstanding collection. It was great fun to watch and a wonderful "commercial" for full opera discs which are still available. All excerpts fully subtitled.

Working in NYC for a couple of years in the mid-60's, with season tickets available at a price my limited salary would bear, and with the new Lincoln Center location (at the then new Lincoln Center), I was able to see the numerous Balanchine productions of the era (as well as the brilliant opera productions with the likes of Beverly Sills performing). Knowing nothing of ballet and only what I learned from watching Fred Astaire, Gene Kelly, The Nicholas Brother on film (and many others live, benefit of growing up in Brooklyn. leaving permanently only with the onset of the Korean War (does anyone remember that UN Police action these days?).For various reasons that period ended my experience of live formal dance save for the occasional television production I managed to catch. Only with retirement did I amass a collection of DVD's with assorted choreographers represented as they came to my attention. Withal, I write as a  pure amateur in dance and commend Teachout's introduction to Balanchine from that perspective only. At the prices shown today on Amazon for used copies (or new for that matter), it is easy to commend it wholeheartedly to the viewer who wants to learn a valuable bit about dance and one of its modern masters. Teachout is a self-identified enthusiast of the choreographers work and should be read with that perspective but he also makes quite clear, if only with great brevity, the behavioral patterns which many of us would find quite distasteful. Whether or not one accepts these as the privilege of genius, whether or not one believes these to be inevitable flaws when this genius involves working groups of people in intimate and extended circumstances, bringing them forward to public view, even with brevity does create stimulating contemplation of just how to take the man. As to the choreographer, though quite unable to make an  informed comparison with others of his period, Teachout makes a fair case for Balanchine being a man whose work all who enjoy watching dance would want to see. In fact, as is true in my case, you might be sufficiently interested as to collect a number of other biographical works both on the Master and some of his students.

Charlotte MacLeod's Peter Shandy leads the reader on an amusing chase for the villain who 'did in' a quite boring and entirely irritating retired Professor. More than likely he and most of his colleagues, including the redoubtable College President, would likely have let the incident pass unnoticed if it did not seem likely to cast a shadow upon their beloved university. For there was an election of importance to the University in  process and nefarious forces somehow associated with the event seemed bent upon damaging public  opinion with regard to its students and policies. A further murder reinforces the President's determination that Professor Shandy provide aid and comfort to the seemingly bumbling sheriff who proves to be capable of rising to the occasion under the tutelage and with the support of the academic who has, through chance, become something of a crime fighting legend on campus.Readers of the series will have some advantage in appreciating this visit to New England but others should be able to find almost equal pleasure in the book. There is nothing here to awaken deeper sources of personal anxiety or raise momentous issues of crime and punishment. The author seeks only to entertain without recourse to often ugly and disturbing reality nor the sexuality which adorns many current mysteries. In this book she succeeds pretty well in achieving that objective.

I bought this book just after viewing my disc of The Hard Nut for the second time, appreciating much more than the first time, the distinctiveness of so much of the dancing. It is well worth reading but be aware before buying that it is really just Mark Morris Part I since it was written when he was just about 35 years of age and had a lifetime of mature work ahead of him. It does, however, do a very good job within that limited scope, ably covering his youthful experiences as well the early stages of his career, the nature of his approach and the difficulties he faced in the now somewhat famous  Danish period when he played to often hostile houses and critics. I should be clear that the lack of a five star rating is due only to the limitations for the reader interested in a single book covering his entire career to date rather than for any failings on the part of the author. It is excellent for the period it does cover.

Nice, brief "cozy' about the owner of a housecleaning business and the ex-con she has just hired. While on a cleaning job, they find a client  dead, leading to  various complications which challenge the detective in the heroine in order to protect her new employee from returning to prison. Follows one of the normal patterns for a cozy with a number of welcome exceptions. The heroine does not have a romance with anyone involved and she is a middle aged woman whose only peculiarity is an overweening curiosity. A quick and pleasant read.

Follows general model for a "cozy". Murder in the heroins newly opened tearoom. Tough, aggressive cop on the case.  Supportive female friends. Loving employees. Determined to solve case herself since she might be a suspect and her tearoom might go down the drain if case not closed soon. What makes the book readable (for me) was the likable nature of the heroine and the general atmosphere of the tearoom set. Don't look for much in the way of excitement, suspense or novelty. Just a pleasant work to fill a few vacant hours.

I see that this is currently unavailable from Amazon but new and used copies are undoubtedly available from other sources, This leads me to make a brief comment only.As far as this reviewer is concerned, despite being drawn from performances of a number of years, this can be considered and feels in almost every way, a single concert. In fact, aside from the brief excerpt from the year 2000 at the very end, it is quite nicely designed to provide quite an entertaining mixture of voices and content.Americans might be particularly interesting in the sometimes thrilling arias from Neil Shicoff  in this period wherein he is seeking to overcome the emotional and vocal problems which torpedoed his rapid movement into the higher circles of American opera. (Brooklyn born, Julliard educated he had made great strides, including performances at the Met in NY, when various forces came together to earn him a reputation as an unreliable and uncertain cast member. In the years since, beginning about the years covered in this disc, he rebuilt his reputation in Europe which allowed him then to be once more accepted in the best of the American companies.)There is sparkling work by other singers, male and female, as well, of course, as a number of good but run of the mill turns. Included, inevitably to the bemusement of those old enough to have been  around when the Older Germany still existed, was a number from Fiddler on the Roof, sung stylishly by Kurt Rydl.So, given the wide range of concerts available at a rather high prices, you might think twice about this one (no price given here), but if the price is a reasonable one, I think the average viewer will find they have purchased the ingredients for a most  entertaining evening.

After a quarter century of David Suchet portraying Hercule Poirot with such perfection, it is a bit difficult to return to the original from which his character emerges. Nonetheless, Agatha Christies, late in her career. still was able to take me in hand, so to speak, and make the text speak to me with her voice not that of the fine British actor who made her character live on television. This is a rather simple story, overall, beginning with the murder of a pre-teen age girl at a party. Was the precipitating event her saying earlier at the  party that she had once seen a murder done? Was this congenital liar, in fact, telling the truth this time? Visiting his friend, Ariadne, Poirot takes up the case, which leads him into the past as well the present of the small, peaceful village. This is not the last murder accomplished or attempted that enters into his purview,  but, baffling as they are, he pursues his investigations with the ruthless calm for which he is known.This is a book written late in the day by the Mistress of British Crime Writing but it still has vigor, character and the gift for clarity which marks her style. Not a classic, it should be good reading for those who have a taste for mysteries that lack cuteness, sexiness, or the grime of the city streets.

I'm  only a few books from having read all the Chalmers series that Kindle offers. While not among the best series in the genre, I always find them a good read when I am not ready for intricate plotting and full blown character development. Chalmers is a decent sort of guy, college professor in a third rate British university, esteemed by his colleagues and available when  the authorities above him are in need of a steady hand at the tiller with the intelligence to handle difficult situations. This book tackles a rather bizarre set of events in which the stealing of the magna carta is threatened by the head of a criminal organization which masks itself as the exponent of a political cause. Our hero is drawn into the affair because of his connection with  MI5, a British security agency, and his academic standing. Readers of previous works will be familiar with his Dean and his girlfriend who play some role in this book as well. Questions of forgery and theft arise. Some may find these a bit incredible...but it if you can go along with the premise, it is good fun.All in all, not among the best in the series---but pleasant reading.

Julie Smith is a reliable author of mysteries and the first three Rebecca Schwartz entries were well done light stories. This, too, is worth reading if you like any of the earlier books or some of her other numerous works. The large role played by children somewhat diminished my pleasure in the same way as too much emphasis on dogs, cats or spirits does. That's a personal quirk. Actually, in her characterization of one of the mothers who plays a central  role in the story, she has created one of her more complex and interesting figures. Less stress is placed on the heroines religious affiliations than in previous works but that is neither a positive nor negative factor. Naturally, the heroines love life or absence of same is important to the story as one expects it will be throughout the series.This is understandable since the majority of readers for the genre are female.Without treading on ground which should be untouched, it does no harm, I think, to let you know that the ending is rather more intense than one might have expected from the earlier sections.This work is not as generally favored by reviewers as are some of her others. As one who read the previous three in the series, I liked it. As is not unusual, you will have to be guided by your own judgment of the reviews.

The mystery here is why this should be called a mystery. By none of the normal standards which apply to the categorization of contemporary books does this qualify for the label. That is why I assigned the lowest rating I have ever given  (or felt is justifiable) for this author who is one of my  favorites. It is an interesting book if you have a penchant for historic New Englanders and/or New England churches. The story of how and why a new church was built in a Massachusetts community in 1868 has its merits. The search of the Kelly's for churches previously unknown and/or with a unique, distinctive or appealing feature for his new book on churches seems more a justification for the book than an intrinsic part of it.In sum, the reader who has purchased the book  expecting to find a crime of some sort and its solution by the redoubtable Homer Kelly will spend the entire book looking ....and never finding it. They might find the book interesting, none the less.  I can offer no hypothesis as to why the estimable Langton chose to end the series of eighteen volumes in this mysterious manner.

Given that this is the catalog for the first traveling exhibition of any part of the Barnes collection, the emphasis on Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse is understandable. As I recall, under the very strict terms of Dr. Barnes' Will, color reproductions, external exhibitions, admission prices, and a host of other matters were detailed and binding upon the trustees. By 1990, the roof was leaking badly and building maintenance, generally, as well as the maintenance of the collection, threatened the very existence of paintings and other artifacts which comprised one of the jewels of Art in America. While modestly wealthy in his day, Barnes did not leave sufficient funds to insure the quality of collection forever. At this point, the Trustees went to the Orphan's Court, which governs such matters in the legal jurisdiction within which the Building exists, and received permission to undertake an traveling exhibition. It, in turn, netted them about ten million dollars, which apparently paid for meeting immediate needs. It was considered a great success. (As most know,  ultimately the Trustees sought and received permission from the same Court to move the entire collection to a building to be located in Philadelphia where it would be far more accessible (under further altered terms of the Will accepted by the Court) and thus capable of earning sufficient funds for present and future needs.One consequence of decision in the 1990's we have this excellent volume, giving a distorted picture of the collection, with its emphasis on the most 'salable' Masters, but still one most lay readers will enjoy. The reproductions are good, each major one being accompanied by a brief explanatory essay, no more difficult to grasp than would be a guided tour in the average museum. Those who know of how Dr. Barnes made Soutine's career and almost single handedly saved him the impoverished state in which he lives, would like to have seen more work by him. However, for the general art public, certainly the emphasis alluded to previously, on Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse, is justifiable and well worth the price of admission.I can't speak for or to specialists in art history, but for the layman, the book is a worthwhile reading experience and one with reproductions which will repay the occasional further leafing through its pages over the years.

This is the second time I've watched the disc but the first time I noticed that men were dancing traditional female parts costumed as were the women dancing these same parts. Morris gives his version of why this occurs. I did not watch the interview first time out. Whether or not one can accept his explanation as the "real" truth of it, the fact is that it makes not the remotest difference in watching the disc or, I imagine, for any member of the audience beyond the first few rows. No doubt it was, and still is,  an issue for those who make an issue of such matters, but should have no impact on the average viewers enjoyment of a quite novel approach to the Nutcracker.I leave to the expert reviewers discussion of technical matters, I speak only to those like me, someone who watches for the same reason I watched The Nicholas Brothers, Fred Astaire and other stars of stage and screen, it is entertaining, touching or exhilarating, exciting or romantic. I was lucky enough to be working in NYC when Balanchine was still viewable for the attainable price of a City sponsoredcompany, but, over the years, have learned more about dancers but not enough about dancing than is required of a naive member of the audience. Limited to discs these days, I still watch because it is fun, entertaining, exciting and romantic.From this naive viewpoint, I speak only to the similarly endowed (or, I suppose, unendowed). This is fun, there is excitement, there is a touch of romance,  the costumes are vivid, the performances seem to be top notch for what is required, and the sets are eminently appropriate.  After all, it is not an either-or situation: one can watch Morris' interpretation and a classical one and enjoy both (or neither). Those who  have not given this a chance may be missing a couple of hours of pleasure.

I suppose I cannot give new younger readers advice on these books by Phoebe Taylor which I  read and enjoyed many decades ago and am now re-reading. Her works are not classics of the mystery genre. They are light, mildly amusing tales built around a central "character" which have no objective other than to entertain without  inducing sober reflections. I enjoy the characters, in this case, the redoubtable engineer and man of a all work for the Porter Motorcar Company and  its founders Family, the New Englander to the core, Asey Mayo. In this book, Asey's good friend, the  Village doctor has found a body....which has disappeared by the time he has been able to call for help...Asey responds to the call and encounters a group of  young College students doing a site visit in town. There are complications galore and a tricky ending all of which add to the fun.All in all, a good one for reading when not in the mood for contemplation or the seamy side of life.

Nice contemporary British Mansion mystery. Time is early fifties. Wounded British agent and his 13 year old  daughter are billeted in said mansion....or is it a castle, which hasn't long to survive, for at the end of the seven year waiting period before its owner, who disappeared four years previous, will be declared dead, and his heir will sell it. Nearby is a barely masked secret government facility in which data is processed which is used, among other things, to uncover secret agents for the Soviet. It is to this agency that the agent is assigned. First thing to confront him upon arrival is a newly discovered corpse buried on the premises. Not only is it a who dun it but a why was it done as well.Aside from well designed portraits of the agent and his  precocious daughter, there are a number of other interesting characters in the mix as well as a small ex-urban British community. The author pretty well conveys the flavor  of the classic British mystery school, including the political powerful with exalted pride in Self and the connivance of government with  law enforcement agencies to keep official secrets and the misbehavior of elites under  the covers.Should be a good read for those who have a taste for the traditional of the mystery genre as well as those with a taste for the non-saccharin  'cozy'.

This is the third of the Kelling and Bittersohn books in her series about the now impoverished widow of one of Boston's Blue Bloods and a Jewish art theft investigator. Previously we have learned about the former's marriage to a man old enough to be her father and then her establishment of a Boarding House in the mansion in which they had lived. Somewhere along the way, he has come to live in the house but their romance has progressed slowly because of her views on how soon a bereaved spouse can undertake a full-blooded new romance. Of course, in both previous books murder has somehow been visited to someone who has been in interaction with her. The same, of course, is true of this book which  opens with the fall from the upper balcony of one of Boston's landmark museums. The almost couple are attending an event there and, inevitably find themselves, even though somewhat remotely, caught up in the event. That is not the end of their involvement, however, for other events follow which tie them into the life....and death...of the museum.Readers of other works in the series will know the author to be a skilled story teller and adept writer. While there is plenty of action, the book is not for those looking for tough guy antics, teasing sexuality or suspenseful adventure. There is a leavening of humor, some colorful characters, an interesting plot and an appealing heroine. It is a series in which there is a progressive development in the lives of the characters involved rather than the Rex Stout Nero Wolfe books in which there is some progression from one book to another but where each of the central characters remain essentially the same over the decades.I enjoyed these book on first reading and find them equally appealing some decades later. New readers can jump right in with this book without missing much since necessary background is sketched in. If you afford it, and find your first taste acceptable, you are likely to develop a desire to go  back to book one  and continue from there. On the other hand, as I pointed out, those seeking taut action, high suspense or descriptive sexuality, should look elsewhere.

This second volume of the Sarah Kelling-Max Bittersohn mystery series carries forward the life of now widowed Sarah as working proprietor of a rooming house in what was once the mansion in which she lived with her now deceased husband and mother-in-law. Once again, murder strikes her household and, once again, Max is there for her to rely upon to carry the investigative burden.It all begins when her most offensive renters falls from a subway platform to his death. Was one among her other paying guests in some way responsible. What did she really know about them? Would the publicity kill her little venture before it has a chance to build roots? There are surprises, indeed, as both she and Max pursue the truth.As always MacLeod provides a well-written text with characters into whom she instills distinctive characteristics which are revealed as her  interesting story unfolds. This is good reading for those who have not read the first volume of the series, better for those who have.  I have read all twelve of the books,  with pleasure, and many in the three other series she authored, as well as the occasional independent work she produced. Of course, they vary in quality but all are quite readable. They are not  for the reader who seeks adventure, ardent sexuality, tough, gun-toting heroes, or the gritty streets of blighted urban areas, In today's lexicon, her works fall into the category of "cozy"...but I would prefer to identify them with the British tradition of Christie and her like (or their American counterparts of the teens and twenties of the last century).

Works well, fits well. --and it's a three pack!This kit comes with everything you need to apply the screen protector. Cleaning cloths, etc.The screen protector went on easy, no fighting it to line up right and no fighting with bubbles.The screen is just as responsive as before, no problems.I got this for free in exchange for my honest review

They taste great, but in a smoothie you really don't taste them, so that is a great way to hide some extra nutrition into some foods your kids will actually eat! :) I also love that they are pesticide free. OMG I love this!! I make "Bullet Proof" coffee but I don't use a blender. I used to shake up my coconut milk and oil in a jar. This makes it sooo easy. Have I said LOVE enough?

Cleaning cloths, etc.The screen protector went on easy, no fighting it to line up right and no fighting with bubbles.The screen is just as responsive as before, no problems.I got this for free in exchange for my honest review

So far so good! I live in SW Florida and bugs in your house are just a part of life... unfortunately.More times than I care to remember I've been lying in bed watching a little cockroach crawl up over the covers to join me.It's gross.  I've plugged this in in my bedroom and since I have, the room has remained bug free.So I am going to call that a win.It comes with a one year money back guarantee/warranty, so order with confidence.I got a discount on this in exchange for my honest review.

Great privacy fence screen for our chain link fence. Things on our street have got shady lately... and frankly I wanted a little more privacy for a yard. I have feeling on display when I'm out sitting in the yard, or when the kids are out playing, etc. This screen works really well. It blocks the view enough that people would have to put forth effort to spy on us :)It was easily attached with zip ties, looks nice, it gets enough air passing thru it, looks well made and durable. I believe this will last a long time.I got a discount on this in exchange for my honest review.

I've had other sets of these but they didn't come with a stand so I'd have to tuck them into an old plastic container and they were still prone to falling over. This stand is just perfect. I love making our own ice pops because the ones in the stores are made with artificial junk. These work well, easy to make, easy to clean, easy to get the ice pop out of. The lids stay on well (LOVE that they are attached).Best version of this product yet!I got these for free in exchange for my honest review.

This knife sharpener works great!  I have some favorite knives of mine that have been around for a long time.But after a decade they had got really dull. A friend of mine was making fun of them recently as she tried to cut a lime with one and couldn't even get it to go thru the peel!So I jumped at the chance to try this sharpener. I forgot how great those knives could be! I sharped them all using this device and they are good as new. I was actually able to cut a lime again!It's small, but mighty. I keep mine tucked away in a cabinet. It doesn't take up a lot of space. I like that this one has the added ceramic rod for serrated blades.I was given a discount on this item in exchange for my honest review, and I honestly love it.

This Nootropic energy supplement is a medium sized capsule that is easy to swallow.There is no bad odor or taste or aftertaste.I've had no negative side effects from taking this supplement.You get 60 capsules in the bottle --which is a 20 day to two month supply depending on how many you take and how often.No gelatin. I did notice that I have more energy when I take this supplement.It's made in the USA and comes with a money back guarantee, so order with confidence.I got these for free in exchange for my honest review.

Really cool little mold! Looks like "lego" people.So far I have used it to make kombucha gummies and they turned out great, popped right out of the mold when done too.This mold could be used for many things from ice cubes to crayons.Easy to use, easy to clean,  well made and durable.I'm really happy with this.I got this for free in exchange for my honest review.

This is a great big lot of embroidery thread.One of the other reviewers made a great point of pointing out the colors are off a little from what your patterns might call for, so for complicated shading/color patterns you might not want to use this thread. But I don't use patterns. For me it's OK to just eyeball one of the colors and grab what will work for my current project --which tends to be naughty worded subversive cross stitch ;)This set is really perfect for me. I love the selection of color, I love the quality of thread, no complaints. Great price for the lot!I got a discount on this in exchange for my honest review.

Nice timer. I have a child with autism and sometimes being able to set a timer for various reasons can be very helpful.This counts up or down. The magnet is a nice way to store it away but slapping it to the side of the fridge, and there is a little stand on the back if you want to set it up. Nice large display, easy to see.Not sure how long the battery will last since it doesn't shut off --but so far, so good.I got a discount on this in exchange for my honest review.

I just love my new sheets from Beckham Luxury Linens!!First let me say, I proclaim how much I hate microfiber on a daily basis... and now I need to change that statement... "I hate all microfiber that is not BRUSHED microfiber!" It makes all the difference. I didn't notice these were microfiber when I ordered them, otherwise I would have passed them up. I am glad I didn't notice. For me it's a sensory issue, I can't stand to touch microfiber, the brushed microfiber feels more like a cotton blend. These are so incredibly soft.I got Navy color and I love it.They are well made, nice stitching, no loose strings.And they come with a lifetime replacement warranty, for real! Order with confidence. I will be buying more sets for all the beds in the house.Also, I love that they are made to fit deep mattresses. I have a regular mattress but the way they are made helps to keep the sheet on the mattress without slipping off.I got a discount on these in exchange for my honest review and I honestly love them... how many times did I say love? ;)

This portable lap top cooling pad works really well.The fans do a great job of keeping the heat down --especially on my old laptop that was getting to the point where it was too hot to keep in my lap --even after taking it apart and cleaning it.I love that I can just power it with a USB cord into the computer. The adjustable height is nice, too.The reason for 4 stars, I see some people saying it quiet but I found mine to be a bit loud. Not sure if it's just a personal difference as to what one finds loud or quiet --or if there is something wrong with mine? It's not so loud that I'd send it back, but it isn't what I would call quiet.I got this for free in exchange for my honest review.

Well made, nice quality.The stitching is done well, no loose strings. The ID windows in well made and you can easily fit a standard sized ID card in and get it out again easily --but it won't fall out. Not too heavy or bulky to wear. All in all a very nice two sided, leather, ID card holder.The lanyard is comfortable to wear too, not scratchy.I got this for free in exchange for my honest review.

Really nice dimmer bulb!I have a small lamp that take this kind of bulb and has a dimmer switch on it --it fit perfect and works really well.The price is nice considering the length of time you should get out of the bulb and it comes with 1 year warranty so order with confidence!No lead or mercury in the bulb which is a great plus.I got this for free in exchange for my honest review.

These chalk board stickers are very nice.Good quality, stick well to any surface you might want to stick them too.I put them on jars in the bathroom with the kids names on them and they put their toothbrushes, etc in them.Also great for marking your jars for canning --or any other organizing and craft idea that you can think of.I got the three sheet version which is a great price, but if this is your first time getting them, get the bigger package that comes with the chalk pen so that you have everything you need.I got these for free in exchange for my honest review.

Norwegian Electronica producer Bård Aasen Lødemel recording under the name of Skatebård brings us his high energy version of Balearic beat  EDM.  The tracks on this album are tied together by the underlying thumping beat. But on top of that, he reveals his innovative approach by drawing upon Italo, synth music, ambient strings, minimalist repetitions and more.  The result is an album that engages the ear as much as it drives the body to dance.

This is a fun book for the beginning reader who is a Toy Story fan.  The plot of Toy Story 3 is greatly simplified.  Each page has a couple of simple sentences, with illustrations based on the movie. This is a great way for young readers to conquer a story that they already know from the movie.

This is a great book for fans of Scooby-Doo who are in their first early elementary years.  This tie-in book tells that story seen in the video of the same name.  This can help your early reader. By knowing the story already, it helps them read this chapter book.  In the center of the book are a couple of scenes from the movie.

This is a beautiful pop-up book.  Each page features incredibly elaborate cut-out scenes that pop-up when the page is opened.  Winter's Tale will excite children and provides a jumping off point for telling stories.  The text is brief and describes the scene in a couple of sentences, but this is an opportunity rather than a limitation.Your children will be delighted to read this book with you.

Maxie Baum has used the well-known Hanukkah song "I Have a Little Dreidel" as a jumping off point for this fine children's book.  Baum has adapted this song into a multi stanza poem that describes a family's Hanukkah celebration.  The illustrations by Julie Paschkis bring this song to life.  Her drawings will delight readers young and old.To help those unfamiliar with Hanukkah customs (and the song), there is musical notation for the song, a latke recipe, and the rules of the dreidel game.

This is an introductory yoga book for kids.  It presents 13 animal-named postures (lion, giraffe, camel, etc.), each in a 2 page spread.  The left hand page has a marvelous illustration of the animal. The right-hand page features text that describes how to assume the pose, and why it is like the animal.  There is a photograph of a child performing the pose, to help your see how is should look.  And then, there are a series of line drawings, with instructions, showing how to move form starting position to your target position.If you have children interested in yoga, or you want to stimulate their interest, this book is a great place to start.

If it were only for the Maurice Sendak illustrations, this young children's book would be worthwhile. However, the playful text by Sesyle Joslin makes it a timeless classic.  This book playfully teaches children about manners.  Joslin presents (and Sendak brings to life) a ridiculous situation (you crash a plane into a house, you bump into a crocodile).  At the end of each paragraph describing the situation, Joslin asks "What do you say, dear?".  The next page is a polite reply, e.g. "I'm sorry" or "Excuse me."  I can think of no better way to introduce the idea of manners to young children.This is a fantastic book that you will love reading with your children.

This is a great book for beginning readers who are fans of the animated movie stories.  Their are 5 episodes in this book.  One each from Toy Story, Cars, Finding Nemo, Ratatouille, and Monsters Inc.  Each page has one or two simple sentences illustrated by a colorful picture.  Your child will recognize the elements from each of these movies, and that helps motivate them to read.

The Carp in the Bathtub is a great tale by Barbara Cohen and wonderfully illustrated by Joan Halpern.  It harkens back to the late 19th and early 20th century when Jews lived in tenements in New York.  Leah, the little girl who tells the story, and her brother Harry decide one year that the carp who is living in their bathtub for the week before Passover is their pet.  At the time, it was common practice to buy a live fish in advance of the holiday and keep it alive until cooked into gefilte fish.This story teaches about Jewish life at the time, but it also centers on a brother and sister who become aware of other animals and concerns for their welfare.

With taller ceilings, lights, fixtures and smoke alarms, often I have needed to use my step ladder to access, clean or fix.  2-step stools just don't give me enough height extension.  This Rubbermaid 3-step stool is fantastic.  It is surprisingly light, less than 9 lbs!  Each time I go to pick it up, I am expecting something much heavier, and it flies into the air.  It is even lighter than my shorter 2-step stools.  The secret is it the aluminum that is very strong, but does not weigh much.  That being said, when you climb up, it feels very stable.  The top step is 34 inches off the ground, which gives a 5 foot 6 inch person (like this reviewer), over a 9 foot reach.  This step stool easily folds for storage.This is a great step stool to help you tackle loads of chores and projects around the house.

Over Me is an addictive album.  One listen and you are hooked.  Hannah Lew (bass player from Grass Widow) transfixes us with her ethereal voice.  Her bass playing is complemented by Kyle King's energetic guitar, and Bianca Sparta's strident drums.  Cold Beat gives us a sound that defies classification.  We get melancholia twinged New Wave, riding a smoothed out post punk sensibility.  You are equally comfortably listening to and dancing to Cold Beat's songs.

Panasonic's versatile beard and hair trimmer is ready to tackle any place on a hirsute individual.  It achieves its flexibility by using 2 different combs, and than an adjustable dial allows you set the length of hair to remain.  From a 0.5 mm hipster barista to a 20 mm (8/10 of an inch) length.  The settings adjust every 0.5 mm to let you tailor to your taste.Although it does a fantastic job on beards, this trimmer does a great job on keeping sideburns from becoming unruly, as well as adjusting your hair.  Depending on the degree of your body hair, it can also help reduce your outer wolf man.This Panasonic trimmer is well designed.  It is easy to hold, and heady to move around in a variety of angles, without feeling awkward or stressed.

Microfiber cloths are a boon for cleaning.  This set of 6 includes 2 each of gray, black, and black & white patterned (on one side only, other side is solid white.  The black and white cloths are the softest.  The other 2, have a raised banded pattern on one side, and a homogeneous texture on the other.  As dish cloths, they are on the smaller size, squares, with 12 inches on a side.These cleaning cloths are very versatile.  They are great for cleaning all sorts of surfaces and materials, and are pretty good for drying.  The microfiber weave does not scratch and is very effective on dust when dry, and slightly damp for removing offending dirt, oil or random shmutz.The patterns pleasant.  The black and white geometric pattern is the best.  These will look good in any kitchen.  The are both utilitarian and aesthetically attractive.

Skillful cartoonist Gavin Aung Than adapts inspirational writings of a wide variety of people into cartoon vignettes in this collection of his comics.  The writings come from Isaac Asimov to Sir Ken Robinson, from The Dalai Lama to William Shakespeare.  For each of the stories, Than subtly shifts his drawing style to match the theme as well as the setting.His poignant depiction of Albert Camus's love story in 'The Middle of Winter' contrasts with persistent effort of George Mallory in 'Because It's There'.  Percy Shelley's famous poem 'Ozymandias' leaps out of the page as does Kahlil Gibran's 'Work is Love Made Visible'.  With each story, Than rapidly draws us into each world, and breathes life into the text with his original drawings.  Than is able to entertain while at the same time reinforcing the messages from the authors.The themes of many of these episodes overlap and blend with Than's autobiographical stories.  They call upon us to be true to our own nature, to set out on our own and to make a difference in the world.

These are delicious apricots.  As much as I love the flavor of Turkish apricots, they are often tough and overly chewy.  Fruit Bliss, reinfuses their dried fruit with extra water.  They become soft and almost melt in your mouth.  Combine this luxurious texture with a robust apricot flavor, and you get a fantastic snack.

Photographer Eilon Paz captures the world of obsessive vinyl record collectors. He photographed them with their collections. Often they are displaying specific records that have emotional or musical importance to the collector.We see the mundane mixed in with the weird and the wonderful. Saw blade edged records and obscure Turkish psychedelia. The collectors live around the world and come from all walks of life. In addition to Paz's engrossing photographs, many of which, take up a 2 page spread, we get a variety of short essays and interviews (which are also well-illustrated) with 13 of these obsessive collectors.  These give us insight into this fascinating world.The unique and varied LP album cover art often plays a critical role in these images and in the collections.This beautiful book is fun to leaf through. It is an immersive experience. However, spending some time reading the essays is a great complement to the photographs.

This Bissell Multi-Cyclonic Vacuum is fantastic.  It is compact, quiet (relatively), and has great suction power.  I use it primarily on a hard wood floor.  Granted we don't have a challenging environment, but the Multi-Cyclonic easily removes the every day detritus that we encounter.  It is much quieter than any of the other equivalently sized vacuums that I have used.The regular vacuum extension wand, telescopes from 18 to 31 inches.  The large wheels on the vacuum unit make it easy to maneuver around.  And of course, who doesn't like the spring-powered plug rewinder (why more appliances, besides vacuums, don't have these I often wonder).  In addition to the efficient Turbine Hard Floor tool, the vacuum comes with a Multi-Surface Floor Nozzle, Crevice Tool (of course), Dusting Brush, and Upholstery toolThe vacuum unit is quite compact, which makes it easy to carry as well as to store.  Being a bag less vacuum has positive and negative aspects.  It is a little more involved to clean than a bagged vacuum, but the dirt cup easily comes apart into to hits components when you need to clean a little more than when you routinely dump the dirt cup.  However, on the plus side, you never have to worry about buying bags, finding the rest size bags, because like ink jet printers, it seems that each vacuum uses a different sized bag.  You just vacuum away.This is a versatile vacuum, that will help keep your house or apartment shiny and clean.

I like Blunt umbrellas.  This XS seems long (it does not have a super-compact folding scheme.  However, it opens up to a good size (37 inches).  On a recent trip to Boston, it kept me dry, but allowed me to maneuver crowded streets.  And, with the blunt corners, you don't worry about blinding or skewering your fellow street denizens.  The umbrella dries quickly and comes with a thin, but strong, carrying case.  I have found that very strong wins wan cause it to invert, but that is under gusts that umbrella can withstand.This is a fantastic travelling umbrella

I was looking for a simple, yet stylish CD player (yes, some of us still play CDs) for the bedroom.  The Panasonic SC-HC38 is a winner on a number of fronts.  It's slim design (although 20 inches long) does not take up a huge foot print.  The sound is actually pretty good for a compact system. Much better than the Sony model it replaced.  Loading CDs is simple, as the central panel slides to the side to allow you to vertically mount the CD.  You can control this system with a simple remote, so you do not need to get out of a chair or bed.  There is an FM (no AM) tuner built in.  You can also charge/play our iPod, but for most flexibility, it can play music using Bluetooth connectivity.This is a great, versatile compact music system.  I purchased for less than $80, and it has performed very well.

I have used a variety of travel and vacuum mugs previously, and Aladdin has them all beat.  First and foremost function is most important, but then other factors of aesthetics play in.  I drink coffee and tea, and want it to stay hot.  Because Aladdin has a vacuum layer, hot stays hot for at least 4 hours (and continues to stay warm for even longer).  It can keep beverages cold for 24 hours, much longer than I would ever need.  So this mug is great for temperature control.Equally important is the drinking experience.  I have used Thermos travel mugs that have a 2 partial slits at 180 degrees from each other. If drink for the opening drinks flow well.  If you are not looking when you pick up the Thermos mug and drink from a different place a mess can ensue.  With Aladdin there is but one way to drink from the top of the mug.  The opening is the right size and fits my mouth.  There is a tab for sealing close the drinking opening, and it serves as a protective covering to keep it clean.  Once closed, no drinks will leak out during transport.The sides of the mug are tapered to the middle where you would naturally pick it up.  This makes it easy to lift, hold, and drink.  The stainless steel has a nice feel to it.  The Marina (blue/green) color is more interesting than most, but also understated. Finally, with it being dishwasher safe, clean up is a cinch.This is a fantastic insulated mug.

Let's face it, there are times when our biological functions conspire against us.  We all have a classmate who was voted "Most Likely to be Weaponized" in our high school yearbook, because of his "emanations."Alas, the same odoriferous expulsions can happen to any of us.The day after a particularly large steak dinner, our feces may smell so bad that a lion would be ashamed to release this into the environment.  This can be particularly embarrassing, if you have just passed your judgment on the porcelain throne generating a caustic cloud in the restroom at work and your boss comes in just as you (the only one there) leave the stall.  Looking at you askance wondering if your intestinal system has become a liability to mankind and hoping that he can finish his business without taking another breath.Or, you and your spouse are at a dinner party, and the call of nature rings, but not on your mobile.  You go to their bathroom, and find the fan to be a feeble excuse for pushing a couple molecules of air around.  Your dung smells like a dead rat has been rotting for a month.  You notice that the glade is empty and the potpourri is completely overwhelmed.  As you exit the bathroom as quickly as possible, you encounter you host and several friends.  Their faces turn, involuntarily, to horror as the get a whiff of something so vile they cannot imagine a human produced it.  For some reason, invitations to other parties stop coming.To prevent destroying the nasal cavities of your co-workers, friends and family, you need Poo-pourri.  This cleverly formulated toilet scent works wonders.  Simply spritz 3-5 times the Poo-Pourri into the bowl before you go about your business.  Poo-pourri does double duty by forming a layer of oil that creates a chemical block to trap the nasty smells and prevent their release into the air.  It also contains pleasant vanilla and mint scents that perfume the air.Poo-pourri works wonders.  Never poison the bathroom air again.

Popsalot Brazilian Samba Popcorn is a delicious snack.  The popcorn is crunchy, with a light exterior.  The cashew-embedded carmel coating is a great alternative to the usual peanut caramel popcorn.  The cashews lend a richer taste to the mix.Popsalot has balanced the sweetness of the caramel with nuts and popcorn to give a satisfying flavor.

The Starling Project is more an radio play, or rather audio play, than an audiobook.  Using a host of actors, special effects and music, this is no mere read book.  In this thriller, mild mannered professor and the leader brilliant leader of the "Volunteers," Harry Middleton tries to uncover the secret of "The Starling Project."  The story opens with a raid on international arms dealer's house to retrieve some hard drives.  The Volunteers get the drives, but lose one of their members in the process.  As the story unfolds, nothing is quite what it seems.  Harry's intelligence-driven approach is challenged by the act-first tactics of his newest recruit, DC police detective Kyle Nelson.  We are taken through a roller coaster series of twists and turns before Deaver wraps up the story and deposits us at the end, waiting for the next installment.By taking a radio play approach to this audiobook, the story is elevated and also brought to life in ways that an audiobook alone is unable.  The Starling Project takes you for a thrill ride, and it is short enough to binge-listen in one session, or spread out over only a few.

If you want an in-depth, detailed guide to your Apple Watch, look no further than Marc Saltzman's Apple Watch for Dummies (I do dislike the "Dummies" title though).  For the reader who has newly acquired an Apple Watch, Saltzman methodically takes you through set-up, its features, and all the Apple apps.  Then, it serves, as well, as a useful guide to go back to since there is only so much you can soak up in one, or even several sessions.  What helps this book to excel, is that it is also useful for those of us who have had our watches for a few months.  Saltzman includes loads of insights, small tricks, embedded features, and even exercises to help you discover and remember these features, for example using Siri on your watch to read incoming texts, or having Siri calculate your tip.Saltzman is not content to just give you a set of instructions.  He explains why the watch apps work they do and what is happening behind the scenes.  This gives you a better understanding and more control of your watch.  There are many illustrations and screen shots to help you see what is happening and what you need to do. There are a few 3rd party app recommendations, but of course, since the Apple Store is so dynamic, there are always new 3rd party apps appearing.This is a great manual for the Apple Watch. Wisely, Saltzman focuses on the native Apple apps, and his book will give you mastery over these.

The ET-2500 is a great start-up printer.  It is a bit pricier than a regular inkjet printer, but with a new type of liquid ink that is designed to last 2 years, instead of an inkjet's 2 months.  It seems a bit of a turn around from the inkjet business model of cheap printers as a way to sell expensive ink cartridges. The ink in the Expression series is liquid, and requires you to fill the tanks during initial set-up.  The instructions advise you to use disposable gloves. This is wise.Set-up of this printer was extremely easy.  You need to add the ink, which takes a little care.  Then, you need to have the printer prime the system.  You price a few buttons, and walk away for 20 minutes.  Then, the set-up is quick and easy.  You download and install the driver software.  I am using mine on the wi-fi network.  The driver looks for the printer, grabs your network information from your computer and you are ready to go.Like with many printers, you can opt for a fast mode. It takes only a few seconds per page (depending on what you are printing), and this is the most common mode that I use.  If you are printing photographs, you can use a higher quality mode.  This takes much longer, but results in excellent resolution.There are buttons for color or black and white copying.  Once again, it is really easy to copy single pages.  The scanner runs off Epson's software. It is not flashy, but does all the standard functions I need in a scanner.The ET-2500 has a reasonable footprint.  It is roughly 12 inches deep, by 19.5 inches long by 6 inches high.  However, it is not a rectangular box.  The paper is fed from a vertical tray in the rear.  My other printers have all been much bigger, but they are large paper-capacity all-in-ones or dedicated high quality printers.The ET-2500 is the lowest model in the Expression series.  It does not have have a bottom tray feeder, double-sided printing or AirPrint support (it does support Epson's proprietary mobile system).  If these features are important, you may wish to consider a different model. Otherwise, you will save money on ink jet cartridges with no quality compromise.

Zebra gives you a set of 12 colored mechanical pencils ranging from a light peach to black.  The triangular shaped body makes it easy to hold and is especially useful for younger children.  A couple of important items to note.  The lead at #2 hardness, requires some pressure to produce a good color, but then you don't want to press too hard, or have the point too far extended to prevent snapping.  The pencils all come with a pre-sharpened point. Of course, this shape will change with use.This is a useful set of colored pencils to have for drawing, coloring or other art projects around the house or at school.

I have been experimenting with a number of different lens, especially macro lenses, for the iPhone.  Some require dedicated cases.  Others require gluing on magnetic rings to your iPhone, and then there were a couple of clever static-adhering plastic bubbles.  The Clemagic 3 in 1 earns its five stars for ease of use, versatility and photographic quality.  You get 3 lenses, a 10x macro, a fish eye, and a wide angle.  Each one can be screwed into a clip, that will securely anchor the lens onto your phone.  For your ease or carrying around, Clemagic has included a microfiber bag to carry around.  This makes it extremely easy to take interesting photos with little additional effort.  The lens screw into and out of the clip.  And you can move the phone around without worry that the lens will fall off.  The lenses are made of high grade aluminum ensuring that they will last longer than your phone.Clemagic brings macro, fish eye and wide angle photos to the masses with this competitively priced, high quality lens set.

One might think the smartphone and tablet age would make pencils obsolete.  Of course, anyone with school age children know that it is anything but that.  So, it is great to have not only functional, but aesthetically interesting pencil sharpeners.  With its blend of pear and cylindrical, the Westcott iPoint almost looks like an LED light bulb at first glance.  The see-through type allows children (and adults) to watch the shavings flying off your pencil as it gets quickly sharpened.  Powered by 4 AA batteries, the iPoint has an auto-shutoff so you don't waste energy and overly grind down your pencils. And also being battery powered, you can carry it wherever you need it.The iPoint delivers a sharp pencil point quickly.  The shape of the grinding face gives you a bit shorter shaved area than many others, but that is more a subjective preference than a functional one.  This is a great pencil sharpener to have around.

As that iconic candy bar of our youth expands its flavor-line, they achieve an even better nirvana.  Instead of being stated by mere peanuts alone, we now get Hazelnut Snickers.  The smooth, nuanced nutty flavor of hazelnuts go fantastically well with the chocolate and nougat of Snickers.  There is no better to pick up your energy in the afternoon (or morning or evening), than by munching on one of these candy bars.

Karen Bergreen gives an absurdist mystery in her debut novel Following Polly.  After losing her job working at a casting agency run by the quirky Mona Hawkins, Alice Teakle runs into a Harvard classmate, the incredibly popular Polly Dawson.  For reasons rooted in her dysfunctional childhood (her father and brother had died in a plane crash, her mother suffered a nervous breakdown, and Alice had to raise herself until her mother met and married Barnes when Alice was an adolescent), Alice starts to follow Polly around New York for obsessive reasons.  After Polly is murdered and discovered by Alice, she becomes a prime suspect.  Fleeing from police interrogation, Alice, after stalking (there is a theme here), teams up with another classmate, Charlie, with whom she has been infatuated since freshman year. As Charlie and Alice try to discover the identity of the murderer with help of Alice's best friend Jean, they lurch from one absurd situation to another.  One marvel's at Bergreen's clever twists and turns of plot.  No normal people would behave this way, which is exactly why we love this story.  It is like watching a train wreck of crazy people.  You can't pull your eyes away, nor can you believe what they will do next.

When you need a coin envelope, no other envelope or package will do.  In my case, I often used them for seeds and foreign coins. These coin envelopes do the job very well.  They arrived quickly.  At 15 cents each, the price is not bad.

As great as the iPad is, for lots of typing, it is not.  I use this Belkin QODE Keyboard case with an iPad Air 2, and it is fantastic.  The case accepts a variety of tablets (though not, I should point our my old iPad 3).  It has 2 clips on a flexible spring, that hold the bottom 2 corners.  When using the keyboard, there is a small switch to turn on.  Pairing is extremely easy.  The QODE has a Fn key for first time pairing.  Then, you can type away.  The iPad sits in a slot with a magnetic strip just above the keyboard to hold it in place.  Typing is easy, and there are a number of special use Fn keys to enable control on music  and movie programs.  There is a search button as well.The case is somewhat light, but made of a very sturdy plastic. The keyboard has pretty good response for a portable one.  With this case, I no longer need my laptop.  I can do everything I need with my iPad.  One important thing to note, is that the magnets will not activate the auto off on the iPad Air.This is a fantastic case.  It protects your tablet, and adds a keyboard, that makes typing a breeze.

Geraldine Brooks breaths life into the story of the King David.  Using the Bible as a jumping off point, Brooks starts with David's youth and brings us through his life.  We get a complex character full of contradictions who is can be both noble and self-serving.  The story is told through voice of Natan, the prophet.  This gives us the advantage of an intimate view, and at the same time external that can present the good with the bad.From his early life as a cruel bandit, through his fighting years to kingship.  David often perpetrates and is surrounded by violence.  At the same time, there is affection and love.  Indeed, the most controversial part of this book is David's relationship with Yonatan, only hinted at in the Bible. But this is Brooks's gift - her ability to develop a historical novel that is firmly set in the Biblical era, yet written with a modern sensibility that will appeal to a broad swath of readers.  Moreover, she is able to shed greater light on internal motivations that drive these characters to commit many of the acts that are only flatly told in the Bible.

Another in the entree of convenient, pre-packaged coffee drinks, Skinny Cow's Vanilla Latte is not too bad.  As the name implies, it has lower calories than a full-fat sweetened latte drink.  That is accomplished by using reduced fat milk, and less sugar (although it still has 18 g).  To make up for this and boost the sweetness, they have added monk fruit extract, a source of natural non-caloric sweetener.  And to give this drink the mouth feel you would get from fat, Skinny Cow has added a variety of gels (cellulose and carrageenan) and gums (gellan and cellulose).The coffee flavor is mild in this drink.If you are looking for an easy way to satisfy a quick latte craving, keep a couple of these in your refrigerator.

Journalist David Eimer gives us a fascinating book that covers ground rarely discussed in the usual Westerner-Goes-to-China genre, that of the far-flung regions of China and the minorities who live there.  The title comes from one of the famous Chinese chengyu (short sayings) that translates as "The mountains are high and the emperor is far away". It is used to describe remote, lawless regions.  And for some places the Eimer journeys to, the description is still apt. Eimer travels to the far Northwest - Xinjiang, the Southeast - Yunnan, the Northeast - collectively known as Dongbei.  These are not regions that are particularly easy for tourists.  For the most part, Eimer is traveling to small towns where even the basic amenities of a hotel room, of sorts, and restaurant can be few and far between, not to mention his often inventive means at obtaining transport.Eimer is a keen observationalist, and his humor-inflected writing flows naturally.  One observation about certain dire pit toilets and how they could induce constipation in one suffering from dysentery; well, you don't get an image much more vivid then that.Eimer mixes his travelogue's tales with the history and anthropology of the region he is visiting.  Thus, when in Yunnan, not only do learn about the various ethnic groups, but also, the history of Han migration to the region, the Golden Triangle drug trade, fluidity of cross border traffic (indeed the borders have been redrawn numerous times in history ignoring that various ethnic groups are not defined by political borders),  human trafficking, relationship between the ethnic groups and the Han, and more.  Always, in each place, Eimer also highlights the life stories of people he meets along the way, some intentional, some happenstance encounters.  These personal stories enliven and inform the historical information.Although Eimer brings fresh and honest eyes to Tibet and Xinjiang, I was more intrigued by his visits to the less written about Northeast provinces where ethnic Koreans and ethnic Russians live alongside other ethnic groups and Han Chinese.  The harsh climate has not prevented a robust trade with neighboring countries (Russia and North Korea) to create a strong economic engine for Chinese growth.  In tropical Yunnan, which has half of China's 55 recognized ethnic groups, one, the Dai, had their own kingdom for hundreds of years until it was folded into China in the 1950s. Then there is the Wa state in Myanmar (where they have achieved a country-like independence),  and the Wa people have thrived, moving freely across the border to the benefit of people in both countries.In each of the regions, we see the struggle for the local ethnic groups to maintain their identity. Through intermarriage, national educational policies, and internal migration, many of these groups are losing their languages and unique customs.  In the more remote regions, not being exploited for natural resources, it is easier because of less government oversight, or import of Han Chinese to maintain some of the traditional practices.  However, these regions also tend to be areas of extreme rural poverty.In addition to being pulled into and entertained by Eimer's meanderings, I learned a lot about China that is often not discussed in other books.

Aimed at late elementary school/early middle school kids, Upside Down Magic uses 5th graders at a magical school to tell the allegory of how differences should be celebrated and not suppressed  The writing triumvirate of Susan Mlynowski, Lauren Myracle and Emily Jenkins brings us the story of Nory Horace, the youngest of child of 3.  Her older samplings Hawthorn and Dalia attend the elite magic school Sage Academy, where their father is the headmaster.  The magic world is divided into 5 classes of abilities - Fluxers, who can change their form into animals or other objects; Flickers, who make things disappear, Flares, who can set things on fire; Flyers, who can levitate and fly; and Fuzzies, who can attract and control animals.Nory is a Fluxer, but has trouble controlling her shape-shifting, often appearing as hybrid animals like the bitten, a beaver-kitten hybrid.  Then, she often loses control of the animal part and destroys things.  After failing the Sage Academy admissions test, Nory is rather cruelly packed up and sent to live with her Aunt Margo to the attend the public school, Dunwiddle School. In the Upside Down Magic class, Nory meets other kids who have similar issues with their magic.  They have a teacher who uses unorthodox approaches to deal with their unorthodox magical abilities.The authors use this story as a jumping off point to deal with common middle school issues of belonging, being normal, friendship and more. The morality story comes through that not only is it okay to be different, but it can be a great advantage in life.  Whereas with conformity you lose a bit of yourself.  If there is one complaint, it is the excessive use of the term wonky, meant to mean things that are unsteady and askew.This is a fun story for late elementary readers.  The story moves along quickly so they will not be bored.  The lesson is not heavy-handed, so kids will learn while being entertained.

Always looking for something to make carrying my camera easier, I bought this for my Sony RX100.  Phone cameras may be handy, but they lack many of the features of higher end point and shoot camera.  So, I want my RX100 to be as easy to grab and at hand as my iPhone. The Spider Holster performed just as promised.  The main section, is a sturdy plastic holder that you loop your belt through.  You can use either on the right or left.  Then you attach the metal pin into the tripod mounting socket at the bottom of your camera.  The pin is tightened with the included wrench (you do not want the pin to come loose while walking).  The pin slips easily into the holster, and your camera dangles on the side.  To get your camera, you merely, push down on the red release switch with one hand, while picking up the camera with your other.This holster is very comfortable with a point and shoot.  Much better than carrying on your shoulder or around your neck.  Yet, it is just as handy as these more conventional carrying styles.

For awhile, I had been searching around for a scale that in the spirit of what measures gets improved, would sink with your i-device.  The Vitasigns VS-3200 measures your weight and % body fat, and then syncs the information to your iPhone or iPad, via blue tooth.  It does a great job on the scale, and is very consistent.  For the % body fat, because it runs a weak electric current through you, your feet need to be slightly moist.As much as I like the scale, the app is very so-so.  It is an iPhone app, and does not have a native iPad version. Because I use my iPad, I am usually viewing at a 2x size.  You need to have the app on your phone on, when the scale is sending a bluetooth signal (at the end of weighing, for only a few seconds).  It would be nice if there were a button to tap, to download stored data to your iPhone/iPad.  Otherwise you need to be poised to receive the data immediately.  The Vitasigns app has a few nice features, but the interface is a little clumsy at times, and is sorely in need of an upgrade.

British singer/songwriter, multi-instrumentalist Eliza Carthy shines on this album.  She is often called a British folk singer, but this recording has a much more contemporary feel to both the harmonies and the lyrics.  Some of the songs deal with the darker side of love 'Train Song' and 'In the Company of Love'.  Others are introspective 'Poor Little Me'.  The narrative lyrics wrap us in the emotional tales of the songs.  Carthy's superb alto voice is complemented by her band's virtuosic performances. Their use of British folk sounds updated for the 21st century give a sonic landscape that sounds comfortingly familiar while being simultaneously innovative and modern.

When you think of instrumental duos, the violin and guitar do not immediately leap to mind.  Yet, after listening to the Lyrical Strings Duo, composed of Czech violinist Lucia Conrad and guitarist Stephen Osserman, they seem like a completely natural combination.  Perhaps it is the bowed soprano voice of the violin that when combined with the strummed tenor of the guitar offers the right amount of contrast and complementation to result in a beautiful sound.Conrad and Osserman have cleverly solved the problem of the limited violin-guitar repertoire by creating their own arrangements on this Kickstarter-funded debut album.  The focus of this album is Romantic piano music, whose complex harmonies and sophisticated rhythms gain a new footing on the violin and guitar.  If you were not familiar with the originals, you might not realize that these pieces are transcriptions. The works range from Chopin 'Nocturnes' to Mendelssohn's 'Songs Without Words' to Kreisler's 'La Gitana' to Satie's 'Gymnopedie'.Conrad and Osserman's performance stirs the soul.  Their heartfelt playing brings out the deep emotional content in these works.  Although titled "Evening Songs" for some of the darker elements embodied in these works, this is a great album to listen to any part of the day.

This review is of the pocket mug.I wasn't quite sure how I would use this mug but it has become a new favorite. I like using it for tea. I can fill it with hot water and use the pocket for a lemon slice. I don't get to use it much as the kids think it's the best way to have milk and cookies. The pocket holds one homemade chocolate chip cookie or three biscoff biscuits. I have a feeling that although it's a piece that coordinates with our Christmas china we will be leaving it out all year. The quality is excellent, on par with our other Lenox pieces. It's a fun piece to add to a larger collection but is a stand alone piece and would work just as well as a Christmastime addition to a group of everyday mugs.
