I've added this bowl to our collection of Lenox Christmas China and it fits right in. The winter greetings pieces and the holiday pieces coordinate with each other to create a more interesting table. The bowl itself is good quality, on par with our other Lenox pieces. It went through the dishwasher no problem and didn't scratch when I used a metal serving spoon. The size is good for all around use. It's a nice bowl for side dishes at larger dinner parties but is shaped so as it can be use for smaller quantities as well. The only thing I wish I had was a lid. I find myself reaching for our serve and store Lenox holiday bowls before this one because it's so easy to pop leftovers in the fridge. That said, this is still a wonderful piece and I appreciate the interest it adds to our table.

This review is of the accent plate.This is a lovely plate. While it's a different pattern it coordinates well with our regular Lenox Christmas plates since the holly leaves and berries design around the edge is very similar. The quality is great, on par with the other Lenox porcelain pieces we have. It come through the dishwasher no problem and while we're using it more as a serving plate I ate a meal off it, cutting food with a knife and fork, and it works fine for that purpose. There were no scratches. It's a pretty piece that makes a nice addition to a larger collection but would also be good as a stand alone piece to use around Christmas.

Overall I'm very impressed with this sweater. The quality and workmanship is top notch. I'd say it fits a bit large but I've been wearing it over fitted t shirts. If you're wearing it as a coat over a heavier top it should be just right. While there's some give to it I wouldn't size down unless you're sure you'll only wear it over fitted shirts.The fit is a bit boxy but has a feminine look with the side buttons and neck. There is a lot of room in the waist and hips as the buttons are all up towards the top, including the hidden button to help keep it closed. It would be a great piece for a woman to wear while pregnant if she'd like a sweater jacket that can carry her through the pregnancy while still being a functional piece of clothing after the baby comes. I've found it to be nice for nursing too. I can unbutton the top and use the extra material around the neck for privacy.The one thing I don't like is the feel of the wool. It's scratchy, no two ways about it. It would be perfect if it was knitted from softer wool. I can't stand to wear it with short sleeves underneath and my little one refuses to lay on my shoulder when I have it on. I had expected a softer feel as it's labeled as being merino wool. I lanolized it when I washed it which seemed to help soften it somewhat. I'm still happy with it but every time I put it on I wish it was a bit softer.I just wanted to add my wash routine for this sweater:I handwash it in water that is neither cold nor warm with a soap called eucalan. It says it doesn't have to be rinsed but I like to rinse it anyway. I then take a walnut sized dollop of lanolin and put it in a jar with a very hot water and a drop or two of the soap (some people melt the lanolin in the microwave). I then shake it until it becomes a cloudy liquid. This liquid is then poured into the sink which has the sweater and fresh water. I let it sit for 20 minutes or so although some people go up to overnight soaks. I gently squeeze it dry then put in in the washer for a spin cycle. Then I dry it flat after reshaping it. The lanolin is a product that comes off the wool of sheep. It not only softens the fibers but makes them water and stain resistant as well.

This is the second bed rail we've owned and I'm very pleased with it. It's very, very well made. With our old one we were constantly having to adjust it as it would come loose but this one stays put even when using the folding feature when making the bed. I wasn't sure how the curved sides would work out, I thought they would leave an unsafe gap when the rail was used far up the bed against the headboard but it has turned out to be a non issue. The curve leaves almost no gap once attached to the bed and feels both safe and secure.The rail itself expands to cover about half of the length of a twin bed. It is held up by the mattress itself but, thankfully, doesn't use big thick posts under the mattress that leave noticeable bumps on the sleeping surface. The fold down function works well although it's fine staying up all the time if you're like me and don't often take the time to make each child's bed each day. My little one just climbs in bed from the foot so the rail can stay in place.The one thing I don't care for with this rail is the mesh. I feel it could stand to a sturdier fabric. Although I certainly wouldn't call it flimsy it's just not as strong or as thick of a material as I would like. A rambunctious toddler could tear it if they decided to try and climb over it, especially if they're wearing shoes.All in all this is a great bed rail despite the fabric. It's good quality and should last through several children, possibly with a few sewing repairs along the way. The gray color looks clean and modern and the size is just right.

We just got done playing this game. I'd like to say, right off the bat, that I did not have trouble with the cards dropping too soon as many have mentioned. It functioned as it should throughout about an hour of play. We had a group of neighborhood kids playing it. They're age 7-12 and everyone was able to play together. We allowed the youngest few kids to do only easy cards and the adults in the group played with only hard cards to level the playing field. The sweet spot for the game turned out to be the 11 and 12 year olds. They kept playing after everyone else was done.The one problem I have with the game is that a couple of the cards have adult words. Nothing kids don't hear at recess anyway but we could have done without seeing our middle schooler try to act one of these cards out. This isn't a complaint but I'm not sure how long we will hang onto this game as once you work your way through all the cards it's not as fun since everyone has an idea of what the words will be. An expansion pack might be a good addition.All in all this is a fun game that works for a wide range of ages. Even our younger kids had fun watching the goofy 'acting'. While the quality of the card holder could stand to be improved it worked as it should and turned out to be a great game.

After reading so many negative reviews regarding the quality of this diaper pail I have to say I'm pleasantly surprised by how much I like it. The size and height are just right for me as a woman of average height. It works well with standard size kitchen glad bags which is so much less expensive than buying specialty liners. It's high quality and the open and close mechanism (what concerned me after reading other reviews) works well and seems sturdy. It really doesn't hold odors. Stainless steel is a big step forward for diaper pails in my opinion. We didn't own one for years (we have a large family and have had at least one child in diapers for 11 years) because I had smelled the plastic ones in friends houses and knew I didn't want to deal with deodorizing plastic.My favorite thing about it is the two stage open and close. It keeps it from smelling up the room and allows me to open it before I start the diaper change which means I can set the diaper right in it and come back to close it up once I've washed my hands. With my other diaper pail I'm always having to use the handle with dirty hands then go back and wipe it down.All in all this is a great diaper pail. I'd say it's best suited for families who plan to use a diaper pail for several years or as a garbage can later on simply because of the high price tag. It works well for our family with two currently in diapers. The size is such that I only have to empty it twice a week. I tried putting cloth diapers in it with a fabric liner and while it works I would say it's definitely more suited for disposable diapers. Just an all around solid, well built diaper pail that looks nice next to the changing table.

This review is of the stackable mugs set.These have become a wonderful addition to our Lenox Christmas collection. We have a set of teacups that came with our place settings but they're very formal so we really only use them after our big dinner each year. These are different. They're casual and can be left out throughout the season for coffee or hot chocolate. They're not huge but for hot chocolate for the kids they're perfect. They stack securely. I've had all four stacked up at once without feeling like they'll tip over. Normally I have two stacks of two which lets me fit them into our regular mug shelf without the need to pack up what we already have out. Just an all around good addition to a collection or as a stand along set to use at Christmastime.

I have mixed feelings on this music box. As part of our Lenox Christmas collection it's a unique addition that allows me to tie together my decorations in the kitchen with an item on my dresser. As a stand alone music box, however, I'm less impressed. While it is perfectly functional there are a couple things about it I wish were different. The size is the first thing. The area where you put things is very small. I use it for jewelry and it's filled with just a necklace, a couple rings, a bracelet, and a pair of earrings set inside. This works well for daily use for a short time but I have to keep swapping out the item I'd like to wear. I'm not sure I'll keep this up throughout the season so the box will likely just be for decoration. The other thing is the music. It's a pretty tune when it's playing but it's far from a full song and seems like it was put there just to be able to call it a music box while it's really more of a basic trinket box. The music turning key is set into a paperboard inset in the bottom of the box. At this price point it really should be made entirely of the porcelain or have a wooden inset. All that said, I still like it for being a lovely piece that brings my kitchen Christmas decor into another room.

I selected this item primarily for my six and nine year old boys but most of our kids and their friends have been enjoying it. Like all our playmobil items the quality is top notch. I was expecting the players to be well made with a not so great rink but the rink itself is nice too. The plastic is sturdy and smooth, allowing the puck to be sent across the rink.The box boldly states '76 pieces'. Yes, it's 76 pieces but those pieces are parts of larger items. For example, one of the side pieces of one net or one goalie shin pad counts as a piece. It's really just the rink, which comes as two halves that snap together, two goalies with sticks, two players with sticks and movement/shooter grips, and two nets. The rink has score keeper sliders much like air hockey tables. There are decals from every nhl team to use to customize the rink.The set is not open and play. There are several pages of directions for assembly. It's not quite like assembling a Lego kit but it's significantly more involved than any of the other playmobil sets we have. Our nine year old was able to do it mostly independently. If you're buying for younger or particularly impatient kids pre assembling everything might work out well.The whole set works well but both I as well as the kids wish there was more to it. Two more players and some extra pucks (it comes with four) at a minimum. The kids are having fun with it but the rink is plenty big enough for several kids to play with at once. We plan to get several more players and the zamboni, just for fun.All in all this is a great set for elementary school age hockey fans. It's a new favorite toy around here. The quality is fantastic especially when compared to most toys on the market today. I expect it will last as long as kids are interested in playing with it and stil be in good enough shape to pass along to another family.--------------------------------------I wanted to add that since writing this review we have added two more players (playmobil, please make players from more teams please!), the referee and Stanley cup set, and the zamboni. It gets a lot more playtime now and the kids like creating hockey games complete with national anthems and the zamboni making the rounds. We're still going to add a few more players but I'm waiting too see if players from our favorite team become available before buying more.

This review is of the glass bowl.I was surprised at the size of this bowl. I pictured it as more of a serving bowl size but it's actually more along the lines of a cereal bowl. While it would make a nice candy dish if you don't mind not having a lid on your candy bowl I'm using it as a serving piece alongside my other Lenox Christmas china. It matches well but I have to say the painted decoration looks very different on clear glass compared to china or porcelain. Not better or worse, just different. The painted design is slightly raised and the rim has gold trim so I'll be hand washing it. It's a nice change from the regular ivory colored Lenox and makes a nice addition to a collection. My one complaint is the thickness of the glass on the sides, it could stand to be a bit thicker. Although I wouldn't call it fragile sturdier glass would be a welcome improvement.

This is our third and biggest aerogarden. Our first one was one of the early models with tubular bulb lights. These led models are so much better. They use less power, don't give off as much heat, emit a light that is more pleasant to be around, and don't need replacing. Setup was super easy. Just click the top on, plug it in and let it walk you through a handful of steps and then you're up and running. Ten minutes, tops, and that includes filling it with water and choosing which plants you'd like where.What sets this model apart is the touch screen and the trellis pieces that, along with the extra high light adjustment, allow tomatoes to be grown more easily. The touch screen is color and surprisingly high resolution. It walks you through setup starting right when you plug it in. It also saves your info should you need to unplug it or if your power goes out, you just have to reset the clock. The best part is being able to program the timing of the lights. With our other aerogarden I have to be sure to set it right when I want it to turn on each day.The 'home screen' tells you:- how long until the next time you need to add nutrients- your light schedule- the mode (such as germination mode)- the current time- if your water level is ok- your plant program, such as lettuce gardenThere is a secondary screen which offers buttons for:- clock setup- light schedule- nutrient cycle setup- pump test and minutes run- quick plant, a QuickStart guide when you get a new pod set- audio alert settings- contact info- help and tips- restore defaults- order supplies (just a phone number and pump part number)- garden status, basically home screen infoMy one complaint regards the touch screen. It sticks out rather far. This makes the whole unit take up more space than it should. It could be moved back a full inch. I'm not sure if there was a reason for designing it this way, if it needed to be out of the way of the pump perhaps, but moving the screen back would be a welcome improvement in my opinion.All in all this is a great aerogarden for those with larger families or who like growing a wide variety of herbs. It doesn't take up more space than the seven spot models. I'm somewhat concerned the plants will be crowded but time will tell if this really does turn out to be a problem. The best use is, arguably, growing tomatoes but it's a good garden for any type of herbs or small plants.

This is our first piece of bakeware to go along with our collection of Lenox Christmas China and it's a new favorite. The quality is on par with our other Lenox pieces. It's heavy weight, made well, and the decoration is sized appropriately for the piece. I wasn't sure the handles would turn out to be functional or just decorative but they work fine, allowing me to grip the dish securely when taking it out of the oven. Although we have a big family so our meal sized portions are larger than other families I'd say this is a good size for a family of 3-4 to have a dinner size casserole, a family of 5-7 to have a side dish like baked macaroni and cheese, or for a side dish that is eaten in small portions or not by everyone in attendance when served to a larger gathering. For us this will be a piece used for green been casserole at our big Christmas dinner but it would also work great for stuffing or yams.I'd like to point out that the description states 'made of bone china' and while this may be true for some of the pieces in this listing it is not true of the square baker. I've double checked with Lenox and it's made of porcelain. That said, it matched our bone china plates and serving pieces well. I mix and match the bone china and porcelain, I can hardly tell the difference side by side and no one has ever mentioned it. The advantage of the Lenox porcelain pieces is their ability to withstand oven temperatures and cleaning in the dishwasher. I find myself reaching for my porcelain serving pieces throughout December for this reason and only bringing out the china ones for special dinners.

With seven kids we've owned our share of strollers, everything from graco to uppababy. This stroller would be a middle of the road option if it wasn't for the wonderfully small fold and reversible seat which both serve to elevate it to the level of a higher end stroller. Everything else is good but not anything that stands out. The seat is comfortable and a good size for my small for age two year old and is usable for my three year old but is big for my infant (although the car seat works) and too small for my five year old. The basket is reasonably big and is accessible enough to be usable while out and about although it's not big enough for a larger diaper bag.The fold is, admittedly, rather awkward. You have to first press two buttons, which don't press all that easily on mine but I'm hoping will loosen up. Then you use your foot to press another button while folding up the foot area of the seat and folding down the handles. While the fold is not the easiest it is very stable while folded with the attached security clip fastened. It's also stable when unfolded although since it's lightweight I haven't felt comfortable hanging more than a small purse off the handles.The included car seat, the mico ap, is nice and light. Our current seat is an aton q which is a heavy seat, this mico seat feels so much lighter. My youngest is still well under a year but is a chunky 18lbs already. This seat, while usable, is just about outgrown from a comfort standpoint. The belts are well placed and the chest clip is easy to use. The chest clip is small enough where I would feel comfortable with a tiny newborn in the seat. The base installs easily and securely with latch but I had a bit of trouble getting a sufficiently tight install with just the belt. This may be because I drive a large passenger van and few seats like to install easily with the belts. The seat clicks on and off the stroller frame easily, a welcome change from the adapters needed for our daily use uppababy stroller. Other maxi cosi compatable seats, like our aton q, also clicks on easily.The height of this stroller is just right for me as an average height woman. My husband is able to push it easily as well. Our older kids, who are middle school age, can push it with some difficulty. I'm not sure how comfortable it would be for a tall person to push as far as handle height but the wheels are configured so they're all towards the center, leaving plenty of kick space between the back wheels. These closely set wheels allow the stroller to maneuver through tight spots like clothing racks in stores.Despite all it's good points there are a few things about it I'm not crazy about. The biggest one is the looseness of the handles. They are able to move about an inch in all directions. It's not a big deal when pushing it in a straight line but it's annoying when turning it or trying to steer one handed. I have yet to investigate the bolts and screws to see if I can tighten it up. The other thing I don't care is the wheels. They're a firm, smooth plastic and don't like to take tight turns easily. This is not a stroller I would select if I was currently living in a cold climate where use on ice and packed snow in parking lots was a possibility. The wheels just don't have any grip and provide a bumpy ride for the baby in the seat even on relatively smooth ground. The wide, fixed back wheels make turns less than graceful. I often find myself having to almost stop to pick up the front wheels and pivot the stroller to avoid the need to strong arm the back wheels into making a tight turn. It's a small complaint but padded handle grips would be a welcome addition.Comparatively, it's most on par with our maclaren triumph though it also has the reversible seat of our super pricy uppababy vista and the combination of comfortable seat and small fold that I liked about our peg perego p3. The small fold is really what makes it. It's a little over half the length of a folded pack and play and about the same size around. One of our cars is a hybrid and this stroller fits on the little shelf in the trunk over where the batteries are, leaving plenty of space for shopping bags or luggage.Overall, this is a nice stroller in spite of it's faults. There isn't much else on the market that compares with the way it folds. This is a great option for those who want a full featured stroller and travel system but need the ability to put it in a coat closet or small trunk when not in use or two car families looking for a stroller to keep in their second car that won't take up too much trunk space.

These are wonderful headphones. I wore them while watching the second episode of The Man in the High Castle and the sound was absolutely flawless. The faint sounds came through perfectly and the base and depth of sound was unbelievable for being essentially earbuds with a bit more oomph. I'm used to the higher end apple earbuds with the different size covers and these are noticeably better for all of $20 more. The sound is not quite comparable to my bose headphones but these come close and are wireless all for a third the price.The setup was simple even without the instructions. They synced to my iPad quickly and stayed on across our living room and when I walked behind a partial wall into another room. They'd be great to wear while doing housework. The quality is excellent with rugged, matte finish plastic and several sizes of tips to fit to your ear size. They're weighty compared to regular earbuds but are lighter than over the head styles. The cord, and this is my one real complaint, is a bit short and somewhat stiff. I'm hoping the cord will soften up and straighten out with use because right out of the package the stiffness and bent angles caused it to press against my neck uncomfortably. There is a small plastic piece on the cord to shorten it but I can't imagine anyone ever needing to use it.All that said, I personally have mixed feelings about these headphones but just because they don't happen to fit me well. I have very small ears and have trouble finding earbuds or anything else that fits in the ear to be comfortable and stay put. These are no exception. Both the hook and the earpiece are too big for my ears. They do, however, comfortably fit my husband who has average size ears for a man. Since they fit him well I'm rating them based on performance and quality rather than fit.

I just finished reading Coal River. It was unexpectedly enjoyable. The plot has layer after layer which are unraveled at just the right moments. Without giving too much away the story is that of an older teen girl who loses her parents and must live with her less than kind aunt and uncle. She moves to the Pennsylvania mining town of Coal River, where she once stayed for a few months as a child. She eventually becomes involved in the cause of improving conditions for miners and their families, particularly for children working there. The focus is really this crusade with her personal family life and small town politics taking on supporting roles in the storyEach of the main characters is incredibly well developed. The more minor characters are also brought to life in a vivid way. Many characters developed in unexpected ways. I often found myself realizing someone wasn't what I had imagined them to be without really being able to pinpoint when the change occurred. This depth of writing made for emotional reading. I was physically tense during the more intense parts of the book, felt warm and happy during the few sweet/romantic parts, and cried during the particularly sad parts. Start to finish, this book was an emotional experience.While I can't say for sure how much of the history presented is accurate everything I've fact checked checks out although at different times and places. There is an attention to historical authenticity not often found in non fiction literature. Everything from the clothes to the mining process to the way miners families lived is, often sadly, correct from a historical standpoint. Wiseman takes license to tell the story as it could have happened. She does this believably, the mark of an accomplished author of historical fiction. Although this is a minor detail the one glaring error was a funeral prayer. A priest at that time would have said the prayers in Latin rather than English. Not a big deal and this in no way detracts from the plot but it stuck out to me in an otherwise very well researched book.If I had to come up with something I don't like about the book it would be that while the descriptive writing paints an incredible picture it gets to be somewhat tedious after the first hundred pages or so. Still good reading but could be made better by omitting some of the redundant and recurrent adjectives. That said, throughout the book I was able to picture the people and locations in detail. I was never left wondering how a place or a character looked.This is a book where I would pick it up, intending to read for a little while, and find myself saying 'one more chapter' over and over until I look up and hours had gone by. It's a wonderful book for those who like to lose themselves in what they're reading. While I began a bit haltingly I couldn't put it down after the first few chapters. Although I'm more of a non fiction reader this novel has earned a long term spot on my shelf, I'm looking forward to rediscovering it in a few years and getting to read it again.

I've tried quite a few self tanning lotions over the years but I've never been really thrilled with the results from any of them. This one is much better. It goes on nicely with the xen-tan mitt (the mitt really is a nice add on if you're wanting the most even application possible). The color develops fairly quickly, I made sure to wear gloves under the mitt. The color is just right, a natural darkening of my own pale skin tone. No orange, none! The color lasted a couple days before starting to fade but it faded just like a real tan does with a gradual lightening, no brassy or orange tone. I'm not sure it's a true 'weekly' tan but it's a solid 4-5 day tan which is long lasting compared to other tanners I've tried. Just an all around nice tanner that goes on evenly and give a great color.

I finally had the chance to use this cough syrup this week when most of our kids came down with a nasty cold. Our older kids are able to take regular cough syrup but for the little ones there are very few options available and most are just honey or agave nectar sold at an inflated price in the medicine aisle. I was skeptical as to how well this would work when I gave it to my two year old. It didn't seem to be doing much of anything for the first half hour or so but now it's working well. I have to say, it's not quite the relief the older kids are getting from the adult cough syrup they're able to take but it's pretty close and is safe for the younger kids to take.My only complaints are the taste, not great but I expected that, and the dosing instructions. The dosing really needs to be by weight. My two year old is very small, more like the weight of a 10-12 month old so I was left wondering if the dose for two year olds would be too high. I ended up giving a bit less than the recommended dose for age but it would have been nice to have this choice affirmed by weight based dosing instructions.

This review is of the spoon rest.We have a large collection of Lenox Christmas China but this was the first time I've seen a spoon rest. The quality is on par with our other Lenox pieces and the size is just right. I have it on the stove and it's plenty big enough for larger ladles while still fitting between the burners. The design on this price is well done. Some have the holly placed a bit oddly or sized too small for the item but this one looks just right to me. I've run it through the dishwasher and it came out just fine (this piece is porcelain, some other Lenox items are china and do best with hand washing). Just an all around nice addition to a Lenox Christmas collection.

This is a great speaker. It's on par with our Bose soundlink III as far as sound but offers more substantial bass. Music is sharp and clear with a sound that fills our large living room.The setup is as quick and easy as most any bluetooth device. I was able to have it up and running within a couple minutes of opening the box. The controls are simple and intuitive.The construction is top notch. It feels heavy for it's size and sits steadily on the table (a nice change from my easily tipped over bose). The plastic is sturdy and has a nice finish.Overall I'm very pleased with this speaker in terms of both quality and sound. It's solid competition to the more expensive bose line of speakers.

Unpacking this scale, I was immediately impressed by the build of the scale.  It is really rock solid and doesn't feel flimsy at all.  Stepping on it is also a comfortable experience; you won't get any stability rocking if you don't step on it "just so" and it doesn't slip on our linoleum floor.On to the features....The scale is set to allow up to 4 people to program their height, age, and gender.  The first parameter, of course, is to allow the scale to easily compute your BMI.  The next 2 are used to compute to calculate your calorie intake to MAINTAIN your current weight.  This should go without saying, but (and even the instruction manual states this) you should only seek to go on a diet with the aid of a professional.  I'm a heavy fellow and the scale indicated that I needed 2,581 calorie intake to maintain my weight which I know is completely false.  Why, you ask?  Because I actually went through metabolic testing which indicated that I need only 1,400 calories per day; I have an extremely low metabolic rate (aka I don't need much to function) which also happens to be why I gain weight so easily.While it's an interesting feature, I don't place much credence or value on the calorie feedback so I have docked it one star for that.Apart from that, it's a great scale and the BMI feedback is good too.  Selecting the individual person's feedback is as simple as a couple of toe presses on the scale to find the correct "P#" (i.e. P1, P2, P3 or P4) and then stepping on.  The capacity of the scale is 440 pounds and the accuracy is within 0.1 lbs.  I had myself weighed at the doctor's office and then immediately weighed myself upon my return to home.  While not scientific, I found that the result was within 0.1 lbs of the doctor's office which could easily be attributable to calibration or slight weight variations (water, etc.) during that time.This is a solid, good scale and I recommend it...just don't take the calorie feedback at face value.

As much as I love R/C planes and helicopters, I really wanted this little gizmo (which fits in your hand) to work.  However, it was "dead on arrival" for me.  The device wouldn't accept a charge when plugged into my desktop (as instructed) and I have tried other laptops in our home and even went to the trouble to hooking it up to an AC powered USB hub.  No luck.  Hopefully others have had better success than I did.

I have had my fair share of protein shakes from powders that I have bought at Costco (some aren't half bad) to pre-prepared shakes like Muscle Milk, etc.I thought that a chocolate raspberry protein shake sounded intriguingly delicious.It was decidedly NOT for me.  Is it horrific?  No, but I can definitely say that it would be more of an acquired taste for me.  At first taste, it definitely came across more as a protein shake than as something that was chocolate.  The raspberry was there, but almost as a slightly nauseating aftertaste that I got used to as it went down.After making my way down, I definitely had the impression that this had to be artificially sweetened and was floored when I read 28 grams of sugar on the label.  For something that tasted like this, it sure didn't taste like 28 grams of sugar (that's 7 tablespoons of sugar, folks)...certainly made me wonder at what point did the development team keep adding sugar before they held up their hand and shouted, "No, stop!  Perfect!"  It didn't seem that way.I let my daughter have a sip and she reported that she liked it (hence the added star), but there is no chance that I'd be handing over a 28g sugar drink for her to consume on a regular basis.  She liked it, however, so this might be to SOMEONE'S taste...just not mine.This is definitely on my "don't recommend" list.

For the asking price of just under $20 at the time of this review, this is a superb set of scissors.  The blades are made out of titanium and they cut effortlessly.  The blades do stick a little, but I believe this is attributable to designing the scissors for eventual wear and I believe that "breaking the scissors in" will result in a set of scissors that will glide effortlessly with prolonged use.Handles are comfortable and I don't experience the kind of cramping as soon as I usually do between my index finger and thumb; the contour of the handle is well thought out.I'm glad to have this set and look forward to endless crafting with my daughter and Christmas/birthday gift wrapping in the years to come.  I highly recommend this set.

My daughter is 11-year olds and crafts like there's no tomorrow.  She'll watch Youtube videos endlessly and learn how to create new things using common household items.I decided to have her run through this product, knowing that fun, creativity, and ease of use would be something that she could easily provide feedback on.  In her words, "It's awesome!"  There are plenty of materials within the package and a high-quality, magazine-like book provides the full gamut of "try this" options which she went through and tried out.My only warning...you will likely be assaulted with numerous "look at this" moments.  :)  She loves it...and I'm sure that your kids will too.

Digital downloads are all the rage these days, and McAfee has followed that proud tradition of going disc-less with their software and opting through digital account management instead.  This virus package allows you to download and install to 3 PCs through what seems to be an endless string of numbers.My first attempt was unsuccessful, but that was only because one of the letters--a "J"--almost looked like a "1" to me.  After fixing that, it went through without a problem and I was up and running in about 5 minutes (40 Mbps connection speed).McAfee is one of several recognized names in the business regarding internet security, so I won't delve into that here.  Of higher concern, however, is impact to my day-to-day operation.  I installed it on my Asus laptop, which certainly has minimal power considering its near $500 price point.  I'm happy to report, however, that the software is minimally intrusive and didn't appear to exhibit any performance degradation on my operation of the laptop.The software does come with a suite of parental protections that you can enable/disable on a whim.  One feature that was lacking for me, however, was a secure storage for my logins.  One thing that I do like about Norton Internet Security on my Alienware Desktop is my "Vault"...a place where my logins are stored for bank/billing accounts so that it saves me the time of having to log in to pay my bills.  It's a time saver for me and convenience for my wife who has trouble remembering all that stuff.  I wished that McAfee would have that feature because it would be a perfect 5 star rating for me.Apart from that, rest assured that you'll receive decent residential-level security protection that won't reduce your computer to a crawl in its protective efforts.

This is actually a pretty good grip.  With no frills, the vent attachment has a 4-tooth prong system that would work with just about any vent system that I could think in a vehicle.  The grip system itself utilizing a very powerful spring-loaded system that will clamp hard and whatever you put in it.  I tried it on my iPod Classic and I wasn't worried about that little bugger slipping out on me.Where it failed, however, was on my Samsung Galaxy S5.  While I'm sure that it would have gripped the phone itself just fine, it BARELY misses being able to accommodate the Galaxy S5 in an Otterbox Defender case.  By barely, I really mean by about 1/8"...it's sooooo close to working that I was disappointed that it wouldn't work.  I'm accident prone, so taking the phone out of the case is not an option for me and if you're familiar with the Otterbox case, it's not exactly something that you easily just slip in/off at the drop of a hat.Apart from that, it's a really good clip...just be aware of the limitation that I came across.

Out of the box, I have to say...without a doubt....this is probably one of the easiest printers that I have had the pleasure to install.  The Quick Setup Guide is well-written and is easy to follow.It also features some fairly well laid out menus on a very responsive touchscreen and the software will find the printer readily and enable it for use as a printer, scanner, and fax machine.It does all this in pretty good stride and the prints look great.  Speed is pretty good too, but I think that you'd be hard pressed to find a slow printer these days so it hardly amounts as a differentiator.  Scans are also fairly decent without exhibiting much in the way of chromatic aberrations or ghosting of text outlines; it looks really crisp and the PDF capability is a nice added feature.  I didn't use the fax since we no longer use a landline and most companies that I deal with would rather receive a PDF anyway, but it is an additional feature and I would find it doubtful that it is incapable of producing a decent fax based on its scanning capability.However, there are some cons:1.  One of my gripes is that NO CABLES ARE INCLUDED.  For a $149 printer, it's sad that a $2-$3 USB-A to USB-B cable could not be included.  While many households have gone towards a WiFi setup, some have not and having to purchase an additional cable just to hook it up to a PC is disappointing.2.  Build is a little flimsy.  While the top opens and closes with ease, there is a little side-to-side play on this thing.  It is definitely recommended that you grab both edges when you open and close the lid...I'm not saying that it'll break, per se, but the sidesway doesn't lend a lot to comfort.3.  Ink usage.  While not as bad as the venerable Epson 777 (which is what turned me off from Epson in the first place - felt like every 3rd print job needed a suspicious amount of ink cartridge cleaning), the ink usage can still be high.  I would recommend leaving the printer on to minimize unnecessary ink cartridge cleanings.4.  Paper tray.  It feels hard to use compared to my HP and the slide bar for varying paper sizes didn't feel as smooth to operate at first until I realized it needed more of a firm hand to get it motivated...be prepared to get a "feel" for moving it.  If you primarily printer on 8.5 x 11, this may not be a concern.  However, the lack of paper size options may make this printer seem like a chore for some.That said, the cons aren't too bad in my opinion and for the price, you're getting a pretty solid 3-feature printer.

I always love a great mill-and-brew coffeemaker and have owned a Cuisinart a long time ago.First and foremost, I'll say that this coffeemaker does brew a good cup of coffee, especially for its price point.  Also, I find the programmable feature of the coffee maker quite easy to use and adjusting the time on the clock doesn't involve some convoluted process of hitting menu or setup buttons; you merely hit "MIN" or "HR" and you're good to go on adjusting the clock and programming it is simply an extra step of hitting the program button.Filling water on the coffeemaker is also quite easy and has a relatively low profile, so it can accommodate about 5-6 inches of clearance below your cabinet if this is a concern.That said, there were some design features that I was NOT enamored with...but you may have no qualms about them, so please read and decide accordingly:1.  The mill/filter.  At first, I was intrigued by the design decision to incorporate the mill WITH the filter.  This minimizes the amount of upkeep on the coffee maker since coffee makers with a separate mill chamber often require maintenance in terms of cleaning out the chute where the coffee grounds exit because they tend to "gum up" over time.  However, I found several problems with this:  a.  Cleaning the filter is...challenging.  The rotating blade the bottom of the filter makes it a little difficult to scrub and I was apprehensive about getting my fingers close to it...definitely recommend a slender brush to get those hard to reach areas.  b.  This filter requires you to fill it with beans (or grounds) EVERY MORNING.  You won't have the luxury of storing your beans and refilling occasionally.  This adds an extra step to the ritual of prepping your coffee maker for coffee the next morning.2.  Grind adjustment.  This one still has me scratching my head.  Considering that you have to measure your beans each morning, why on earth would you incorporate a feature that adjusts the grind according to how many beans you have in there?  I know that sounds like a silly argument, but my first 2 runs resulted in beans that were not ground up (but I wanted them to be) and I'm not keen on seeing if I can "regrind them" after they've been flushed with hot water.  On my 3rd attempt, I just set the grind setting for something much higher to avoid having beans wasted in my brew.3.  Carafe.  My biggest pet peeve with any coffee maker is having an integral lid.  I like to be able to remove mine to clean it properly since integral lids tend to make cleaning a little more problematic.  I'll be the first to admit it...I'm a clumsy ox and this might not bother you.  However, it makes me nervous as I like to clean everything properly.Beyond those issues (and if they don't bother you), this is a fairly decent coffeemaker...just not my cup of tea.  ;)Please let me know if you have any questions and I'll do my best to answer them.

I've set up several routers in the past and this has probably the easiest by far.  The quick setup guide is well illustrated and easily points you in the right direction.  What's even better is that the setup routine includes an auto-detect feature to ease in transitioning your internet setup for the router's subsequent use.Speedwise, I don't have anything that utilizes the AC bandwidth, but my n- and g-enabled devices find it quite readily and transmitting data around our home network seems quite responsive without any perceptible degradation of what would normally be wired responsiveness.The router itself is quite large and takes up a little more real estate than my older Netgear N900, but the built-in stand (not adjustable, sadly) holds it up quite well and the white aesthetic of the router makes it quite easy to make out the status of your internet connection, broadcast, etc., at a glance with fairly intuitive green LED icons.Enabling security through the router is also fairly simple through a web interface (local-based web control) that allows you to set up both home and guest networks.  Guest networks can also be configured to separately screen other devices of your network from view, which is a nice feature if you want to secure your home network a little further.One demerit, however, is range.  My N900 was able to boost the signal quite well.  I was hoping that the Archer C8, with 3 external antennae, would at least equal or surpass it.  My current experience is that it has not.  We have an 1,800 square foot home and sometimes our bedroom is a little bit of a "dead zone."  Much older routers had trouble with it, but the N900 took care of our issue.  While the Archer C8 is weaker, it still provides a reliable enough signal that I'm not worried in having our signal dropped.  The WiFi Analyzer app showed anywhere from a 5-10 dB loss in strength in the same placement as the N900.  While that seems like a bit, it was still strong enough to work.  However, with the real estate of 3 external antennae, I was hoping for better; I was disappointed.Is that a reason not to get it?  I would say no...individual routers may perform differently and I suspect--given the quality found in the router's construction and setup--that this router may find a good home in yours; I have a feeling that this router may perform better in our household away from monitors or other EM interference that may be impacting its performance differently than our venerable N900.  At $150, however, you may wish to consider other options and also ask if you really need an AC router to get the most bang for your buck.

This was a fun read. I liked learning about the Southern Louisiana area while enjoying a good mystery. The book is a quick read and easy to get in to. The characters are interesting and the setting is unique. I like the touch of romance added to the mystery as well.  I didn't relate to the "bad guy" character. She didn't seem real to me - far too stupid. But then again, bad guys can be really stupid! In spite of that, I enjoyed the book and I'm looking forward to the next one.

Probably one of the best trackers so far, but I'm still not impressed.Here's what I don't like: It slips during the night, 2 out of 3 nights for me. In order to read accurately, it must be pretty snug on your arm which can be a bit uncomfortable. I didn't care for the food tracker.Here's what I liked: the step counter seems to be fairly accurate. It motivated me to work out more, which is the number one reason to wear one of these! It works with My Fitness app, which is the one I prefer to use for tracking food.

I've been wearing these for a week and I'm more than satisfied. The pads are much thinner than the regular Poise, which makes them much more comfortable. In spite of this, they have excellence absorption. For mild to moderate leakage, these will do the trick. At the current price on Amazon, these cost $ .225 each, not a bad price either. My only complaint is that they are bit on the short side. I would love to see them lengthened. I recommend these!

I gave this three stars to this product for the reason that there is a lot unknown about Triclosan - the ingredient in this product that is supposed to keep your gums healthy. Before you buy, I recommend you read the consumer update on Triclosan on the FDA site. So far, there is no link found between Triclosan and cancer; however, the FDA is looking into it. For me, I would rather use regular Colgate and rinse with a product like Listerine that kills germs very well.
This is a fun collection of dies that makes beautiful cards. The designs can be used in a variety of ways to create different looks. Use waxed paper between die and paper for easy removal. Love them!

The only thing that would make this better is color! I love the planner. It has everything I need including a month at a glance as well as a daily log of events. It also has room for notes on every page which is essential for me as a teacher. The back includes a section for event planning - a few lines to jot down a few notes about the event, some blank sheets, a quick reference page (perhaps for website addresses - not sure what this is), and finally an envelope in the back cover for loose items. All in all, a great planner. I just wish they would make them in colors!

These earrings are not heavy and they apparently have no nickel or other metals that react to my ears. They were very comfortable to wear. The design is nice - black and silver look well together. They do seem to be made well.As I got these for review purposes, I don't know what the price is. I looked up similar items and they seem to be in the $20 range. For the price, this is a good buy. However, don't expect these to look like diamonds. They don't.

My dog and I love this blanket! It's SUPER soft and cuddly. It's a good size (36"x48") for a small to medium dog. I have a Shitzu-jack russell mix and she fits perfectly. She likes to "dig" it up and mix it around until it gets just the way she wants it. I love the soft blue color as well. The design is from thread color; it's not stitched in so there are no rough edges. As far as how thick it is, it's a medium weight - not too heavy; not too light.

I should have figured that you get what you pay for. This towel is thin. It's a good size for drying off a dog, but way too thin to soak up much water. Personally, I would rather have one with more soaking potential, but I suppose that would cost a lot more. It's cute. The dog bone makes it perfect for not mixing up with your other towels, but overall, I'm a bit disappointed.

This unit is great for someone who has a new license for operating a ham radio and who is not sure exactly how far he or she wants to take the hobby. It is a small investment, yet lets you get started with talking on local repeaters.I am a licensed ham radio operator and found the radio to be easy to program. I was up and running within 30 minutes of opening the package. For newbies, you will probably want to use the software, CHIRP. As for the quality of the radio - it is what the old axiom says, "You get what you pay for." It's a starter radio. The sound quality is good, not great. The short antennae reaches the 8.5 miles from my house to the local repeater, but you will want a longer one to reach further. I had no problem using the keypad, but those unfamiliar with the lingo of ham radio will have difficulty with programming it. You will need help from someone who is familiar with the terms. It will only allow you to use the 2 meter band between 138 and 174 MHz and the 70cm band between 400 and 480 MHz. You can program it so that you can listen to two bands at once. You can also listen to FM radio.NOTE: While it is possible to program the radio to transmit on the General Mobile Radio Service and Family Radio Service bands, the radio is not FCC type accepted for use on these channels. Doing so may be illegal and should be done only in a dire emergency with no other radio communications options possible. You MUST have a ham radio license to use frequencies to get on local repeaters. If you use frequencies that require a license, you are subject to fines ranging from $7,500 to $10,000, and there are ham operators who go around looking for signals coming from unlicensed operators. You will get caught! But the other side is that is is easy to get your license. You can study for your license using books, local classes, or online (example: Ham Test Online; www.hamradiolicenseexam.com), and you can take the test through local ham radio clubs listed on ARRL (www.arrl.org). There are three licenses, each one allowing you to use more frequencies on the radio band: Technician, General, and Extra. I took and passed all three in one year, so if I can do it, you can do it! There are children in our club as young as eight years old who have taken the test as well. The test only costs $15 (currently). It's a small investment to get into ham radio and a fun hobby, as well as a great communication system during emergencies. And this radio is an inexpensive way to get started.

Awesome pair of scissors! They are the perfect choice for office use and crafting. They are tough, sharp, easy to handle, and comfortable. They are great for opening packages, even those nasty plastic cases that electronics are encased in. They easily cut through metal attachments on my die cutting packages, and cutting card stock is a snap. I have found dozens of uses for these blades. For me, the only issue I have with them is that the measurements are printed on the right side of the blade. I'm right handed, so I can't see the measurements as I am cutting. probably wouldn't use this feature anyway, so it's not a problem for me. But, if you are buying them for the measurements and you are right handed, you might take note of that.

The idea is a good one - lighter is always better; unfortunately, I don't like the smell. I am so spoiled by FRESH STEP CAT LITTER 261323 Fresh Step Lasting Power Litter Boxes for Cats, 25-Pound that this one just doesn't do it for me. There is more urine smell even after cleaning it than I have with my Fresh Step. Other than that, it's about the same, but lighter. For those with allergies to flowery scents, this might be a better choice. For me, I'd rather have a better smell than 25% lighter.

All of the Rosetta Stone products are excellent and this one is a great addition to the line. A nice reading-reinforcement tool for both parents and small classrooms. Easy to use and set up. My copy worked easily on the Mac using Safari. The games were fun and there was a variety of activities which increases motivation to use the product. The educational value is excellent for reinforcing beginning reading skills - PreK-1st grade. My only complaint is that it is an annual subscription, which makes it much more expensive for a family to use with more than one child. Why not make this a stand-alone software? Is there a reason for this?

This is an excellent gift idea for a young child just learning the U.S. states or for use in a classroom. The product is well constructed and will last a LONG time!The large background is heavy - made from wood and magnetic. The state pieces are also made of wood and fit into the puzzle very nicely. The pieces are large - some of the smaller states have been combined into one piece such as Delaware and New Jersey; also Rhode Island is combined with Vermont, New Hampshire, and Massachusetts. The pieces are colorful and fun to work with.There is a clear plastic cover that you can place over the board when not in use, and there is a rope handle for carrying or hanging. Although this is not inexpensive, it definitely illustrates the saying, "You get what you pay for." This is a quality product that will last for years.The only suggestion I have for the publisher is to include a worksheet that students could use to practice the states without the state name clues.Great product - highly recommended!

I am really happy with this product. I have been working out at the gym and was used to professional equipment. At home, I had some really cheesy resistance bands; so, I began searching for some that were comparable to what I was using at the gym. I read reviews on the Black Mountain products and decided to give them a try. I'm glad I did. This is exactly what I was looking for. Quality product - flexible - a variety of resistance weights - and easy to change the handles. I am buying a 2nd set of handles so I can quickly change weights as needed. But it's not necessary. It's very easy and quick to change them if you want to save money. Highly recommend this product!

I was looking forward to these little bars because they appeared to be a healthier version of fig newtons. They are, but not that much better, and there is not near as much fruit. The photo is deceiving. There is the finest line of fruit sandwiched between the crust. You can barely taste it. The crust is good and the ingredients appear to be good for you.Comparison with strawberry fig newton:1 bar Plum organics (19g): 70 calories, 1.5 grams of fat, 0 cholesterol, 50 mg sodium, 12 g of carbs, 5 g of sugar, 1 g. of fiber.1 strawberry Fig newton (15g):  50 calories, .75 g. fat, 0 cholesterol, 55 mg. sodium, 10.5 carbs, 6.5 g. sugar, 0g fiber.Bottom line: If you really want to eat healthy and don't mind losing out on some flavor, this will satisfy you. If you're more concerned with taste, stick to the fig newton!

This little unit is awesome! If you are looking for an extremely portable speaker unit, you can't lose with this one. It's only about 2" by 5" in size, but the sound quality is pretty awesome. No, you won't get big, booming bases, but if you want to amplify Spotify on your smart phone, this will do the trick. In fact, I demonstrated this little speaker to my teacher daughter, and she immediately talked me into giving it to her to take to her classroom!Slip this one in your pocket or purse, and you'll be ready to amplify your phone anytime you want.

I love the Brainwave M2 Headphones! I'm pretty picky about my headphones. I like to listen to all types of music from classical to rock to country western. In addition, I have some hearing loss in my ears, and I want to be able to hear all the tones. With Brainwavz M2, I was able to sit back and enjoy all my music, every note of it!Another thing I liked about this product is that there are several sets of ear tips for every size of ear! Not a one-size fits all. I found the perfect size for my small ears with no trouble at all. The only complaint I have is that the clip for attaching the cords to your shirt was not satisfactory. I could not get it connected satisfactorily. Maybe I just don't know how, but I wish they would have put it on for me!  Oh, another thing I did like is the case! Perfect for my purse!For me, the price was reasonable for the quality of the headphones. I'm a fan.

You will like or not like this fitness band depending on your size and fitness level. I took it with me to my trainer at the gym to get him to help me figure out how to use it. Unfortunately, I don't have the arm stretch to use it for my arms alone; however, I can use it if I wrap it around something. The problem with that is that it is too hard for me to use. I was able to use it when I step on it, but I didn't feel like I was accomplishing much. The loops were comfortable to grip. That is one thing I liked. My trainer was disappointed that it didn't have any resistance levels on the band or on the packaging.The bottom line for me: I think it has potential with those who are more fit than I am! For a beginner or someone who not as fit as they should be, it's just not the right band.

After using this product a few times, I've decided that I like it for a once in a while use. I like the fact that you can peel open the door seal and spray in that area, which is hard to clean. However, for daily use, I prefer to use tablets, specifically Whirlpool - Affresh High Efficiency Washer Cleaner, 3-Tablets, 4.2 Ounce. The biggest reason is that it's easier to use the tablets. This is just one more thing I have to do. Whereas, the tablets, I throw in and forget it. As far as deodorizing, I guess this product does a good job. I don't have a lot of problems with my front loader, so there is not much to deodorize. But, I like the idea of cleaning it on a regular basis even if I don't smell anything. So, this works fine. I just like the ease of use with a tablet.
